VILLAGE PERSONNEL POLICIES
1-15-1: JOB TITLES, CLASSIFICATIONS AND DESCRIPTIONS:
Job titles, classification and description for certain village employees shall be as set forth in that certain document entitled "Job Title, Classifications And
Descriptions", dated on or about May 1 and updated annually, said document hereby made a part of this code by reference, and said document being on
file at all times in the village offices for public inspection. (Ord. 2007-4135, 8-20-2007)

Minimum and maximum salaries and hourly wages for certain village employees shall be as set forth in that certain document entitled "Departmental
Position Designation And Salary Structure", dated on or about May 1 and updated annually, said document hereby made a part of this code by reference,
and said document being on file at all times in the village offices for public inspection. (Ord. 2007-4135, 8-20-2007)
Chapter 16
PUBLIC WORKS CONTRACTS
1-16-1: WAGE RATES FOR PUBLIC WORKS CONTRACTS:
To the extent and as required by "an act regulating wages of laborers, mechanics and other workmen employed in any public works by the state, county,
city or any public body or any political subdivision or by any one under contract for public works", approved June 26, 1941, as amended1, the general
prevailing rate of wages in this locality for laborers, mechanics and the workmen engaged in the construction of public works coming under the jurisdiction
of the village is hereby ascertained to be the same as the prevailing rate of wages for construction work in the DuPage County area, as determined by the
department of labor of the state as of June 2, 1980, a copy of that determination being incorporated herein by reference. The definition of any terms
appearing in this chapter which are also used in the aforesaid act shall be the same as in said act.
Nothing herein contained shall be construed to apply said general prevailing rate of wages, as herein ascertained, to any work or employment except
public works construction of this village to the extent required by the aforesaid act.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 17/460
The village clerk shall publicly post or keep available for inspection by any interested party in the main office of the village this determination of such
prevailing rate of wage, and said clerk shall mail a copy of this determination to any employer, and to any association of employers and to any person or
association of employees who have filed, or file, their names and addresses, requesting copies of any determination stating the particular rates, and the
particular class of workmen whose wages will be affected by such rates, and shall promptly file a certified copy of this chapter with both the secretary of
state and the department of labor of the state of Illinois. (Ord. 80-938, 7-1-1980)

(A) The village of Lisle shall provide access to public records as required by the Illinois freedom of information act, 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 140/1 et
seq., as amended.
(B) All requests for inspection or copies of public records must be submitted in writing in accordance with the village of Lisle freedom of information act
policy, which policy is available for inspection at the village of Lisle business office. (Ord. 2010-4295, 1-4-2010, eff. retroactive to 1-1-2010)
Chapter 18
EMPLOYEE ETHICS
1-18-1: REGULATIONS:
(A) The regulations of section 5-151 and article 102 of the state officials and employees ethics act, 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 430/1-1 et seq. (hereinafter
referred to as the "act" in this section) are hereby adopted by reference and made applicable to the officers and employees of this governmental entity
to the extent required by 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 430/70-5.
(B) The solicitation or acceptance of gifts prohibited under the act, by any officer or any employee is hereby prohibited.
(C) The offering or making of gifts prohibited by the act, to an officer or employee is hereby prohibited.
(D) The participation in political activities prohibited under the act, by any officer or employee is hereby prohibited.
(E) For purposes of this section, the terms "officer" and "employee" shall be defined as set forth in 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 430/70-5(c).
(F) The penalties for violations of this section shall be the same as those penalties set forth in 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 430/50-5 for similar violations of
the act.
(G) This section does not repeal or otherwise amend or modify any existing enactment which regulates the conduct of officers and employees. To the
extent that any such existing ordinances or policies are less restrictive than this section, however, the provisions of this section shall prevail in
accordance with the provisions of 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 430/70-5(a).
(H) Any amendment to the act that becomes effective after the effective date of this section shall be incorporated into this section by reference and shall
be applicable to the solicitation, acceptance, offering and making of gifts and to prohibited political activities. However, any amendment that makes its
provisions optional for adoption shall not be incorporated into this section by reference without formalaction by this governmental entity.
(I) If the Illinois supreme court declares the act unconstitutional in its entirety, then this section shall be repealed as of the date that the Illinois supreme
court's decision becomes final and not subject to any further appeals or rehearings. This section shall be deemed repealed without further action if the
act is found unconstitutional by the Illinois supreme court.
(J) If the Illinois supreme court declares part of the act unconstitutional but upholds the constitutionality of the remainder of the act, or does not address the
remainder of the act, then the remainder of the act as adopted by this section shall remain in full force and effect; however, that part of this section
relating to the part of the act found unconstitutional shall be deemed repealed without further action by this governmental entity. (Ord. 2005-3895, 2-21-
2005)
Chapter 19
ELIGIBILITY UNDER THE PUBLIC SAFETY EMPLOYEE BENEFITS ACT
1-19-1: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this chapter is to provide a fair and efficient method of determining the eligibility of an employee for the benefits enumerated under the
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 18/460
public safety employee benefits act1. All benefits provided to employees pursuant to the public safety employee benefits act ("act") will be consistent with
the act. (Ord. 2016-4676, 9-12-2016)
1-19-2: APPLICATION FOR PSEBA BENEFITS:
A PSEBA benefit application form prepared by the village shall be the standard form required for PSEBA benefit applicants (hereafter the "applicant") to
utilize to request benefits under PSEBA. The form shall be completed and executed by the requesting applicant and delivered to the village manager. The
applicant shall provide, along with the application, any medical records regarding the injury, any decision by a governing public safety pension board and
supporting documentation related to such pension board decision, any decision by the Illinois workers' compensation commission, and any additional
pertinent documentation that the applicant wants to have considered or that is requested by the village. (Ord. 2016-4676, 9-12-2016)
1-19-3: APPLICATION REVIEW PROCESS:
(A) Upon receipt of a fully completed and executed PSEBA benefit application, the village manager shall review the application and supporting
documentation, and if necessary complete additional fact finding and/or investigation.
(B) The village manager shall make a written recommendation, including reasons for the recommendation, to the village board within forty five (45)
calendar days after the later of the following:
1. The submission of the relevant documentation; or
2. The completion of the such additional fact finding or investigation as deemed necessary or appropriate by the village manager.
(C) The village manager's written recommendation shall state whether:
1. The applicant is eligible for benefits under PSEBA; or
2. A hearing should be convened in order to determine whether or not the applicant is eligible for benefits under PSEBA and shall inform the applicant,
in writing, of the decision and the reasons for the decision.
(D) If the village manager recommends that the applicant is eligible for benefits under PSEBA, the recommendation shall be presented to the village board
at the next regularly scheduled village board meeting (subject to notice provision of the open meetings act).
(E) The village board shall make a determination that:
1. The applicant is eligible for benefits under PSEBA; or
2. An administrative hearing should be convened in order to determine whether or not the applicant is eligible for benefits under PSEBA. (Ord. 2016-
4676, 9-12-2016)
1-19-4: ADMINISTRATIVE COMPOSITION:
If the village board determines that a hearing should be convened, the system of the administrative hearing shall be comprised of a hearing officer whose
power and authority and limitations are as follows:
(A) Power Of The Hearing Officer: The hearing officer shall have all of the powers granted to him under common law relative to the conduct of an
administrative hearing including the power to:
1. Preside over all village hearings involving the public safety employee benefits act2;
2. Administer oaths;
3. Hear testimony and accept evidence that is relevant to the issue of eligibility under the public safety employee benefits act3;
4. Issue subpoenas to secure attendance of witnesses and the production of relevant papers or documents upon the request of the parties or their
representatives;
5. Rule upon objections in the admissibility of evidence;
6. Preserve and authenticate the record of the hearing and all exhibits in evidence introduced at the hearing;
7. Issue a determination based on the evidence presented at the hearing, the determination of which shall be in writing and shall include a written
finding of fact, decision and order.
(B) Appointment Of The Hearing Officer: The mayor with the consent of the board of trustees is hereby authorized to appoint a person to hold the position
of a hearing officer for each and every individual hearing that shall come before this village. In making said selection, the mayor shall consider all
pertinent information, including, at a minimum:
1. The candidate's ability to comply with the job description as set forth herein;
2. Background and performance data made available to the mayor on file with the village or otherwise obtained by the village;
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 19/460
3. The candidate must be an attorney licensed to practice law in the state of Illinois for at least three (3) years and have knowledge of and experience
in employment and labor law, general civil procedure, the rules of evidence, and administrative practice. (Ord. 2016-4676, 9-12-2016)
1-19-5: ADMINISTRATIVE HEARING:
An administrative hearing shall be held to adjudicate and determine whether the subject public safety employee is eligible for benefits under the public
safety employee benefits act4. If the employee is found eligible, the employee benefits shall be consistent with the act.
(A) Time And Date: Hearings shall be held on the date, time and place as established by the village with appropriate notice served upon the public safety
employee.
(B) Record: All hearings shall be attended by a certified court reporter and a transcript of all proceedings shall be made by said certified court reporter.
(C) Procedures: The village and the petitioning public safety employee shall be entitled to representation by counsel at said hearing and may present
witnesses, may present testimony and documents, may cross examine opposing witnesses, and may request the issuance of subpoenas to compel the
appearance of relevant witnesses or the production of relevant documents.
(D) Evidence: The rules of evidence as set forth in the Illinois code of civil procedure shall apply.
(E) Final Determination: The determination by the hearing officer of whether the petitioning public safety employee is eligible for the benefits under the
public safety employee benefits act5 shall constitute a final determination for the purpose of judicial review under the common law writ of certiorari.
(Ord. 2016-4676, 9-12-2016)
1-19-6: PSEBA BENEFITS GRANTED:
If the applicant is determined to be eligible for PSEBA benefits, the applicant will be eligible to receive continued health coverage consistent with PSEBA
under the village's basic group health insurance plan. The basic group plan shall be the least expensive plan offered by the village employees at the time
the PSEBA benefits are awarded.
If an applicant becomes eligible to receive health insurance benefits from another source, including, but not limited to, medicare, the applicant's PSEBA
coverage may be reduced or eliminated as determined by the village consistent with PSEBA. The village reserves the right on an annual basis to have the
applicant provide an affidavit affirming continued eligibility for PSEBA benefits. (Ord. 2016-4676, 9-12-2016)
Title 2
BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS
Chapter 1
PLANNING AND ZONING COMMISSION
2-1-1: CREATED:
A planning and zoning commission for the village is hereby created under the authority of the Illinois municipal code, 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-1-1
et seq. (Ord. 2003-3451, 4-7-2003, eff. 5-1-2003)
2-1-2: MEMBERS:
The planning and zoning commission shall consist of seven (7) members, one of whom shall be the chairman and the said seven (7) members of said
planning and zoning commission shall be appointed by the president, subject to confirmation by the corporate authorities. Members of the planning and
zoning commission shall reside within the village or within the territory contiguous with the village. The chairman of the planning and zoning commission
shall be designated by the president, subject to confirmation by the corporate authorities. (Ord. 2003-3451, 4-7-2003, eff. 5-1-2003)
2-1-3: TERMS OF MEMBERS:
Members appointed by the president, confirmed by the corporate authorities, shall serve the following terms: two (2) shall be appointed for a term of one
year, two (2) for a term of two (2) years and the remaining three (3) for a term of three (3) years. The members so appointed shall, after the expiration of
their first term, if they are reappointed, be appointed for a period of three (3) years. All vacancies occurring in the planning and zoning commission shall be
filled by appointment of the president, subject to confirmation of the corporate authorities, for the remainder of the unexpired term in the same manner as
original appointments. (Ord. 2003-3451, 4-7-2003, eff. 5-1-2003)
2-1-4: PROCEEDINGS:
Meetings of the planning and zoning commission shall be held at the call of the chairman and at such other times as the planning and zoning commission
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 20/460
may determine. Such chairman or, in his absence, the acting chairman, may administer oaths and compel the attendance of witnesses. The presence of at
least four (4) members of the planning and zoning commission shall be necessary to constitute a quorum.
The planning and zoning commission shall adopt its own rules of procedure and shall keep a record of its own proceedings, showing the vote of each
member upon each question, or, if absent or failing to vote, indicating such fact, and shall also keep records of its hearings and other official actions.
Findings of fact shall be included in the minutes of each case of a requested variation or appeal, and the reasons for approving or denying such variation
or appeal shall be specified.
All records of proceedings, findings, determinations and actions of the planning and zoning commission shall be filed immediately in the office of the
planning and zoning commission and shall be a public record. All meetings of the planning and zoning commission shall be open to the public. (Ord. 2003-
3451, 4-7-2003, eff. 5-1-2003)
2-1-5: OFFICERS; COMPENSATION:
As soon as possible after the original appointment of members of said planning and zoning commission or upon the appointment of a new member for the
remainder of an unexpired term, the president shall designate a chairman of the planning and zoning commission subject to confirmation by the corporate
authorities. Said commission may have a secretary, a staff or both, and such other officers as may in their judgment be necessary. All members and all
officers of said planning and zoning commission shall serve without compensation with the exception of the secretary, who may receive such
compensation as may be fixed from time to time by the corporate authorities and as may be provided for in the annual appropriation ordinance. The
members of the planning and zoning commission, by their chairman, shall from time to time make recommendations to the village board of trustees with
respect to compensation for the secretary of said commission. If the planning and zoning commission deems it advisable to obtain technical or legal advice
or other professional services, it may do so, but it first must obtain from the village board of trustees prior approval and authority to incur any expense and
said expense, before incurred, must have been provided for in the annual appropriation ordinance or budget as amended and as passed by the village
board of trustees. The corporate authorities may appropriate or budget such sums as they may deem proper for the maintenance and operation of said
planning and zoning commission and/or planning department which may hereafter be created, including the salaries of all paid members and employees;
development of a planning program; preparation of regulations, projects and programs pertinent to the development, redevelopment and renewal of the
municipality and such surrounding territory over which the municipality exercises subdivision jurisdiction; the preparation and revision of the official map
and the exercise of such powers germane to the purposes for which it was created, as may be conferred upon the planning and zoning commission or
planning department by ordinance. (Ord. 2003-3451, 4-7-2003, eff. 5-1-2003)
2-1-6: PLANNING DEPARTMENT:
The corporate authorities may, by ordinance, establish a planning department. (Ord. 2003-3451, 4-7-2003, eff. 5-1-2003)
2-1-7: HEARINGS; APPEALS; NOTICES:
Appeals to the planning and zoning commission may be taken by any person aggrieved or by any officer, department, board or bureau of the village
affected by a decision of the building commissioner and/or zoning inspector. Such appeal shall be taken within such time as shall be prescribed by the
planning and zoning commission by general rule, by filing with the building commissioner and with the planning and zoning commission a notice of appeal,
specifying the grounds thereof. The building commissioner shall forthwith transmit to the planning and zoning commission all of the papers constituting the
record upon which the action appealed from was taken. (Ord. 2003-3451, 4-7-2003, eff. 5-1-2003)
2-1-8: STAY OF PROCEEDINGS:
An appeal shall stay all proceedings in furtherance of the action appealed from, unless the building commissioner certifies to the planning and zoning
commission after the notice of appeal has been filed with him that, by reason of facts stated in the certificate, a stay would, in his opinion, cause imminent
peril to life or property, in which case the proceedings shall not be stayed otherwise than by a restraining order granted by the planning and zoning
commission, or by a court of record, on application or notice to the building commissioner on due cause shown.
The planning and zoning commission shall fix a reasonable time and place for the hearing of the appeal, shall give due notice thereof to the parties in
interest, and shall render a decision within a reasonable time.
Any person may appear and testify at the hearing, either in person or by duly authorized agent or attorney. (Ord. 2003-3451, 4-7-2003, eff. 5-1-2003)
2-1-9: POWERS OF COMMISSION:
Said planning and zoning commission shall, in addition to all other powers provided by law, have the following powers:
(A) To prepare and recommend to the board of trustees of the village a comprehensive plan of public improvements looking to the present and future
development of the village, which plan shall be known as the official plan of Lisle. Such plan shall include reasonable requirements in reference to
streets, alleys and public grounds, unsubdivided lands within the corporate limits of the village and in contiguous territory outside of and distant not
more than one and one-half (11/2) miles from such limits and not included in any city, village or incorporated town. Said requirements to be effective
whenever such land shall be subdivided after the adoption of such plan.
(B) To prepare and recommend to the board of trustees from time to time such changes in the plan as may be deemed necessary by the board of trustees
or by the planning and zoning commission; provided, however, that such change will not affect the general principles of the plan as adopted.
(C) To prepare and recommend to the board of trustees from time to time general plans for specific improvements in accordance with such official plan.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 21/460
(D) To give aid to the officials of the village charged with the direction of projects for improvements embraced within the official plan, to further making of
such improvements and generally promote the realization of the official plan.
(E) To exercise such other powers germane to the powers granted by law and as may be conferred by the corporate authorities of the village.
(F) The power to perform the duties that are set out in the zoning regulations of the village, being in particular title 5, chapter 19 of this code. (Ord. 2003-
3451, 4-7-2003, eff. 5-1-2003)
2-1-10: PRELIMINARY APPROVAL OF SUBDIVISION PLATS1:
All plats of subdivision shall be submitted initially to the planning and zoning commission for preliminary approval. The application for approval shall show
location and width of proposed streets and public ways; shall indicate proposed location of sewers and storm drains; proposed dedication of public
grounds, if any; lot sizes; proposed easements for public utilities; and proposed methods of sewage and waste disposal; but need not contain
specifications for proposed improvements.
The planning and zoning commission shall approve or disapprove the application for preliminary approval within ninety (90) days of the date of application
or the filing by the applicant of the last item of required supporting data, whichever date is later, unless such time is extended by mutual consent. If such
plat is disapproved, then within ninety (90) days the planning and zoning commission shall furnish to the applicant a statement, in writing, setting forth the
reason for disapproval and specifying with particularity the aspects in which the proposed plat failed to conform to the ordinances including official map. If
the plat is approved, the corporate authorities shall accept or reject said plat within thirty (30) days after its next regular stated meeting following the action
of the planning and zoning commission. Preliminary approval shall not qualify a plat for recording.
Application for approval of the plat shall be made not later than one year after preliminary approval has been granted. The application must be supported
by such drawings, specifications and bond as may be necessary to demonstrate compliance with all requirements of applicable statutes and such
regulations as the corporate authorities may provide by ordinance under law.
The applicant may elect to have final approval of the geographic part or parts of the plat that received preliminary approval and may delay application for
approval of other parts until a later date or dates beyond one year with the approval of the corporate authorities; provided that all facilities required to serve
the part or parts for which the final approval is sought have been provided. In such case only, such part or parts of the plat as have received final approval
shall be recorded.
When a person submitting a plat of subdivision or resubdivision for final approval has supplied all drawings, maps and other documents required by the
municipal ordinances to be furnished in support thereof, and if all such material meets all municipal requirements, the corporate authorities shall approve
the proposed plat within sixty (60) days from the date of filing the last required document or other paper or within sixty (60) days from the date of filing
application for final approval of the plat, whichever date is later. The applicant and the corporate authorities may mutually agree to extend the sixty (60)
day period.
Any person seeking approval of a subdivision or resubdivision map or plat shall post a good and sufficient bond with the village clerk and a penal sum
sufficient to cover the estimate made by the village engineer, or other authorized person, of expenditures including, but not limited to, reasonable
inspection fees to be borne by the applicant, necessary to conform to the requirements established and conditions upon completion of said requirements in
a reasonable time. The form of bond shall be a form from time to time prescribed by the corporate authorities as will be the required surety to be approved
by the corporate authorities; provided that the village may permit the deposit of cash or other security acceptable to the corporate authorities, to complete
the improvements required in lieu of bond, and further provided, that no bond or securities shall be required to be filed until the corporate authorities have
approved the plat in all other respects and have notified the applicant of such approval.
If the preliminary or final plat is approved, the village clerk shall attach a certified copy of the order or resolution of approval to a copy of the plat. If the
proposed plat is disapproved, the order or resolution shall state the reasons for disapproval, specifying with particularity the aspects in which the proposed
plat fails to conform to the official map. A copy of the order or resolution shall be filed in the offices of the village clerk. (Ord. 2003-3451, 4-7-2003, eff. 5-1-
2003)
2-1-11: PREEXISTING PLATS OR MAPS:
The provisions of this chapter shall not affect the validity of any official plat or map adopted and in force prior to the effective date hereof. (Ord. 2003-3451,
4-7-2003, eff. 5-1-2003)
2-1-12: REFERENCES TO COMMISSION:
Any reference within this code to either the plan commission or the zoning board of appeals shall hereafter be seen as a reference to this combined
planning and zoning commission and any power or responsibility delegated to either individual body shall henceforth be the power or responsibility of this
combined commission. (Ord. 2005-3906, 3-21-2005)
2-1-13: EX OFFICIO STUDENT PARTICIPATION:
(A) In order to encourage civic responsibility and to provide hands on learning experiences, the high school student representative position(s) is
established for the planning and zoning commission.
(B) Student representatives shall be Lisle residents and open to all high school grade levels with preference being given to qualified seniors.
(C) Student representatives shall be expected to attend one meeting per month as regularly scheduled.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 22/460
(D) Student representatives shall serve a one year term consistent with the term of the school year.
(E) Student representatives who engage in improper behavior or are absent from two (2) or more consecutive meetings without notifying the village
planner may be removed from the commission by the chairman of the planning and zoning commission at the recommendation of the village planner.
(F) Student representatives shall not vote, nor are they to be considered a member of the commission as it relates to vote counts or quorum requirements.
(Ord. 2017-4705, 2-6-2017)

Chapter 6
BOARD OF FIRE AND POLICE COMMISSIONERS
2-6-1: CREATED:
There is hereby created a board of fire and police commissioners consisting of three (3) members, whose terms of office shall be three (3) years and until
their respective successors are appointed and have qualified.
The members of said board shall possess qualifications required by state law, and shall take the oath or affirmation of office set forth in section 2-6-4 of
this chapter, and said members shall be subject to removal from office as provided by state law. (Ord. 188, 7-6-1965; amd. 1979 Code)
2-6-2: OFFICERS OF BOARD, DUTIES:
Such board may designate one of its own members to act as secretary. The secretary shall keep the minutes of the board's proceedings, the original of
which is to remain on file and secure in the village hall so as to avoid being taken away from the village's possession or from being lost, and the secretary
shall be custodian of all papers pertaining to the business of the board, shall keep a record of all examinations held, and shall perform such other duties as
the board shall prescribe. (Ord. 188, 7-6-1965; amd. 1979 Code)
2-6-3: DUTIES AND RESPONSIBILITIES OF BOARD:
Such board of fire and police commissioners shall appoint all officers and members of the police department of the village, except the chief of police, which
appointment shall be made by the mayor with the consent of the board of trustees. All appointments made by the board of fire and police commissioners
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 23/460
shall be from the rank next below that to which the appointment shall be made, other than that of the lowest rank.
Such board of fire and police commissioners shall make such rules and make such appointments and removals except those herein reserved to the village
president and board of trustees, and shall have such other and further powers as are provided by statute. (Ord. 188, 7-6-1965; amd. 1979 Code)
2-6-4: OATH AND BOND OF COMMISSIONERS:
The member commissioners of the police board of the village shall be considered officers of the village and shall file an oath and a fidelity bond in the
amount of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) prior to their entry into and qualification for the office of police commissioner of the village. The village clerk
shall prepare an oath to be signed on appointment, but prior to taking office of each police commissioner of the village, and the village shall pay, from
monies budgeted or appropriated, the premium on any fidelity bond necessary to be taken out under state law and this section in connection with the
appointment of police commissioners of the village. (Ord. 697, 6-21-1977)
Chapter 7
POLICE PENSION FUND BOARD OF TRUSTEES
2-7-1: BOARD OF TRUSTEES; DESIGNATION:
There is hereby created a board to be known as the BOARD OF TRUSTEES OF THE POLICE PENSION FUND, such board to be composed of five (5)
members1. The members appointed by the mayor shall be residents of the village, but those elected from the regular police force, by active members and
the fifth member to be elected by and from among the beneficiaries, as hereinafter provided, need not be residents of the village. (Ord. 194, 10-7-1965;
amd. 1979 Code)
2-7-2: SELECTION OF MEMBERS:
Two (2) members of the board shall be appointed by the mayor of the village, the third and fourth members of said board shall be elected from the regular
police force by the active members thereof, and the fifth member shall be elected by and from among the beneficiaries, if any, of the fund.
Following their appointment, the members so appointed shall provide for an election of two (2) board members to be elected from the regular police force
by the active members thereof and for the election of a board member from among the beneficiaries, if any, of the fund. The election shall be held under
the Australian ballot system, at such place or places within the village and under such other regulations as shall be prescribed by the appointed members
of the board. The first election following the creation of the board shall take place as soon after the appointed members take office as is possible and those
members elected shall serve until the second Tuesday of the second May after such election. Thereafter, such members shall be elected for a term of two
(2) years, beginning on the second Tuesday of the first May after such election.
Upon the death, resignation or inability to act of any member of the board elected under this section, his successor shall be elected for the unexpired term
at a special election, to becalled by the board and conducted in the same manner as the regular biennial election.
All members of the regular police force shall be entitled to vote only for the police force members of the board. All beneficiaries of legal age shall be
entitled to vote only for the member chosen from among the beneficiaries. No person shall be entitled to cast more than one ballot at such election. (Ord.
194, 10-7-1965)
2-7-3: TERM OF OFFICE:
One of the board members appointed by the mayor shall serve until the second Tuesday in May following his appointment. The other board member
appointed by the mayor shall serve until the second Tuesday of the second May following his appointment. The successors to any of the appointed
members of the board shall serve for two (2) years each or until their successors are appointed and qualified. (Ord. 194, 10-7-1965)
2-7-4: BOARD MEETINGS:
The board shall hold regular quarterly meetings on the second Tuesday of July, October, January and April annually, and special meetings as called by the
president of the board.
At the first meeting following the election of the first board members, and thereafter at the regular July meeting, the board shall select from its members a
president, vice president, secretary and assistant secretary. The initial officers so selected shall serve until the regular July meeting and thereafter the term
of office shall be for a period of one year and until his respective successor is elected and qualified.
The vice president of the board shall perform the duties of president during any vacancy in that office, or during such time as the president is absent from
the village or for any other reason is disqualified or by reason of illness or other causes is unable to perform his duties.
The assistant secretary shall act for the secretary whenever necessary to discharge the functions of such office. (Ord. 194, 10-7-1965)
2-7-5: POWERS AND DUTIES OF BOARD:
The board shall have the powers and duties stated in 40 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3-132 to 5/3-140, and as hereafter altered or amended, in addition to
the other powers and duties granted it in said chapter. (Ord. 194, 10-7-1965)

Chapter 8
FLOOD INFORMATION COMMITTEE
2-8-1: ESTABLISHMENT AND PURPOSE:
A flood information committee for the village is created for the purpose of developing a program for public information as part of the village's community
rating system (CRS) program. A program for public information, as defined by CRS, is an ongoing local effort to identify, prepare, implement, and monitor
a range of public information activities that meet specific local needs as they relate to flood protection, flood insurance, floodplain mapping, and other flood
related issues. The CRS program is a voluntary incentive program that recognizes communities for implementing floodplain management practices that
exceed the federal minimum requirements of the national flood insurance program to provide protection from flooding. (Ord. 2016-4635, 3-7-2016)
2-8-2: MEMBERSHIP AND APPOINTMENT:
(A) The committee will consist of at least five (5), but no more than nine (9), members. The mayor, with consent of the village board of trustees, will appoint
the members as follows: three (3) members shall be appointed for a term of three (3) years and up to four (4) members for a term of two (2) years.
Thereafter, the term of each member of the commission shall be two (2) years, unless such appointment is to fill the unexpired term created by a
vacancy, occasioned by removal, resignation or death. All vacancies occurring in the flood information committee shall be filled by appointment of the
mayor, subject to confirmation of the village board of trustees, for the remainder of the unexpired term in the same manner as original appointments.
Notwithstanding the foregoing, all appointees shall hold office until their successors are appointed.
(B) The village stormwater manager and village communications director are hereby appointed to the committee, as nonvoting members. Each new or
acting stormwater manager or communications director will automatically assume the place of his or her predecessor on the committee.
(C) Membership to the committee will be appointed in the following order of priority:
1. Qualified floodplain residents who are registered electors of the village who have lived in the FEMA special flood hazard area (SFHA) for at least one
year prior to the date of appointment;
2. Qualified floodplain landowners who are at least eighteen (18) years of age and have owned property in the SFHA for at least one year prior to the
date of appointment;
3. Village of Lisle residents; and
4. Community stakeholders who are representatives of a school district, a park district, or a library district serving village residents, not for profit
community organizations serving village residents, and village businesses. (Ord. 2016-4635, 3-7-2016)
2-8-3: POWERS AND DUTIES:
(A) The duties of the committee will be:
1. To prepare and recommend, for consideration and adoption by the board of trustees, a program for public information that meets the requirements of
the CRS program.
2. To annually monitor and evaluate the program for public information for efficacy.
3. To recommend modifications to the program for public information to the village board of trustees from time to time.
(B) The stormwater manager will serve as coordinator for the committee and prepare materials for distribution and conduct such other business of the
committee as may be assigned by the committee from time to time. The communications director will serve as secretary and keep meeting minutes and
conduct such other business of the committee as may be assigned by the committee from time to time. (Ord. 2016-4635, 3-7-2016)
2-8-4: REMOVAL OF MEMBERS:
The mayor may remove any member of the committee whenever, in the mayor's sole and absolute discretion, the best interests of the village are served
thereby. Committee members who are absent from two (2) or more consecutive meetings without notifying the stormwater manager may be removed from
the committee by the mayor at the recommendation of the stormwater manager. (Ord. 2016-4635, 3-7-2016)
2-8-5: RECORDS AND PUBLIC INSPECTION:
The committee will operate in accordance with the requirements of the open meetings act and keep a written record of its proceedings that will be open to
public inspection during regular business hours of the village clerk's office and subject to the freedom of information act. (Ord. 2016-4635, 3-7-2016)
2-8-6: ANNUAL REPORT REQUIRED:
The committee will submit an annual written report to the mayor and the board of trustees no later than September 15 of each year. The report will
evaluate the implementation of the program for public information and provide recommendations for modifications to the program for public information for
the following year. (Ord. 2016-4635, 3-7-2016)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 25/460
Chapter 9
EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT AGENCY
2-9-1: ESTABLISHMENT:
There is hereby created the Lisle emergency management agency (Lisle EMA) to prevent, minimize, repair, and alleviate injury or damage resulting from
the explosion of atomic or other means from without or by means of sabotage or by other disloyal actions within, or from fire, flood, earthquake,
telecommunications failure, or other natural or technological causes, in accordance with the Illinois emergency management act1 ("the act").
The EMA shall consist of the coordinator and such additional members as may be selected by the coordinator. (Ord. 97-2866, 4-7-1997)
2-9-2: COORDINATOR:
The coordinator of the EMA shall be appointed by the village president without the need for consent by the village board, as may be from time to time
necessary. The coordinator shall have direct responsibility for the organization, administration, training, and operation of the EMA, subject to the direction
and control of the mayor and board of trustees as provided by the act. (Ord. 2001-3291, 3-5-2001)
2-9-3: CONTINUITY OF GOVERNMENT:
The principal executive officer ("PEO") of the village is the village president. The "PEO", or the emergency interim successor, is the only individual who can
officially declare a disaster in the village. The "PEO" or the emergency interim successor is the ultimate authority in the village during any declared
disaster,but relies directly on information and advice from the coordinator and the village manager.
In the event that the "PEO" is unavailable, the powers of office shall be exercised, and duties shall be discharged by the designated emergency interim
successors in the order specified. The emergency interim successors shall exercise the powers and discharge the duties of the office to which designated
until such time as a vacancy which may exist shall be filled in accordance with statutes to exercise the powers and discharge the duties of office.
Emergency interim successors in the following order of succession are hereby designated for the "PEO" as follows:
Village board:
(A) Senior trustee.
(B) Next most senior trustee.
(C) Most senior trustee available.
In cases in which two (2) or more trustees have served the same length of time, seniority of those trustees will be determined as follows: The most
senior trustee will be the trustee who received the greatest number of votes in the election in which the trustees who are tied for seniority were first
elected to the village board. If two (2) or more trustees who are tied for seniority have served intermittent terms on the board, the vote count used to
determine seniority shall be from the election from which the trustee was elected to this current and consecutive length of service. Trustees will be
ranked for seniority purposes by the total numbers of votes received by each individual trustee from highest number to lowest number. Seniority will
continue to be assigned by vote totals from the above designated election to the village board.
All emergency interim successors shall exercise the powers and discharge the duties of an office until a successor is appointed or elected and qualified
as may be provided by the constitution, statutes, charters, and ordinances or until the lawful incumbent is able to resume the exercise of the power and
discharge the duties of office.
All vital records shall be maintained and protected by the coordinator for use in reestablishing governmental operations after the emergency is declared
over. (Ord. 2002-3365, 1-7-2002)
2-9-4: FUNCTIONS:
The EMA shall coordinate emergency management functions within the territorial limits of the village as are prescribed in and by the state emergency
operations plan, and programs, orders, rules, and regulations as may be promulgated by the Illinois emergencymanagement agency and, in addition, shall
conduct such functions outside of those territorial limits as may be required under mutual aid agreements and compacts as provided in the act. (Ord. 97-
2866, 4-7-1997)
2-9-5: SERVICE AS MOBILE SUPPORT TEAM:
All or any members of the EMA may be designated as member of a mobile support team created by the director of the state EMA as provided by law.
The leader of such mobile support team shall be designated as provided by the act.
Personnel of a mobile support team, while on duty pursuant to such a call or while engaged in regularly scheduled training exercises, whether within or
without the state, shall either:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 26/460
(A) If they are paid employees of the village, have the powers, duties, rights, privileges, and immunities, and receive the compensation incidental to their
employment;
(B) If they are not employees of the village, be entitled to at least one dollar ($1.00) per year compensation from the state. (Ord. 97-2866, 4-7-1997)
2-9-6: AGREEMENTS WITH OTHER POLITICAL SUBDIVISIONS:
The coordinator may, in collaboration with other public agencies within his immediate vicinity, develop or cause to be developed mutual aid arrangements
with other political subdivisions within this state for reciprocal disaster response and recovery assistance in case a disaster is too great to be dealt with
unassisted. The mutual aid shall not, however, be effective unless and until approved by each of the political subdivisions. The arrangements shall be
consistent with the state emergency operations plan and state emergency management program, and in the event of a disaster, it shall be the duty of each
emergency management agency to render assistance in accordance with the provisions of the mutual aid arrangements. (Ord. 97-2866, 4-7-1997)
2-9-7: LOCAL DISASTER DECLARATION:
A local disaster may be declared only by the "PEO" of the village, or his emergency interim successor. It shall not be continued or renewed for a period in
excess of seven (7) days except by or with the consent of the governing board of the village. Any order or proclamation declaring, continuing, or
terminating a local disaster shall be given prompt and general publicity and shall be filed promptly with the village clerk.
The effect of a declaration of a local disaster is to activatethe emergency operations plan of that village and to authorize the furnishing of aid and
assistance thereunder. (Ord. 97-2866, 4-7-1997)
2-9-8: EMERGENCY ACTION:
A proclamation of a disaster by the governor shall activate the state emergency operations plan and the village's emergency operations plan, and it shall
be authority for the deployment and use of any forces that the plan applies and for use or distribution of any supplies, equipment, and materials and
facilities assembled, stockpiled, or arranged to be made available under the act or any other provision of law relating to disasters. (Ord. 97-2866, 4-7-
1997)
2-9-9: REIMBURSEMENT BY STATE:
The state treasurer may receive and allocate to the appropriate fund any reimbursement by the state to the village for expenses incident to training
members of the EMA as prescribed by the state director of EMA; compensation for service and expenses of members of a mobile support team while
serving outside the village in response to a call by the governor or state director of the EMA, as provided by law; and any other reimbursement made by
the state incident to EMA activities as provided by law. (Ord. 97-2866, 4-7-1997)
2-9-10: PURCHASES AND EXPENDITURES:
In carrying out the provisions of the act, the village may enter into contracts and incur obligations necessary to place it in a position effectively to combat
the disaster; to protect the health and safety of persons; to protect property; and to provide emergency assistance to victims of those disasters. If a
disaster occurs, the village may exercise powers vested under the act in the light of exigencies of the disaster and, excepting mandatory constitutional
requirements, without regard to the procedures and formalities normally prescribed by law pertaining to the performance of public work; entering into
contracts, incurring of obligations; the employment of temporary works; the rental of equipment; the purchase of supplies and materials; and the
appropriation, expenditure, and disposition of public funds and property. (Ord. 97-2866, 4-7-1997)
2-9-11: OATH:
Each person whether compensated or noncompensated, who is appointed to serve in any capacity in the Illinois emergency management agency or the
village emergency management agency, shall, before entering upon his duties, take an oath, in writing, before the coordinator or before other persons
authorized to administer oaths in this state, which oath shall be filed withthe coordinator and which oath shall be substantially as follows:
I, , do solemnly swear (or affirm) that I will support, defend, and bear true faith and allegiance to the Constitution of the United States and the
Constitution of the State of Illinois, and the territory, institutions and facilities thereof, both public and private, against all enemies, foreign and domestic;
that I take this obligation freely, without any mental reservation or purpose of evasion; and that I will well and faithfully discharge the duties upon which I
am about to enter. I do further affirm that I do not advocate, nor am I nor have I been a member of any political party or organization that advocates the
overthrow of the government of the United States or of this State by force or violence; and that during such time as I am affiliated with the Lisle EMA
organization, I will not advocate nor become a member of any political party or organization that advocates the overthrow of the government of the United
States or of this State by force or violence.
(Ord. 97-2866, 4-7-1997)
2-9-12: OFFICE:
The village president and board of trustees are authorized to designate space in a village building, or elsewhere, as may be provided for by the village
president and the board of trustees for the village EMA as its office. (Ord. 97-2866, 4-7-1997)

https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 27/460

Chapter 11
LISLE IN TOUCH COMMISSION
2-11-1: CREATED:
There shall be and is hereby created an advisory commission known as the Lisle in touch commission for the purpose of developing and implementing
programs intended to educate and raise the awareness of Lisle area residents concerning ways to raise a generation of drug free youth to break the cycle
of substance abuse in the community. (Ord. 91-2146, 5-6-1991)
2-11-2: APPOINTMENT OF MEMBERS:
(A) The commission shall consist of eleven (11) members, each of which shall be appointed by the board of trustees. Of the eleven (11) members, five (5)
of the members, who shall be voting members of the commission, shall be as follows: one member shall be an elected official of the village; one
member shall be employed by or be an elected official of the Lisle School District 202; one member shall be a member of the Lisle police department;
one member shall be employed by or be an elected official of the Lisle park district; and one member shall be a resident who lives within the village
planning jurisdiction. Of the remaining six (6) members, who shall be nonvoting ex officio members of the commission, there shall be one member who
shall be under the age of eighteen (18) years and attend a public or private religious school, institution or system located within the village planning
jurisdiction, the remaining five (5) members shall be representatives of local community service organizations (Lions Club, Rotary Club, Jaycees,
Kiwanis Club, etc.); the health service industry; youth services or community outreach organization; or residents who live within the village planning
jurisdiction.
(B) 1. Of the five (5) voting members, the term of appointment for the member who is an elected official of the village, the member who is employed by or
an elected official of the Lisle School District 202, and the member who is a resident who lives within the village planning jurisdiction shall be from
November 5, 2001, through April 30, 2002. The term of appointment for the member who is a member of the Lisle police department and the member
who is employed by or an elected official of the Lisle park district shall be from November 5, 2001, through April 30, 2003. Thereafter, the term of each
voting member of the commission shall be two (2) years, unless such appointment is to fill the unexpired term created by a vacancy. Notwithstanding
theforegoing, all appointees shall hold office until their successors are appointed.
2. Of the six (6) nonvoting ex officio members, the term of appointment for the member who is under the age of eighteen (18) years shall be from
November 5, 2001, through April 30, 2002. Of the remaining five (5) nonvoting ex officio members, the term of appointment for two (2) members shall
be from November 5, 2001, through April 30, 2002, and three (3) members shall be appointed for a term from November 5, 2001, through April 30,
2003. Thereafter, the term of the member under the age of eighteen (18) years shall be one year and the term of each other nonvoting ex officio
member of the commission shall be two (2) years, unless such appointment is to fill the unexpired term created by a vacancy. Notwithstanding the
foregoing, all appointees shall hold office until their successors are appointed.
(C) The voting members of the commission appointed as set forth herein shall elect from among themselves a chairman and a vice chairman to preside
over the commission meetings and to direct the business of the commission. (Ord. 2001-3354, 10-15-2001)
(D) A recording secretary shall be furnished by the village to record the minutes of each meeting and to furnish clerical and record keeping support to the
commission. (Ord. 91-2220, 11-18-1991)
(E) The member who is an elected official of the village shall be the liaison between the village board and the commission. The member who is a member
of the Lisle police department shall be the liaison between the village staff and the commission. (Ord. 99-3130, 7-6-1999)
(F) A quorum necessary in order to conduct business of the commission shall be defined as any three (3) voting members of the commission. (Ord. 2001-
3354, 10-15-2001)
2-11-3: DUTIES OF COMMISSION:
(A) The commission shall be an advisory commission only and shall meet as necessary to manage the business of the commission, and to discuss and
make recommendations to the board of trustees to effectuate the purposes and goals of the commission. To the extent approved by the board of
trustees, the commission shall implement programs discussed and recommended.
(B) All contractual obligations, expenditures, solicitations and collection of funds shall be entered into or made only with the express consent of the board
of trustees. (Ord. 91-2146, 5-6-1991)
Chapter 12
ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT COMMISSION
2-12-1: ESTABLISHMENT AND PURPOSE:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 28/460
There is hereby established a commission which shall be known as the Village of Lisle Economic Development Commission for the purpose of
encouraging industrial development, commercial business, retail and other supporting services which will provide job opportunities, broaden the tax base,
and improve the quality of living in the Village. The Economic Development Commission (commission) shall develop a plan for proper economic
development of the Village and shall coordinate its activities with appropriate local and regional organizations. Said commission shall make its findings and
recommendations to the Mayor and Board of Trustees in the manner prescribed herein. (Ord. 2019-4806, 2-4-2019)
2-12-2: MEMBERS:
The commission shall consist of nine (9) members. The Mayor, with the consent of the Village Board of Trustees, will appoint the members as follows:
three (3) members shall be appointed for a term of three (3) years, three (3) members for a term of two (2) years, and three (3) members for a term of one
year. Thereafter, the term of each member of the commission shall be three (3) years, unless such appointment is to fill the unexpired term created by a
vacancy, occasioned by removal, resignation or death. The Mayor may also appoint, with the consent of the Village Board of Trustees, up to two (2) ex
officio members from the Board of Trustees, to serve two (2) year appointments. All vacancies occurring in the Economic Development Commission shall
be filled by appointment of the Mayor, subject to confirmation of the Village Board of Trustees, for the remainder of the unexpired term in the same manner
as original appointments. Notwithstanding the foregoing, all appointees shall hold office until their successors are appointed. (Ord. 2019-4806, 2-4-2019)
2-12-3: MEMBER QUALIFICATIONS:
(A) Members shall:
1. Reside within the corporate limits of the Village; or
2. Be an employee, officer, manager or owner of a business which has one or more business locations within the corporate limits of the Village; or
3. Otherwise have a significant economic stake in the Village.
(B) A member shall have experience or expertise in one or more of the following areas:
1. Commercial or industrial real estate development;
2. Real estate brokerage;
3. Financial institutions;
4. Manufacturing or industrial activity;
5. Retail sales;
6. Large business (greater than 50 employees) within the Village;
7. Small business (50 employees or less) within the Village;
8. Business development;
9. Experience in legal or other aspects of business operations, expansion, retention or attraction such as involvement in economic incentives, business
districts or other public/private business agreements.
(C) In the event a member of the commission no longer meets the qualifications of subsection (A) of this section, that member may continue to serve on
the commission if the Board, upon recommendation by the Mayor, determines that the member's previous experience with the commission or the
member's experience or expertise as noted in subsection (B) of this section, would remain a benefit to the commission. (Ord. 2019-4806, 2-4-2019)
2-12-4: REMOVAL OF MEMBERS:
The Mayor may remove any member of the commission whenever the best interests of the Village shall be served thereby. Commissioners who are
absent from two (2) or more consecutive meetings without notifying the Chairperson or Village Manager or his/her designee ahead of time, or without a
valid excuse, may be removed from the commission by the Mayor at the recommendation of the Chairperson. (Ord. 2019-4806, 2-4-2019)
2-12-5: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The duty of the commission shall be to encourage and facilitate economic growth within the Village. The commission shall function in an advisory capacity
to the Mayor and the Village Board of Trustees on the following goals and objectives. However, unless authorized by the Village Board, the commission
shall not review or make recommendations relative to zoning or the use of specific sites if the zoning or use is or will be subject to review of the Planning
and Zoning Commission, Village Board or other Village agency.
(A) To prepare, develop and recommend to the Village Board a strategic plan, including such amendments as may from time to time be appropriate, to
encourage the location, retention and expansion of businesses within the Village.
(B) To prepare, review and evaluate proposals to encourage the location of new businesses within the Village, and to encourage the retention and
expansion of existing businesses.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 29/460
(C) To prepare, review, and develop materials to market or otherwise promote the Village as a desirable location to locate, retain and expand a business.
(D) To review, evaluate and make recommendations to the Village Board concerning the funding and promotion of projects and programs, which
encourage the location, retention and expansion of businesses within the Village.
(E) To identify and evaluate business development or redevelopment opportunities within the Village, identifying parcels whose development or
redevelopment will benefit economic conditions.
(F) Reserved.
(G) Reserved.
(H) Reserved.
(I) To identify other community economic development needs as they arise and devise plans to meet those needs.
(J) To consider and evaluate economic incentive applications regarding the attraction, retention and expansion of business in Lisle at the request and
direction of the Village Board and make recommendations relative to said applications in an advisory capacity.
(K) To provide input and assistance in the development of strategic plans for business areas and commercial areas of the Village such as downtown Lisle,
Ogden Avenue, Route 53 or other Commercial or Business Districts at the request and direction of the Village Board. (Ord. 2019-4806, 2-4-2019)
2-12-6: OFFICERS AND MEETINGS:
(A) A commission Chairperson and Vice-Chairperson shall be selected from among the membership of the commission, every twenty four (24) months.
The Chairperson shall preside at all meetings of the commission. In the absence of the Chairperson, the Vice-Chairperson shall act as a presider.
(B) The commission shall meet regularly. Special meetings may be called as deemed necessary by the Chairperson.
(C) The commission shall be bound by the ordinance of the Village and comply with all applicable provisions of the Illinois Open Meetings Act.
(D) Robert's Rules of Order shall guide the commission meetings procedures. (Ord. 2019-4806, 2-4-2019)
2-12-7: STAFF ASSIGNED TO THE ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT COMMISSION:
It shall be the duty of the Village Manager or his/her designee to have the responsibility for administration of the commission and to recommend to the
Village Mayor and Board of Trustees, in conjunction with the commission programs and policies that encourage and promote the retention and expansion
of business within the Village. (Ord. 2019-4806, 2-4-2019)
2-12-8: ANNUAL REPORT:
A report of the Economic Development Commission activities will be made to Village Board annually. (Ord. 2019-4806, 2-4-2019)
2-12-9: VOLUNTEERS:
The commission is authorized to enlist the volunteer services of such other members of the community who will assist in achieving the goals of sound
economic growth, recognizing broad community involvement will assure broad community support. (Ord. 2019-4806, 2-4-2019)

There shall be and is hereby created an advisory commission known as the Lisle technology commission for the purpose of advising the village board of
trustees regarding the use of available technology by village government to provide high quality and cost efficient benefits to the residents and businesses
of the village of Lisle. (Ord. 2001-3324, 7-2-2001)

(A) The commission shall consist of seven (7) members, each of which shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice and consent of the board of

trustees, the commission shall implement programs discussed and recommended.
(B) All contractual obligations, expenditures, solicitations and collection of funds shall be entered into or made only with the express consent of the board
of trustees. (Ord. 2001-3324, 7-2-2001)

Chapter 16
BICYCLIST AND PEDESTRIAN ADVISORY COMMITTEE
2-16-1: ESTABLISHMENT AND PURPOSE:
A Bicyclist and Pedestrian Advisory Committee is hereby created for the purposes of promoting and encouraging bicycling and walking through Lisle, for
both recreation and transportation, including the creation of safer routes, capital improvements, amenities, events and programs. (Ord. 2018-4763, 5-7-
2018)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 31/460
2-16-2: MEMBERSHIP AND APPOINTMENT:
(A) The Bicyclist and Pedestrian Advisory Committee will consist of at least five (5) members, but no more than nine (9) members. The Mayor, with
consent of the Village Board of Trustees, will appoint the members as follows: three (3) members shall be appointed for a term of three (3) years and
two (2) members for a term of two (2) years. Thereafter, the term of each member of the commission shall be two (2) years, unless such appointment is
to fill the unexpired term created by a vacancy, occasioned by removal, resignation or death. All vacancies occurring in the Bicyclist and Pedestrian
Advisory Committee shall be filled by appointment of the Mayor, subject to confirmation of the Village Board of Trustees, for the remainder of the
unexpired term in the same manner as original appointments. Notwithstanding the foregoing, all appointees shall hold office until their successors are
appointed.
(B) The Village Planner and Public Works Director or their designees shall serve on the Bicyclist and Pedestrian Advisory Committee as non-voting
members. Each new or acting Village Planner or Public Works Director will automatically assume the place of his or her predecessor on the committee.
(C) A representative appointed by the Lisle Park District shall serve on the Bicyclist and Pedestrian Advisory Committee as a non-voting member.
(D) Membership to the committee may be appointed from the following:
1. Village of Lisle residents; and
2. Community business owners/managers. (Ord. 2018-4763, 5-7-2018)
2-16-3: POWERS AND DUTIES:
(A) The duties of the Bicyclist and Pedestrian Advisory Committee will be as follows:
1. Plan for bicyclists and pedestrians as part of a Village wide and regional multi-use transportation system;
2. Evaluate and prioritize ways to improve the level of bicycle and pedestrian services, trails, paths, on-street bikeways, and other economically
feasible projects;
3. Identify high-priority projects that improve safety for motorists, bicyclists, and pedestrians, while reducing vehicle and bike/pedestrian conflicts;
4. Establish communications with bicycle and pedestrian advocacy groups such as Ride Illinois, Active Transportation Alliance, and other related
community groups;
5. Make recommendations to the Village Board for the planning of bikeway and pedestrian routes; and
6. Perform such other duties and functions as may be requested of it by the Mayor and Village Board. (Ord. 2018-4763, 5-7-2018)
2-16-4: REMOVAL OF MEMBERS:
The Mayor may remove any member of the Bicyclist and Pedestrian Advisory Committee whenever, in the Mayor's sole and absolute discretion, the best
interests of the Village is served thereby. (Ord. 2018-4763, 5-7-2018)
2-16-5: RECORDS AND PUBLIC INSPECTION:
The Bicyclist and Pedestrian Advisory Committee will operate in accordance with the requirements of the Open Meetings Act and keep a written record of
its proceedings that will be open to public inspection during regular business hours of the Village Clerk's Office and subject to the Freedom of Information
Act. (Ord. 2018-4763, 5-7-2018)
Title 3
BUSINESS REGULATIONS
Chapter 1
GENERAL BUSINESS LICENSES
3-1-1: LICENSES REQUIRED:
No person shall engage in any of the businesses or occupations enumerated in the village of Lisle annual fee ordinance without first obtaining from the
business office manager, in accordance with the applicable procedures, a license to engage in said business or occupation. (Ord. 2007-4107, 4-16-2007)
3-1-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSES; ISSUANCE:
Written application for such license shall be made to the business office manager stating the name of the applicant, the place of business, number of
persons to be employed and the kind of business to be carried on and all such other information as may be requested by the application form as amended
from time to time. All licenses shall issue by authority of the president and board of trustees of the village or their designee. Provided, however, that no
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 32/460
business license shall issue to any person engaged in or intending to engage in the operation of a food service establishment and/or retail food store
within the village until and unless evidence of a valid permit issued by the DuPage County health department pursuant to the provisions of this code, as
may be from time to time hereafter amended, regulating and supervising food service and retail food store sanitation, is presented with said application to
the business office manager. Further, it shall be the responsibility of any licensee engaged in or intending to engage in the operation of a food service
establishment and/or retail food store within the village to maintain a valid permit issued by the DuPage County health department, during the entire term
of the village license and issuance of a village license shall not relieve the licensee of such obligation. The failure to maintain a valid permit issued by the
DuPage County health department, as required, shall be grounds for revocation of a village license. (Ord. 2002-3425, 11-4-2002)
3-1-3: FEES PRORATED:
Except as otherwise specified herein or otherwise in this code, when application is made for an annual license after July 1 of any calendar year, applicant
shall give satisfactory evidence that he has not engaged in the business, profession or occupation so licensed prior to July 1 of said year and, in that
event, such fee shall be fifty percent (50%) of the annual fee provided therefor. Fees for licenses issued for peddling foodstuffs1 shall not be prorated.
(Ord. 2002-3425, 11-4-2002)
3-1-4: CONDITIONS OF LICENSES:
(A) The mayor, with the approval of the board of trustees, shall have the power to revoke any license granted hereunder for violation by the licensee or his
agents of any village ordinance or state or federal statute, regulation or order relating to the conduct of such business or occupation. Said licenses shall
not be transferable. Upon notice to the licensee of said revocation, said licensee shall have the right to a hearing conducted by the mayor and board of
trustees, upon request, therefor, prior to such revocation.
(B) Annual license fees for all licenses except those issued for Lisle commuter parking lot mobile concessionaire/merchandiser shall be paid to the village
no later than twelve o'clock (12:00) noon on December 15 of the preceding year for which the license is issued. A fee paid after that date shall include
a late fee as established by the annual fee ordinance. After January 16 of the applicable license year, the village shall issue a citation of an ordinance
violation and an additional late fee shall be charged as established by the annual fee ordinance. (Ord. 97-2906, 8-4-1997)
3-1-5: INVESTIGATION OF APPLICANTS AND/OR PREMISES:
The police or any other official designated by ordinance to make inspection under any licensing or regulatory ordinance or to enforce the same shall have
the right of entry to any licensed place of business for the purpose of enforcement or inspection, and may arrest or cause to be arrested any person who
violates the provisions of this or any license ordinance of the village.
Wherever any licensing or regulatory ordinance provides for inspection by the police chief, such inspection may be performed by said police chief or by his
designated representative. (Ord. 280, 7-20-1968)
3-1-6: LICENSES TO BE POSTED:
Every licensee shall conspicuously post his certificate in the place of business in such place as to be in plain view, and no person shall destroy, alter or
mutilate such certificate or other evidence of license. If the licensee has no regular established place of business, he shall then carry such license upon his
person whenever engaged in his licensed occupation. (Ord. 280, 7-20-1968)
3-1-7: LICENSE FEES:
The annual license fees for specific businesses and occupations shall be as established by the annual fee ordinance. (Ord. 2005-3937, 6-20-2005)
3-1-8: EXEMPTIONS FOR LOCAL CHARITABLE OR MUNICIPAL ORGANIZATIONS:
Those organizations described in subsections (A) and (B) of this section shall be exempt from the requirements set forth in the annual fee ordinance.
(A) Charitable: A "charitable organization" shall mean and include an organization or institution, whose primary office is within the village, which is
organized and operated to benefit an indefinite number of the public. The service rendered to those eligible for benefits must also confer some benefit
on the public.
(B) Municipal: A "municipal organization" shall mean a body politic, organized in whole or in part within the village, pursuant to Illinois Compiled Statutes.
(Ord. 82-1047, 6-1-1982)
3-1-9: PENALTIES:
Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be fined as established by the annual fee ordinance. (Ord. 96-2776, 5-20-1996)
Chapter 2
LIQUOR CONTROL REGULATIONS
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 33/460
3-2-1: DEFINITIONS:
Unless the context otherwise requires, the words and phrases herein defined are used in this chapter in the same meaning given them in the following
definitions:
ALCOHOL: The product of distillation of any fermented liquid, whether rectified or diluted, whatever may be the origin thereof, and includes synthetic ethyl
alcohol. It does not include denatured alcohol or wood alcohol.
ALCOHOL, POWDERED: Any powder or crystalline substance containing "alcohol", as defined in this section, produced for human consumption.
ALCOHOLIC LIQUOR: Includes "alcohol", "spirits", "wine" and "beer" and every liquid or solid, patented or not, containing alcohol, spirits, wine or beer and
capable of being consumed as a beverage by a human being. The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to alcohol used in the manufacture of
denatured alcohol produced in accordance with acts of congress and regulations promulgated thereunder, nor to any liquid or solid containing one-half of
one percent (0.5%) or less of alcohol by volume.
BEER: A beverage obtained by the alcoholic fermentation of an infusion or concoction of barley, or other grain, malt and hops in water, and includes
among other things, beer, ale, stout, lager beer, port and the like.
CHAMPAGNE: Any "wine", as defined herein, further characterized by effervescence caused by fermentation and consequent generation of carbon
dioxide.
CONVENIENCE STORE: A "grocery store" as defined in this section, equal to or less than five thousand (5,000) square feet.
GROCERY STORE: A commercial retail establishment of more than five thousand (5,000) square feet with the majority of the total sales area on the
licensed premises being devoted to the sale of items which may include, but are not limited to, prepackaged foods, fruits, vegetables, meats, dairy
products, baked goods, nonalcoholic beverages, household products, magazines, books, greeting cards, prescription medications, health and beauty
products.
HOTEL: Every building or other structure kept, used, maintained, advertised and held out to the public to be a place where food is actually served and
consumed and sleeping accommodations are offered for adequate pay to travelers and guests, whether transient, permanent or residential, in which
twenty five (25) or more rooms are used for the sleeping accommodations of such guests and having one or more public dining rooms where meals are
served to such guests, such sleeping accommodations and dining rooms being conducted in the same building or buildings in connection therewith and
such building or buildings, structure or structures being provided with adequate and sanitary kitchen and dining room equipment and capacity.
LICENSED PREMISES: Every building, establishment, structure, place of business or location, whether or not enclosed from the elements, owned or
leased by the licensee, having been designated on the license application as the location for the operation of the licensed business, for which a current
license is in effect.
MANAGER, ASSISTANT MANAGER, PART TIME OR TEMPORARY MANAGER: Any person whose full time, part time or temporary activities include any
of the following: a) overseeing the operation of a liquor establishment; b) ordering, receiving or managing liquor inventory; c) hiring, training or supervising
bartenders, servers or sellers of liquor products; d) paying employees or suppliers; e) responding to customer complaints related to liquor establishment
operations; f) communicating on behalf of the liquor license holder with the Local Liquor Commissioner, Village Business Office Manager, Village Police
Department or other Village agencies and departments. If more than one person performs all or any of the above functions, each such person shall be
deemed a manager, assistant manager or temporary manager.
OFF SITE CATERING BUSINESS: A business which serves food at a location not owned or leased by such business.
PACKAGE STORE: A commercial retail establishment with the primary revenue source for its licensed premises being the sale of alcoholic products in
their original unopened packages.
PERSONAL SERVICES ESTABLISHMENT: Retail establishments whereby the principal business is to provide personal services related to hair care, skin
care, nail care, cosmetics, deep muscle body treatments, facials, and massage. Personal services establishments as defined in this chapter do not include
tattoo establishments.
RESTAURANT: Any public place kept, used, maintained, advertised or held out to the public as a place where meals are regularly prepared and served,
and where adequate provision is made for sanitary kitchen and dining equipment and a sufficient number of employees to prepare, cook and serve a
reasonable variety of meals for its customers. The mere availability of snack items, prepackaged food items, or cold sandwiches alone shall not be
sufficient to meet this definition, the intent being that meals consisting of more than one course shall be available at all times liquor sales are being
conducted until at least ten o'clock (10:00) P.M. After such time, a reduced menu of appetizers, hors d'oeuvres or other similar foods may be offered. Food
service must be provided continuously until one hour prior to closing.
RETAILER: A person who sells, or offers for sale, alcoholic liquor for use or consumption and not for resale in any form.
SALE OR SELL: Any transfer, exchange or barter in any manner, or by any means whatsoever, including, but not limited to, a transaction involving
telephone, mail, facsimile, internet or any other electronic or remote messaging device, and includes and means all sales made by any person, whether
principal, proprietor, agent, servant or employee. The taking of an order for immediate or future remote delivery shall also be deemed a sale.
SPIRITS: Any beverage which contains alcohol obtained by distillation, mixed with water or other substance in solution, and includes brandy, rum,
whiskey, gin or other spirituous liquors, and such liquors when rectified, blended or otherwise mixed with alcohol or other substances.
