federal law of the United States;
15. In the case of noncommercial solicitation, the applicant shall submit a financial statement of said noncommercial organization for the preceding
twelve (12) months which shall include a balance sheet and statement of income and expenses clearly stating forth the following: gross receipts and
gross income from all sources specifying total receipts and income from each separate solicitation project or source; cost of administration; cost of
solicitation; cost of programs designed to inform or educate the public; funds or properties transferred out of the state, with explanation as to recipient
and purpose; total net income amount for each major purpose, charitable or otherwise. Statements shall be signed by the president or other
authorized officer or agent and shall be accompanied by an opinion signed by an independent certified public accountant that said financial
statement fairly represents the financial operation of the organization.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 47/460
A copy of the annual report to the attorney general of Illinois required by 225 Illinois Compiled Statutes 460/4 may be presented in lieu of the
aforementioned financial statements. For the purpose of financial statements, the definitions and standards applicable to the annual report to the
attorney general as set forth in said provision shall be utilized. This subsection (A)15 shall not apply to any organization which is a political
subdivision or is associated with a political subdivision of the State.
In the event a noncommercial organization has not been established for a period of twelve (12) months, a copy of the registration statement filed with
the Attorney General of Illinois pursuant to 225 Illinois Compiled Statutes 460/2, may be utilized;
16. All applicants shall submit an indemnification and hold harmless agreement for the purpose of indemnifying the Village for all claims for damages to
persons or property arising from solicitation activities within the Village. The agreement shall be in a form provided by the Business Office Manager;
17. All applicants shall provide all such other information as may be requested by the application form, as amended from time to time.
(B) Fees: Each application for solicitation permit shall be accompanied by a license fee as established by the annual fee ordinance.
(C) Permit Duration: A permit referred to herein shall be valid for a period of up to ninety (90) days as specified on the permit application. (Ord. 2011-4408,
10-17-2011)
(D) Grounds For Denial: All applications for a solicitation permit shall be filed with the Village Manager or his/her designee and shall be verified under oath.
The Village Manager or his/her designee, within five (5) business days of receipt of the application, shall consider the information contained therein and
shall deny only the applications of applicants:
1. Who have violated one of the provisions of this chapter;
2. Whose solicitation permit issued hereunder has previously been revoked pursuant to section 3-4-10 of this chapter within the last thirty six (36)
months;
3. Who are themselves or who employ to solicit any person who has been convicted of a serious felony (as defined in section 3-4-1 of this chapter)
under the laws of any State or Federal law of the United States; or
4. Whose application does not contain all of the information and documentation required in this section.
If the applicant has complied with the above provisions, a solicitation permit shall be issued. The grounds set forth above shall be the only grounds
under which an application to solicit will be denied. In addition, failure to render a decision within five (5) business days shall constitute an approval of
the application and a permit shall be issued. (Ord. 2018-4761, 4-16-2018)
(E) Notification Of Denial; Appeal:
1. In the event that any permit to engage in solicitation is denied for the reasons stated herein, the Business Office Manager shall immediately notify
the applicant in writing of the reasons for said denial.
2. If the applicant is denied a permit, an appeal may be filed. The President and Board of Trustees shall hear appeals concerning a denial. An appeal
must be filed in the Village Manager's Office within twenty one (21) days after the date of denial of the application of permit by the Business Office
Manager.
3. If a hearing is requested, the President and Board of Trustees shall schedule a hearing at their next regularly scheduled meeting. The appealing
party shall have the right to file additional documents, amend the written appeal, and to appear at such hearing in person, or by attorney, or
otherwise to examine and cross examine witnesses.
4. The President and Board of Trustees shall not be bound by the rules of evidence prevailing in the courts of law, but shall, in ascertaining the
conditions and practices involved in the decision appealed, take into account all reliable, probative, and substantial evidence produced at the hearing
relating to the denial of the application. (Ord. 2011-4408, 10-17-2011)
3-4-4: RECORDS OF APPLICATIONS, PERMITS:
The Village Clerk shall cause to be kept in his office an accurate record of every application received and acted upon together with all other information
and data pertaining thereto, all solicitation permits issued under the provisions of this chapter, and a record of the denial of any and all applications.
Applications for permits shall be numbered in consecutive order as filed, and every permit issued and any renewal thereof shall be identified with the
duplicate number of the application upon which it was issued. (Ord. 2011-4408, 10-17-2011)
3-4-5: VILLAGE POLICY ON SOLICITING:
It is hereby declared to be the policy of the governing body of the village that the occupant or occupants of the residences or businesses in the village shall
make the determination of whether solicitors shall be, or shall not be, invited to their respective premises. (Ord. 2011-4408, 10-17-2011)
3-4-6: NOTICE REGULATING SOLICITING:
(A) Every person desiring to secure the protection intended to be provided by the regulations pertaining to soliciting contained in this chapter, may post
written notice on or near the main entrance with lettering no less than one-half inch (1/2") in height, indicating that there is to be no soliciting on the
premises. Such written notice so displayed shall constitute sufficient notice to any solicitor.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 48/460
(B) It shall be the duty of every solicitor upon going onto any premises in the village to first examine the notice provided for above, if any is attached, and
be governed by the statement contained in said notice. If the notice states "No Solicitors Invited", or similar wording, then the solicitor shall immediately
and peacefully depart from the premises.
(C) Any solicitor who has gained entrance to any residence, whether invited or not, shall immediately and peacefully depart from the premises when
requested to do so by the occupant. (Ord. 2011-4408, 10-17-2011)
3-4-7: PROHIBITED ACTS:
(A) Uninvited Soliciting Prohibited: It is hereby declared to be unlawful and shall constitute a nuisance for any person to go upon any premises and ring the
doorbell upon or near any door, or create any sound in any other manner calculated to attract the attention to the occupant of such premises for the
purpose of securing an audience with the occupant thereof and engage in soliciting as herein defined in defiance of the notice exhibited at the
premises in accordance with the provisions of section 3-4-6 of this chapter.
(B) Time Limit On Soliciting:
1. Residential Areas: No person shall engage in "commercial solicitation" as herein defined, in residential areas, prior to nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. or
after eight o'clock (8:00) P.M. of any day. No person shall engage in "noncommercial solicitation" as herein defined, in residential areas, prior to nine
o'clock (9:00) A.M. or after nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. of any day.
2. Highways: Persons approved to solicit upon highways as provided in section 3-4-8 of this chapter shall not engage in solicitation prior to six o'clock
(6:00) A.M. or after eight o'clock (8:00) P.M. of any day from April 1 to October 31. There shall be no solicitation upon highways during the period
beginning November 1 and ending March 31.
3. Train Station: Persons approved to solicit at the Lisle/Burlington Northern Railroad commuter parking facility, depot and platform as provided in
section 3-4-9 of this chapter shall not engage in solicitation prior to six o'clock (6:00) A.M. or after nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. of any day.
4. Soliciting Outside Of Hours: It is hereby declared to be unlawful and shall constitute a nuisance for any person, whether registered under this chapter
or not, to violate any portion of this section, to go upon any premises and ring the doorbell upon or near any door of a residence located thereon, or
rap or knock upon any door, or create any sound in any other manner calculated to attract the attention of the occupant of such residence, for the
purpose of securing an audience with the occupant thereof and engage in soliciting, as herein defined, outside of the hours provided for in this
section.
(C) False Plans Or Schemes: It shall be unlawful for any person who engages in solicitation or peddling to use any false plan, scheme or pretense or make
any false statement which indicates or implies that the purpose of such person's visit is other than to obtain contributions or orders for sales of goods or
services.
(D) Right To Cancel: It shall be unlawful for any person who engages in solicitation or peddling to misrepresent the right of a buyer to rescind or cancel a
sale under the provisions of applicable law.
(E) Misrepresentation: It shall be unlawful for any person who engages in solicitation or peddling to cheat, deceive or fraudulently misrepresent, whether
through himself or through an employee, while acting as solicitor in the village, or to barter, sell or peddle any goods, merchandise or wares other than
those specified in his application for permit.
(F) Interfering With Vehicles Or Pedestrians: No solicitor shall interfere with either vehicular or pedestrian traffic on the public right of way.
(G) Sound Or Voice Systems: It shall be unlawful for any solicitor to use sound or voice amplification systems or other mechanical sound devices in any
solicitation or peddling.
(H) Safety Badge: Each applicant eighteen (18) years of age and older who has been issued a permit by the village shall wear a safety badge on outer
garments so as to be visible at all times. Such badge shall be issued by the village and shall contain, in a form authorized by the business office
manager, the application number of the permit, as set forth in section 3-4-4 of this chapter, together with the following statement:
PERMIT NUMBER
I HAVE BEEN APPROVED BY THE VILLAGE OF LISLE TO SOLICIT WITHIN THE VILLAGE. MY PERMIT WAS ISSUED ON [date] AND EXPIRES
ON [date].
Permitted solicitors under the age of eighteen (18) shall have in their possession a copy of an approval letter issued by the village business office
manager containing the beginning and expiration date of the permit, together with the application number of the permit, as set forth in section 3-4-4 of
this chapter.
(I) Felons: It shall be unlawful for any person or organization to utilize as a solicitor any person who has been convicted of a "serious felony" (as defined in
section 3-4-1 of this chapter) under the laws of the state or any other state or under the federal law of the United States.
(J) Solicitation Near School Bus Stops: It is hereby declared to be unlawful and shall constitute a nuisance for any person to offer for sale or for free any
property, real or personal, tangible or intangible, whether of value or not, including, but not limited to, goods, books, pamphlets, tickets, publications or
subscriptions to publications or brochures within two hundred fifty feet (250') (except within the confines of an enclosed structure or building) of any
location identified for the picking up or letting off of schoolchildren by a clearly recognized school bus from thirty (30) minutes before to thirty (30)
minutes after any time at which schoolchildren are scheduled to be picked up or dropped off. This prohibition shall extend to sites located at or near
school property where schoolchildren are directed to be dropped off or picked up at the school building and to school bus stops throughout the village
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 49/460
which have been identified by the village or respective school district as a location where schoolchildren are scheduled to be picked up or dropped off
before, after or during school hours. (Ord. 2011-4408, 10-17-2011)
3-4-8: SOLICITATION ON HIGHWAYS:
(A) Solicitation Of Charitable Contributions On Highways: Solicitation of charitable contributions on highways within the village shall be permitted; provided,
however, that all such activity shall be conducted in strict conformity with and shall be limited to that activity permitted under the provisions of the Illinois
vehicle code paragraph 5/11-1006(c) and this code.
Solicitation on highways within the village shall be allowed only at intersections where all traffic is required to come to a full stop by a traffic light. The
soliciting agency shall be:
1. Registered with the attorney general as a charitable organization as provided by "an act to regulate solicitation and collection of funds for charitable
purposes, providing for violations thereof and making an appropriation therefor", approved July 26, 1963, as amended;
2. Engaged in a statewide fundraising activity; and
3. Liable for any injuries to persons or property during the solicitation, which is causally related to an act of ordinary negligence of the soliciting agent.
(B) Age Requirement: Any person engaged in the act of solicitation shall be eighteen (18) years of age or over and shall be wearing a high visibility vest.
(C) Time Limit: There shall be no solicitation on highways within the village at the same location or for the same group or organization on whose behalf the
solicitation is being conducted, for more than three (3) consecutive days per fundraising activity.
(D) Insurance Coverage: No solicitor shall be permitted to solicit on highways unless and until the solicitor provides proof to the village of general liability
insurance coverage naming the village as well as its respective agents, officers and employees, as additional insureds in an amount as established by
the annual fee ordinance for each occurrence. (Ord. 2011-4408, 10-17-2011)
3-4-9: SOLICITATION AT THE LISLE/BURLINGTON NORTHERN RAILROAD COMMUTER PARKING FACILITY, DEPOT AND
PLATFORM:
(A) Solicitation at the Lisle/Burlington Northern Railroad commuter parking facility, depot and platform shall be allowed only in the following areas as set
forth on exhibit A attached to ordinance 94-2460 and incorporated herein by reference: the tunnel, the breezeway connecting the depot and tunnel
shelter, and the sidewalk on the southwest side of the depot building.
(B) No solicitor shall be permitted to solicit at the commuter parking facility unless and until the solicitor provides proof to the Village of general liability
insurance coverage naming the Village and the Burlington Northern Railroad, as well as their respective agents, officers and employees, as additional
insureds in an amount as established by the annual fee ordinance for each occurrence.
(C) All persons soliciting at the Lisle/Burlington Northern Railroad Commuter Parking Facility shall be sixteen (16) years of age or older.
(D) Solicitation at the Lisle/Burlington Northern Railroad commuter facility shall be limited to five (5) days per calendar month. Only one organization may
be permitted to solicit at the train station at one time. (Ord. 2011-4408, 10-17-2011)
3-4-10: REVOCATION:
(A) Revocation Of Permit: The Village Manager or his/her designee shall revoke a solicitation permit for a violation of any of the regulations listed in
sections 3-4-1 through 3-4-9 of this chapter, inclusive. Immediately upon such revocation, written notice thereof shall be given by the Village Manager
or his/her designee to the holder of the permit by certified or registered mail, return receipt requested. Upon receipt of said notice of revocation, all
solicitation shall cease.
(B) Appeals: In the event the Village Manager or his/her designee revokes any permit for solicitation, the person aggrieved by said decision shall have the
right to appeal and have a hearing before the President and Board of Trustees. Such appeal shall be taken by filing with the Village Manager or his/her
designee within ten (10) days after receipt of the notice of revocation, a written statement under oath setting forth specifically the grounds for appeal.
The President and Board of Trustees shall thereupon set forth the time and a place for the hearing on such appeal, and notice of such hearing shall be
given to the appellant in the same manner as provided in subsection (A) of this section. The decision of the President and Board of Trustees on such
appeal shall be by a vote of a majority of all the members then holding office and shall be final. (Ord. 2018-4761, 4-16-2018)
3-4-11: PENALTIES:
Notwithstanding any other remedies available to the Village pursuant to this chapter, any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be
fined as established by the annual fee ordinance for each offense. A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day on which the violation
occurs or continues to occur. (Ord. 2011-4408, 10-17-2011)
Chapter 5
PEDDLING FOODSTUFFS
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 50/460
3-5-1: LICENSE REQUIRED AND EXEMPTIONS:
(A) It shall be unlawful to sell or offer for sale, or to peddle any ice cream, candy, confection, milk, dairy product, beverage or other foodstuff for immediate
human consumption from any vehicle, including motor vehicles and nonmotorized vehicles, on any public street, alley or parkway in the village without
having a license therefor.
(B) It shall be unlawful to sell or offer for sale, or to peddle any beef, poultry, fish or pork not intended for immediate human consumption from any vehicle,
including motor vehicles and nonmotorized vehicles, on any public street, alley or parkway in the village. The proscriptions contained in this section
shall not apply to items ordered twenty four (24) hours prior to transfer of said item to purchaser. (Ord. 98-2958, 2-2-1998)
3-5-2: APPLICATION; FEE:
Application for such licenses shall conform to the regulations of the general provisions relating to all such applications, as set out under chapter 1 of this
title, and the annual fee shall be as established by the annual fee ordinance, which fee shall not be prorated. (Ord. 2002-3425, 11-4-2002)
3-5-3: TRAFFIC HAZARD PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful to permit any such vehicle to stand or remain in any place where parking vehicles is prohibited, or to sell or offer any commodity for
sale on any through street or at any place or time when an unusual traffic hazard or danger to prospective customers exists; or within two hundred feet
(200') of the scene of any accident or destructive fire or any place where the members of the fire or police departments are responding to an emergency
call. (Ord. 136, 8-7-1962)
3-5-4: SANITARY REGULATIONS:
(A) Vehicles: All such vehicles shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition and shall be thoroughly cleaned each day they are so used. It shall be
unlawful to permit stale foods, decaying matter or any other waste material or product to accumulate in or on any such vehicle while it is so used.
If unwrapped foodstuffs are transported in any such vehicle, such foods shall be carried in a portion or compartment of the vehicle which is screened
and protected against dust and insects. (Ord. 136, 8-7-1962)
(B) Temperature Control: Readily perishable foods or beverages, while in transit, shall be maintained at a temperature of not more than forty one degrees
Fahrenheit (41F). The temperature for hot liquid foods or beverages shall be maintained at not less than one hundred forty degrees Fahrenheit
(140F); and for frozen foods at not more than zero degrees Fahrenheit (0F). The compartments in vehicles used for carrying such food shall be so
constructed, equipped and maintained as to preserve the temperature as above indicated for the respective types of food. (Ord. 98-2968, 3-16-1998)
3-5-5: INSPECTIONS:
It shall be the duty of the village president, or his designee, to make or cause to be made such inspections as may be necessary to ensure compliance
with the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 2002-3425, 11-4-2002)
3-5-6: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be fined as established by the annual fee ordinance for each offense; and a separate offense shall
be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. (Ord. 96-2776, 5-20-1996)
Chapter 6
SCAVENGERS
3-6-1: DEFINITIONS:
COMMERCIAL PREMISES: Real property and/or buildings used in whole or in part for business purposes.
JUNK REMOVAL SERVICE: An individual, firm, organization, corporation or other entity that does not provide curbside service, but is engaged in the
business of removing and hauling away junk from commercial premises or residential premises and is not otherwise a "scavenger" as defined in this
chapter.
LOCAL OFFICE: A location at which a scavenger conducts normal administrative and/or business operations, within thirty (30) miles of the corporate limits
of the village of Lisle, which has a local Downers Grove or Naperville telephone exchange.
MAIN OFFICE: A location at which a scavenger conducts the bulk of its administrative and/or business operations.
RECYCLABLES: Those articles defined as "recyclables" in section 8-2-1 of this code.
RESIDENTIAL PREMISES: Real property and/or buildings used exclusively for residential occupancy, including, but not limited to, single-family homes
and multi-family dwellings. Single-family dwelling units which contain a section devoted to the business purposes of the residential occupant or occupants
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 51/460
shall be considered residential premises for the purposes of this chapter.
SCAVENGER: An individual, firm, organization, corporation or other entity engaged in the business of curbside waste collection.
SCAVENGER SERVICE: The provision of waste collection within village limits.
VILLAGE: The village of Lisle.
WASTE: Garbage, rubbish and refuse of any kind, nature or description, including, but not limited to, recyclables. (Ord. 2007-4141, 9-17-2007)
3-6-2: LICENSES:
(A) License Required: No person shall engage in the business of junk removal service or scavenger service within the village limits without first securing a
license to conduct such business.
(B) Application For License:
1. Application for a junk removal service or scavenger service license shall be made, in writing, under oath or affirmation, to the business office
manager annually, and shall state whether the application is for a new license or for a renewal. An application for renewal of any such license must
be received by the business office manager on or before the expiration date of the applicant's previous license.
2. All applications shall state the name and business address of the applicant's main and local offices, and shall include a list of the make, model and
license plate number of all junk removal or scavenger vehicles operated by the applicant. The applicant shall disclose any previous revocations of
any similar licenses for junk removal or scavenger service by any other governmental entity.
3. The names and addresses of the applicant, or if the applicant is a corporation, of the president, vice president, secretary and all persons owning,
beneficially or otherwise, seven and one-half percent (7.5%) or more of the common stock of said corporation, shall be listed and disclosed on said
application.
4. The applicant shall provide all other information as may be requested by the application form, as amended, from time to time, by the village
manager.
5. All applicants for a residential scavenger service license shall attach to the application, proof of all insurance coverage required by the contract
provided for in section 3-6-3 of this chapter.
6. All applicants for a junk removal service license shall attach to the application proof of all insurance coverage required under section 3-6-3 of this
chapter.
7. Any application shall be accompanied by the required fee as provided by section 3-6-4 of this chapter.
8. If the business office manager finds and determines that all the requirements for the license have been met, the license shall be issued.
(C) Term: The term of a junk removal or scavenger service license shall be from January 1 through December 31, inclusive. (Ord. 2007-4141, 9-17-2007)
3-6-3: NUMBER OF LICENSES:
(A) Residential Premises: Only one license shall be issued for scavenger service to residential premises and unlimited number of licenses may be issued
for junk removal services.
(B) Commercial Premises: An unlimited number of licenses may be issued for scavenger service or junk removal services to commercial premises.
(C) Terms; Agreement:
1. The terms of any residential premises license for scavenger service shall be subject to an agreement for scavenger service which shall be entered
into by the applicant and the village. The agreement for scavenger services may be let by the village with or without bid under such terms and
conditions as the village may deem and find advisable and beneficial to the village and to the best interest of its citizens. The terms of this chapter
shall be construed in accordance with the terms of said agreement for scavenger service.
2. The terms of any residential junk removal service license shall be subject to an agreement for junk removal services which shall be entered into by
the applicant and village. The agreement for junk removal services may be let by the village with or without bid under such terms and conditions as
the village may deem and find advisable and beneficial to the village and to the best interest of its citizens. The terms of this chapter shall be
construed in accordance with the terms of said agreement for junk removal service.
(D) Junk Removal Services Insurance And Bond Requirements: Any applicant for a junk removal service license shall procure, at the applicant's sole cost
and expense, and submit with its application a certificate of comprehensive liability insurance. The comprehensive liability insurance required under this
subsection shall be effective for the full term of the license and shall be in amounts with liability coverage under the comprehensive liability insurance of
not less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) each occurrence, and two million dollars ($2,000,000.00) in aggregate liability insurance coverage.
Each such policy shall name the village as an additional insured and shall contain an affirmative statement by the issuer that it will give written notice to
the village at least thirty (30) days prior to any cancellation of its policy. Any cancellation shall be grounds for automatic revocation of the license. (Ord.
2007-4141, 9-17-2007)
3-6-4: LICENSE AND FRANCHISE FEES:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 52/460
The annual fee for residential premises and commercial premises licenses issued under this chapter shall be as established by the annual fee ordinance.
No license for junk removal service or scavenger service shall be valid unless payment of the entire fee due for the license term has been received by the
village. Notwithstanding any other license fee provisions contained within this code, no required fee under this chapter shall be prorated or discounted
according to the date on which such fee is paid or application for license is made. (Ord. 2007-4141, 9-17-2007)
3-6-5: REVOCATION, SUSPENSION OR NONRENEWAL OF LICENSE; REFUND OF FEES:
(A) Any license issued under this chapter may be suspended or revoked by the village board of trustees or renewal of such license may be denied, for any
violation by the licensee of any provisions of local, state or federal law, or for failure to perform services in accordance with any agreement with the
village or for a false or misleading statement on the license application.
(B) At least five (5) days prior to the suspension or revocation of any such license or the expiration of any license that is to be denied renewal, the village
shall give written notice to the licensee at the licensee's business address, stating the reason for the suspension, revocation or nonrenewal. The
licensee may, within ten (10) days of receipt of the notice, appeal to the village board of trustees by filing a notice of appeal with the business office
manager stating the basis for such appeal. Upon receipt of the notice of appeal, the village board shall fix a time and place for a hearing, to be held not
more than twenty (20) days following the receipt of the notice of appeal. The filing of a notice of appeal by the licensee shall not operate as a stay of a
revocation, suspension or nonrenewal during the pendency of the appeal.
(C) In the event any license is revoked or suspended pursuant to this section, no part of any license fees paid shall be refundable. In the event an
application for an initial license is denied, an existing license is not renewed or a contract for residential junk removal service or scavenger service
expires and is not renewed after the license fee for that year has been paid, fifty percent (50%) of the license fee paid for that year shall be refundable.
(Ord. 2007-4141, 9-17-2007)
3-6-6: PROHIBITED WASTE COLLECTION; COLLECTION OF RECYCLABLES:
(A) It shall be unlawful for any person not holding a residential premises scavenger service license hereunder to remove any recyclables placed in or
adjacent to any villagerecycling bins or placed at the curb of any village street for routine pick up by the scavenger service holding a residential
premises license.
(B) Where a scavenger licensed to provide scavenger services to commercial premises is hired to collect waste from a site which contains units for both
commercial and residential use, and where the waste for the entire site is to be collected from a single container, that scavenger shall provide to the
residential occupants the collection of recyclables comparable to the recyclables collection services provided to residential premises by the scavenger
licensed to provide scavenger services to exclusively residential premises. If the commercial premises scavenger is unable to provide such service, the
commercial scavenger may subcontract the service to an appropriate entity for the collection of recyclables if approved by the village.
(C) All scavengers licensed to provide scavenger services, except those which provide recycling services only, shall provide its customers with recycling
services appropriate to that customer. The recycling services may be subcontracted to a village licensed provider of such services, but in no event shall
a holder of a junk removal service license be allowed to provide any such recycling services to any customer in the village. (Ord. 2007-4141, 9-17-
2007)
3-6-7: MONTHLY REPORTS:
Each residential premises scavenger shall prepare and submit a monthly report which shall provide such information as the village requests pursuant to
the aforementioned agreement for scavenger services.
Each commercial premises scavenger shall prepare a quarterly report on a form provided by the village and submit the report to the village no later than
one month after the end of the applicable quarter. The report shall state the following:
(A) The amount of waste collected, measured in tons;
(B) The amount of waste landfilled, measured in tons;
(C) The location of any landfilling;
(D) The business address of recycling processors who received village recyclables; and
(E) The amount of recyclables collected, measured in pounds or tons. (Ord. 2007-4141, 9-17-2007)
3-6-8: PENALTY:
Any person found to have violated any provision of thischapter shall be fined as established by the annual fee ordinance and a separate offense shall be
deemed committed for each day of violation. This penalty shall not be exclusive of any other remedy afforded the village by this code. (Ord. 2007-4141, 9-
17-2007)

Chapter 7
MASSAGE ESTABLISHMENT LICENSING
(Rep. by Ord. 2018-4789, 10-1-2018)
Chapter 8
TAXICABS; PUBLIC LIMOUSINES
3-8-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section:
CAB COMPANY: A person or company engaged in business as proprietor of one or more taxicabs.
CAB STAND: An area designated by an official sign for the use of taxicabs duly registered within the Village for the loading and unloading of passengers
and the waiting for of passengers and potential passengers.
DISABLED/HANDICAPPED PERSON: A Village resident who is unable to engage in any substantial gainful activity by reason of a medically determinable
physical or mental impairment which can be expected to result in death or which has lasted or can be expected to last for a continuous period not less than
twelve (12) months. Proof that a claimant is eligible to receive disability benefits under the Federal Social Security Act (42 USCA section 302 et seq.), as
from time to time amended, shall constitute proof of disability for the purpose of this section. A disabled person not covered under the Federal Social
Security Act shall provide proof by a physician acceptable to the Village establishing his or her status as a disabled person determined by using the same
standards as used by the Social Security Administration. The cost of any such examination shall be borne by the claimant.
DRIVER: A person who drives or is licensed to drive a taxicab or public limousine on the streets and ways within the Village.
LIVERY COMPANY: A person or company, engaged in the business that offers public limousines with drivers for hire, and that are not otherwise taxicabs.
MILEAGE: The distance in rate of fare, as mechanically registered, from the point of passenger pick up to the point of passenger delivery.
OWNER: Every individual, trustee, partnership, association, or corporation owning, operating or having the use or control of one or more taxicabs or public
limousines in the Village.
PERSON: Includes a natural person, partnership, firm or corporation.
PUBLIC LIMOUSINE: A public conveyance for hire only at lawful rates, which rates are charged on an hourly, or portion thereof, or on a prearranged
contractual basis.
SENIOR CITIZEN: A village resident who is sixty five (65) years of age or older. Proof thereof shall consist of a state of Illinois photograph identification
card, containing proof of age.
TAXICAB: A public conveyance for hire only at lawful rates of fare, which rates are as recorded and indicated by a taximeter.
VILLAGE BOARD: The village of Lisle board of trustees. (Ord. 2005-3935, 6-20-2005)
3-8-2: LICENSES REQUIRED:
Each cab company and livery company shall, as a condition precedent to operation of a taxicab or public limousine in the village, obtain the appropriate
village license as hereinafter provided. (Ord. 2005-3935, 6-20-2005)
3-8-3: TAXICAB COMMISSIONER:
A taxicab commissioner (hereinafter referred to as the commissioner) shall perform all the duties and functions of commissioner as provided in this
chapter, including, but not limited to, the following:
(A) Convening and presiding at certain hearings and meetings required by this chapter; and
(B) Revoking and suspending licenses pursuant to the provisions of this chapter.
The village manager shall assume the duties of commissioner. The commissioner may at any time appoint a deputy commissioner who shall have the
power to perform any of the tasks assigned to the commissioner hereunder. (Ord. 2005-3935, 6-20-2005)
3-8-4: USE OF TAXICABS, PUBLIC LIMOUSINES:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 54/460
(A) It shall be unlawful to refuse any person transportation in a taxicab to any place of destination within the village in a taxicab that is unoccupied by a
passenger for hire unless it is on its way to pick up a passenger or otherwise out of service or unless the person to be served appears intoxicated or
uses profane or abusive language in attempting to contract for service. When the taxicab is out of service or carrying a passenger, there shall be
displayed on the windshield of that taxicab, a sign reading "not for hire" in letters at least two inches (2") in height.
(B) Group riding is permitted in taxicabs; provided, that the driver accepts no more than five (5) passengers for any trip, and provided that the fare charged
to any passenger will be not greater than if he rode alone.
(C) It shall be unlawful for any driver to stop, stand or park a taxicab within the corporate limits of the village, under circumstances manifesting an intent to
solicit a passenger or fare, unless said taxicab is duly registered with the village as provided in subsection 3-8-14(C) of this chapter. For the purpose of
this section, circumstances manifesting an intent to solicit a passenger or fare shall include, but not be limited to, the following:
1. The presence or absence of a sign or other indicator, such as a flag or light, upon or within the taxicab, when the presence or absence of such sign
or indicator signifies that the taxicab is currently available for hire;
2. A driver placing or allowing another to place luggage or other parcels or packages into the taxicab;
3. Any other circumstances which tend to show that the driver intended to pick up a passenger within the village.
(D) In addition, there shall be designated by the village board certain cab stands within the village, which cab stands shall be marked by official signs. Said
cab stands shall be for the purpose of loading and unloading of passengers and the waiting for of passengers or potential passengers. No taxicab
entering onto premises having a designated cab stand shall park, stop or stand at any place upon said premises other than the designated cab stand.
Further, no taxicab shall park, stop or stand in any designated cab stand unless said taxicab either is registered with the village as provided in
subsection 3-8-14(C) of this chapter or is present at a cab stand for the purpose of dropping off passengers who were initially picked up outside of the
village.
(E) A public limousine may discharge a person in the village provided that the pick up was made outside the village and may pick up a person within the
village, but under no circumstances may a public limousine pick up a person within the village for the purpose of discharging a person within the village.
(F) Under no circumstances may a public limousine stand at a cab stand.
(G) Under no circumstances may a public limousine park or otherwise travel any street or road within the village with the intent and purpose to solicit fares.
All fares for public limousines must be prearranged with the customer based upon the origin, destination and time duration of the trip. In no event may
an hourly fee for a public limousine exceed such fares on file with the business office manager, as required under subsection 3-8-7(B) of this chapter.
(Ord. 2005-3935, 6-20-2005)
3-8-5: IDENTIFICATION OF TAXICAB OR PUBLIC LIMOUSINE BY A LICENSED COMPANY OR LIVERY COMPANY
REQUIRED:
(A) Every taxicab operated by a cab company licensed by the village hereunder shall have displayed thereon, in the appropriate place, the following
identification materials:
1. On the center of the main panel of the front or rear doors of each such taxicab, there shall appear the cab number and the cab company's name and
telephone number; provided further, however, that in lieu of placing the cab company's name on the door, the name may be placed on a lighted sign
which must protrude from the top of the cab.
2. On the inside panel separating the front and rear seats of each such taxicab, facing to the rear, there shall be affixed a copy of the telephone number
of the cab company and the rates charged for trips inside and outside of the village.
(B) Every public limousine operated by a livery company licensed by the village hereunder shall:
1. Keep a copy of a valid and binding license issued under this chapter in the glove compartment of the public limousine; and
2. Keep a copy of the most current hourly rate schedule on file with the business office manager, as required under subsection 3-8-7(B) of this chapter.
(Ord. 2005-3935, 6-20-2005)
3-8-6: TAXIMETERS:
Every taxicab operated by a cab company licensed by the village shall be equipped with a taximeter connected with and operating from the transmission of
the taxicab, subject to the following regulations:
(A) No taximeter shall be attached to a taxicab unless it has been inspected by an approved inspector and found to be accurate. The cab company shall
keep certificates of accuracy from the inspector for each taximeter and provide the same for inspection by a passenger upon request. The taximeter
case shall be sealed by the inspector if found to be accurate.
(B) Each taximeter shall be inspected annually, not more than sixty (60) days prior to July 1, and a certificate of accuracy, as provided in subsection (A) of
this section, shall be submitted by the cab company to the business office manager prior to the renewal of the license.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 55/460
(C) All taximeters shall be equipped with a flag that is plainly visible. This flag shall be kept up only when the taxicab is for hire. Taximeters shall have a
lighted dial or dials to register the tariff in accordance with lawful rates as expressed herein and the dial shall at all times be maintained by the cab
company so that it is in plain view and readable by the passenger.
(D) No driver or cab company shall operate a taxicab with a taximeter that is unsealed, inaccurate, has not been inspected as provided herein or is
otherwise not in compliance with the provisions of this chapter.
(E) It shall be unlawful for any person to tamper with a taximeter seal or sealed taximeter.
(F) Upon the request of the commissioner, the cab company shall submit any taximeter installed on a taxicab to an inspection to determine its accuracy.
(Ord. 2005-3935, 6-20-2005)
3-8-7: TAXICAB AND PUBLIC LIMOUSINE FARES:
(A) The rates of fare, fees or charges of any kind for taxicabs while being operated from a point of origin within the corporate limits of the Village shall be
according to a schedule filed with the Business Office Manager by each company licensed hereunder. A change in rates of fare, fees or charges of any
kind shall not be effective and shall not be quoted to, required by or requested of any passenger until at least thirty (30) days after an amended
schedule has been filed with the Business Office Manager.
(B) The rates of fare, fees, or charges of any kind for a public limousine shall be on an hourly or prearranged contractual basis. Under no circumstances
may a public limousine use a meter of any kind to charge fares. Each livery company shall file an hourly rate schedule with the Business Office
Manager. (Ord. 2005-3935, 6-20-2005)
3-8-8: TRANSPORTATION SUBSIDY:
(Rep. by Ord. 2018-4762, 4-16-2018, eff. 5-1-2018)
3-8-9: CONDUCT OF TAXICAB AND PUBLIC LIMOUSINE DRIVERS GENERALLY:
It shall be unlawful for any driver to conduct himself in a disrespectful or contemptuous manner towards any person, or to use abusive or profane language
while so occupied or in charge of such vehicle. (Ord. 2005-3935, 6-20-2005)
3-8-10: CONDITIONS OF TAXICABS AND PUBLIC LIMOUSINES GENERALLY:
Every taxicab and public limousine operated in the Village by a cab company or livery company licensed by the Village shall be maintained in a safe
condition at all times. Each taxicab shall have two (2) doors on each side of the taxicab. If a taxicab or public limousine shall become unsafe for operation
or if its body or seating facilities shall be so damaged as to render the taxicab or public limousine unfit for public use, the Commissioner may suspend the
license issued to the cab company or livery company operating that vehicle until the vehicle is made safe for use by the public. (Ord. 2005-3935, 6-20-
2005)
3-8-11: BOOKS AND RECORDS OF ACCOUNT:
Every licensed cab company or livery company shall keep accurate books and records of account and log books of services rendered. Each licensed cab
company shall keep such books and records in its dispatching office located in the Village. The Commissioner shall be permitted to examine those books
and records of account and logs as they may relate to a specific charge that is the subject of a public hearing under the provisions of this chapter. (Ord.
2005-3935, 6-20-2005)
3-8-12: COMPLAINTS:
(A) Any person may file a written complaint with the Commissioner regarding the conduct of a driver, cab company, or livery company.
(B) The Commissioner shall investigate all complaints against drivers. He shall notify the driver and cab company or livery company of the complaint and
shall hold a meeting on that matter, if he determines that such a meeting is necessary, at which meeting the driver and a representative of the cab
company or livery company shall be present. If the Commissioner determines that any provision of this chapter has been violated, he shall take any
further action consistent with the provisions of this chapter and shall also refer the matter to the Police Department.
(C) The Village Board shall investigate complaints against a cab company or livery company, notify the cab company or livery company of the complaint
and hold a meeting on the matter, if the Village Board in its sole discretion determines that such a meeting is necessary, at which meeting a
representative of the cab company or livery company shall be present. If the Village Board determines that any provision of this chapter has been
violated, it shall refer the matter to the Police Department and the Commissioner for any further action consistent with the provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. 2005-3935, 6-20-2005)
3-8-13: CAB COMPANY AND LIVERY COMPANY LICENSE REQUIRED:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 56/460
It shall be unlawful for any cab company or livery company to operate a taxicab or public limousine for transportation of passengers for hire from a point of
origin or destination within the village unless the cab company or livery company is licensed by the village. (Ord. 2005-3935, 6-20-2005)
3-8-14: APPLICATION FOR AND ISSUANCE OF CAB COMPANY OR LIVERY COMPANY LICENSE:
Each cab company or livery company shall apply to the business office manager for a cab company or livery company license before operating any
taxicabs or public limousines within the village. The application for a cab company or livery company license shall be approved by the village manager and
a cab company or livery company license issued pursuant to the following rules and regulations: (Ord. 2005-3935, 6-20-2005)
(A) An application shall be submitted to the business office manager along with payment of an initial first year nonrefundable application fee and an annual
license fee as established by the annual fee ordinance. Renewal applications shall be subject to the deadlines and late fees as established by the
annual fee ordinance.
There shall be no refund of any portion of the annual license fee imposed under this chapter for any portion of a year during which the licensee ceases
to operate a taxi or livery company within the village. (Ord. 2009-4257, 6-1-2009)
(B) The cab company or livery company shall be required to include in the application a true statement of certain facts including, but not limited to, the
state of incorporation if the cab company or livery company is a corporation; whether the cab company or livery company is organized and qualified to
do business under the laws of the state of Illinois if the cab company or livery company is a corporation; principal place of business; the names of the
individuals who own the cab company or livery company; whether the cab company or livery company, if not a corporation, is a limited liability
company, partnership, or sole proprietorship, or other type of business organization; the registered agent of the corporate cab company or livery
company; principal office if different than principal place of business; and all such other information as requested by the application form as amended
from time to time.
(C) The cab company or livery company shall be required, with its application for a license, to register each taxicab or public limousine operated by such
company within the village by providing the following information:
1. The year, make, color and serial number;
2. The actual owner of the taxicab or public limousine;
3. Written certification that required inspections of each taxicab and each taximeter or public limousine have been completed within sixty (60) days of
such application and that these inspections have demonstrated each taxicab or public limousine to be safe, and that each taximeter is in proper
working order and accurate;
4. The name, address, and home phone number of each driver;
5. A valid and current state of Illinois operator's or chauffeur's license number and license expiration date for each driver; and
6. A schedule of rates of fares, fees or charges.
(D) The chief of police shall investigate the owners of the applicant cab company or livery company to determine the good character and business
reputation of those owners and shall report his findings to the business office manager before issuance of a license. If this investigation uncovers
information showing that any owners have been convicted of a felony, have not paid a judgment against them, or have misrepresented facts in the
application for a license, the village manager shall not approve such application and no license shall be issued.
(E) The cab company or livery company shall be required to file with the business office manager, along with its application for a license, a certificate of
insurance showing that the cab company or livery company, its drivers and employees, are adequately insured against public liability, property damage,
and workers' compensation claims on account of its operation of taxicabs or public limousines in the village.
(F) Failure to fully comply with the application and disclosure requirements of this section shall constitute grounds for the business office manager to deny
issuance of a license. (Ord. 2005-3935, 6-20-2005)
3-8-14-1: TRANSFER OF LICENSE:
If a licensee holding a cab company or livery company license under this chapter changes its principal place of business of the company, the cab company
or livery company shall apply to the business office manager for a transfer of the license.
Upon approval of the village manager, the business office manager shall make the necessary alterations and endorse the transfer of the license. No fee
shall be required for the transfer of a license for a change in the principal place of business of the cab company or livery company.
If ownership of a cab company or livery company, licensed under this chapter is conveyed to a new owner, the new owner shall apply for a new license in
his name in accordance with the procedures and standards set forth in this section 3-8-14. There shall be no transfer of a license issued under this chapter
from the owner of one cab company or livery company to the owner of another cab company or livery company. (Ord. 2005-3935, 6-20-2005)
3-8-15: TERMS OF LICENSE; PRORATION:
The term of all licenses issued under the provisions of this chapter shall be one year from the date of issuance and shall expire at the end of the last day of
the applicable term. The full license fee shall be charged no matter when the license is applied for or issued. (Ord. 2005-3935, 6-20-2005)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 57/460
3-8-16: CHANGES IN TAXICABS OR PUBLIC LIMOUSINES DURING LICENSE YEAR:
During the term of any license, if a cab company substitutes another taxicab for any taxicab registered with the village or the livery company substitutes
another public limousine for any public limousine registered with the village pursuant to subsection 3-8-14(C) of this chapter, or adds any additional taxicab
or public limousine to the list of registered taxicabs or public limousines, the company shall register such substitute or additional taxicab or public limousine
with the village by providing the information required by subsection 3-8-14(C) of this chapter concerning such substitute or additional taxicab or public
limousine. (Ord. 2005-3935, 6-20-2005)
3-8-17: SUSPENSION AND REVOCATION OF LICENSES:
Any license issued under the provisions of this chapter may be revoked or suspended for a violation of the provisions of this chapter by the commissioner.
The commissioner may revoke or suspend a license only after a public hearing has been held at which hearing the driver, cab company or livery company
may appear to present evidence in his or its behalf. The business office manager shall give ten (10) days' notice of the public hearing by certified mail to
the driver or the cab company or livery company, as the case may be, whose license may be revoked or suspended. This notice shall state the date, time,
and place of the public hearing and the nature of the charges that may result in revocation or suspension of the license. Upon the conclusion of this public
hearing, the commissioner may revoke or suspend the license, in his discretion or as required by this chapter, if he finds that the preponderance of the
evidence presented at the hearing is such as to substantiate a violation of the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 2005-3935, 6-20-2005)
3-8-18: MANDATORY REVOCATION OF A LICENSE:
A license issued under this chapter shall be revoked by the commissioner as follows:
(A) If the cab company or livery company or any driver is convicted of a felony or violent crime while holding the license;
(B) If the cab company or livery company or any driver fails to pay a judgment;
(C) If an owner of the cab company or livery company or any driver is found in possession of narcotics;
(D) If a driver directs anyone to a house of prostitution or to illegal gambling houses;
(E) If a driver is convicted of drunken driving or reckless driving by a court of competent jurisdiction; or
(F) If any other section of this chapter requires revocation for a violation thereof. (Ord. 2005-3935, 6-20-2005)
3-8-19: TAXICAB HOURS OF SERVICE:
Not less than forty percent (40%) of the total number of taxicabs registered for operation, pursuant to subsection 3-8-14(C) of this chapter, by a cab
company licensed under this chapter shall be operated regularly between the hours of seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. and twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight on
Mondays through Fridays, and may be operated at such other times, and on weekends, as shall be deemed necessary by the cab company. (Ord. 2005-
3935, 6-20-2005)
3-8-20: CHANGES IN THE NUMBER OF TAXICABS OR HOURS OF SERVICE:
(A) The village board alone shall determine whether the public convenience and necessity require a change in the number of taxicabs which may be
registered for operation in the village or hours of taxicab services required by section 3-8-19 of this chapter. In determining whether the public
convenience and necessity require change in the number of taxicabs which may be registered for operation in the village or hours of taxicab service,
due consideration shall be given by the village board to the following:
1. The public demand for taxicab service.
2. The effect of increased competition on revenues of taxicab operators, on cost of rendering taxicab service including provisions of proper reserves
and a fair return on investment in property devoted to such service, and on the wages or compensation, hours and conditions of service of taxicab
drivers.
(B) A cab company may request that the village board amend the number of taxicabs which may be registered for operation in the village or required hours
of service as required in section 3-8-19 of this chapter in the same manner as if it were requesting a fare revision under section 3-8-7 of this chapter.
(Ord. 2005-3935, 6-20-2005)
3-8-21: PENALTY FOR VIOLATION OF THE PROVISIONS OF THIS CHAPTER:
The commissioner may revoke or suspend a license issued hereunder upon violation of any provision of this chapter in accordance with applicable
requirements for hearing and notice. Notwithstanding any revocation or suspension of a license by the commissioner hereunder, the cab company, livery
company, or driver may be convicted of a violation of any section of this chapter by a court of competent jurisdiction and shall be subject to the fines and
other penalties established in the annual fee ordinance. (Ord. 2005-3935, 6-20-2005)

Chapter 9
AUTOMATIC DRY CLEANING MACHINES
3-9-1: COMPLIANCE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to install, operate or maintain any "automatic dry cleaning machine", as hereinafter defined, except in compliance with the provisions of
this chapter, or without complying with all of the provisions pertaining to the installation and operation of such machines herein contained, or in violation of
any laws, rules or regulations of the Illinois department of health relating thereto. (Ord. 138, 10-16-1962)
3-9-2: DEFINITION:
An "automatic dry cleaning machine", as the term is used herein, shall be construed to include and mean any device or apparatus for the cleaning of
clothes or fabrics, and designed to be used or operated by the owner or an employee of the owner, which machine or device makes use of or contains
perchloroethylene or any other chemical solvent or substance which may cause harm to human beings by reason of inhalation or contact. (Ord. 138, 10-
16-1962)
3-9-3: LICENSE AND PERMIT:
It shall be unlawful to install any automatic dry cleaning machine without first having secured a permit therefor. Applications for such permit shall contain
full information as to the mechanical equipment of such machine and provisions for ventilation for both the machine and the room in which the machine will
be located. Applicants shall supply all such other information as may be requested by the permit application form as amended from time to time. It shall be
unlawful to engage in the business of maintaining any such machine for use by the public upon payment of a fee without having first secured a license
therefor. The annual fee for such license shall be as established by the annual fee ordinance plus an amount as established by the annual fee ordinance
for each unit in addition to five (5) maintained in any one establishment. (Ord. 98-2956, 2-2-1998)
3-9-4: INSTALLATION REGULATIONS:
Each machine shall be completely enclosed by a cabinet and shall be vented with intake at the top and the outlet at or near the bottom of such machine.
Groups of machines may be entirely enclosed or supported on all sides by an enclosure topped with a hood vented as provided for each individual
machine.
The exhaust system must maintain a minimum flow of one hundred (100) cubic feet per minute face velocity through the loading door whenever the door is
open.
The discharge stack for the machines and for the room in which the machines are located shall extend at least two feet (2') above the level of any window
which can be opened, located within fifty feet (50') of the outlet of the stack, and shall be at least fifty feet (50') away from any fresh air intake leading to
any premises.
The machines must be so constructed so as to prevent the loading door from being opened during the normal cycle of operation. Each machine shall be
equipped with a transparent door or port to allow visual examination of the status of the cleaning cycle.
Any connection of such machine with the water supply system must be equipped with an air gap or vacuum breaker in the line upstream from the
condenser; with no control valves downstream from such gap or breaker. Wastewater shall be discharged through an air gap.
Each machine must be so designed and constructed as to prevent the leakage of liquids, gas or vapors.
The solvent shall be stored in closed containers and should be transferred from the containers in a line free of leaks. All storage facilities for solvent,
external from the equipment, must meet the requirements of the village fire inspectors.
Filter residue and other residues containing solvent shall be disposed of so as not to create a health hazard or nuisance.
Respiratory protective equipment shall be provided for maintenance personnel and must be kept in good repair and available for immediate use. Chemical
cartridge respirators are approved for light solvent concentrations and the wearer should replace the cartridges immediately upon noting odor.
A utility fire extinguisher of either the carbon dioxide or dry chemical type must be provided for use against electrical or oil fires.
Only the front or customer side of the dry cleaning machine should be exposed in the customer area. The working or maintenance portion of the
equipment should be separated from the front of the machine by a solid partition. As a means of minimizing any solvent buildup in the customer area and
also tocontrol any minor solvent leakage, it is required that there be a minimum flow rate from the customer area through the partition as follows:
Number Of Machines
Minimum Flow Rate
Per Machine (cfm)
1 - 3 500
4 - 8 400
9 - 16 375
17 or more 360
Example: An 8 machine installation requires a minimum continuous exhaust flow rate of 3,200 cfm.
The exhaust ventilation as described above shall be provided on a continuous basis while the store is open for business. The fan wiring shall be such that
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 59/460
the dry cleaning equipment cannot be operated unless the fan system is in operation.
Where grille openings are to be installed in the partition to facilitate air movement, they should be sized on the basis of about five hundred (500) cfm per
square foot of net grille area and should be placed as close to the machines as possible. An example would be the use of a thirty inch by six inch (30" x 6")
grille located directly over a machine.
Access doors to the maintenance area shall be kept locked.
It is also required that a general ventilation fan be installed in the back room or maintenance area to be used in case of serious solvent leakage. This may
be installed in the rear wall and when combined with the system required in the minimum flow rate table above, should enable the exhausting of a
minimum of one thousand (1,000) cfm per machine.
A satisfactory means of preventing liquid leaks from escaping the enclosure must be provided. This should include some method of "diking" the floor of the
enclosure or machine base to hold a liquid volume equal to the maximum quantity of solvent which might possibly escape from the system. Some means
must be provided for draining solvent in the event of a leak and containment. This can be done by gravity flow with the solvent transferred to a standby
holding tank. This tank should be vented to the outside.
An interlock system must be provided on the machine to prevent the loading door from being opened during the normal cycle. This system may be either
electrical and/or mechanical and so connected that in the event of a power failure the machine remains safe.
A step by step instruction list must be posted in a conspicuous location near the machine for customer use. Competent, trained and maintenance
personnel must be available or on call as long asthe premises is open for business.
A solvent vapor sensing device within the tumbler is desirable to control the drying cycle and to prevent the removal of solvent laden garments.
The machine design must be such that essentially no solvent is retained in the cleaned items upon completion of the dry cleaning cycle. A simple
performance test which must be satisfied is the lack of any solvent odor in a closed automobile containing a newly cleaned load.
It is the responsibility of the proprietor to make certain that clothing which cannot be properly cleaned and dried will not be placed in the machines.
The machine should be checked daily and kept in good repair. All maintenance personnel should be familiar with necessary machine repairs and
instructed as to the solvent hazards.
Solvent control is to be such that under normal operation and use conditions no solvent odor can be detected in the customer area.
Only the solvent specified by the equipment manufacturer shall be used.
A supply of tempered (heated to 60 or 65 degrees Fahrenheit) make-up air equal to or greater than the total volume of air exhausted from the plant should
be provided in order to eliminate any negative pressure conditions which might otherwise develop.
It is important that solvent contaminated air, even in very low concentrations (5-20 ppm), be kept out of the air intakes of all combustion equipment so as to
minimize the thermal decomposition of the solvent. Breakdown products such as hydrochloric acid, free chloride and phosgene corrode metal surfaces
including flues and heater components and can seriously damage cloth through acid burns or weakening of fibers.
Exhaust ventilation stacks from dry cleaning machines should be located as far as possible from combustion air or dryer intakes. (Ord. 138, 10-16-1962)
3-9-5: OPERATION REGULATIONS:
No such automatic dry cleaning machine shall be operated unless all the equipment described in the foregoing section is properly installed and in good
working condition.
No establishment for which a license is required under this chapter shall be open for business, and it shall be unlawful to admit the public or customers into
the room where such machines are located unless there is on duty in the establishment at all times a competent person in charge of the establishment,
and in charge of the operation of such machines. There shall be warningsigns posted in places of easy observation warning of the dangers in the event
leakage of liquids, gas or vapor occurs. It shall be unlawful to permit any residue containing solvent to flow into the sewer system of the village; tightly
covered metal containers may be used for temporary storage of such waste outside the building. Such containers shall bear labels indicating the contents
and dangers involved in handling, and shall be locked if in an unenclosed place.
At least one legible sign shall be maintained in a place available to customers giving the name, address and phone number of the owner of the
establishment, and of the service department or agency responsible for the proper maintenance of the machine. (Ord. 138, 10-16-1962)
3-9-6: INSPECTIONS:
It shall be the duty of the village president to cause such inspections to be made as are necessary to see to the enforcement of the provisions of this
chapter. (Ord. 138, 10-16-1962)
3-9-7: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provisions of this chapter shall be fined as established by the annual fee ordinance for each offense; and a separate offense shall
be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. (Ord. 96-2776, 5-29-1996)
Chapter 10
MUNICIPAL OCCUPATION TAXES
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 60/460
3-10-1: RETAILERS' OCCUPATION TAX:
A tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in the business of selling tangible personal property at retail in this village at the rate of one percent
(1%) of the gross receipts from such sales made in the course of such business while this section is in effect, in accordance with the provisions of 65
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/8-11-1 of the Illinois municipal code.
Every such person engaged in such business in the village shall file, on or before the last day of each calendar month, the report to the state department
of revenue required by section three of "an act in relation to a tax upon persons engaged in the business of selling tangible personal property to
purchasers for use or consumption" approved June 28, 1933, as amended. At the time such report is filed, there shall be paid to the state department of
revenue the amount of tax hereby imposed on account of the receipts from sales of tangible personal property during the preceding month.
The village clerk is hereby directed to transmit to the state department of revenue a certified copy of this section not later than five (5) days after the
effective date hereof. (Ord. 318, 9-2-1969)
3-10-2: SERVICE OCCUPATION TAX:
A tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in the village in the business of making sales of service at the rate of one percent (1%) of the cost price
of all tangible personal property transferred by said servicemen either in the form of tangible personal property or in the form of real estate as an incident
to a sale of service, in accordance with the provisions of 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/8-11-5 of the Illinois municipal code.
Every supplier or serviceman required to account for municipal service occupation tax for the benefit of this village shall file, on or before the last day of
each calendar month, thereport to the state department of revenue required by section nine of the "service occupation tax act", approved July 10, 1961, as
amended. At the time such report is filed, there shall be paid to the state department of revenue the amount of tax hereby imposed.
The village clerk is hereby directed to transmit to the state department of revenue a certified copy of this section not later than five (5) days after the
effective date hereof. (Ord. 319, 9-2-1969)
3-10-3: USE TAX:
A tax is hereby imposed in accordance with the provisions of 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/8-11-6 of the Illinois municipal code upon the privilege of
using, in the village, any item of tangible personal property which is purchased outside Illinois at retail from a retailer, and which is titled or registered with
an agency of Illinois government. The tax shall be at a rate of one percent (1%) of the selling price of such tangible property with selling price to have the
meaning as defined in the use tax act, approved July 14, 1955.
Such tax shall be collected by the Illinois department of revenue for all municipalities imposing the tax and shall be paid before the title or certificate of
registration for the personal property is issued.
The village clerk is hereby directed to transmit to the Illinois department of revenue a certified copy of this section not later than five (5) days after its
effective date. (Ord. 533, 10-15-1974)
3-10-4: LEASING OCCUPATION TAX:
A tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in the business of renting or leasing tangible personal property to the users thereof at the rate of onehalf
of one percent (0.5%) of the gross receipts from such renting or leasing made in the course of such business while this section is in effect, in
accordance with the provisions of 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/8-11-6 of the Illinois municipal code.
Every person engaged in such business in the village shall file with the state department of revenue the return in the manner as required by section five of
the "leasing occupation tax act" as adopted by the 74th general assembly. At the time such return is filed, there shall be paid to the state department of
revenue the amount of tax hereby imposed on account of the receipts from renting or leasing tangible personal property during the preceding month.
The village clerk is hereby directed to transmit to the state department of revenue a certified copy of this section notlater than five (5) days after the
effective date hereof. (Ord. 193, 10-7-1965)
3-10-5: AUTOMOBILE RENTING USE TAX:
A tax is hereby imposed upon the privilege of using in the village an automobile which is rented from a renter outside Illinois and which is titled or
registered with an agency of this state's government in this village at the rate of one percent (1%) of the rental price of such automobile while this section
is in effect, in accordance with the provisions of 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/8-11-8 of the Illinois municipal code.
The tax provided for in this section shall be collected from the persons whose Illinois address for titling or registration purposes is given as being in this
village.
The tax imposed by this section shall be paid to the Illinois department of revenue.
The village clerk is hereby directed to transmit to the state department of revenue a certified copy of this section not later than five (5) days after the
effective date of this section.
Certified proof of publication shall be forwarded to the Illinois department of revenue along with the certified copy of this section required by paragraph 4 of
this section. (Ord. 82-1029, 1-19-1982)
3-10-6: AUTOMOBILE RENTING OCCUPATION TAX:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 61/460
A tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in the business of renting automobiles in the village at the rate of one percent (1%) of the gross
receipts from such rentals made in the course of such business while this section is in effect, in accordance with the provisions of 65 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/8-11-7 of the Illinois municipal code.
Every person engaged in such business in the village shall file on or before the last day of each calendar month, the report to the state department of

personal property to purchasers for use or consumption".
At the time such report is filed, there shall be paid to the state department of revenue the amount of tax hereby imposed on account of the renting of
