4-1-6: ILLINOIS ACCESSIBILITY CODE ADOPTED:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 96/460
There is hereby adopted by the village, for the purpose of establishing rules and regulations for the minimum design, construction and alteration
requirements to facilitate access to and use of public facilities by environmentally limited persons, that certain code known as the Illinois accessibility code,
being particularly title 71, chapter I, subchapter b, part 400 of the Illinois administrative code, and the whole thereof, save and except such portions as may
be deleted, modified or amended from time to time, of which not less than three (3) copies have been and now are filed in the office of the village clerk,
and the same are hereby adopted and incorporated as fully as if set out at length herein, and from the date on which this section shall take effect, the
provisions thereof shall be controlling within the village. (Ord. 98-2977, 4-20-1998)
4-1-7: LANDSCAPING PLANS AND REQUIREMENTS:
(Rep. by Ord. 2005-3890, 1-17-2005)
4-1-8: MULTIPLE-FAMILY BUILDING REGULATIONS:
Each dwelling unit contained in a multiple-family residence building shall have a ceiling and floor and walls of a material with a minimum two (2) hour fire
rating. All exterior walls of multiple-family residence buildings shall be of solid masonry construction except for "townhouse or row house" buildings as
defined in this chapter. (Ord. 98-2977, 4-20-1998)
4-1-9: CONCRETE BLOCK EXTERIOR CONSTRUCTION:
No building within the village shall be constructed in such a manner so as to have an exposed concrete block exterior wall. (Ord. 98-2977, 4-20-1998)
4-1-10: ROOFTOP SCREENINGS REQUIRED:
All heating, air conditioning, ventilating or other mechanical equipment located on the roof of any structure or building within the village shall be screened
or enclosed in such manner as to mask such equipment, and no building permit shall be issued for any building unless the plans therefor provide for such
screening, as described herein. Also, no occupancy permits shall be granted for buildings unless such screening is provided, although building permits
may have been issued prior to the passage of this section. Said screening shall be of noncombustible material and of the same character and design as
the building upon which the screening is erected, subject to approval by the community development director. (Ord. 98-2977, 4-20-1998)
4-1-11: SIDEWALKS:
Sidewalks satisfying the standards and details as specified in section 7-7-5 of this code shall be installed on all parcels being developed by the owner or
developer of those parcels. However, this section shall not be construed to require sidewalks for parcels being developed for single-family dwelling unit
purposes unless the parcel is being developed within a subdivision which improvements for the subdivision include the installation of sidewalks. (Ord. 98-
2977, 4-20-1998)
4-1-12: APPLICABILITY:
Nothing in the building code and sections hereby amended shall be construed to affect any suit or proceeding now pending in any court, or rights acquired,
or liabilities incurred, or any cause(s) of action accrued or existing, under any act or section amended hereby. No right or remedy of any character shall be
lost, impaired or affected by this chapter. This chapter shall prevail to the extent of any inconsistency over all prior sections. (Ord. 98-2977, 4-20-1998)
4-1-13: PENALTY:
Any person having been found by a court of competent jurisdiction to have violated or failed to comply with any provision of this chapter or the building
code or prior sections hereby amended shall be fined for each violation or such failure a sum as established by the annual fee ordinance. Additional
violations or any such failure to comply shall be construed and deemed to be separate and distinct offenses subjecting the violator to an additional fine for
each day of each violation or noncompliance. (Ord. 98-2977, 4-20-1998)
Chapter 2
ELECTRICAL CODE
4-2-1: ADOPTION OF CODE:
There is hereby adopted by the village of Lisle, for the purpose of establishing rules and regulations concerning the installation, alteration, removal,
relocation, use, location, and maintenance of electrical equipment, including permits and penalties, that certain document, three (3) copies of which are on
file with the office of the village clerk, being marked and designated as the 2011 national electrical code as published by the National Fire Protection
Association, and each and all of the regulations, provisions, penalties, conditions and terms of said code are hereby referred to, adopted and made part
hereof as if fully set out in this chapter, with the additions, insertions, deletions and changes prescribed in section 4-2-3 of this chapter, and from the date
on which this chapter shall take effect, the provisions thereof shall be controlling within the village. (Ord. 2014-4543, 8-18-2014)
4-2-2: PERMIT REQUIRED:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 97/460
(A) A permit shall be required to install, repair, alter, or make additions to any and all electrical equipment, fixtures, wiring system, service, and
appurtenances connected to any electrical distribution system within the purview of this code as further defined under section 90.2 of the adopted code.
Electrical fixture or device replacement shall not require the issuance of a permit provided the existing work is legal conforming and the new work is
installed in conformance with requirements of this code using only permitted materials.
Exception: Revision and/or replacement of any electrical service equipment shall require the issuance of an electrical permit prior to commencement of
such work.
(B) Should any work for which a permit is required be commenced or be done before such permit is issued and obtained, the required permit may be
issued for such and subsequent work, however, the amount of the required fee as provided herein for all work shall be double that otherwise so
provided. The issuance of such permit does not act to bar any other penalty, liability or action otherwise provided for in this chapter or village code but
shall be in addition thereto.
(C) All applications for permits shall include plans and specifications of sufficient clarity to clearly depict the proposed work. The application shall include
such other information as lawfully may be required by the building official. One copy of the plans shall be returned to the applicant by the building
official after he shall have marked such copy either as approved or disapproved and attested to same by his signature on such copy. The second copy
of the plans, similarly marked, shall be retained by the building official.
(D) The electrical permit placard or copy thereof shall be displayed on site in a location viewable from the public right of way until the completion of the
project.
(E) An application for a permit for any proposed work shall be deemed to have been abandoned ninety (90) days after the date of filing, unless such
application has been pursued in good faith or a permit has been issued; except that the building official is authorized to grant one or more extensions of
time for additional periods not exceeding ninety (90) days each. The extension shall be requested in writing and justifiable cause demonstrated.
(F) For all projects wherein no work has occurred within the prescribed deadline, the electrical permit shall be terminated and an amount as established by
the annual fee ordinance in relation to the required permit fee shall be refunded. For all projects wherein work has begun and has stopped for any
reason, no part of the required permit fee will be refunded upon expiration of the building permit.
(G) The following types of inspections may be required depending upon the type and scope of work permitted. It is the responsibility of the permit holder to
make themselves aware of the required inspections for their particular project and to comply in obtaining inspection approval of each phase of work
prior to continuation of work. Possible inspection types include:
1. Electric service inspection.
2. Rough in - underground electric inspection.
3. Rough in - slab prepour inspection.
4. Rough in - aboveground wall inspection.
5. Above ceiling inspection (commercial).
6. Modular furniture inspection, rough and final.
7. Underground street lighting cable/parking lot lighting base inspection.
8. Sign inspection, rough and final.
9. Temporary wiring.
10. Final inspection.
(H) Permit fees shall be assessed and collected in accordance with the annual fee ordinance as amended from time to time by the village of Lisle. (Ord.
2008-4174, 1-7-2008, eff. 1-17-2008)
4-2-3: AMENDMENTS:
The following modifications and additions are hereby made to said national electrical code, 2011 edition, hereinabove adopted:
(A) Conductors And Devices:
1. Electrical conductors shall be of the proper capacity to serve the loads connected hereto and shall not be loaded in excess of the current ratings
shown in the national electrical code. The minimum size conductor for use in residential wiring systems shall be #14 AWG and for commercial wiring
systems shall be #12 AWG.
2. Electrical conductors used on service conductors and on branch circuits shall be insulated copper wire. No aluminum wire or cable is allowed inside
of any building.
3. All duplex receptacles installed in other than residential use units shall be minimum 20 amp rated devices.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 98/460
4. All motors and pumps serving hot tubs, spas, hydro massage tubs, or similar fixtures shall be protected by a ground fault protected (GFCI) circuit
breaker mounted in the main electrical service panel or sub-panel. Individual GFCI protected outlet devices are not permitted. A properly sized and
identified equipment grounding conductor shall also be installed.
(B) Electric Service Grounding:
1. A primary and secondary grounding connection shall be made on every building.
2. The primary grounding connection shall be made to the neutral or common conductor of the system, where one exists; and shall be made at each
individual service on the supply side of the service disconnection device. The grounding shall in no case be smaller than #8 AWG copper wire and
shall be connected directly to the water system on the street side of the water meter with a continuous un-spliced jumper connection to the house
side of the water meter. Where a plastic water service is used an approved ground rod shall be installed. In any case, there shall be not less than two
ground paths on every electric service.
3. The secondary ground on all commercial use buildings shall be a concrete-encased electrode of one or more bare, zinc galvanized, or other
electrically conductive reinforcing bars, or rods not less than 1/2 in diameter, installed in one continuous length or in multiple pieces totaling 20 feet or
#4 bare copper to be installed in footing or foundation.
4. The secondary ground on all one- and two-family dwelling units shall be a driven rod installed in conformance with NEC 250-52 (A)(5), or a concrete
encased electrode as described above.
5. Ground clamps for use on copper water pipe shall be of copper or brass, and those for use on galvanized or iron pipe shall be of galvanized iron and
so designed as to avoid physical damage to pipe.
(C) Service Requirements:
1. Service wire attachment to the building should be in accordance with the requirements of the local public utility company.
2. Rigid galvanized, IMC, or rigid aluminum conduit shall be used on all services from service head to inside disconnecting means.
3. In single-family dwelling units, both attached and detached, the service size shall be a minimum of 100 amps per dwelling unit utilizing a maximum
30 branch circuits. Sub panels on 100 amp service shall be maximum 60 amp utilizing no more than 8 branch circuits.
4. All overhead services shall be equipped with approved raintight service heads. Gooseneck configurations are not permitted.
5. The main service disconnecting means (circuit breaker or fused switched device) shall be located within (5) five feet of the point where the service
conductors enter the building and/or within (5) five feet of the metering device. A service disconnecting means shall be provided on all commercial
use buildings. The required disconnect shall be readily accessible from the outside of the building or a shunt device shall be installed in conjunction
with the fire alarm system to allow manual disconnect of power to the building by fire department personnel.
6. A main lug breaker panel shall be installed in all single-family use buildings where an exterior main disconnect is required. All main lug panels shall
have a permanent placard installed in a conspicuous location stating the location of the main service disconnect.
7. Where the use and installation of multi-metering devices are provided in buildings and/or structures such as apartment complexes, condominiums,
etc., all service entrance equipment shall be grouped and installed in a dedicated area.
8. All commercial and industrial use installations shall use bolt-in type circuit breakers.
9. No more than one conductor may be connected to an individual circuit breaker terminal or fuse holder.
10. For wiring 277 volts and above, conductors shall be identified as follows: A phase-brown, B phase-orange, C phase-yellow, neutral-gray.
11. Electrical panels shall contain no more than 42 circuit breaker spaces.
(D) Conduit Fittings:
1. All conduit fittings, locknuts, bushings, couplings or connectors shall provide secure mechanical and electrical joints.
2. All fittings shall be either set screw or compression.
3. A building or other premises shall be supplied at one service location. The village electrical inspector may permit additional service locations if where
justified.
4. EMT and copper wire shall be the main wiring method for both residential and commercial installations.
(E) Concrete Encased Conduits:
1. Rigid steel galvanized pipe, IMC conduit, or approved rigid plastic conduit shall be installed in all concrete construction located at or below grade
level.
2. EMT conduit may only be used in concrete construction located above grade.
3. All non-metallic conduits must be protected from physical damage at the point where the conduit enters or exits the concrete, or where exposed
above grade, by use of approved metallic conduit elbows. Metallic conduit exiting concrete in parking garages, or similar locations where road salt
may be present, shall be encased in a concrete curb or shall be sleeved to a point not less than 4" above the parking deck.
(F) Buried Conduits:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 99/460
1. Conduits buried in other than concrete shall be rigid galvanized steel, IMC, or rigid plastic with approved grounding. Minimum burial depth shall not
be less than 24 inches in commercial applications.
2. Directional boring is permitted using HDPE conduit. Minimum burial depth shall be not less than 24 inches.
(G) Additional General Requirements:
1. All lighting fixtures designated as emergency lighting luminaires shall be identified as such by a red dot not less than 3/4" diameter affixed to the
fixture in a readily visible location.
2. All test buttons on emergency lighting luminaires shall be readily accessible without disassembly of the luminaire, nor located above ceilings
requiring portable means to activate.
3. All rooms and spaces in office occupancies shall have a room number posted on door or door frame. Any space having more than two office
modular furniture cubicles shall have each cubicle numbered. Electrical panel directory shall identify all room/cubicle number circuits.
4. All emergency generators providing power for a required emergency back-up power system shall be inspected and tested annually as specified in
the adopted international fire code.
5. All motors, actuators, dampers, controllers and pumps, rated 120 volts or more, shall have a disconnecting means installed within sight of the
equipment. Disconnecting means installed not within sight shall have a provision for locking or attaching a lock to the disconnecting means and must
be part of the disconnect and a permanent component of the switch or circuit breaker.
6. All new commercial fire alarm system wiring shall be installed in conduit. Existing buildings or building areas being renovated so as to expose the fire
alarm wiring shall be brought into conformance with the current code requirement for new construction. All fire alarm junction box covers shall be
painted red so as to readily identify the fire alarm wiring raceway.
(H) Additions, Deletions, And Insertions: The following additions, deletions and insertions and changes are hereby made to the national electrical code,
2011 edition:
1. The following articles of said code are hereby deleted in their entirety:
(a) Article 320 - Armored Cable: Type AC
(b) Article 322 - Flat Cable Assemblies: Type FC
(c) Article 326 - Type IGS
(d) Article 330 - Metal Clad Cable: Type MC. Exception: factory fixture wiring assemblies
(e) Article 332 - Type MI
(f) Article 334 - Nonmetallic-Sheathed Cable: Types NM, NMC, NMS
(g) Article 340 - Type UF
(h) Article 355 - Type RTRC
(i) Article 356 - Type LFNC
(j) Article 360 - Type FMT
(k) Article 362 - Electrical Nonmetallic Tubing: Type ENT
(l) Article 382 - Nonmetallic Extension
(m) Article 394 - Concealed Knob-And-Tube Wiring
(n) Article 398 - Open Wiring On Insulators
2. The following articles have been amended:
(a) Article 110.26 shall be amended by adding subsection 110.26 (B): In commercial and industrial installations, all required working spaces around
electric service entrance equipment shall be illuminated at all times.
(b) Article 300-11(a) shall be amended by the addition of the following language: "Support wires and associated fittings that provide secure support
and that are installed in addition to the ceiling grid support wires, shall be permitted as the sole support. Where independent support wires are
used, they shall be secured at both ends. Lighting fixtures, including recessed can type fixtures, may also be secured using not less than two
screws to grid, or tie wires at not less than two corners."
(c) Article 338 Service-Entrance Cable: Type SE and USE shall be amended so as to disallow the use of type SE cable in any application and to
allow for the use of type USE cable for underground feeder cable to street lighting fixtures.
(d) Article 348 Flexible Metal Conduit: Type FMC shall be amended so as to allow for its use only in limited applications. The permitted uses shall be:
1. As described within section 348.20 (A)(1) and (A)(2).
2. As electrical conduit to indoor equipment subject to vibration or movement.
3. As electrical conduit to a fixture box where minor adjustment to the final box location is required dependent upon the placement of finish
materials.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 100/460
4. In limited remodeling applications where it is necessary to fish the conduit through existing concealed spaces so as to minimize damage to
existing finished surfaces. A separate grounding wire shall be provided so as to bond adjacent junction boxes at each end of the flexible conduit.
5. In any other application approved by the electrical inspector due to impractical installation of non-flexible raceways.
(e) Article 352 PVC: Type PVC shall be amended so as to not allow permitted uses as described under subsections 352.10 (A) and 352.10 (F).
(f) Article 358.30 (A) shall be amended by and replacing it with the following: Electrical metallic tubing shall be installed as a complete system as
provided in article 300 and shall be securely fastened in place at least every 7 feet (2.13m) and within 3 feet (0.914m) of each outlet box, junction
box, cabinet or fitting.
(I) Additional Single-Family Residential Requirements:
1. In all applications a single main disconnecting means shall be installed.
2. Any heating plant shall be on a separate circuit.
3. All recessed fixtures shall be of the "prewired" type, marked sixty degrees centigrade (60C) maximum for supply connections, and shall be wired
with approved wire.
4. A light shall be installed in every accessible storage area, including attic and crawl spaces, all closets and pantries over ten (10) square feet in area.
5. Duplex weatherproof receptacles ground fault (GFI) shall be installed at the front and rear of each building. This is meant to include balconies.
6. Walk in closets shall have a recessed or fluorescent light controlled by a wall switch.
7. Crawl spaces with horizontal type heating plants shall have one light at the access to the crawl space and one light at the heating plant, both being
controlled by a wall switch at the access. This is also meant to include remote sump pumps, sewage ejectors, etc.
8. There shall be no more than ten (10) load openings per circuit.
9. A light shall be installed directly over every kitchen sink, bathroom lavatory and utility sink in addition to the general lights in the room.
10. An outside light controlled by a wall switch shall be installed at each entry and exit, including garages, balconies, patios, loading docks, ramps,
overhead doors, service doors, etc.
11. Stairways, halls, passageways, corridors, garages, patios and rooms accessible by more than one entry or exit shall have a ceiling light or lights
controlled by three-way or four-way switches.
12. Twin, tandem, duplex or split circuit breakers are not permitted.
13. Each motor load of one-fourth (1/4) horsepower or more shall be on a separate circuit.
14. Low voltage wiring for lighting circuits, control or signaling circuits, or communication systems may be run exposed only in accessible areas when
not subject to mechanical injury.
15. Built in ovens and surface sections (ranges) shall each be supplied by a separate circuit unless they are directly adjacent to or adjoining each other.
Built in microwave ovens and dishwashers shall be supplied by separate 20 amp circuits.
16. All motors and pumps serving hot tubs, spas, hydro massage tubs, or similar fixtures shall be protected by a ground fault protected (GFCI) circuit
breaker mounted in the main electrical service panel. Individual GFCI protected outlet devices are not permitted. A properly identified and sized
equipment grounding conductor shall also be installed.
17. All convenience outlets serving bathroom vanities and kitchen countertops shall be 20 amp rated GFCI protected devices, wired using #12 wire,
and protected by 20 amp circuit breakers. A minimum of one 20 amp circuit is required per bathroom and two 20 amp circuits shall be provided
serving kitchen countertop outlets.
18. Smoke detectors shall be installed in all new one- and two-family residential dwelling units in conformance with requirements of the village of Lisle
one- and two-family dwelling building code. All existing one- and two-family dwelling units shall be equipped with a minimum (1) one battery powered
smoke detector on each floor level of the dwelling unit.
Further, carbon monoxide detection devices shall be installed in conformance with requirements of the state of Illinois carbon monoxide detector act
requiring at minimum (1) one battery powered detector within (15') fifteen feet of every room used for sleeping purposes.
19. Detached garage buildings shall have electricity supplied to them, shall be on separate circuits, and shall include the following, which will also apply
to any other accessory building that incidentally has electric power:
(a) Direct burial conductors shall be a minimum of eighteen inches (18") below the surface of the ground.
(b) Direct burial cable shall be in rigid metal conduit or IMC for eighteen inches (18") when it leaves and enters the building.
(c) One ceiling light controlled by a wall switch.
(d) A minimum of one grounding type 20 amp duplex GFI receptacle.
(e) Properly sized equipment grounding conductor shall be installed in detached garage or other auxiliary buildings. (Ord. 2014-4543, 8-18-2014)
4-2-4: RIGHT TO ENTER FOR INSPECTION:
The electrical inspector, building inspector, and building official shall have the right, during reasonable hours, to enter any building in the discharge of his
official duties or for the purpose of making any inspection or test of the installation or alteration of electrical equipment contained therein, or for the purpose
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 101/460
of reinspecting present wiring installations to determine whether or not such wiring installations conform to the provisions of this chapter, and shall have
the authority to cause the turning off of all electrical currents and to cut or disconnect, in cases of emergency, any wire where such electrical currents are
dangerous to life or property or may interfere with the work of the fire department. (Ord. 2008-4174, 1-7-2008, eff. 1-17-2008)
4-2-5: CERTIFICATE OF COMPLIANCE:
Upon the completion of the wiring of electrical installations in or on any building or structure, it shall be the duty of the person doing the same to notify the
community development department, which shall cause to be inspected said wiring or electrical installation, and if the same conform to the requirements of
this chapter shall cause to be issued a written certificate of compliance, in triplicate, one copy of which shall be delivered to the person doing the same,
one copy to be delivered to the person or firm which is to furnish electricity or electrical service (if so required), and the third copy shall remain in the village
files.
It shall be unlawful for any person to install electrical energy recording meters on any electrical equipment that has been installed or connect any electrical
distribution system or circuit to any electricity system previous to the issuance by the electrical inspector of a certificate of compliance. (Ord. 2008-4174, 1-
7-2008, eff. 1-17-2008)
4-2-6: NONLIABILITY OF VILLAGE:
This chapter shall not relieve from nor lessen the responsibility of any person owning, operating or installing any electrical wires, appliances, apparatus or
equipment for damages to anyone injured by any defect therein by reason of the inspections authorized herein or the certificate of compliance issued by
the community development department; nor shall the village be held liable for any damages resulting from the enforcement of the provisions of this
chapter. (Ord. 2008-4174, 1-7-2008, eff. 1-17-2008)
4-2-7: APPEALS:
Any person shall have the right to appeal a decision of the code official or request a variation from the terms of this code before the board of appeals. An
application for appeal shall be based on a claim that the true intent of this code or the rules legally adopted hereunder have been incorrectly interpreted,
the provisions of this code do not fully apply, or an equivalent form of construction is to be used. The board of appeals shall grant variations from the strict
application of any of the requirements of this code in the case of exceptional conditions, whereby such strict application would result in practical difficulty or
unnecessary hardship that would deprive the owner of reasonable use of the land or building involved. In granting any variation, the board of appeals shall
prescribe any conditions that it deems to be necessary or desirable. The board shall affirm, modify, or reverse the decision of the code official by a majority
vote. The board of appeals shall be the village of Lisle president and board of trustees and the chairman of the board of appeals shall be the president,
also known as the mayor, of the village of Lisle. (Ord. 2008-4174, 1-7-2008, eff. 1-17-2008)
4-2-8: PENALTY:
Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter or of the code adopted by reference herein shall, on conviction, be fined as established by the
annual fee ordinance for each offense; and every person shall be deemed guilty of a separate offense for each day such violation shall continue, and shall
be subject to the penalty under this section for each and every separate offense. (Ord. 2008-4174, 1-7-2008, eff. 1-17-2008)
Chapter 3
PLUMBING CODE
4-3-1: ADOPTION OF PLUMBING CODE:
There is hereby adopted by the Village, for the purpose of establishing rules and regulations for plumbing and the fixtures, materials, design and
installation methods of plumbing systems that certain Plumbing Code known as the Illinois Plumbing Code, the latest edition thereof, and the whole
thereof, save and except such portions as are hereafter amended, of which not less than three (3) copies have been and now are filed in the Office of the
Village Clerk and the same are hereby adopted and incorporated as fully as if set out in length herein, and from the date on which this chapter shall take
effect, the provisions thereof shall be controlling within the Village. (Ord. 2018-4767, 5-21-2018)
4-3-2: AMENDMENTS TO THE PLUMBING CODE:
The Plumbing Code of the Village, as hereinbefore adopted, is amended in the following respects:
(A) Definitions: The following definitions are added supplemental to the definitions contained within the Illinois plumbing code;
"Code": The latest edition of the Illinois plumbing code as adopted and amended by the village of Lisle.
"Existing Legal Non-Conforming Plumbing System": A plumbing system, or portion thereof, presently in existence on a premises which lawfully existed
prior to the enactment of this code and which complies with the plumbing code in effect at the time of installation.
"Existing Non-Conforming Piping": Any part of an existing plumbing system installed without proper permit approval and which does not comply with
the requirements of the plumbing code in effect at the time of installation.
"Strip Mall": A single story commercial building arranged or divided into several occupiable areas, each with independent entrance and egress, lacking
a common core area, with the potential need for the addition or reconfiguration of plumbing fixtures within each unit.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 102/460
(B) Materials: Only the following materials are permitted for the following locations:
1. All PVC piping shall be primed and glued. Cell core PVC is not permitted.
2. Underground Water Supply Piping: Type "K" copper or ductile iron is permitted. Polyethylene plastic pipe or tubing may be used for private wells
only.
3. Above Ground Water Supply Piping: Only type "L" copper, type "M" copper and properly installed cross-linked polyethylene tubing is permitted.
4. Repairs to existing plumbing systems using dissimilar materials shall be allowed only if the repair results in one material transition between the point
of repair and the building sewer or waste/vent stack.
5. Fixture Supply Stops And Fixture Supply Lines: Non-metallic stops and slip-on stops/supply lines are not permitted. Fixture supply lines shall be
copper tubing or flexible braided stainless steel fixture supplies sized for the use and installed without loops or kinks.
Exception: Fixture supplies that are integral to the faucet by the manufacture will be allowed.
(C) Water And Sanitary Sewer Service: All building water and sewer services must comply with the following requirements:
1. Water and sewer services shall be installed a minimum of five feet (5') in depth and shall have a horizontal separation of ten feet (10').
2. All single-family residential building drains must be minimum four inch (4") in diameter. A commercial building sewer must be brought into the
building a minimum of six inches (6") in diameter. All strip malls require six inch (6") sanitary waste line for future tenant build out at thirty six inches
(36") below finished floor with six inch (6") cleanout in last tenant space.
3. The minimum size water service is one inch (1"). Copper water service lines must be continuous one piece lengths of pipe from the service stop to
the water meter.
4. A full port shut-off valve is required on the inlet side of the water meter. The first joint of the valve inlet shall be a flared type adapter with brassthreaded
connections to meter adapter.
5. Private wells are prohibited within the corporate boundaries of the Village and must be sealed in accordance with the DuPage County Health
Department regulations once connection to the public water system has occurred.
6. Minimum one inch (1") cold water supply to water heater inlet or branch piping is required.
(D) Fixtures: The following special fixture requirements shall apply in the Village:
1. All residential kitchen sinks require a minimum two inch (2") waste opening with two inch (2") cleanout.
2. Commercial kitchens, deli's, and catering business with triple bowl sinks and mop basins must have a 1/2" hot water supply at fifty four inches (54")
above finish floor for future chemical feeder water supply.
3. Tank type urinals are not permitted.
4. All new plumbing fixtures and irrigation controllers installed after the effective date of this ordinance shall bear the WaterSense label (as designated
by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency WaterSense Program), when such labeled fixtures are available.
5. No residential water softeners may use more than seventy five (75) gallons (285 liters) during the entire regeneration cycle, and sized to cycle no
more than three (3) times per week.
(E) Drainage System: The following additional requirements will apply to drainage systems:
1. Grease interceptors must be installed outside of a building in a location convenient to being pumped out. Outside grease interceptors must be
properly vented into the building using a minimum three inch (3") vent separately terminated thru roof.
Exception #1: Non-grease producing kitchens & restaurants may install in floor grease interceptors meeting IL plumbing code and DuPage health
department requirements.
Exception #2: An inside grease trap may only be used with the prior approval of the plumbing inspector when field conditions absolutely prohibit the
use of an outside grease trap.
2. Floor and/or trench drains are prohibited in private residential garages unless drained to all approved gas and oil interceptor. Drywells are not
permitted.
3. Any proposed acid or chemical waste systems must be approved by the DuPage County department of environmental concerns.
4. Properly installed floor drains with tamper proof covers must be installed in each commercial restroom. In residential basements the floor drain must
be within five feet (5') of a furnace, boiler or water heater.
5. Individual pump units for the use of lifting waste from a fixture is prohibited unless prior approval from the plumber inspector.
6. Floor drains in mechanical rooms, fire sprinkler equipment rooms, and adjacent to reduced pressure zone principle backflow preventor assembly
(RPZ) must have eight and a half inch (81/2") round top with rough finish.
(F) Special Requirements: The following special requirements will apply:
1. Where piping is installed through studs, joist or rafters close enough to be pierced by nails, nail guards or stud guards must be installed.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 103/460
2. All new or remodeled car wash facilities must have a water recycling system installed to recycle the water used for car washing.
3. A minimum two inch (2") sewage pump is required where laundry facilities discharge into a sanitary ejector pit.
4. All irrigation sprinkler systems shall have unthreaded valve connections or hose bibbs after the reduced pressure zone principle backflow preventor
assembly (RPZ).
(Ord. 2018-4767, 5-21-2018)
Chapter 4
SIGN CODE
4-4-1: SHORT TITLE:
This chapter shall be known and cited as the LISLE SIGN CODE. (Ord. 2005-3891, 1-17-2005)
4-4-2: INTENT:
The purpose of this chapter is to preserve and protect the public health, safety, welfare and aesthetics of the village by regulating outdoor advertising and
signs of all types. It is intended to enhance the physical appearance of the village, make it a more enjoyable and pleasing community, and create an
attractive economic and business climate. Also, it is intended to reduce the sign or advertising distractions which may increase traffic accidents, eliminate
hazards caused by signs overhanging or projecting over public rights of way, relieve pedestrian and traffic congestion, provide more open space and avoid
the "canceling out" effect of adjacent signs. (Ord. 2005-3891, 1-17-2005)
4-4-3: INTERPRETATION, CONSTRUCTION AND DEFINITIONS:
Where there is a conflict between the provisions of this chapter and the zoning provisions of the village1, the provisions contained in this chapter shall
prevail; and if there is found a conflict between any provisions of this chapter, the more restrictive provision shall prevail.
For the purpose of this chapter, the following words and phrases are hereby defined:
AREA, SIGN: The total exposed surface devoted to the advertiser's message, including all ornamentation, embellishment and symbols, but excluding the
supporting structure which does not form part of the sign proper or of the display. The area of a sign, composed of characters or words attached directly to
a large uniform building wall surface, shall be the smallest rectangle which encloses the whole group.
ATTENTION GETTING DEVICE: A sign or other device designed to attract attention by means of flashing or moving parts, bright color or light, or
movement of any kind. Examples of such signs include pennants hung in series, whirligigs, spinners, streamers, flashing lights, searchlights, beacons, and
balloons or similar inflatable devices.
AWNING SIGN: Any structure made of cloth or other nonrigid material attached to and projecting from a building and including structures which are fixed
or so erected as to permit their being raised or retracted to a position against the building when not in use.
BALLOON SIGN: Any outdoor inflatable sign, including, but not limited to, air dancers, balloons, blimps, costumes, helium balls and rooftop or freestanding
gorillas.
BUILDING LINE: The line as established by the face of the building.
BUILDING SIGN: A sign attached to and supported by the exterior of any part of a building, except the roof.
CANOPY SIGN: A permanent roof like structure extending from part or all of a building and constructed of a metal framework with an approved covering.
COMMERCIAL SIGN: Any sign which promotes goods or services for sale and profit.
ELECTRONIC MESSAGE CENTER: A variable message sign that utilizes computer generated messages or some other electronic means of changing
copy. These signs include displays using incandescent lamps, LEDs (light emitting diodes), LCDs (liquid crystal displays) or a flipper matrix. Such signs
shall be permitted by special use permit only.
EXTERNALLY ILLUMINATED SIGN: A sign illuminated by a source of light which is cast upon, or falls upon, the surface of the sign illuminated by
reflection only.
FESTOON LIGHTING: A group of ten (10) or more incandescent light bulbs hung or strung overhead, not on a building or advertising structure, which are
exposed to persons on a public right of way, and which are not shaded or hooded to prevent the direct rays of light from shining above four feet (4') from
sidewalk grade.
FLASHING SIGN: A sign whose illumination intermittently flashes off and on, in whole or in part.
FREESTANDING SIGN: Any sign which is not a "building sign" or a "roof sign" as those terms are defined herein. A freestanding sign may be either an off
premises sign or an on premises sign.
Freestanding Off Premises Sign: A sign that does not direct persons to a business, person, activity, goods, products or services located on the premises
where the sign is to be maintained.
Freestanding On Premises Sign: A sign identifying or advertising a business, person, activity, goods, products or services located on the premises where
the sign is installed and maintained.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 104/460
FRONTAGE: That amount of a subject property fronting on a street or right of way. Multiple frontages shall not be construed to allow additional square
footage of sign area beyond the maximum areas permitted under the zoning district in which the premises are situated.
INTERIOR SIGN: Any sign wholly within and enclosed by a "building" as defined in section 5-1-7 of this code.
INTERIOR SIGNS: Permanently affixed to a window or the walls enclosing the display area behind a window, which are obviously intended for viewing
from the exterior, shall be considered exterior signs.
INTERNALLY ILLUMINATED SIGN: A sign, all or any part of the letters or design of which is made of incandescent, neon or other types of lamps, a sign
with painted, flush or raised letters lighted by an electric lamp or lamps attached thereto, a sign having a border or incandescent or fluorescent lamps
thereto attached and reflecting light thereon; or a transparent glare sign, whether lighted by electricity or other illuminant.
LOCATION: A lot, premises, building, wall or any place upon which a sign is located.
MONUMENT SIGN: A sign which is completely or principally supported by a short wall typically constructed of masonry material which is a minimum of
eighty percent (80%) of the width of the sign, and is not attached to the principal building on the property, and is anchored in or upon the ground.
NEON BORDER WINDOW SIGN: Any shapes that form skeleton tubing, outline lighting, and other decorative elements or art forms, in various colors and
diameters that creates neon borders around the perimeter of a window.
NONCOMMERCIAL SIGN: Any sign which promotes something other than goods or services for sale and profit.
PERMITTEE: That person to whom a sign is issued.
PERSON: An individual, corporation, association, firm, partners and the like, singular or plural.
POSTERBOARD OR BILLBOARD: A sign used for the display of advertising posters not usually associated with the product or major enterprise offered on
the premises on which the sign is located.
PRINCIPAL PRODUCT: A product described by category rather than by name; that is, refrigerators and not Frigidaire refrigerators.
PROJECTING SIGN: A sign, other than a wall sign, which overhangs public property and is supported by a wall of a building or structure.
RIGHT OF WAY: A strip dedicated to the public and occupied or intended to be occupied by a street, crosswalk, railroad, electric transmission line, oil or
gas pipeline, water main, sanitary or storm sewer main, public utility easements or for another special use.
ROOF SIGN: A sign located or painted on or above any roof of a building.
ROOFLINE: Either the edge of the roof or the top of the parapet, whichever forms the top line of the building silhouette; and where a building has several
roof levels, this roof or parapet shall be the one belonging to that portion of the building on whose wall the sign is located.
SHOPPING CENTER: Any concentration of retail stores and service establishments in one or more buildings under single ownership or management with
common parking facilities.
SIGN: Any name, identification, description, letters, figures, design, display, trademark, symbol, illustration, or illumination intended to attract attention to a
place, subject, firm, institution, organization, business, corporation, public performance, service, article, items, idea, product, activity, object, machine or
merchandise, painted, printed or constructed and displayed in any manner whatsoever. However, this shall not include any notices from or in connection
with any court, village, county or other judicial, quasi-judicial, municipal, or governmental body, or the flag, emblem, or insignia of a government, school or
religious group when displayed for official purposes.
SIGN FACE AREA: Is to be construed as the area of a single face of a sign. For a double faced sign, both faces shall be of the same dimensions, parallel
to each other and supported by the same structure. The total allowable area of the double faced sign shall be twice that of a single faced sign.
UNUSUALLY SHAPED SIGNS: Such as globes, cylinders or pyramids shall be considered double faced signs, and the sign area shall be computed as
one-half (1/2) the total of the exposed surfaces.
WALL SIGN: A sign attached to or painted on a wall of a building, with the exposed face of the sign approximately parallel to the wall surface.
WINDOW SIGN: Any sign, picture, symbol, or combination thereof, designed to communicate information about an activity, business, commodity, event,
sale, or service that is placed inside a window or upon the window panes or glass and is visible from the exterior of the window. (Ord. 2005-3891, 1-17-
2005)
4-4-4: GENERAL PROVISIONS:
(A) Permits Required: No sign shall be erected, altered or relocated without a permit issued by the building commissioner, except as otherwise provided
herein. Where electrical permits are required, they shall be obtained at the same time as the sign permit.
Application for a permit shall be made upon blanks furnished by the building commissioner, and shall include the following information:
1. Name, address and telephone number of applicant;
2. Location of the building, structure or parcel of property to which, or upon which, the sign is to be attached or erected;
3. Position of sign in relation to nearby buildings, structures, lot lines and street grade;
4. Two (2) copies of plans and specifications showing method of construction, location and support, sealed by a registered architect or structural
engineer;
5. Sketch showing sign faces, exposed surfaces and proposed message thereof accurately represented in scale as to sign, proportion and color;
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 105/460
6. Name of person, firm, corporation or association erecting the sign;
7. Written consent of the owners of the building, structure or land on or to which the sign is to be erected; and
8. Such other information as the building inspector shall require to show full compliance with this and all other laws and ordinances of the village.
(B) Conformance With Electrical Code: All signs in which electrical wiring and connections are required shall conform to the applicable provisions of the
electrical code of the village2.
(C) Wind Pressure And Dead Load Requirements: Any "sign" or advertising structure, as defined in this code, shall be designed and constructed to
withstand a wind pressure of not less than thirty (30) pounds per square foot of net surface area and to receive dead loads as required in the building
code or other ordinances of the village.
(D) Issuance Of Permits: It shall be the duty of the building commissioner, who shall be the enforcing officer hereof, upon the filing of an application for
permit, to examine such plans and specifications, the premises upon which it is proposed to erect the sign or other advertising structure, and other
data; and if it shall appear that the proposed structure is in compliance with all the requirements of this chapter, and all other ordinances of the village,
he shall then issue the permit. If the signage is located in, on, is a part of or is associated with a planned unit development then the signage and any
changes thereto shall also be in compliance with those requirements set forth in title 5, chapter 14 of this code. If the work authorized under the permit
has not been completed within six (6) months after date of issuance, said permit shall become null and void.
(E) Permit Fees:
1. Fees: Every applicant, before being granted a permit hereunder, shall pay the following permit fee for each sign to the village collector:
A fee as established by the annual fee ordinance per square foot of facing, for all signs requiring a permit, other than temporary signs, canopies,
awnings or marquees; and an additional amount as established by the annual fee ordinance per square foot if the sign is electrical.
A fee as established by the annual fee ordinance for a temporary sign.
2. Permit For Work Commenced Prior To Issuance: Should any work for which a permit is required be commenced or be done before such permit is
issued and obtained, the required permit may be issued for such and subsequent work, however, the amount of the required fee as provided herein
for all work shall be double that otherwise so provided. The issuance of such permit does not act to bar any other penalty, liability or action otherwise
provided for in this chapter or this code but shall be in addition thereto.
3. Security Deposit: A cash security deposit is required to guarantee performance by each building permit holder of the obligation to maintain the
building and adjacent public and private property in a clean condition both during and after construction, installation or demolition in accordance with
applicable laws and ordinances of the village of Lisle. The cash security deposit required under this section shall be in the amount as established by
the annual fee ordinance.
4. Preerection Inspection: The sign contractor shall schedule an inspection with the building and zoning department prior to the installation of any sign
that requires a foundation inspection, if applicable, and confirmation of the other details of mounting and placement.
5. Final Inspection: The sign contractor shall notify the building and zoning department upon completion of the work and, accordingly, schedule a final
inspection.
(F) Unsafe Or Unlawful Signs: If the building commissioner shall find that any sign is unsafe, insecure or a menace to the public, or has been constructed,
erected or maintained in violation of the provisions of this code, he shall give written notice to the permittee thereof. The permittee shall remove or alter
the structure so as to comply with the standards herein set forth within ten (10) days after such notice.
The building commissioner may cause any sign or other advertising structure which is an immediate peril to persons or property to be removed
summarily and without notice.
(G) Maintenance Required: The owner of a sign shall be required to maintain it in a safe, neat and attractive condition. The sign and sign supports must be
kept painted to prevent rust, rot or deterioration.
(H) Removal: Any commercial sign, which no longer identifies a bona fide business conducted or a product sold, shall be taken down, together with any
supporting structure, and removed by the owner, agent or person having the beneficial use of the building, structure or property upon which said sign
may be found.
(I) Exemptions: The provisions and regulations of this chapter shall not apply to the signs hereinafter listed; provided, however, no sign, excluding signs
denoted in subsection (I)6 of this section, shall be placed within the public right of way:
1. "For Sale", "For Rent", and "Sold" signs, which advertise the sale or rental of the real estate upon which said sign is located or indicating that the
property has been sold. The following restrictions apply to such signs:
(a) The total allowable sign face area of such signs shall be as prescribed by the zoning district regulations of this chapter, but in no event shall the
total sign face area of such a sign exceed one hundred twenty (120) square feet;
(b) The maximum allowable height of such signs shall be as prescribed by the zoning district regulations of this chapter;
(c) Said signs may remain in place during the time the property is for sale or rent, and for a period not to exceed one week after the consummation of
the sale or rental of the property to a ninety percent (90%) occupancy level.
2. Professional nameplates not exceeding one square foot in area.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 106/460
3. Bulletin boards for public, charitable or religious institutions, when the same are located on the premises of said institutions and are not over fifteen
(15) square feet in area.
4. Occupational signs denoting only the name and profession of an occupant in a commercial building or public institutional building and not exceeding
two (2) square feet in area.
5. Memorial sign or table, name of building and date of erection, when cut into any masonry surface or when constructed of bronze or other
noncombustible materials.
6. Traffic or other village signs, legal notices or railroad crossing, danger or such temporary emergency or nonadvertising signs as may be approved by
the president and board of trustees.
7. Address signs not over one square foot in area.
8. Window signs; provided, however, that they shall be subject to the provisions of this section relating to the area for such signs.
9. Any civic event or family event signs.
10. Political signs pursuant to the requirements in subsection 4-4-6(A)3 of this chapter.
11. Sandwich board signs, provided the signs comply with the provisions found under the sign regulation sections of this chapter where such signs are
permitted.
(J) Indemnity Policy: Each person maintaining a projecting sign, canopy, awning or marquee overhanging public property prior to the effective date of this
chapter, shall file with the building commissioner a policy of insurance showing the village as an additional named insured in the amount as established
by the annual fee ordinance conditioned to indemnify the village for any loss, damage or liability which may result from the construction or maintenance
of such a sign.
(K) Obstructions To Doors, Windows Or Fire Escapes: No sign shall be erected, relocated or maintained so as to prevent free access to or egress from
any door, window or fire escape. No sign of any kind shall be attached to a standpipe or fire escape.
(L) Signs Not To Constitute Traffic Hazards: In order to obtain and secure traffic safety, no sign shall be erected or maintained in such a manner as to be
likely to interfere with, obstruct the view of, or be confused with any authorized traffic sign, signal or device, as determined by the chief of police.
Accordingly, no sign, marquee, canopy or awning shall make use of the words "Stop", "Go", "Look", "Slow", "Danger", or a similar word, phrase, symbol
or character or employ any red, yellow, orange, green or other colored lamp in such a manner as to interfere with, mislead or confuse traffic.
(M) Illumination: The light from any illuminated sign shall be so shaded, shielded, or directed that the light intensity or brightness will not be objectionable
to surrounding areas.
1. No sign shall have blinking, flashing or fluttering lights or other illuminating device which has a changing light intensity, brightness or color. Beacon
lights are not permitted.
2. Neither the direct or reflected light from primary light sources shall create a traffic hazard for, or confuse, operators of motor vehicles on public
thoroughfares.
3. No exposed reflective type bulb or incandescent lamp which exceeds fifteen (15) watts shall be used on the exterior surface of any sign so as to
expose the face of the bulb, light or lamp to any public street or adjacent property.
4. Signs shall be shaded wherever necessary to avoid casting light upon property located in any residence district or upon any public street or park.
Any illuminated sign located on a lot adjacent to or across the street from any residence district, which sign is visible from such residence district,
shall not be illuminated between the hours of eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. and seven o'clock (7:00) A.M.
5. Internally illuminated signs shall permit light to shine fully through the lettering and graphic elements of the sign. The background for such lettering
and graphics shall be opaque or translucent, and shall transmit light at a level substantially less than that transmitted through the lettering and
graphics.
(N) Glass; Limitation: Any glass forming part of a sign shall be safety glass. In case any single piece or pane of glass has an area exceeding three (3)
square feet, it shall be wired glass.
(O) Public Hearing Procedure: No action of the corporate authorities shall be taken on any variance request which requires a public hearing until a public
hearing is held at which parties in interest and citizens shall have an opportunity to be heard. No less than fifteen (15) nor more than thirty (30) days'
notice of the time and place of such hearing shall be caused to be published by the village clerk at the applicant's expense in a newspaper of general
circulation in the village. Such notice shall contain the number designation of the request, the date, time, location and purpose of the hearing, the name
of the applicant and a description of the subject property. There shall be posted notice of the hearing on a sign to be located on the subject property for
which the variance is requested. The applicant shall submit a fee as established by the annual fee ordinance with his application to defer the costs of
the hearing including cost of publication, notice, and erection, maintenance and removal of said sign by the village. Failure of the village to post said
sign shall not impair or in any way affect the validity of any variance granted subsequent to published notice. The applicant shall also furnish the village
with a list of people who own property within two hundred fifty feet (250') of the subject property who shall be given notice of the public hearing.
(P) Sight Obstruction: No sign shall be constructed so as to obstruct the view of motorists of oncoming traffic and of pedestrians. Signs that exceed three
feet (3') in height shall not be located within a twenty five foot (25') line of sight vision clearance triangle at the intersection of driveways and roadways.
(Ord. 2005-3891, 1-17-2005)
(Q) Ground Mounted Signs; Structural Requirements:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 107/460
1. Requirements: The structural frame of all ground signs shall be constructed using noncombustible materials securely fastened to an approved
foundation system capable of supporting the sign under maximum design loads.
All signs shall be designed and constructed so as to withstand a wind pressure of not less than thirty (30) pounds per square foot of net surface area
and to receive dead loads as required by the building code.
All plans for ground mounted signs shall be prepared and "stamped" by a licensed structural engineer registered in the state of Illinois.
2. Exception: Ground signs, the top of which is no higher than four feet (4') above grade, and less than fifty (50) square feet in face area, may be
constructed using an approved decay resistant wood and shall not require certification by a structural engineer subject to conformance with the
following specifications:
(a) All structural posts shall be not less than six inches by six inches (6" x 6") nominal dimensions and of a decay resistant material approved for
direct earth contact.
(b) Posts shall be set in minimum sixteen inch (16") diameter holes, not less than forty eight inches (48") below grade, and backfilled using selfcompacting
or self-draining material such as three-fourths inch (3/4") washed limestone, or a similar material approved by the village building
official, compacted to within four inches (4") of the finished grade.
(c) The lowest edge of the sign face shall be constructed not less than twelve inches (12") above finished grade. (Ord. 2008-4218, 8-4-2008)
4-4-5: LEGAL AND NONCONFORMING SIGNS:
Signs existing at the time of the enactment of this chapter and not conforming to its provisions, but which were constructed in compliance with previous
regulations, shall be regarded as legal nonconforming signs.
Nonconforming signs which are discontinued or abandoned for a period of thirty (30) days or more, structurally altered, damaged, relocated or replaced, or
which advertise a business which use or business name is changed, shall comply immediately with all provisions of this chapter.
(A) Sign Amortization Of Nonconforming Signs: All nonconforming signs shall be removed or made conforming to the requirements of this chapter within
seven (7) years of the effective date hereof. (Ord. 2005-3891, 1-17-2005)
4-4-6: TEMPORARY SIGNS:
(A) The following signs shall be permitted anywhere within the village and shall not require a permit:
1. Construction Signs: Construction signs, identifying the architects, engineers, contractors, but not including the advertisement of any product, and
announcing the intended character of the building up to a maximum area of sixteen (16) square feet for each firm. The signs shall be confined to the
site of the construction, and shall be removed within fourteen (14) days after the beginning of the intended use of the project.
2. Real Estate Signs: Real estate signs not exceeding a total area of four (4) square feet advertising the sale or rental of all, or part, of the premises on
which the signs are displayed. These signs must be removed within seven (7) days after the sale is closed or the lease signed. (Ord. 2005-3891, 1-
17-2005)
3. Political Campaign Signs: Political campaign signs, announcing the candidates seeking public political office and other data pertinent thereto, which
are confined exclusively within private property, not exceeding 3.5 square feet per individual sign. Properties that have a street frontage of more than
one hundred fifty feet (150') shall be allowed one additional sign not to exceed forty eight (48) square feet. Political campaign signs on nonresidential
property shall be displayed not more than thirty (30) days prior to an election, and shall be removed within seven (7) days after the election. (Ord.
2011-4367, 1-17-2011)
4. Show Window Signs: Show window signs in a window display of merchandise, when incorporated with such a display. They need not be related in
content with the display.
5. Temporary Sale Signs: Garage sale, yard sale or other temporary signs of this nature. Such signs must be located on private property with the
property owner's permission. Said signs may not exceed four (4) square feet in area and six feet (6') in height. Said signs may not be erected for a
period longer than seventy two (72) hours and must be removed by the property owner or by the party who posted the sign at the end of the seventy
two (72) hour period. Signs erected or maintained in violation of this section may be removed by village enforcement personnel.
(B) The following signs shall require a permit and shall conform in all respects with all applicable regulations imposed under section 4-4-4 of this chapter.
1. Street banners advertising a public entertainment or event, if specifically approved by the village board and then only for locations designated by
said village board, during fourteen (14) days before and three (3) days after the event. (Ord. 2005-3891, 1-17-2005)
2. Temporary signs not in excess of forty (40) square feet in area for the promotion of a specific event, grand opening, or other like function. Said time
period shall not exceed thirty (30) days. No flashing or sequential lights shall be allowable and any business, person or location shall be entitled to
only two (2) such approvals within any single calendar year. Any signs shall be mounted in a secure fashion and shall in all respects comply with all
other applicable provisions of this chapter and other ordinances of the village. (Ord. 2005-3904, 3-7-2005)
3. Inflatable balloons or other cold air advertising devices for the promotion of a specific event, grand opening, or other like function. Only one such
inflatable balloon or other cold air advertising device is permitted. Any inflatable advertising device shall not exceed twenty five feet (25') in height
measured at grade and shall not exceed ten feet (10') in diameter. Said advertising device shall be ground mounted and properly secured to avoid
being a windblown hazard. Said device shall be displayed one time per calendar year for a maximum of seven (7) days. (Ord. 2005-3901, 2-21-2005)
4. Pennants or streamers for the promotion of a specific event, grand opening, or other like function. The pennants or streamers shall be mounted in a
secure fashion and shall in all other respects comply with all other applicable provisions of this chapter and other ordinances of the village. Said
device shall be displayed one time per calendar year for a maximum of seven (7) days. (Ord. 2005-3904, 3-7-2005)

4-4-7: EXEMPTIONS:
The following types of signs are exempted from all the provisions of this chapter, except for construction and safety regulations and the following
requirements:
(A) Public Signs: Signs of a noncommercial nature and in the public interest, erected by, or on the order of, a public officer in the performance of his public
duty, such as safety signs, danger signs, trespassing signs, traffic signs, memorial plaques, signs of historical interest and the like.
(B) Integral: Names of buildings, dates of erection, monumental citations, commemorative tablets and the like when carved into stone, concrete or similar
material or made of bronze, aluminum, or other permanent type construction, and made an integral part of the structure.
(C) Traffic Direction: Signs directing traffic movement onto a premises or within a premises, not exceeding four (4) square feet in area and four feet (4') in
height for each sign. Illumination of these signs shall be permitted in accordance with the regulations contained in this chapter.
(D) Flags: Flags provided any flagpoles are set back at least five feet (5') from any property lines.
(E) Decorative: Noncommercial holiday decorations or seasonal banners.
(F) Address Signs: Address signs provided the sign does not exceed one square foot in area. (Ord. 2005-3891, 1-17-2005)
4-4-8: PROHIBITED SIGNS:
(A) Flashing signs;
(B) Roof signs;
(C) Commercial signs which promote an enterprise not in existence, or product or service no longer sold;
(D) Signs which move or have moving parts, which movement is caused either by the wind or mechanically;
(E) Signs which contain statements, words or pictures of obscene, indecent or immoral character and which offend the public morals or decency;
(F) Miscellaneous advertising devices, other than signs which conform to the provisions of this chapter, shall not be allowed;
(G) Signs in conflict with traffic signals;
(H) Billboard signs;
(I) Graphics or other signs attached to power poles or light standards;
(J) Attention getting devices except electronic message center signs approved by special use permit;
(K) Off site advertising signs;
(L) Neon border window sign;
(M) Any signs in the public right of way except those signs denoted in subsection 4-4-4(I)6 of this chapter;
(N) Any sign not expressively expressed in this chapter. (Ord. 2005-3904, 3-7-2005)

(A) Permitted Sign Types:
Awning and canopies, which shall not exceed one square foot for every linear foot of wall frontage. Surface area for awnings and canopies are counted

ground.
Exempt and temporary signs (sections 4-4-6 and 4-4-7 of this chapter).
Freestanding signs, in accordance with the bulk requirements stipulated below.
Sandwich board signs, no more than one sign per business is permitted, must be located entirely or partially on the sidewalk in front of the business,
allowing at least four feet (4') of sidewalk clearance and shall not exceed ten (10) square feet or exceed four feet (4') in height. Signs shall not be
displayed before sunrise and shall be taken down by sunset. Any signs encroaching any public right of way, must comply with the indemnity policy set
forth in subsection 4-4-4(J) of this chapter. Sandwich board signs shall be professionally made and maintained in good condition. Signs shall be of an
A-frame design and properly weighted so as to not create a windblown hazard. Signs shall not have any nails, tacks, wires, or sharp metal edges
protruding therefrom. Sandwich board signs must be located on the ground and not be attached to any structure or person.
Wall signs, in accordance with the bulk requirements stipulated below.
Window signs, which shall be limited to no more than twenty five percent (25%) of the total window display area.
(B) Bulk Requirements For Freestanding And Wall Signs:
1. Number Of Signs Per Lot: No more than one freestanding sign shall be permitted per lot, except an additional sign shall be permitted where the lot
has frontage on two (2) arterial roads and the signs are at least two hundred feet (200') from each other. Each building is allowed a wall sign per
each roadway frontage.
2. Surface Area: Each side of the freestanding signs shall not exceed forty (40) square feet. "V" shaped freestanding signs shall be prohibited. Wall
signs shall not exceed one square foot per linear foot of building frontage.
3. Height: No freestanding sign shall be erected to exceed a height of ten feet (10') above ground level.
4. Location: Monument freestanding signs shall be set back at least five feet (5') from any property lines. Pylon or pole freestanding signs shall be set
back at least ten feet (10') from any property lines. Attached signs shall not extend more than twelve inches (12") from the face of the building. The
area surrounding the base of freestanding signs shall be landscaped in accordance with the provisions of the landscaping and tree preservation
ordinance (section 5-26-10 of this code). (Ord. 2005-3891, 1-17-2005)

4-4-15: REVOCATION OF PERMIT:
The building commissioner may seek revocation of a permit for alleged violation of any provision of this chapter. He shall do so by mailing written notice by
certified or registered mail to the permittee. Said notice shall specify the alleged violations of this chapter relied upon and shall contain the time, date and
place of the hearing before the president and board of trustees of the village. Said hearing shall be no sooner than five (5) days from the date of mailing.
The notice shall also specify that the person or organization may be represented by counsel with the right to confront and cross examine adverse
witnesses.
Hearing regarding revocation:
(A) At the hearing, the aggrieved permittee may be represented by counsel with the right to confront and cross examine witnesses against him.
(B) Testimony shall be taken upon oath or affirmation, first of witnesses in support of the revocation of the permit; the aggrieved permittee may then testify
and present witnesses on his/her behalf.
(C) The findings and order of the president and board of trustees shall within ten (10) days of the conclusion of the hearing be forthwith sent to the
permittee by certified or registered mail, return receipt requested, at the address listed on the permittee's application.
(D) If the permit is revoked, it will become effective immediately upon service on the permittee or upon mailing, whichever occurs sooner, unless a court of
competent jurisdiction rules otherwise, or appealed pursuant to subsection 4-4-16(B) of this chapter. (Ord. 2005-3891, 1-17-2005)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 112/460
4-4-16: ADMINISTRATION AND PENALTIES:
(A) Enforcement: The building commissioner and building inspector are hereby authorized and directed to enforce all the provisions of this chapter.
(B) Right Of Appeal: Any person aggrieved by a decision or order of the building commissioner or building inspector may appeal to the corporate
authorities by serving written notice on the village clerk.
The building commissioner or building inspector shall take no further action on the matter pending the corporate authorities' decision, except for unsafe
signs which present an immediate and serious danger to the public.
This appeal shall be heard at the next regularly scheduled meeting of said corporate authorities, and that body may affirm, reverse, or modify the action
of the building commissioner or building inspector, or it may grant a variance to this chapter, subject to the provision of subsection (C) of this section.
(C) Grant Of Variance: The corporate authorities may grant a variance to this chapter, where said body finds that strict application of the provisions of this
chapter would result in practical difficulties or unnecessary hardships, but in no case shall a variance be granted for more than twenty five percent
(25%) increase in size, height, sign face area, or square footage, nor for more than twenty five percent (25%) decrease in required setback or for any
increase in number of signs or any change in sign illumination without a public hearing before the corporate authorities in compliance with subsection
4-4-4(O) of this chapter. Said variance shall run with the land which is the subject of the variance request, and the corporate authorities reserve the
right to grant said variance for a term of years or other term of limited duration. All requests or petitions for such variance shall be heard only after
application for same has been made by a petitioner on form for same to be supplied by the village and plans depicting proposed signage have been
provided to the village. Said application forms shall include information determined from time to time by the village building and zoning
commissioner/director of community development to be relevant, necessary and germane.
(D) Penalties: Any person who violates the provisions of this chapter shall be fined as established by the annual fee ordinance, and every such person
shall be deemed guilty of a separate offense for each day such violation shall continue, and shall be subject to the penalty provided hereunder for each
and every separate offense. (Ord. 2005-3891, 1-17-2005)
