Footnote 2: See chapter 2 of this title.
Chapter 5
FIRE CODE
4-5-1: ADOPTION OF FIRE CODE:
There is hereby adopted by the village, for the purpose of establishing rules and regulations governing conditions hazardous to life and property from fire
or explosion, and for the prevention and control of fire, the 2015 edition of the international fire code. The provisions of aforesaid code are incorporated
herein by reference and are further clarified in this chapter. The clarified provisions together with the aforesaid code and other provisions specifically
adopted herein shall be collectively known as the VILLAGE OF LISLE FIRE PREVENTION ORDINANCE of which one copy of the aforesaid code is on file
in the office of the village clerk, and is available for public use, inspection and examination. From the date on which this chapter shall take effect, the
provisions of the aforesaid code, as clarified by this chapter, shall be controlling within the corporate limits of the village. (Ord. 2016-4628, 1-4-2016)
4-5-2: BUREAU OF FIRE PREVENTION ESTABLISHED:
A bureau of fire prevention is hereby established for the purpose of enforcing this chapter. Said bureau of fire prevention shall be composed of the
community development director as chairman, and the chief of the Lisle/Woodridge fire protection district, or their designated representatives. (Ord. 98-
2978, 4-20-1998)
4-5-3: DEFINITIONS:
AUTHORITY HAVING JURISDICTION OR CHIEF OF THE FIRE PREVENTION BUREAU OR FIRE OFFICIAL OR FIRE PREVENTION BUREAU: The
community development director of the village of Lisle or his designee.
CORPORATE COUNSEL: The attorney for the village of Lisle, DuPage County, Illinois.
FIRE PREVENTION CODE OR CODE: The village of Lisle fire prevention ordinance in its entirety, including the codes adopted by reference herein.
MUNICIPALITY: The village of Lisle, DuPage County, Illinois. (Ord. 98-2978, 4-20-1998)
4-5-4: PROHIBITIONS EXCEPT BY SPECIAL PERMIT:
(A) Prohibited Storage Of Explosives And Blasting Agents: The storage, handling and use of explosives and blasting agents are hereby prohibited within
the corporate limits of the village except by special permit issued by the Lisle/Woodridge fire protection district.
(B) Prohibited Storage Of Flammable Liquids: The storage of flammable liquids in outside aboveground tanks is prohibited within the corporate limits of the
village except by special permit issued by the Lisle/Woodridge fire protection district.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 113/460
(C) Restricted Bulk Storage Of Liquefied Petroleum Gases: The bulk storage of liquefied petroleum gases in excess of five hundred (500) gallons' water
capacity is hereby prohibited within the corporate limits of the village, except by special permit issued by the Lisle/Woodridge fire protection district.
(D) Motor Vehicle Routes For Transporting Explosives And Blasting Agents: Vehicles transporting explosives and blasting agents are hereby prohibited
within the corporate limits of the village without a special permit issued by the Lisle/Woodridge fire protection district, with the exception of Interstate 88,
Interstate 355, Illinois Route 53, U.S. Route 34, Maple Avenue, Warrenville Road, and Yackley/College Road.
(E) Motor Vehicle Routes For Transporting Hazardous Chemicals And Other Dangerous Articles Including Liquefied Petroleum Gases And Combustible
And Flammable Liquids: Vehicles transporting hazardous chemicals or other dangerous articles are hereby prohibited within the corporate limits of the
village without a special permit issued by the Lisle/Woodridge fire protection district with the exception of Interstate 88, Interstate 355, Illinois Route 53,
U.S. Route 34, Maple Avenue, Warrenville Road, and Yackley/College Road. Additionally, no tank vehicles shall be parked for over one hour or left
unattended at any time within the corporate limits of the village. (Ord. 98-2978, 4-20-1998)
4-5-5: AMENDMENTS:
The fire code of the village of Lisle, as hereinbefore adopted, is amended in the following respects:
101.1 Title. Insert the village of Lisle as name of the jurisdiction.
103.0 Department Of Fire Prevention. Delete section in its entirety.
105.6.45 Temporary Membrane Structures And Tents. Amend section to read:
An operational permit is required to operate an air-supported temporary membrane structure, a temporary stage canopy or a tent requiring a permit
under section 4-9-1 of the village of Lisle code. Delete exceptions.
105.7.18 Temporary Membrane Structures And Tents. Amend section to read:
A construction permit is required to erect an air-supported temporary membrane structure, a temporary stage canopy or a tent requiring a permit
under section 4-9-1 of the village of Lisle code. Delete exceptions.
108.1 Board Of Appeals Established. Amend section to read:
The village of Lisle board of trustees shall serve as the fire code board of appeals.
111.1 Order. Amend section to read:
Where the fire code official finds any work regulated by this code being performed in a manner contrary to the provisions of this code, or in a
dangerous or unsafe manner, the building code official is authorized to issue a stop work order.
Section 202 Definitions. Amend definition of High-Rise Building to read:
High-Rise Building. A building with an occupied floor located more than 50 feet above the lowest level of fire department vehicle access.
307.6 Add the following section:
307.6 Open Burning Prohibited. Open burning of materials prohibited under village of Lisle code 8-3-1 is not permitted.
316.7 Add the following section:
316.7 Truss Markers. A truss marker emblem shall be provided at the fire department key box location on all new commercial building construction
that contain floor and/or roof trusses. The emblem shall be of a bright and reflective color, or made of reflective materials, in a shape and format
acceptable to the fire code official.
503.1.1 Buildings And Facilities. Delete section, including exceptions, in its entirety and replace with:
503.1.1 Required Fire Lanes. Public or private access shall be provided to each building so that the first responding fire department pumper unit will
be able to be so located that all points of the interior of the building may be reached by one hundred fifty (150) feet of initial attack hose. Where the
size or height of the building does not allow this regulation to be met, an approved interior standpipe system equipped with fire department hose
connections approved by the code official may be allowed as an exception. The standpipe system shall be connected to a public water system.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 114/460
506.3 Add the following section:
506.3 Hazardous Material Data. Where minimum reportable hazardous materials exist in a building, the emergency access key box shall contain
information as to the location of the required MSDS information within the building.
507.3 Fire Flow. Amend section to read:
507.3 Fire Flow. This section, in conjunction requirements of appendix B and C of this code, defines water supplies for fire department use for new
construction buildings and structures. All new buildings, structures, or developments shall be served by a public water supply system meeting this
criteria.
507.5.1 Where Required. Delete text including exceptions and replace with:
In conjunction with the fire hydrant spacing requirement of appendix C of this code, hydrants shall be located along public streets so that no portion
of a building will be over 300 feet from a fire hydrant. Where this is not possible, additional hydrants shall be located on the premises accessible to
motorized fire apparatus.
One hydrant shall be located at each street intersection and intermediate hydrants shall be provided where distance between intersections exceeds
400 feet.
In apartments, townhouses, condominiums, town/row or cluster housing areas where streets or parking lots dead end, hydrants shall be placed along
the access route.
At least two (2) fire hydrants shall be located within 300 feet of the building. Hydrants shall be located no closer than 25 feet to a building.
Additional fire hydrants shall be provided within 500 feet of the building so that the fire flow required divided by 1,000 will equal the number of
hydrants available.
Hydrants should be located approximately ten (10) feet from all-weather roadways. If this cannot be done, the closest part of the hydrant shall be set
back at least five (5) feet from the curb.
Access to fire hydrants shall be from all-weather roadways adequate in width, clearance and strength for firefighting purposes. Such routes including
private roadways, shall be maintained accessible during all seasons of the year. Legal provisions will be required for private roads.
Fire hydrants used in conjunction with water supplies shall meet the standards of the American Water Works Association standard no. C-502, and
shall have two (2-1/2) inch and one (4-1/2) inch outlets with auxiliary gate valves on the hydrant branch line. Threads shall be American national
standard. Pumper outlets shall face roadways.
Fire hydrants shall be protected from accidental damage by approved methods when located in areas subject to vehicular damage.
Where non-pressurized water systems are allowed, supplies shall be located not less than 300 feet from the building. Access to the supply shall be
by an all-weather roadway.
Water supplies including hydrant distribution for fully sprinklered buildings need only meet the design standard of NFPA 13, 2013 edition. Water
supplies for sprinkler systems may be supplied in accordance with NFPA 13, sprinkler systems, 2013 edition or in an equivalent manner.
603.3.1 Fuel Oil Storage In Outside, Above Ground Tanks. Delete text and replace with:
Above ground fuel oil storage is not permitted.
703.5 Add new section:
703.5 Hazardous Areas. All storage rooms, mechanical rooms, boiler rooms, electrical closets, fuel storage areas, janitors' closets, maintenance
shops, and kitchens shall be separated from other building areas by assemblies having a fire resistance rating of not less than one-hour with
appropriate protection of openings into the rooms.
Exception: Kitchen areas completely open and unobstructed to the adjacent dining and serving area on at least one side, and configured in such a
way so that a kitchen fire would be immediately known to all occupants of dining and serving area, and located within fire areas equipped with a
complete automatic fire suppression system, are exempt from the above requirement.
703.6 Add new section:
703.6 Tenant Separation. In multiple tenant occupancies, each tenant space shall be separated from other tenant spaces and exit access corridors
by walls, partitions, and floor-ceiling assemblies having at least one-hour approved fire resistance rating.
Exception: Shared office use tenant spaces not greater than 3,500 square feet in total gross area, located within buildings equipped with code
compliant automatic suppression and automatic fire alarm systems, shall be exempt from this requirement subject to compliance with all of the
following:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 115/460
1. All individual rooms within the space shall be used as business offices only. Beauty shops, clinics, educational uses, labs, print shops, doctor's
offices, retail and similar uses are not permitted in a shared office suite.
2. All shared office suites shall provide and maintain a common entry and common use general office area or lobby. Toilet facilities shall be
provided in conformance with requirements of the latest Illinois plumbing code.
3. Individual offices within the suite shall not be less than 100 square feet in area and shall comply with all environmental requirements for light and
ventilation.
4. A building or occupancy permit shall be obtained to establish the shared office suite as a permitted use. Thereafter, each tenant within the suite
shall obtain a separate occupancy permit in conformance with the requirements of sections 5-18-4 and 4-13-2 of the village code.
5. An office directory of current tenants shall be provided and maintained at the front entry to the shared office suites.

903.2.14 Add the following section:
Wood Frame Construction.
An automatic fire suppression system shall be provided throughout all wood frame buildings used for other than single family or duplex residential
use. Variations from this section may be considered by the board of appeals subject to the properties' compliance with the following:
(a) That the subject wood frame building is less than two thousand square feet (2,000') in gross floor area including all floors.
(b) That the subject wood frame building is separated by more than thirty (30) feet from all other buildings on surrounding properties.
(c) That the subject wood frame building is within three hundred feet (300') of at least two (2) separate fire hydrants.
(d) That the furnace room and storage room in the subject wood frame building be enclosed with one hour fire rated construction and a self-closing
forty-five (45) minute rated door.
(e) That the subject wood frame building be used for no use other than, or more hazardous than, an office use.
(f) That a complete automatic fire alarm system, including a fire alarm control panel, pull boxes located at the exit doors, audio-visual signaling
devices, heat detectors located in each room or space, and a direct tie to an approved central station be installed.
(g) That the subject wood frame building have two (2) direct exits to the outside.
(h) That the subject wood frame building complies with all other village codes for the proposed use.
903.3.1 Standards. Amend section to read:
Sprinkler systems shall be designed and installed in accordance with section 903.3.1.1, unless otherwise permitted by other chapters of this code, as
applicable. All sprinkler systems shall be designed with a 10psi or 10% safety factor, whichever is greater. Flexible sprinkler heads are not permitted.

907.2.24 Add the following section:
Where Required-Retroactive In Existing Buildings And Structures.
Fire alarm systems shall be installed and maintained in existing buildings in accordance with requirements of the life safety code (NFPA 101) as
adopted and amended by the village of Lisle.
New fire alarm systems installed in all existing use group R-2 occupancies, as required under applicable provisions of the life safety code, shall be
installed in conformance with the following specifications:
1. The fire alarm control panel (FACP) shall be located at the point of fire department entry, or may be remotely located provided an approved
remote annunciator with silence and reset capability is installed in its place.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 118/460
2. Manual pull stations shall be installed throughout the building in accordance with NFPA 72.
3. System smoke detectors shall be installed in all sleeping rooms, in all public corridors and stairwells, above the FACP, in all elevator shafts, in all
elevator lobbies, and in other areas as deemed necessary by the fire code official.
4. System heat detectors shall be installed in all public storage areas, in all mechanical/electrical/janitors closets, in all elevator shafts, in all closets
in excess of 50 square feet located within dwelling units, in other areas as deemed necessary by the fire code official.
5. Combination smoke and heat detectors shall be installed in the general living space of all dwelling units and in other areas as deemed
necessary by the fire code official. These devices shall be wired so as to act as a local smoke detector and a system heat detector for the dwelling
unit.
6. Audio/visual notification devices shall be installed throughout all public areas as per NFPA 72, as required by provisions of the Illinois
accessibility code, and in other areas as deemed necessary by the fire code official.
7. An audible notification device (sounder) shall be installed in each dwelling unit. Additional sounders may be necessary, or replaced with a/v
devices as approved by the fire code official, to achieve the required audio decibel levels in all areas of the unit.
907.8.6 Add the following section:
907.8.6 Battery Back-Up. All fire alarm systems shall be designed and installed with battery back-up power capable of 60 hours of standby followed
by 5 minutes of alarm.
907.10 Add the following section:
907.10 High-Rise Buildings. In buildings having floors used for human occupancy located more than 50 feet above the lowest level of fire
department vehicle access that are occupied for human occupancy, a separate zone by floor shall be provided for all of the following types of alarminitiating
devices where provided:
1. Smoke detectors.
2. Sprinkler water-flow devices.
3. Manual fire alarm boxes.
4. Other approved types of automatic fire detection devices or suppression systems.
907.11 Add the following section:
907.11 Outside Alerting Devices. All fire alarm and fire suppression systems shall have an outside alerting device (strobe) of a type and at a
location approved by the fire code official.
907.12 Add the following section:
907.12 Tenant Space Light. Each tenant space in a multiple tenant building shall have a light visible in a public access area indicating which tenant
space the activated detector is in or identified on an accessible enunciator or control panel. If tenant lights are used, then a strobe light shall be
installed above each designated apartment or tenant space entry door. The indicator light shall operate upon activation of a detector within the tenant
space.

4-5-6: DANGEROUS CONDITIONS:
In case there shall be, in the opinion of the fire official, a danger to life and property from the hazards of fire and explosion arising from the storage,
handling or use of hazardous substances, materials and devices, or from conditions hazardous to life or property in the use and/or occupancy of buildings
or premises, the fire official shall secure such necessary labor and machinery, equipment and devices and cause the necessary work to be done to render
occupants and property temporarily safe, whether or not the procedures prescribed in this section are implemented.
(A) Where practical and time constraints permit, the owner, occupant or other person in control of the area where the dangerous condition exists shall be
notified of the dangerous condition, and shall have the option of making the condition safe.
(B) If necessary to preserve the health, welfare and safety of the general public, the fire official shall take all necessary and proper action to remove or
mitigate the dangerous condition or emergency, including engaging contractors at a fee. The owner, occupants, and other persons in control of the area
where the dangerous condition exists shall be jointly and severally liable for any costs incurred by the village and Lisle/Woodridge fire district in
connection with their removal or mitigation of the dangerous condition.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 120/460
(C) The fire official of the village shall cause proper action to be taken against the owner of the premises, and the occupants if different from the owners,
for the recovery of costs incurred by the village and the Lisle/Woodridge fire protection district in the performance of their duties under this section.
(Ord. 98-2978, 4-20-1998)
4-5-7: PENALTY FOR VIOLATION:
(A) Any person who violates any provision of this fire prevention ordinance or who fails to comply with any of the requirements hereof shall be subject to a
fine as established by the annual fee ordinance in the case of a first violation, and by a fine as established by the annual fee ordinance for each and
every subsequent violation. Each day that a violation continues shall be deemed a separate violation.
(B) The application of the above penalty shall not prevent the enforced removal of prohibited conditions. (Ord. 98-2978, 4-20-1998)
Chapter 6
ELEVATOR SAFETY CODE
4-6-1: ADOPTION:
For the purpose of assuring that conveyances are correctly and safely installed and operated within the Village of Lisle, and in order to regulate the design,
installation, construction, operation, inspection, testing, maintenance, alteration, and repair of conveyances, including, but not limited to, elevators,
dumbwaiters, escalators, moving sidewalks, platform lifts, stairway chairlifts, and automated people movers, there is hereby adopted by the Village the
following codes, standards, and recommended practices:
(A) American Society of Mechanical Engineers (ASME), Three Park Avenue, New York, NY 10016-5990:
1. Safety Code for Elevators and Escalators (ASME A17.1-2013/CSA B44-2013) and Performance Based Safety Code for Elevators and Escalators
(ASME A17.7-2007/CSA B44.7-07);
2. Guide for Inspection of Elevators, Escalators, and Moving Walks (ASME 17.2-2010);
3. Safety Code for Existing Elevators and Escalators (ASME A17.3-2005), but only as required under section 35(h) and (i) of the State of Illinois
Elevator Safety Act and subsection (d) of section 1000.60 of the Illinois General Assembly's Administrative Code;
4. Safety Standard for Platform Lifts and Stairway Chairlifts (ASME A18.1-2011);
5. Standard for the Qualification of Elevator Inspectors (ASME QE1-2013).
(B) American Society of Civil Engineers (ASCE), 1801 Alexander Bell Drive, Reston, VA 20191-4400: Automated People Mover Standards (ANSI/ASCE/T
& D1 21-13).
All the above codes, standards and recommended practices are incorporated as of the date specified and include no later editions or amendments, and
are hereby referred to, adopted and made part hereof as if fully set out in this chapter, with the additions, insertions, deletions and changes prescribed
in section 4-6-3 of this chapter, and from the date on which this chapter shall take effect, the provisions thereof shall be controlling within the Village.
One copy of all referenced documents has been and is now filed in the Office of the Village Clerk. (Ord. 2018-4778, 8-6-2018)
4-6-2: INSPECTIONS; FEES:
(A) No passenger or freight elevator shall be operated until it is tested, inspected and approved as to its safety. An application fee, to compensate the
Village for initial inspection services, in an amount as established by the annual fee ordinance per elevator, shall be due and payable prior to the
issuance of building permits.
(B) For each conveyance, there shall be an annual inspection fee in the amount as established by the annual fee ordinance payable June 1 of each year.
(C) Inspection and testing shall be conducted by an elevator inspector authorized by the Community Development Director. After making the inspection,
the inspector shall affix a certificate of inspection to the elevator. If the inspector finds that the elevator is unsafe, he shall order that the elevator not be
used until the deficiencies are corrected. The inspector shall immediately report a finding of lack of safety to the Community Development Director who
shall immediately give notice of the unsafe elevator to the owner. (Ord. 2018-4778, 8-6-2018)
4-6-3: AMENDMENTS:
The Elevator Safety Code of the Village, as hereinbefore adopted, is amended in the following respects:
(A) All elevators, dumbwaiters, escalators, moving sidewalks, platform lifts, stairway chairlifts, and automated people movers regulated by this code,
except those conveyances in single-family dwellings, shall be tested and inspected as to its safety at least twice within a one year period; such
inspections to be at least five (5) months apart.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 121/460
(B) All conveyances shall have the inspector's certification clearly posted within the elevator car or lift, or shall be displayed near the main entrance to the
conveyance, within clear view of users of the conveyance.
(C) All upgrades required by application of the safety code for existing elevators and escalators must be completed no later than January 1, 2009, except
that upgrades to the hydraulic cylinder system and the firefighter control system must be completed by January 1, 2011. (Ord. 2018-4778, 8-6-2018)
4-6-4: VIOLATION; PENALTY:
It shall be a violation of this chapter to:
(A) Fail to pay the application or inspection fee;
(B) Fail to affix the inspector's certification within the elevator;
(C) Operate or allow to be operated an elevator prior to initial inspection and approval;
(D) Operate or allow to be operated an elevator found unsafe by the elevator inspector;
(E) Operate or allow to be operated an elevator not in compliance with the codes, standards, and recommended practices set forth in this chapter; or
(F) Resist or oppose the enforcement of any of the provisions of this chapter.
Any person violating or resisting or opposing the enforcement of any of the provisions of this chapter, including the Safety Codes adopted by reference and
made a part hereof, shall be fined as established by the annual fee ordinance for each offense. Each day such violation shall continue shall constitute a
separate and distinct offense; and any builder or contractor who shall construct any building in violation of the provisions of this chapter, and any architect
who shall design, draw plans for or have supervision of such building, or who shall permit it to be constructed, and any owner of such property where the
conveyance exists and who allows its operation and use shall be liable for the penalties provided and imposed by this chapter. (Ord. 2018-4778, 8-6-2018)

Chapter 8
NUMBERING BUILDINGS
4-8-1: NUMBERING SYSTEM ADOPTED:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 123/460
All buildings in the village shall be numbered as hereinafter set forth. (Ord. 37, 3-18-1958; amd. Ord. 86-1482, 10-6-1986)
Buildings fronting on the west side of streets running north and south and on the north side of streets running east and west shall bear even numbers; and
buildings fronting on the east side of streets running north and south, and on the south side of streets running east and west shall bear odd numbers. (Ord.
37, 3-18-1958)
4-8-2: MAPS ON FILE:
Maps and plats showing the number assigned to each building, lot and parcel of property in the village are on file in the village hall, and the numbers on
such maps and plats are hereby adopted and assigned as the official numbers to designate the street addresses of the respective buildings, lots and
parcels shown thereon. (Ord. 37, 3-18-1958)
4-8-3: NUMBERS ASSIGNED:
The building and zoning commissioner, upon request, shall furnish the owner of all existing buildings with the number assigned to such building, as shown
upon said maps and plats, and upon application for a building permit, the building commissioner shall assign a number for the building to be erected,
pursuant to such permit. (Ord. 86-1482, 10-6-1986)
4-8-4: NUMBERS REQUIRED:
Owners and occupants of all buildings in the village are hereby required to procure from the village the numbers assigned to their respective buildings, and
to paint and otherwise affix to the front door adjacent to the street or to some other conspicuous place on the building and visible from the public right of
way, said numbers in plain and legible figures, not less than three inches (3") in height, and to maintain said numbers ingood condition. Additionally,
owners of all nonresidential buildings must affix said numbers to any rear or service doors. (Ord. 86-1482, 10-6-1986)
4-8-5: AMORTIZATION SCHEDULE:
All owners and occupants of all buildings existing in the village on May 1, 1987, shall conform said building to the provisions set forth herein by no later
than September 1, 1987. (Ord. 86-1482, 10-6-1986)
4-8-6: FAILURE TO COMPLY WITH CHAPTER:
Any owner or occupant failing or refusing to comply with the provisions of this chapter shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, and shall be fined as established
by the annual fee ordinance for each offense. A separate offense shall be deemed committed upon each day that such violation continues. (Ord. 96-2776,
5-20-1996)
Chapter 9
TENTS
4-9-1: PERMITS REQUIRED:
(A) Except as is set forth in sections 5-3-4, 5-4-4, 5-5-4 and 5-6-4 of this code, no person or organization shall proceed to construct or erect a tent or make
alterations to an existing tent without first having obtained a permit therefor, said permit issued and signed by the building official upon approval of the
application.
Exceptions:
1. Tents less than two hundred (200) square feet in area and with a capacity or so used to accommodate ten (10) or less persons.
2. Fabric canopies open on all sides and less than seven hundred (700) square feet in area.
3. Tents used exclusively for recreational camping purposes.
4. Funeral tents and curtains or extensions attached thereto, when used for funeral services.
Should any work for which a permit is required be commenced or be done before such permit is issued and obtained, the required permit may be
issued for such and subsequent work, however, the amount of the required fee as provided herein for all work shall be double that otherwise so
provided. The issuance of such permit does not act to bar any other penalty, liability or action otherwise provided for in this chapter or village code
but shall be in addition thereto.
Application for a permit shall be in writing in a form supplied by the building official. Such applications shall include a site plan indicating the
proposed tent location including dimensions from the tent to surrounding buildings and property lines, a basic floor plan depicting the proposed use
and configuration of the interior of the tent, and a certificate of flame resistance for the tent. Approval of the permit application and subsequent
issuance of thetent permit shall serve to authorize inspection of the tent by village officials. The building official may require such additional
information as he deems necessary to substantiate the safety of the proposed use of any material or assembly.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 124/460
(B) Fees for the permits are as follows: Fees shall be assessed in accordance with the annual fee ordinance as amended from time to time by the village
of Lisle. (Ord. 2007-4166, 12-17-2007, eff. 1-17-2008)
4-9-2: LOCATION:
Tents shall be located so as to provide safe means of egress around the tent and so as to minimize potential spread of fire from one structure to another.
Tents may be constructed and used as temporary shelter only subject to conformance with the following requirements:
(A) No tent shall be constructed closer than ten feet (10') to a property line or building.
(B) All adjacent tents shall be spaced a minimum of ten feet (10') between stake lines but not less than the required width for egress between tents.
Exception: Tents, each not exceeding one thousand two hundred (1,200) square feet in area and located in fairgrounds or similar open spaces, shall
not be required to be separated from each other, provided that safety precautions meet the approval of the authority having jurisdiction. (Ord. 2007-
4166, 12-17-2007, eff. 1-17-2008)
4-9-3: CONSTRUCTION:
Specific requirements for tents other than air supported tents:
(A) All supporting members shall be of sufficient size and strength to support the structure.
(B) The poles and their supporting guys, stakes, fastenings, etc., shall be of sufficient strength and attached so as to resist a minimum wind pressure of
twenty (20) pounds per square foot of projected areas of the tent.
(C) Tents shall be adequately guyed, supported, and braced to withstand a minimum pressure of suction of ten (10) pounds per square foot.
(D) Pull down ropes on center poles and side poles on push-pull tents shall be provided. (Ord. 2007-4166, 12-17-2007, eff. 1-17-2008)
4-9-4: CAPACITY AND EGRESS SAFETY STANDARDS:
(A) General:
1. The permitted capacity within any tent shall not exceed one person per ten (10) square feet (net) of floor area.
2. The occupant load in bench seating areas shall be determined at one person per eighteen inches (18") of seating.
(B) Egress; General Requirements:
1. General: Each tent shall provide at least one means of exit for every two hundred (200) people, but in no event shall any tent provide less than two
(2) exits. Further, said exits shall be located in a position remote one from the other. Battery backup illuminated exit signs shall be provided to identify
each required exit when serving an occupant load of one hundred (100) or more persons. Additional directional signs may be required so as to
indicate the proper direction of egress.
2. Exits: No turnstiles, revolving doors, or other devices to restrict the movement of persons shall be installed at any required exit in such a manner as
to interfere with the exit facilities. Doorways or openings serving as required exits or passageways shall be not less than thirty four inches (34") in
clear width, nor less in width than the required width of the exit access served. Where several ways serve as an exit access, each shall have a width
suitable for the traffic but not less than thirty four inches (34") in clear width.
3. Arrangement Of Means Of Egress: Aisles at seating areas shall be provided and maintained in conformance with current requirements of the
building code. Aisles from seating arrangements that do not lead directly to an exit discharge shall discharge into an unobstructed space leading
directly to one or more exit discharges, and shall be so arranged as to be conveniently accessible to every occupant; and such space shall have a
clear width not less than the required width of the exit to which it leads, but in no case less than five feet (5'). A maximum one hundred foot (100')
travel distance to an approved exit is allowed.
4. Illumination Of Means Of Egress: Tents used as places of assembly shall be kept adequately illuminated at all times when such structures are
occupied by the public. Artificial light shall be provided whenever natural light is less than one foot-candle measured at the means of egress walking
surface.
(C) Seating:
1. All seating shall be configured in conformance with the current requirements of the village of Lisle building code.
(D) Guards And Rails:
1. Guards and railings shall be provided in conformance with the current requirements of the village of Lisle building code. (Ord.2007-4166, 12-17-
2007, eff. 1-17-2008)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 125/460
4-9-5: FIRE SAFETY STANDARDS:
(A) General:
1. All applicable provisions of the village of Lisle building code, life safety code, fire code, and electrical code, as they pertain to fire and life safety, are
incorporated herein.
(B) Fire Hazard:
1. The ground enclosed by any structure used in connection with a place of assembly, and for a reasonable distance, but not less than ten feet (10')
outside of such structure or structures, shall be cleared of all flammable or combustible material or vegetation. The premises shall be kept free from
such flammable or combustible materials during the period for which the premises are used by the public.
2. No hay, straw, shavings, or similar combustible materials shall be permitted within any structure used for public assembly.
3. No excessive amount of combustible material, other than tables and chairs serving the occupants of a tent, are permitted inside or within ten feet
(10') of a tent used for assembly purposes.
4. Smoking and open flames are prohibited inside or within ten feet (10') of a tent.
(C) Fire Extinguishing Equipment:
1. Fire extinguishing equipment of approved types shall be furnished and maintained by the person operating, conducting, or promoting any place of
assembly, and in all tents housing food cooking or warming equipment, in such amount and in such locations as may be directed by the authority
having jurisdiction.
(a) Fire extinguishers shall be provided for every three thousand (3,000) square feet of enclosed surface, or fraction thereof.
(b) Fire extinguishing equipment shall be maintained in good working order in accordance with the standard for portable fire extinguishers, NFPA 10.
(c) Employees of places of assembly shall be properly trained to operate fire extinguishing equipment and shall be required to exhibit their skill when
requested by the authority having jurisdiction.
(D) Emergency Communications: One or more methods of fire emergency communication, as approved by the authority having jurisdiction, shall be
provided for tents having a capacity of one hundred (100) or more people.
(E) Electrical: The electrical system and equipment shall be isolated from the public by proper elevation or guarding, and all electrical fuses and switches
shall be installed in approved enclosures. Cables on the ground in areas traversed by the public shall be placed in trenches or protected by approved
covers. All electrical equipment shall be UL listed for the service conditions.
(F) Flame Resistance Of Tent Material:
1. All tent fabric shall meet the requirements of the small scale test contained in the standard methods of fire tests for flame resistant textiles and films,
NFPA 701.
2. The building official may require a certificate or other evidence of approval by a laboratory of recognized standing, or he may accept the report of
tests made by other inspection authorities as evidence that the tent fabric materials have the required flame resistance.
3. The building official may also require confirmatory field tests using specimens from the original material affixed at the time of manufacture to the
exterior of the tent. The test specimen shall consist of a full width of material which has been cut into test strips one and one-half inches by four
inches (11/2" x 4"). (Ord. 2007-4166, 12-17-2007, eff. 1-17-2008)
4-9-6: BLEACHERS, FOLDING AND TELESCOPIC SEATING, AND GRANDSTANDS:
(A) General:
1. All bleachers, folding and telescopic seating, and grandstands shall be constructed, installed, and maintained in conformance with the currently
adopted edition of ICC 300, standard on bleachers, folding and telescopic seating, and grandstands as referenced by the village of Lisle building
code. (Ord. 2007-4166, 12-17-2007, eff. 1-17-2008)
4-9-7: REVOCATION OF PERMIT:
(A) The community development director, or his designee, may revoke a tent permit for violation of any of the regulations listed herein. Immediately upon
such revocation, written notice thereof shall be given by the building official to the holder of the permit by certified or registered mail, or in person. Upon
receipt of said notice of revocation, all use of said tent shall cease, and the holder of the permit shall immediately remove the tent from the premises
and restore the premises to its original condition. (Ord. 2007-4166, 12-17-2007, eff. 1-17-2008)
4-9-8: MEANS OF APPEAL OR VARIATION:
(A) Any person shall have the right to appeal a decision of the code official or request a variation from the terms of this code before the board of appeals.
An application for appeal shall be based on a claim that the true intent of this code or the rules legally adopted thereunder have been incorrectly
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 126/460
interpreted, the provisions of this code do not fully apply, or an equivalent form of construction is to be used. The board of appeals shall grant variations
from the strict application of any of the requirements of this code in the case of exceptional conditions, whereby such strict application would result in
practical difficulty or unnecessary hardship that would deprive the owner of reasonable use of the land or building involved. In granting any variation,
the board of appeals shall prescribe any conditions that it deems to be necessary or desirable. The board shall affirm, modify, or reverse the decision of
the code official by a majority vote. The board of appeals shall be the village of Lisle president and board of trustees and the chairman of the board of
appeals shall be the president, also known as the mayor, of the village of Lisle. (Ord. 2007-4166, 12-17-2007, eff. 1-17-2008)
4-9-9: PENALTIES:
Any party violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be fined as established by the annual fee ordinance for each offense. A separate offense shall
be deemed committed for each day in which the violation occurs or continues to occur. (Ord. 2007-4166, 12-17-2007, eff. 1-17-2008)

If the work described in any mechanical permit has not begun within ninety (90) days from the date of issuance thereof, or the work has stopped for
any ninety (90) day period, said permit shall expire and be canceled by the code official and written notice thereof shall be given to the persons
affected. If the work described in any mechanical permit has not been substantially completed within two (2) years of the date of issuance thereof,
said permit shall expire and be canceled by the code official and written notice thereof shall be given to the persons affected, together with notice
that further work as described in the canceled permit shall not proceed unless and until a special building permit has been obtained. At the discretion
of the code official, such special permit may be based on the original application or he may require submission of a new application. This special
permit may include limitations on time allowed for substantial completion of the work, and provisions for reasonable performance bond to insure
completion within the time limits set.

1-3 of the village code. No plan review fees will be refunded. For all mechanical projects wherein no work has occurred within the prescribed
deadline, the mechanical permit shall be terminated and fifty percent (50%) of the required permit fees shall be refunded. For all mechanical projects
wherein work has begun and has stopped for any reason, no part of the required mechanical permit fee will be refunded upon expiration of the
mechanical permit.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 127/460
108.4 Violation Penalties. Amend section to read:

mechanical work in violation of the approved construction documents or directive of the code official, or of a permit or certificate issued under the

person doing the work. The notice shall state the conditions under which work is authorized to resume. Where an emergency exists, the code official
shall not be required to give a written notice prior to stopping the work. Any person who shall continue any work after having been served with a stop
work order, except such work as that person is directed to perform to remove a violation or unsafe condition, shall be liable to a fine as established
by the annual fee ordinance. Each day that a violation continues shall be deemed a separate offense.

of this code before the board of appeals. An application for appeals shall be based on a claim that the true intent of this code or the rules legally
adopted thereunder have been incorrectly interpreted, the provisions of this code do not fully apply, or an equivalent form of construction is to be
used. The board of appeals shall grant variations from the strict application of any of the requirements of this code in the case of exceptional
conditions, whereby such strict application would result in practical difficulty or unnecessary hardship that would deprive the owner of reasonable use
of a mechanical system or building. In granting any variation, the board of appeals shall prescribe any conditions that it deems to be necessary or
desirable. The board shall affirm, modify, or reverse the decision of the code official by a majority vote. The board of appeals shall be the village of
Lisle president and board of trustees and the chairman of the board of appeals shall be the president, also known as the mayor, of the village of
Lisle.

have the meanings ascribed to them as in those codes or ordinances.

and floodplain regulations.

in the village of Lisle building code and fire prevention code. Where an assembly is required to have both fire dampers and smoke dampers,
combination dampers or a fire damper and a smoke damper shall be required.

4-11-3: MULTIPLE-FAMILY RESIDENTIAL RENTAL PROPERTY OCCUPANCY PERMITS AND INSPECTIONS:
(A) Purpose: The Village Board of Trustees hereby establishes the following occupancy permit and inspection program of multiple-family residential rental
properties so as to protect the public health, safety and welfare of the people of the Village, and
To protect the public health and safety by ensuring rental units comply with minimum housing standards of Village ordinances; and, to correct and
prevent housing conditions that adversely affect or are likely to adversely affect the life, safety, general welfare and health, including the physical,
mental and social well being of persons occupying the dwellings;
To protect the character and stability of residential areas; to facilitate the enforcement of minimum standards for the maintenance of existing residential
buildings; and, to preserve the value of land and buildings throughout the Village;
To promote proper occupancy of dwellings by requiring compliance with minimum space standards per occupant for each dwelling unit.
(B) Definitions:
CONDOMINIUMS: Property subject to the Condominium Property Act.
DWELLING UNIT OR UNIT: A single unit providing complete, independent living facilities for one single "family" as defined by section 5-1-7 of this
Code, including permanent provisions for living, sleeping, eating, cooking and sanitation. Storage areas or lockers in, connected, or adjacent to an
individual unit are included as part of a "dwelling unit" or "unit" for the purposes of this section.
MULTIPLE-FAMILY RESIDENTIAL RENTAL PROPERTY (Hereinafter MRP): A building or buildings on one parcel of property containing more than
three (3) rental dwelling units.
PERSON: Any individual, firm, association, partnership, corporation, trust or any other legal entity.
TOWNHOUSE: Type of dwelling unit normally having two (2), but sometimes three (3), stories; usually connected to a similar structure by a common
wall, and commonly sharing and owning in common the surrounding grounds, sometimes also known as a row house, i.e., horizontally attached and
vertically separated.
(C) Multiple-Family Residential Rental Property Dwelling Unit Occupancy Permits Required:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 130/460
1. It is unlawful for any person to occupy within the Village a vacant MRP dwelling unit without first obtaining an occupancy permit as provided in this
section.
2. It is unlawful for a person to occupy an MRP dwelling unit, or for any owner or property agent to allow anyone to occupy an MRP dwelling unit which
is without an occupancy permit as provided in this section.
3. This section shall not apply to the following structures:
(a) Single-family residences.
(b) Multiple-family residential rental property with four (4) or less rental dwelling units if the property is owner occupied.
(c) Owner occupied townhouses and condominiums.
(d) Hotels, motels, and other structures which rent rooms to occupants which are primarily transient in nature, and making use of the facilities for a
period of less than thirty (30) days.
(e) Dwellings, buildings, structures and uses licensed and inspected by the State or the Federal government, including, but not limited to, nursing
homes, retirement centers and rest homes.
(D) Owner Registration: No occupancy permit required by this section shall be issued unless a true and correct written application is on file with the
Community Development Director. A complete application shall be filed prior to the issuance of any occupancy permit. Application forms may be
obtained from the Community Development Director and shall contain such information as the Community Development Director may, from time to
time, require, including, but not limited to:
1. Full legal name, address, and telephone numbers of each and any owner of the MRP. When the owner is a land trust, the application shall include
the full legal name, address, and telephone numbers of each person(s) holding a beneficial interest and/or power of direction therein.
2. Full legal name, address, and telephone numbers of any person appointed as managing agent of the MRP. If the managing agent is other than a
natural person, the above information shall also be provided for that employee of the managing agent specifically assigned to the MRP.
3. The address of the MRP.
4. The number of dwelling units within the MRP.
5. In the case of an owner of an MRP who is not a resident of the Village, the full legal name, address, work and home telephone numbers of his or her
agent with authority for receipt of service or notice of violation of the provisions of this section.
6. The following statement granting consent to inspections:
By signing this registration application owner consents to permit the Village of Lisle through its inspectors to enter upon the MRP for purposes of
making the inspections required and/or permitted under Title 4, Chapter 11 of the Village of Lisle Code, including the right to inspect unoccupied
individual dwelling units.
(E) Permit Fees: Upon issuance of each occupancy permit, the Village shall charge the owner of the MRP a fee as established by the annual fee
ordinance per permit. The fee shall be paid within thirty (30) days after receipt of invoice. The fee shall be waived if the actual inspection was not
performed by the Village. If the owner fails to pay as required, the Village shall not issue further permits until full payment is made.
(F) Dwelling Unit Inspections Required:
1. Compliance Required: Every MRP shall be owned, operated and maintained in full compliance with all applicable ordinances of the Village.
2. Inspections: Upon vacancy of each dwelling unit, the MRP owner shall obtain an occupancy permit prior to reoccupancy in accordance with this
section.
3. Dwelling Unit Standards: Dwelling units of MRPs will be inspected for compliance with the Village ordinance. Inspections will include, but are not
limited to, matters pertaining to the standards listed below:
(a) Occupancy limited to single-family as defined by section 5-1-7 of this Code.
(b) Properly working smoke detectors, heat detectors and sprinklers where applicable.
(c) No doors or windows missing or broken and all hardware proper and operable and no screens missing, broken or inoperable.
(d) Ceilings, walls and floors with no evidence of structural or material failure.
(e) All ceiling, wall and floor finishes free of unsafe materials or defects.
(f) All electrical fixtures and outlets operate properly, cover plates properly installed, no bad wiring or improper use of extension cords, electrical
panel clear, accessible and clearly labeled.
(g) All plumbing fixtures and piping operate properly free of leaks, obstructions and defects; and valves properly operable, hot water one hundred ten
degrees Fahrenheit (110F) available.
(h) All appliances, including, but not limited to, the furnace, hot water heater, electrical boxes, washer, dryer, oven, range, dishwasher and garbage
disposal properly operable and connected and have proper clearances pursuant to requirements of utility companies and code.
(i) No accumulation of garbage, refuse or combustible materials.
(j) No insect or rodent infestation.
(k) No modification of the MRP or any unit in violation of Village ordinances or building permits or codes.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 131/460
(G) Dwelling Unit Inspection Procedure:
1. Inspection Procedure: On every first business day of the month, each owner of an MRP shall provide to the Village a report which lists all units
currently vacant or expected to become vacant within the applicable month. The list shall include expected vacancy dates.
Within two (2) business days after receipt of the report, the Village shall designate which units it anticipates inspecting ("inspection units") and which
units will be granted permits upon receipt of an inspection form ("form units").
Upon notice to the managing agent, the Village shall issue occupancy permits for dwelling units it has designated as form units immediately upon
receipt of an inspection form properly signed.
The Village shall inspect each inspection unit, and shall inspect each form unit except those form units for which the owner has provided an
inspection form. Inspections shall be made within two (2) business days after receipt of the owner's request for an inspection but not later than the
last business day of each month.
In the event that an inspection unit remains or becomes occupied prior to the Village inspection, the Village shall designate an alternate unoccupied
unit, if available, to be inspected by the Village.
If there are not enough alternate unoccupied units to replace each inspection unit which has remained or has become occupied prior to Village
inspection, the owner shall, for that month, make all unoccupied units available for inspection.
If there are no units made available for inspection within any ninety (90) day period, the Village shall not issue any occupancy permits for the MRP
until it inspects the next available vacant unit.
2. Inspection Form:
(a) The owner may, at its discretion, submit to the Village an inspection form for units designated by the Village. The inspection form shall be in the
following form:

3. Facsimile Notices: Notice of vacancies and correspondence between the Village and the owners or their designees shall be in writing. If sent via
facsimile the notice shall be deemed received if the sender has documented confirmation that the fax transmission was properly transmitted.
4. Permit Issuance Or Remedial Action: Upon inspection of a dwelling unit the Village shall immediately issue an occupancy permit if the inspection
discloses no violations of the codes or ordinances of the Village.
(H) Violations:
1. Whenever, upon Village inspection of a dwelling unit, it is determined that conditions or practices exist which are in violation of the provisions of this
section or any other applicable ordinance of the Village including, but not limited to, the 2015 International Property Maintenance Code, as
incorporated into Village ordinances, the Village shall serve the owner with a notice of violation. Said notice shall include the following:
(a) Description of the property sufficient for identification;
(b) A statement listing the violations of applicable ordinances;
(c) A statement of the date upon which the reinspection will occur; and
(d) An explanation that if upon completion of the reinspection the requirements of applicable Village ordinances have not been met, the dwelling unit
shall not be occupied or reoccupied.
Such notice shall state that unless the violations are corrected within sixty (60) days, the owner shall be cited. Notice pursuant to this section may
be sent by facsimile, U.S. certified mail or hand delivered to the party designated in the application to receive notices and process.
2. At the end of the time allowed for correction of any violation cited or within two (2) business days after written notice from the owner that the violation
has been corrected, the dwelling unit shall be reinspected by the Village. If the dwelling unit meets the requirements of the applicable ordinances, an
occupancy permit shall be issued. If it is determined that the conditions have not been corrected, or they are not in the process of being corrected to
the satisfaction of the Community Development Director, or his designee, the Village may issue an ordinance citation. If the Village does not
reinspect the unit within the applicable time period and if a proper inspection form is supplied by the owner, an occupancy permit shall be issued.
3. Notwithstanding the foregoing, if a dwelling unit is found to be unfit for human occupancy or if there are major life/safety violations, the affected
dwelling unit(s) must remain vacant until the conditions causing the violations are corrected and the reinspection in accordance with reasonable
emergency deadlines set by the Community Development Director, or his designee, has been successfully completed.
4. If any owner, property agent, occupant or other person in control of an MRP or a dwelling unit contained therein fails or refuses to consent to free
access and entry to the property or dwelling unit under his control for any inspection pursuant to this section, the Village may apply to the Circuit
Court for a search warrant or other appropriate court order authorizing such inspections.
5. The following shall constitute violations of this section:
(a) Failure of the owner or owners of an MRP to report vacancies as required by this section.
(b) Failure of the occupants of an MRP to vacate such property within sixty (60) days after receiving notice from the Village that such occupancy is
not properly permitted pursuant to this section.
(c) Failure of the owner of the MRP to vacate all tenants from a dwelling unit lacking an occupancy permit if required by this section within sixty (60)
days after notification of the Village to do so.
(d) Failure of the owners of the MRP and all dwelling units to maintain the structure and premises in compliance with applicable codes and
ordinances.
(e) Knowingly submitting to the Village a false statement on a vacancy report or inspection form.
(I) Owner Liability For Acts And Omissions: Every act or omission of whatsoever nature constituting a violation of any provision of this section by any
officer, director, manager, trustee, employer, agent or managing agent of any owner shall be deemed to be the act of such owner and such owner shall
be punishable in the same manner if such act or omission had been done or omitted by owner personally.
(J) Auditing: If there is a reasonable suspicion of a violation of this section, the owner and manager of an MRP, upon reasonable notice from the Village,
shall allow the Village to audit its vacancy and occupancy records relevant to compliance with this section. No permits shall be issued during any period
in which an owner or manager refuses such an audit.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 133/460
(K) Penalties: Any person who shall violate any provisions of this section shall, upon conviction thereof, be subject to a fine as established by the annual
fee ordinance, at the discretion of the court. Each day that a violation continues after due notice has been served shall be deemed a separate offense.
(Ord. 2019-4818, 4-15-2019)
Chapter 12
ENERGY CONSERVATION CODE
4-12-1: ADOPTION:
There is hereby adopted by the village of Lisle for the purpose of establishing rules and regulations for the construction, alteration, equipment, use and
occupancy, location and maintenance of building construction in accordance with proper energy conservation methods, including permits and penalties
that certain energy code known as the international energy conservation code (IECC) being particularly the 2015 edition thereof, and the whole thereof,
save and except such portions as deleted, modified or amended by the state of Illinois, of which not less than three (3) copies have been and now are filed
in the office of the village clerk and the same are hereby adopted and incorporated as fully as if set out at length herein, and from the date on which this
chapter shall take effect, the provisions thereof shall be controlling within the village. (Ord. 2016-4630, 2-1-2016)
4-12-2: AMENDMENTS:
The 2015 energy conservation code has been adopted by the state of Illinois. The village of Lisle has not adopted any local amendments to the 2015
energy conservation code. (Ord. 2016-4630, 2-1-2016)
4-12-3: APPEALS:
The procedures for a variation or appeal from this code shall be the same as those set forth in the building code of the village. (Ord. 2016-4630, 2-1-2016)
4-12-4: PENALTIES:
Any person who violates a provision of this code or fails to comply with any of the requirements thereof or who erects, constructs, alters or repairs a
building or structure in violation of the approved construction documents or directive of the building official, or of a permit or certificate issued under the
provisions of this code, shall be subject to penalties as prescribed by law. Each day that a violation continues shall be deemed a separate offense. (Ord.
2016-4630, 2-1-2016)
Chapter 13
LIFE SAFETY CODE
4-13-1: ADOPTION:
There is hereby adopted by the village for the purpose of establishing minimum requirements for the design, operation, and maintenance of both new and
existing buildings and structures for safety to life from fire and similar emergencies, that certain code known as the life safety code specifically identified as
national fire protection agency (NFPA) 101, 2003 edition. The provisions of the aforesaid code are incorporated herein by reference and are further
clarified in this chapter together with other provisions specifically adopted herein shall be collectively known as the village of Lisle life safety code of which
three (3) copies of the aforesaid code have been on file for at least fifteen (15) days prior to the adoption hereof and are now on file in the office of the
village clerk, and have been there kept available for public use, inspection and examination, and at the same time are hereby adopted and incorporated as
fully as if set out at length herein. From the date on which this chapter shall take effect, the provisions of the aforesaid code, as clarified by this chapter,
shall be controlling within the corporate limits of the village. (Ord. 2006-4044, 8-7-2006)
4-13-2: AMENDMENTS:
The life safety code of the village, as hereinbefore adopted, is amended as follows: (Ord. 2006-4044, 8-7-2006)
Chapter 3, Definitions, is amended to:
3.3.60.2 Existing Operational Fire Alarm System. An existing fire alarm system continuously monitored by an approved central station and equipped
with: pull stations at each required exit door, hard wired smoke detection devices in all common areas of the building, approved hard wired fire detection
devices in the living area of each dwelling unit, smoke detection and notification devices installed in conformance with section 31.3.4.5.1 of this code, and
audio notification from the fire alarm panel capable of providing a minimum 70 decibels of sound in all common and most remote sleeping room of each
dwelling unit.
3.3.60.3 Existing Non-Conforming Fire Alarm System. An existing fire alarm system permitted and installed in conformance with the requirements of
the applicable fire alarm and/or building code at the time of installation and approved by the authority having jurisdiction over such installations at that time.
Fire alarm systems installed in buildings not under the jurisdiction of the village of Lisle at time of installation shall not be considered to be legal existing
non-conforming systems unless expressly accepted and approved as part of an annexation agreement.
3.3.60.4 Substantial Repair Or Upgrade. Any change, repair, or modification to an existing fire alarm system involving replacement of an obsolete fire
alarm panel, replacement of system devices beyond routine replacement of individual defective devices, or expansion of the existing system, constitutes a
substantial repair or upgrade to the system. Existing fire alarm system components shall not be repaired, modified, or reconfigured in such a way so as to
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 134/460
extend their useful life for the purpose of avoiding necessary improvements to the fire alarm system. Individual alarm components that are damaged due to
an electrical disturbance or abnormality, a leak in the building envelope, a leak in the plumbing system, or which are accidentally physically damaged may
be repaired or replaced and shall not constitute a substantial repair or upgrade to the existing system.
(Ord. 2008-4196, 4-21-2008)

4-13-3: NONCONFORMITIES:
Any building or structure which does not conform to the regulations contained within this chapter at the time it becomes applicable to such building or
structure shall comply in conformance with the following amortization schedule:
(A) Fire Alarm Or Fire Suppression Nonconformity: All existing buildings or structures shall comply with the fire alarm and fire suppression requirements of
this code within three (3) years from the effective date of this chapter.
(B) Means Of Egress Nonconformity: All existing buildings or structures shall comply with the egress requirements of this code within two (2) years from
the effective date of this chapter.
Nothing in this section shall be interpreted or misconstrued so as to allow any existing building to be renovated or changed from its existing condition or
use so as to be any less conforming than already existing without compliance to the requirements of this code. Any renovation work directly impacting
the fire alarm system, fire suppression system, or means of egress of any existing building shall be performed in full conformance with the
requirements of this chapter and shall not be exempt from conformance under this section.
When provisions of this section require compliance by a certain date, that date shall be the date for village approval and acceptance of the completed
system. Submittal of working plans and actual system installation shall occur in advance of the stated date for compliance. (Ord. 2006-4044, 8-7-2006)

4-13-4: PENALTY:
Any person having been found by a court of competent jurisdiction to have violated or failed to comply with any provision of this chapter or the life safety
code or prior sections hereby amended shall be fined for each violation or such failure in an amount as specified in the annual fee ordinance. Additional
violations or any such failure to comply shall be construed and deemed to be separate and distinct offenses subjecting the violator to an additional fine for
each day of each violation or noncompliance. (Ord. 2006-4044, 8-7-2006)

If the work described in any building permit has not begun within one-hundred and eighty (180) days from the date of issuance thereof, or if the

written notice thereof shall be given to the persons affected.

and be canceled by the building official and written notice thereof shall be given to the persons affected, together with notice that further work as

required extension permit fee.

R106.2.1 Add new section as follows:
Topographic Grading Plans: All building permit applications for new construction, or additions to existing structures necessitating the changing of
existing grading, or additions to existing structures having a negative impact on the drainage of surrounding properties, or projects involving the
disturbance of greater than 5000 square feet of ground area, shall be accompanied by a detailed topographic grading plan prepared by a
professional engineer registered in the state of Illinois. The required grading plan shall include all pertinent information as directed by the building
official.
R106.2.2 Add new section as follows:
Foundation (Spot) Surveys: A foundation survey indicating the as-built foundation location and top of foundation elevation is required for all new
construction. The survey must be prepared by a licensed land surveyor registered in the state of Illinois. No structural framing may occur until such
time as the survey has been approved by the building official. Foundation surveys may be required for building additions if the as-built location of
the addition is undeterminable by the building inspector using known reference points on site.
R106.2.3 Add new section as follows:
As-Built Topographic Surveys: A final topographic survey must be submitted for all construction requiring the prior approval of a grading plan. Said
survey shall contain all pertinent information as directed by the building official and must be prepared by a professional engineer registered in the
state of Illinois. The installation of landscape material, or the establishment of ground cover, should not occur until such time as the survey has
been approved by the building official.
R106.3.3 Phased Approval: Delete in its entirety.
R109.1 Types Of Inspections: Amend as follows:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 138/460
The following types of inspections may be required depending upon the type and scope of work permitted. It is the responsibility of the permit
holder to make themselves aware of the required inspections for their particular project and to comply in obtaining inspection approval of each
phase of construction prior to continuation of work. Possible inspection types include:
[] Footing
[] Foundation trench
[] Thickened slab
[] Concrete patio or paver base
[] Fencing

[] Insulation

[] Final site inspection
[] Final public works inspection
R110.1.1 Add new section as follows:
Renovations and additions to existing occupied structures. Renovations to existing structures that result in the dwelling unit becoming
uninhabitable during renovation shall require issuance of a new certificate of occupancy prior to re-occupancy. Additions to existing occupied
structures shall not be used for the intended use until such time as the final inspection has been approved and an occupancy permit has been
issued.
R110.2 Change In Use: Amend as follows:
Changes in the character or use of an existing structure shall comply with the requirements of section 5-18-4 of the village of Lisle zoning
ordinance.
R112.1 Board Of Appeals - General: Amend as follows:
Any person shall have the right to appeal a decision of the code official or request a variation from the terms of this code before the board of
appeals. An application for appeal shall be based on a claim that the true intent of this code or the rules legally adopted thereunder have been
incorrectly interpreted, the provisions of this code do not fully apply, or an equivalent form of construction is to be used. The board of appeals shall
grant variations from the strict application of any of the requirements of this code in the case of exceptional conditions, whereby such strict
application would result in practical difficulty or unnecessary hardship that would deprive the owner of reasonable use of the land or building
involved. In granting any variation, the board of appeals shall prescribe any conditions that it deems to be necessary or desirable. The board shall
affirm, modify, or reverse the decision of the code official by a majority vote. The board of appeals shall be the village of Lisle president and board
of trustees and the chairman of the board of appeals shall be the president, also known as the mayor, of the village of Lisle.
R112.2 Limitations On Authority: Delete in its entirety.
R112.3 Qualifications: Delete in its entirety.
R112.4 Administration: Delete in its entirety.
Chapter 2 Definitions: Add the following:
Sleeping Room: A room physically separated from adjacent room areas by walls and a door, containing a clothes closet, and intended or suitable for
sleeping accommodations.
