Chapter 6A
C/U COLLEGE/UNIVERSITY DISTRICT
5-6A-1: PURPOSE:
It is the purpose of the college/university district to promote higher education within its boundaries. The college/university district is intended to establish
the area in which a college or university may continue to operate in harmony with the surrounding residential and business areas. It is also understood that
segregation of such facilities in a separate district is appropriate given the unique characteristics of college and university areas, the variety of uses
needed to serve the college and university community, and the intensity of land uses in such a community. (Ord. 2004-3804, 1-5-2004)
5-6A-2: USES PERMITTED, SPECIAL AND ACCESSORY:
(A) Principal Permitted Uses: No building, structure or land shall be used and no building or structure shall be erected, altered or enlarged which is
arranged, intended or designed for other than one of the following uses, except as provided in chapter 2 of this title relating to the nonconforming use of
land and/or structures:
Childcare centers.
Colleges or universities with campuses of one hundred (100) or more acres, and with master land use plans approved by the village board.
General commercial centers in accordance with the requirements of the B-2 community business district.
Public and private utility facilities.
Telecommunications towers up to sixty feet (60') in height, set back a minimum of one hundred feet (100') from adjacent residentially zoned
properties or residential developments measured at the property line.
Temporary structures and operations subject to applicable requirements of the Lisle zoning code.
(B) Special Uses: The following uses shall be permitted only ifspecifically authorized by the president and board of trustees, upon recommendation by the
board of zoning appeals in accordance with the provisions of chapter 19 of this title:
Boarding, lodging and rooming houses.
Colleges or universities without master land use plans approved by the village board.
Telecommunications towers greater than sixty feet (60') in height, or set back less than one hundred feet (100') from adjacent residentially zoned
properties or residential developments measured at the property line.
(C) Accessory Uses And Buildings: Accessory use, building or structure customarily incident to a principal permitted use or conditionally permitted use,
located on the same lot therewith, including:
1. Any use, building or structure serving or customarily associated with a college or university, including, but not limited to, the following:
(a) Classrooms; laboratory and research facilities; administration facilities; athletic centers and facilities; gymnasiums, arenas and stadiums;
multipurpose buildings; training centers; conference and seminar centers; auditoriums; student centers; cafeterias; dormitories; maintenance
facilities; and parking lots and decks.
(b) Housing for currently enrolled college and/or university students and their dependents and for current college and/or university employees and
their dependents.
(c) Health clubs, general retail and services, bookstores and dining services and other functions servicing college students.
(d) Religious and cultural uses such as churches and similar places of worship, student centers sponsored by religious organizations within the
college/university, libraries, museums, art galleries, performing arts center and similar public cultural uses.
2. Other uses and structures that are the same general character of the above permitted uses, as determined by the zoning administrator. (Ord. 2004-
3804, 1-5-2004)
5-6A-3: REQUIREMENTS:
Unless otherwise provided in this chapter, the following requirements shall be observed:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 167/460
(A) Maximum Height: There are no height restrictions for college/university uses unless otherwise established.
(B) Minimum Lot Area: There are no area requirements for college/university uses unless otherwise established.
(C) Minimum Lot Frontage: There are no lot frontage requirements for college/university uses unless otherwise established.
(D) Minimum Lot Area Per Dwelling Unit: There are no minimum lot area requirements for college/university uses unless otherwise established.
(E) Yard Coverage: Yard requirements for the college/university district shall be as established in a master land use plan or special use permit.
(F) Off Street Parking And Loading: The off street parking and loading requirements specified in chapter 13 of this title shall not be applicable to uses
within the college/university district. The number and the location of off street parking and loading spaces to be provided shall be as indicated on the
master land use plan or in the special use permit.
(G) Lot Coverage And Minimum Floor Area: Notwithstanding anything to the contrary in this chapter, there shall be no lot coverage or minimum floor area
requirements within the college/university district, unless such requirements are otherwise established in a master land use plan or special use permit.
(H) Master Land Use Plan: The location of the buildings and structures and establishment of uses shall be in general conformance with a master land use
plan. The master land use plan shall designate existing and proposed buildings, structures and land uses. A college or university may: 1) enlarge said
buildings, structures and land uses, 2) utilize any building, structure and land use designated on the master land use plan for any permitted or
permitted accessory use as enumerated above, both at the discretion of the college or university, provided that said enlargement or use is in keeping
with the requirements of this district.
(I) Community Events: The college or university may sponsor a special event of community wide interest or may permit a person or organization to utilize
facilities for such an event with or without renumeration.
(J) Lots Or Tracts Of Land: In the college/university district, any tract of land or lot may contain one or more principal buildings, structures or uses and any
building, structure, or use may be located on one or more lots or tracts of land. (Ord. 2004-3804, 1-5-2004)
5-6A-4: REQUIREMENTS APPLICABLE TO THE BENEDICTINE UNIVERSITY MASTER PLAN AREA:
(A) Intent: This district is created in recognition of the fact that Benedictine University and the surrounding residential,business and institutional uses
constitute a single neighborhood which must develop and grow in a harmonious and compatible manner. It also recognizes that the continual
development and stability of Benedictine University is integral to the viability of the neighborhood and the entire Lisle community. Therefore, the district
is intended to provide flexibility to Benedictine University to develop and expand as it deems necessary to meet the changing requirements of higher
education, with a minimum amount of impact on surrounding areas. The Benedictine University master land use plan dated March 1998, was approved
by the village board on January 5, 2004.
(B) Maximum Height: The maximum height for all buildings and structures in the Benedictine University master land use plan area shall be seven (7)
stories unless a special use is obtained for a building or structure in excess of seven (7) stories.
(C) Yard Requirements: There shall be provided and maintained a building and parking lot setback, not inclusive of any driveways, of one hundred feet
(100') along the perimeter of the Benedictine University master land use plan area, as shown on the plan, except that said setback shall not apply to
existing buildings or parking lots shown in the Benedictine University master land use plan.
(D) Signage: All signage shall be installed in conformance with the village's sign code with the following exceptions and special requirements:
1. Two (2) identification signs shall be permitted along College Road, Maple Avenue and the westerly perimeter roadway. Each sign shall not exceed
three hundred (300) square feet of sign face area, nor exceed twelve feet (12') in height.
2. All signs located over one hundred feet (100') from the perimeter of the Benedictine University master land use plan area, as shown on the plan,
shall not be required to comply with the village's sign code, provided, all such signs shall comply with Benedictine University's sign policy in effect as
of December 10, 2003, and as the same may be amended from time to time.
3. All signage shall relate to the function, activities and events of Benedictine University. Notwithstanding this provision, commercial signage shall be
permitted within a sports stadium.
4. All signage existing as of the date of adoption hereof may remain and may be replaced or reconstructed to the same dimensions and in the same
location as the prior sign even if said sign does not conform to the village's codes. Said signage may be replaced or reconstructed of materials
different from the existing signage provided that said materials are permitted under the village's codes. (Ord. 2004-3804, 1-5-2004)
Chapter 7
O OFFICE DISTRICT
5-7-1: PURPOSE:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 168/460
It is the purpose of the O Office District to restore economic value to developed sections of the Village, generally located along major thoroughfares or in
close proximity to the Central Business District, where existing structures situated on large parcels are no longer practical for single-family residency and
can be removed and replaced by modern office buildings, or would otherwise reasonably lend themselves to office sites without unreasonably affecting
surrounding property, while still maintaining a noncommercial environment. (Ord. 2018-4789, 10-1-2018)
5-7-2: USES PERMITTED:
(A) Principal Permitted Uses: No building, structure or land shall be used and no building or structure shall be erected, altered or enlarged which is
arranged, intended or designed for other than one of the following uses, except as provided in chapter 2 of this title relating to the nonconforming use of
land and/or structures. Any of the following permitted, special or accessory uses, when situated on a parcel of five (5) acres or more, or part of one
development of five (5) acres or more, shall be permitted only as a planned unit development and in accordance with chapter 14 of this title:
Business and professional offices.
Temporary festival parking for a fee during events designated as "special events" by resolution or motion of the Village Board. Unless the Village Board
by resolution or motion specifically allows parking on grass or other surface, all such festival parking shall be on parking lots and driveways meeting the
standards of subsection 5-13-1-5(C) of this title.
(B) Special Uses: The following uses shall be permitted only if specifically authorized by the President and Board of Trustees upon recommendation by the
Board of Zoning Appeals, in accordance with the provisions of chapter 19 of this title:
Colleges for academic instruction.
Daycare facilities for the care of preschool and school age children.
Hospitals and sanitariums for human care, provided that buildings which are used for the treatment of contagious diseases, the care of epileptics, drug
addicts, the feeble minded or insane, shall be at least one hundred fifty feet (150') distant from any lot in any residence district.
Mortuary or funeral homes.
Residences of architects, artists, dentists, lawyers, engineers, physicians or similar professional persons when the office or the studio of the
professional person is located in the same building as the residential use.
(C) Accessory Uses And Buildings: Accessory uses, buildings or structures customarily incidental or accessory to a principal permitted or specially
permitted use, located on the same lot therewith.
No "sign", as defined herein shall be permitted except as is provided in the Sign Code of the Village (title 4, chapter 4 of this Code). (Ord. 2018-4789,
10-1-2018)

(B) Minimum Lot Area: Twenty thousand (20,000) square feet.
(C) Minimum Lot Frontage: The minimum lot frontage at the building line shall be seventy five feet (75').
(D) Yards And Lot Coverage: "Front", "rear" and "side yards" are required as defined in section 5-1-7 of this title and as specified below and the maximum
lot area that may be covered by principal buildings, accessory buildings, parking spaces, or garages, exclusive of areas used for walkways and other

Chapter 8
B-1 NEIGHBORHOOD BUSINESS DISTRICT
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 169/460
5-8-1: PURPOSE:
It is the purpose of the B-1 neighborhood business district to permit and to encourage the establishment of small convenience goods and personal service
centers located in close proximity to residences which are so arranged and designed as to be a functional and harmonious part of a residential
neighborhood. The location of these districts and the nature of commercial activity primarily limits the service area to the surrounding neighborhood, thus
avoiding undue traffic congestion and providing commercial services within a reasonable walking distance. (Ord. 350)
5-8-2: USES PERMITTED, SPECIAL AND ACCESSORY:
(A) Principal Permitted Uses: No building, structure or land shall be used and no building or structure shall be erected, altered or enlarged which is
arranged, intended or designed for other than one of the following uses, except as provided in chapter 2 of this title relating to the nonconforming use of
land and/or structures. Any of the following permitted, special or accessory uses, when situated on a parcel of five (5) acres or more, or part of one
development of five (5) acres or more, shall be permitted only as a planned unit development and in accordance with chapter 14 of this title.
Business and professional offices.
Restaurant outdoor seating areas; provided:
1. The location of any outdoor seating areas comply with all setback requirements in the applicable zoning district and shall not obstruct pedestrian
or vehicular traffic. A minimum of four feet (4') of sidewalk clearance shall be maintained at all times for pedestrian travel;
2. Any outdoor seating area be under the direct supervision and control of the principal restaurant, and such seating area be enclosed by a fence
or decorative chain which shall be constructed in a manner to clearly delineate the boundaries of the area and to protect the health and safety of
restaurant patrons and the general public;
3. The hours of operation of any outdoor seating area be within the normal operating hours of the principal restaurant;
4. Plans shall be provided indicating the location of the outdoor seating area, and such location be approved by the building and zoning
department. The outdoor seating area shall be maintained in compliance with the approved plans; and
5. The principal restaurant and outdoor seating area shall be in compliance with all requirements of this code and all other applicable rules and
regulations of any governing body regarding the restaurant and outdoor seating area.
Retail business or service establishments supplying commodities or performing services primarily for residents of the surrounding neighborhood on a
day to day basis including grocery stores, pharmacies, delicatessen stores, barbershops, beauty parlors, clothes cleaning and laundry pick up
stations, and other similar stores and shops for the conduct of a retail business or personal service, when determined by the president and board of
trustees that said use will conform substantially to the purpose of this section, as set out herein.
Soda fountains, ice cream parlors, tearooms, restaurants and cafes, but not including entertainment, drive-in and carryout restaurants. (Ord. 350;
amd. Ord. 88-1703, 8-1-1988; Ord. 2002-3394, 4-15-2002; Ord. 2010-4320, 5-17-2010)
(B) Special Uses: The following uses shall be permitted only if specifically authorized by the president and board of trustees upon recommendation by the
board of zoning appeals in accordance with the provisions of chapter 19 of this title:
Drive-in banks, building and loan companies and similar financial institutions, provided that the premises shall be enclosed by a solid wall or fence at
least six feet (6') high where it adjoins in the rear or on the sides of any residence district, public park, school or church.
Mortuaries or funeral homes.
Self-service laundries, dry cleaners and similar uses.
Studios, art, television, radio, music and dance studios and/or conservatories. (Ord. 350)
(C) Accessory Uses And Buildings:
Any accessory use, building or structure customarily incidental to a principal permitted use or special permitted use, located on the same lot therewith.
Business identification signs, professional, institutional, announcement, bulletin board, real estate and nameplate signs, subject to the provisions of the
village sign code in title 4, chapter 4 of this code.
No "sign", as defined herein, shall be permitted except as is provided in the sign code of the village in title 4, chapter 4 of this code. (Ord. 83-1126, 7-5-
1983)
5-8-3: REQUIREMENTS:
The following requirements shall be observed:
(A) Business In Enclosed Buildings:
1. All businesses, services or processing shall be conducted wholly within a completely enclosed building, except as specifically authorized by the
corporate authorities upon the recommendation of the board of zoning appeals after a public hearing has been held. (Ord. 90-2093, 10-1-1990)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 170/460
2. Temporary outdoor displays of goods or materials are allowed upon receipt of a permit from the community development director. Not more than two
(2) outdoor display events shall be approved for any business entity during each calendar year. Outdoor displays may remain outdoors for a period
not to exceed seven (7) consecutive days. A permit for any event allowed by this subsection (A)2 shall be issued only if the display of goods or
materials is accessory to the principal use of the land, and is authorized by the principal user and the owner of the land.
Notwithstanding the foregoing, outdoor Christmas tree displays and sales shall be permitted during the period from the third Thursday in November
through December 25 of each year, provided a permit is obtained from the community development director. (Ord. 97-2842, 2-3-1997)
(B) Size Restricted: Each business establishment is restricted to a maximum of twenty five thousand (25,000) cubic feet of gross area. This volume shall
be measured by multiplying the gross floor area by the average ceiling height.
(C) Production For Sale At Retail: All products produced on the premises, whether primary or incidental, shall be sold at retail on the premises where
produced.
(D) Objectionable Uses: No processes and equipment shall be employed or goods sold which are objectionable by reason of odor, dust, smoke, cinders,
gas, fumes, noise, vibration, radiation, refuse matter or water carried wastes.
(E) New Merchandise: Goods for sale shall consist primarily of new merchandise.
(F) Maximum Building Height: No principal structure shall exceed one story or fifteen feet (15') in height.
(G) Minimum Lot Area: For residential uses, minimum lot area shall be ten thousand (10,000) square feet.
(H) Minimum Lot Frontage: For residential uses, the minimum lot frontage shall be seventy five feet (75').
(I) Minimum Lot Area Per Dwelling Unit: For residential uses, same as specified for R-2 single-family residence district.
(J) Yards And Lot Coverage: Front, rear and side yards are required as defined in section 5-1-7 of this title and as specified below; and the maximum lot
area that may be covered by principal buildings, accessory buildings and parking spaces or garages, exclusive of areas used for walkways, access
drives, landscape elements, shall not exceed the percentage of total lot area as specified below:

Chapter 9
B-2 COMMUNITY BUSINESS DISTRICT
5-9-1: PURPOSE:
It is the purpose of the B-2 Community Business District to permit and to encourage the establishment of commercial shopping centers which offer a wide
variety of consumer goods and services. It is intended that the Community Business District serve a larger population and larger area than the B-1 District
and, when located along major highways and thoroughfares, accommodate primarily automotive oriented establishments. (Ord. 2019-4816, 3-18-2019)
5-9-2: USES PERMITTED, SPECIAL AND ACCESSORY:
(A) Principal Permitted Uses: No building, structure or land shall be used and no building or structure shall be erected, altered or enlarged which is
arranged, intended or designed for other than one of the following uses, except as provided in chapter 2 of this title relating to the nonconforming use of
land and/or structures. Any of the following permitted, special or accessory uses, when situated on a parcel of five (5) acres or more, or part of one
development of five (5) acres or more, shall be permitted only as a planned unit development and in accordance with chapter 14 of this title.
1. General. All principal permitted uses as regulated in the B-1 Neighborhood Business District, except as hereinafter modified.
2. Retail stores. Specialty shops such as jewelry stores, shoe stores, dry goods, notion stores, florist shops, or pet equipment and supply stores.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 171/460
3. Personal services and business services.
Eating and drinking places, restaurants and cocktail lounges, subject to all applicable regulations and such permits and licenses as may be required
by law.
General business services.
Personal service establishment.
Post Offices and telegraph offices.
4. Processing. Bakery, catering establishment, laundry or dyeing and cleaning works, employing not more than five (5) persons.
(B) Special Uses: The following uses shall be permitted if specifically authorized by the President and Board of Trustees upon recommendation by the
Board of Zoning Appeals in accordance with the provisions of chapter 19 of this title:
1. General. Any special permitted use and as regulated in the B-1 District.
2. Commercial recreation. Any type of commercial recreation, including baseball fields, swimming pools, skating rinks, and similar open air facilities,
provided such establishments shall be located not less than one hundred feet (100') from any Residential District.
3. Animal hospitals, veterinary clinics. Kennels for display, boarding or treatment of pets and other domestic animals; provided that any structure or
area used for such purposes, including pens, and exercise yards, shall be located at least one hundred feet (100') from any Residential District and
that such pens or exercise runs shall be enclosed on four (4) sides by a sight obscuring, unpierced fence or wall at least five feet (5') in height.
4. Retail sale of animals.
5. Automotive and power equipment services.
Any automobile, truck, trailer, recreational vehicle, motorcycle, mower, tractor, power trimmer or chain saw, including, but not limited to, selling,
servicing, displaying, repairing, cleaning, renovating, and washing, provided that there shall be a minimum distance of fifty feet (50') between the use
and any Residential District, and that the premises shall be enclosed by a solid wall, fence or earthen berm, at least six feet (6') in height where it
adjoins in the rear of or on the side of any Residential District.
Gasoline service stations, but not including repair and/or painting or the storage and/or rental of cars, trucks or trailers provided that:
(a) There shall be a minimum distance of one hundred fifty feet (150') between the parcel of land proposed for the automotive use and any
Residentially Zoned District. In the case of a parcel of land across a street or alley right-of-way from a Residentially Zoned District, the street or
alley right-of-way shall not be included as part of the required distance.
(b) Landscaping and screening shall be installed, maintained and subject to Village inspection and approval. Said landscaping shall be a fence, berm
or hedge at least six feet (6') in height and shall have an opacity of at least eighty percent (80%) when adjacent to a Residentially Zoned District.
(c) Lighting as specified in chapter 27, "Outdoor Lighting", of this title.
(d) Any building or structure be constructed with solid masonry bearing walls with face brick which shall be subject to Village inspection and approval.
(e) The parcel on which such use is proposed is not within the floodplain as defined in chapter 16 of this title.
(f) The Village Corporate Authorities specifically find that such use will not adversely impact, or cause unnecessary hardship to adjacent property
owners. Further, the Corporate Authorities shall find that such use shall not cause substantial injury to the value of other property in the community.
6. Utility stations. Public utility stations and services.
7. Motel and hotels.
8. Minor fabricating and repair. Plumbing shop, painting and decorating shop, tinsmithing shop, automobile service stations, including auto repairing
and tire repair shop.
9. Commercial parking lots.
10. Firearms and ammunition. Sale of firearms or ammunition for firearms; provided, however, that no special use for firearms or ammunition sales
shall be approved for any property located within one thousand feet (1,000') of a public, private or parochial school.
11. Other similar uses.
(C) Accessory Uses And Buildings: Accessory uses, buildings or structures customarily incidental or accessory to a principal permitted or specially
permitted use, located on the same lot therewith including:
1. Sign. No "sign", as defined herein, shall be permitted except as is provided in the Sign Code in title 4, chapter 4 of this Code. (Ord. 2019-4816, 3-18-
2019)

Chapter 10
B-3 CENTRAL BUSINESS DISTRICT
5-10-1: PURPOSE:
It is the purpose of the B-3 District to accommodate pedestrian oriented development in the downtown area consisting primarily of retail service and
specialty shops and a mixture of pedestrian oriented uses, including retail, service, office, residential and public uses. The B-3 District is divided into two
(2) subdistricts to provide a primary retail shopping environment at the street level along the major retail corridor within the downtown and to provide a
Perimeter District to accommodate a variety of mixed uses on the periphery of the downtown area and also provide a transition from the downtown
business area and adjacent single-family residential areas.
(A) Subdistricts: The B-3 Central Business District shall be divided into two (2) subdistricts: 1) the B-3A Central Retail Core District and 2) the B-3B
Downtown Perimeter District. The purpose of the B-3A Central Retail Core District is to accommodate retail, entertainment and restaurant uses at the
ground level. The purpose of the B-3B Perimeter District is to accommodate a variety of uses, including residential, office, retail, service and public
uses.
(B) Boundaries: The boundaries of the B-3 Central Business District and B-3 Subdistricts shall be delineated on the official Village of Lisle zoning map
adopted annually in March by the Mayor and Village Board of Trustees. (Ord. 2019-4816, 3-18-2019)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 173/460
5-10-2: REQUIREMENTS:
The following requirements shall be observed:
(A) Business In Enclosed Buildings:
1. All businesses, services, processing or storage of materials shall be conducted wholly within a completely enclosed building, except for the sale of
automotive fuel, lubricants and fluids at service stations, and such outdoor display or storage of vehicles, materials and equipment as hereinbefore
specifically authorized or as may be authorized by the Corporate Authorities upon recommendation of the Board of Zoning Appeals after a public
hearing has been held.
2. Temporary outdoor displays of goods or materials are allowed upon receipt of a permit from the Community Development Director. Not more than
two (2) outdoor display events shall be approved for any business entity during each calendar year. Outdoor displays may remain outdoors for a
period not to exceed seven (7) consecutive days. A permit for any event allowed by this subsection (A)2 shall be issued only if the display of goods
or materials is accessory to the principal use of the land, and is authorized by the principal user and the owner of the land.
(B) Christmas Tree Displays And Sales: Notwithstanding the foregoing, outdoor Christmas tree displays and sales shall be permitted during the period
from the third Thursday in November through December 25 of each year, provided a permit is obtained from the Community Development Director.
(C) Festival Parking: Temporary festival parking for a fee during events designated as "special events" by resolution or motion of the Village Board. Unless
the Village Board by resolution or motion specifically allows parking on grass or other surface, all such festival parking shall be on parking lots and
driveways meeting the standards of subsection 5-13-1-5(C) of this title.
(D) Exterior Lighting: Exterior lighting fixtures shall be designed or shaded to avoid casting direct light or glare toward surrounding properties or streets and
to direct illumination downward.
(E) Manufacture Of Goods: The manufacture of goods shall be permitted only when ancillary to the principal use of the property. All goods produced shall
be sold at retail on the premises.
(F) Site Plan And Review: Site plan and architectural review for all new structures and parking lots is required to ensure that all Village standards are
satisfied, including, but not limited to, land use, site access, parking circulation, landscaping, stormwater management, open space, signage and
exterior finish materials. (Ord. 2019-4816, 3-18-2019)

1 bedroom and efficiency units 1 parking space
5. Signage: Signage shall be constructed and maintained as specified in title 4, chapter 4, "Sign Code", of this Code. (Ord. 2019-4816, 3-18-2019)
5-10-4: NONCONFORMING USES:
Nonconforming uses may remain indefinitely until a time that one or more of the following occurs:
(A) A structure is damaged beyond fifty percent (50%) of its replacement value.
(B) Change in use.
(C) A use is discontinued for a period of twelve (12) months. (Ord. 2019-4816, 3-18-2019)
Chapter 11
O-R OFFICE-RESEARCH DISTRICT
5-11-1: PURPOSE:
The Office-Research District is intended to provide land for attractively landscaped sites, often along major trafficways, permitting "show place" buildings
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 177/460
having large setbacks. The entire area is intended to create a "park like" atmosphere conducive to the quality development of international headquarters,
large office buildings, research and educational activities, and some specialized nonobjectionable industrial activities. The low intensity and limiting
restrictions provide for permitted uses compatible with adjacent residential and commercial developments. (Ord. 2018-4789, 10-1-2018)
5-11-2: USES PERMITTED, SPECIAL AND ACCESSORY:
(A) Principal Permitted Uses: No building, structure or land shall be used and no building or structure shall be erected, altered or enlarged which is
arranged, intended or designed for other than one of the following uses, except as provided in chapter 2 of this title relating to the nonconforming use of
land and/or structures. Any of the following permitted, special or accessory uses, when situated on a parcel of five (5) acres or more, or part of one
development of five (5) acres or more, shall be permitted only as a planned unit development and in accordance with chapter 14 of this title:
1. Commercial uses:
Restaurants with or without accessory cocktail lounge, but excluding fast food carryout and drive-in service.
Temporary festival parking for a fee during events designated as "special events" by resolution or motion of the Village Board. Unless the Village
Board by resolution or motion specifically allows parking on grass or other surface, all such festival parking shall be on parking lots and driveways
meeting the standards of subsection 5-13-1-5(C) of this title.
2. Office and/or business service establishments such as, but not limited to:
Bank and/or financial institutions.
Business offices.
Computer and/or data processing centers.
Home office operations.
Insurance company headquarters.
International headquarters.
Medical offices, clinics.
Merchandise and product display space, but not direct sales.
Merchandise mart, used primarily for display and the wholesale marketing of products; limited retail sales are allowed.
Personnel training center, including dormitory facilities.
Professional offices of engineering and/or architectural firms.
Regional sales offices including incidental distribution and servicing of products.
Theaters, but not including outdoor theaters.
3. Research and development uses such as, but not limited to:
Design firms.
Electronic and communications industries.
Experimental product development.
Laboratories.
Pharmaceutical industries.
Research firms including incidental pilot plant operations.
4. Light industrial type uses, limited to the following uses only:
Light industrial operations of electronic and communications industries.
Light industrial operations of experimental product development firms.
Light industrial operations of pharmaceutical industries.
Light industrial operations of research firms.
"Light industrial" shall be defined as the production processes, including testing, carried on under circumstances such that the activities shall not be
injurious or offensive to adjacent property owners by reason of emission or creation of noise, vibration, smoke, dust, fly ash, fumes, vapors, gases,
particulate matter, or other forms of air pollution, odors, toxic or noxious materials, glare, heat, liquid or solid wastes, fire or explosion hazards, or
other hazards. All of the referenced activities involved in production shall be carried on, and all storage areas contained, within completely enclosed
facilities that are of materials similar to materials used in the principal building on the site.
5. Public, quasi-public and governmental buildings and facilities such as, but not limited to:
Essential services. Gas regulator stations, telephone exchange, electric substation, well site and water storage facility.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 178/460
Fire station.
Hospital.
Museum, art gallery.
Office building.
Post Office.
(B) Prohibited Uses: No building, structure or land shall be used, and no building or structure shall be erected, altered or enlarged which is arranged,
intended or designed for any of the following uses:
1. Residential:
One-family dwellings.
Two- to four-family dwellings.
2. Institutional:
Childcare centers.
Homes for the aged and similar institutions for human care.
3. Commercial:
Commercial uses, except as listed in subsections (A)1, (A)2, and (C)2 of this section.
Industrial uses, except as listed in subsection (A)4 of this section.
4. Other uses having operations that are deemed by the Board of Trustees to be incompatible with the intended environmental character of the O-R
Office-Research District.
(C) Special Uses: The following uses shall be permitted only if specifically authorized by the President and Board of Trustees upon recommendation by the
Board of Zoning Appeals in accordance with the provisions of chapter 19 of this title:

Dwellings for families of caretakers, watchmen and operators, and such sleeping and boarding accommodations as are customarily incidental and
necessary to a permitted use, which buildings must be located on the same premises as such permitted use; further, additions to existing buildings
may be authorized where the number of families or the number of lodging accommodations is not increased.
Multi-family dwellings.
2. Commercial:
Health, swim and racquet clubs and incidental facilities, separate and apart from those permitted in this subsection.
Hotel and/or motel.
Private, membership only health clubs in multi-building office complexes under single ownership or control on sites not less than ten (10) acres,
when such facility is designed primarily for use by tenants of the office complex. Such structure shall not front on any perimeter road and access
thereto shall be provided only from interior roadways.
Restaurant outdoor seating areas; provided:
(a) That the location of any outdoor seating areas comply with all setback requirements in the applicable zoning district and shall not obstruct any
pedestrian or vehicular traffic;
(b) That no direct access to any outdoor seating area be available except through the principal use restaurant;
(c) That any outdoor seating area be under the direct supervision and control of the principal use restaurant, and that such seating area be
enclosed by a fence or decorative chain which shall be constructed in a manner to clearly delineate the boundaries of the area and to protect the
health and safety of restaurant patrons and the general public;
(d) That the hours of operation of any outdoor seating area be the same as those of the principal restaurant; and
(e) That any restaurant outdoor seating area be subject to all regulations, and such permits and licenses as may be required by law.
Restaurants with accessory cocktail lounges, in multi-building office complexes under single ownership or control, located on sites not less than ten
(10) acres in size, and provided such facility is incidental to and designed primarily for the use by tenants of the office complex. The restaurant may
be freestanding or located within an office building; however, if freestanding, such structure shall not front on any perimeter road and access thereto
shall be provided only from interior roadways.
3. Public, quasi-public and governmental buildings and facilities:
Church.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 179/460
Heliport, public and private, located on lots not less than one acre in area and having a touchdown space which is enclosed by a fence and which is
not less than one hundred feet (100') in diameter. The landing area shall, as a minimum, have two (2) approach-departure paths, with centerlines
radiating from the center of the area forming an angle greater than ninety degrees (90), which are not less than seventy five feet (75') in width and
which are unobstructed above an imaginary plane extending from the edge of the landing area at an incline of one foot (1') vertically to each six feet
(6') horizontally.
4. Institutional:
Schools, workshops, training centers for developmentally disabled persons.
Vocational, trade, technical schools, colleges, or universities.

10-1-2018)

(A) Maximum Building Height: No structure or portion thereof (except a mechanical penthouse structure) shall exceed a height of eighty feet (80').
(B) Minimum Lot Area: A separate ground area of not less than four (4) acres shall be designated, provided it is continuously maintained for each structure
of land containing a permitted use. Variations in lot size for the development of special uses as specified in subsection 5-11-2(C) of this chapter may be
granted by the president and board of trustees after public hearing before the zoning board of appeals. (Ord. 85-1336, 10-7-1985)
(C) Minimum Lot Frontage: A minimum lot frontage of three hundred feet (300') shall be provided for each lot used for a permitted or special use.

4. Yards Adjacent To Residential Districts: All structures and parking lots shall be at a distance of not less than two hundred feet (200') from a
residential zoning district and all vehicular drives shall be set at a distance of not less than one hundred feet (100') from a residential zoning district;
provided, however, that the yards may be reduced to one hundred feet (100') for structures and parking lots and fifty feet (50') for vehicular drives if
adequate screening, landscaping, earth berming, or walls, or a combination thereof, and controlled lighting is provided in accord with plans submitted
and approved by the mayor and board of trustees. The screening plan shall be submitted to, reviewed by and a report rendered to the mayor and
board of trustees by a competent, recognized landscape architect.
In the case of a parcel of land across a street or alley from a residential district, the street or alley right of way shall not be included as a part of the
required yard.
If other provisions of this chapter require greater yards than this subsection, the greater yard shall be required.
(E) Maximum Lot Coverage: No building with its accessory buildings shall occupy in excess of thirty percent (30%) of the area of the lot. (Ord. 502, 2-19-
1974)
(F) Floor Area Ratio: Not to exceed 0.5. Additionally, not to exceed 0.8 where over ninety percent (90%) of the required parking is provided underground or
in an enclosed parking structure. Parking structures will be included in calculating the square footage of the floor area ratio as follows:
1. Underground parking, that is parking in a story or level that is more than one-half (1/2) below the adjacent grade measured at all points around the
structure, shall not be counted as floor area in computing the floor area ratio.
2. Aboveground parking, that is any parking in a structure that is not considered underground, shall be counted when computing the square footage
figure for calculating the floor area ratio.
3. Aboveground rooftop structured parking shall be counted at the rate of fifty percent (50%) of the rooftop area for purposes of calculating the floor
area in the floor area ratio. (Ord. 89-1994, 10-2-1989)
(G) Off Street Parking And Loading: Off street parking and loading facilities shall be provided as specified in chapter 13 of this title. In addition to said
requirements, off street parking, with the exception of guest parking not to exceed space for eight (8) vehicles and pick up areas, shall not be located
within the front yard area required by the provisions of subsection (D)4 of this section.
In addition, all parking and drives shall be set back at least ten feet (10') from all side and rear property lines. (Ord. 502, 2-19-1974)
(H) Open Space: All unpaved areas shall be landscaped subject to the approval of the mayor and board of trustees. A complete landscape plan for the
building area and entire site must be approved by the mayor and board of trustees or their assigned representatives in the village staff. Open spaces
shall not be less than forty percent (40%) of the site area. Land occupied by buildings, vehicular drives and open automobile parking lots shall not be
included in the calculation of the required open space. (Ord. 89-1994, 10-2-1989)
(I) Performance Standards: All uses shall be developed in compliance with the applicable performance standards required in chapter 15 of this title. (Ord.
502, 2-19-1974)
1. Enclosure Of Operations:
(a) All business, services, processing, storage and all truck and miscellaneous loading operations shall be conducted within completely enclosed
buildings. Provided, miscellaneous loading operations for office, office type, hotel and motel uses may utilize "open air" loading spaces located in
the rear and side yards only. Said "open air" loading spaces shall be designed and constructed according to the applicable provisions of ordinance
350 (this zoning title), as from time to time amended. Garage doors and loading space doors shall be fully screened and located on the side yard
or rear yard exposure of the building only. (Ord. 90-2093, 10-1-1990)
(b) Temporary outdoor displays of goods or materials are allowed upon receipt of a permit from the community development director. Not more than
two (2) outdoor display events shall be approved for any business entity during each calendar year. Outdoor displays may remain outdoors for a
period not to exceed seven (7) consecutive days. A permit for any event allowed by this subsection (I)1(b) shall be issued only if the display of
goods or materials is accessory to the principal use of the land, and is authorized by the principal user and the owner of the land.
Notwithstanding the foregoing, outdoor Christmas tree displays and sales shall be permitted during the period from the third Thursday in
November through December 25 of each year, provided a permit is obtained from the community development director. (Ord. 97-2842, 2-3-1997)
(c) Temporary indoor display and retail sale of goods or materials shall be allowed upon receipt of written approval from the community development
director. Not more than four (4) indoor display or retail sale events shall be approved for any business entity during each calendar year. No indoor
display or retail sale event shall exceed seven (7) consecutive days in length. The approval of four (4) indoor events shall not limit a business
entity from obtaining permits for temporary outdoor displays of goods or materials as provided in subsection (I)1(b) of this section. No approval of a
temporary indoor display or retail sale event shall be given unless the business entity has submitted to the community development director a copy
of the multiple site vendor filing which has been filed with the Illinois department of revenue. Notated thereon or attached thereto shall be the
business entity's Illinois business tax number. (Ord. 93-2369, 3-15-1993)
2. Utility Facilities: All utility cables, conduit, sewer and water lines shall be located belowground. Fire hydrants and similar relatively small
appurtenances may be located aboveground. More sizeable appurtenances and facilities, which are located aboveground, such as transformers,
shall be adequately screened or be given building treatment compatible with the quality of this zoning classification and subject to the approval of the
board of trustees.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 181/460
3. Lighting: In addition to the performance standards of subsection 5-15-6(H) of this title dealing with glare, no other lighting shall be constructed in
such a way as to be objectionable to adjacent property owners. Lighting of buildings, interior street lighting, and landscape lighting shall be directed
away from adjacent highways, streets and properties. Screening shall be provided to conceal from adjacent properties the direct light created by
vehicle headlights.
No neon, moving, revolving or flashing signs shall be permitted and all permissible signs shall be illuminated by interior lighting, indirect lighting or
direct lighting concealed from view from adjoining highways and streets, or as part of the general floodlighting of the building. (Ord. 502, 2-19-1974)
Chapter 12
I-1 INDUSTRIAL DISTRICT
5-12-1: PURPOSE:
It is the purpose of the I-1 industrial district to create industrial areas that will be acceptable within the village and will not adversely affect adjacent
business or residential neighborhoods by permitting industrial establishments which are either: a) ones whose operations are relatively free from
objectionable influences, or b) ones whose objectionable features will be obviated by design and/or appropriate devices. In the interest of general health
and welfare, residential and certain institutional uses are not permitted within this district. (Ord. 350; amd. 1979 Code)
5-12-2: USES PERMITTED, SPECIAL AND ACCESSORY:
(A) Principal Permitted Uses: No building, structure or land shall be used and no building or structure shall be erected, altered or enlarged which is
arranged, intended or designed for other than one of the following uses, except as provided in chapter 2 of this title relating to the nonconforming use of
land and/or structures. Any of the following permitted, special or accessory uses, when situated on a parcel of five (5) acres or more, or part of one
development of five (5) acres or more, shall be permitted only as a planned unit development and in accordance with chapter 14 of this title:
Any manufacturing use or process including assembling, fabricating, altering, converting, finishing, processing, treating and packaging, except any use
or process hereinafter specifically excluded, and providing that such use will not be hazardous, offensive or objectionable by reason of odor, dust,
cinders, gas, fumes, noise vibrations, radiation, refuse matter or water carried waste.
Professional offices or business offices not exceeding two (2) stories or thirty feet (30') in height.
Storage, handling, assembly and distribution of goods and materials for retail, wholesale or on site use, except any combustible materials and/or
flammable liquids.
Temporary festival parking for a fee during events designated as "special events" by resolution or motion of the village board. Unless the village board
by resolution or motion specifically allows parking on grass or other surface, all such festival parking shall be on parking lots and driveways meeting the
standards of subsection 5-13-1-5(C) of this title. (Ord. 350; amd. 1979 Code; Ord. 85-1326, 9-3-1985; Ord. 88-1703, 8-1-1988; Ord. 2002-3399, 5-20-
2002)
(B) Prohibited Uses: No building, structure or land shall be used and no building or structure shall be erected, altered or enlarged which is arranged,
intended or designed for any of the following uses; provided, however, that any of the uses herein described that legally exist in the I-1 district at the
time of adoption of these provisions, or any amendment thereto, shall be classified as a "nonconforming use", as defined in section 5-1-7 of this title,
and subject to the provisions of chapter 2 of this title. No lot on which is located such legally existing uses shall be used for the construction or erection
of a building for another use, so as to create a mixed use of said lot.
Dwellings, dwelling units and residences of any kind, including hotels, motels, rooming houses and tourist homes.
Industrial uses are as follows:
Acid manufacture.
Cement, lime, gypsum or plaster of Paris manufacture.
Crematories.
Distillation of bones.
Explosives manufacture or storage.
Fat rendering.
Fertilizer manufacture.
Garbage, offal or dead animal reduction or dumping.
Gas manufacture.
Glue manufacture.
Junkyards, including automobile wrecking and industrial metal and waste salvage.
Petroleum refining.
Smelting of tin, copper, zinc or iron ores.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 182/460
Stockyards or slaughter of animals.
Any other use which, in the opinion of the president and board of trustees, is of similar character to those hereinbefore described.
Schools, orphanages, childcare centers, homes for the aged and similar institutions for human care, except where they are incidental to a principal
permitted use. (Ord. 350; amd. 1979 Code)
(C) Special Uses: The following uses may be permitted only if specifically authorized, as may be authorized by the president and board of trustees upon
recommendation of the board of zoning appeals:
1. Dwellings for families of caretakers, watchmen and operators, and such sleeping and boarding accommodations as are customarily incidental and
necessary to a permitted use, which buildings must be located on the same premises as such permitted use, further, additions to existing buildings
may be authorized where the number of families or the number of lodging accommodations is not increased.

(a) Gymnastics training centers.
(b) Indoor baseball hitting and instructional facilities.

Chapter 13
OFF STREET PARKING AND LOADING
5-13-1: OFF STREET PARKING SPACES:
5-13-1-1: PURPOSE AND SCOPE:
It is the purpose of these off street parking regulations to reduce congestion on the streets due to excessive use for parking of motor vehicles and to
provide for adequate construction of said parking facilities, including suitable and attractive landscaping and screening.
The provisions of this section shall apply and govern in all zoning districts. (Ord. 501, 2-19-1974)
5-13-1-2: GENERAL REQUIREMENTS FOR PARKING SPACES:
(A) Responsibility: The duty to provide and maintain off street parking space shall be the joint and several responsibility of the operator and/or owner of the
use and/or land for which off street parking space is required to be provided and maintained.
(B) Existing Parking: For land, structures or uses actually used, occupied or operated on the effective date of this chapter, there shall be provided such off
street parking space as was required for such land, structures or uses by any previous ordinance regulations. If such land, structures or uses are
enlarged, expanded or changed, there shall beprovided, for that increment of expansion only, at least the amount of off street parking space that would
be required hereunder if the increment were a separate land, structure or use established or placed into operation after the effective date hereof.
(C) New Uses: For all uses established or placed into operation after the effective date hereof, there shall be constructed, provided, preserved and
maintained the amount of off street parking space hereinafter set forth.
(D) Change In Use: A change in the use of a parcel of land, building and/or premises shall require at least the minimum number of parking spaces to be
provided for the new use, in accordance with the requirements of section 5-13-1-7 of this chapter. A "change of use" permit shall be obtained from the
village before the new use is allowed to occupy the premises.
(E) Requirements: All off street parking space, whether provided in accordance with the provisions of this chapter or in accordance with the provisions of
any former ordinance regulations, shall be maintained as hereinafter required.
(F) Location: Parking for all types of uses may be provided either in garages or parking areas conforming with the provisions of this chapter.
(G) Charge: Parking may be with or without charge, subject to the provisions of the zoning district in which said parking area lies. No parking may be with
charge unless provided for in the applicable zoning district. (Ord. 501, 2-19-1974)
(H) Parking In Yards:
1. Front Yards:
(a) R-1, R-2, R-3 Zoning Districts: Parking shall be permitted within the front yard or required front yard in the R-1, R-2 and R-3 zoning districts only
when located upon a properly constructed driveway for which a driveway permit has been issued by the village.
Parking access driveways shall be permitted in the front yard or required front yard of any R-3 zoning district property if said parking access
driveways are set back a minimum of five feet (5') from the side lot line, provided furthermore, common access driveways may be located up to the
side property line in the R-3 zoning district where two (2) properties share a common access driveway; provided, however, common access
driveways shall be permitted only in those instances where the property owners sharing the common access driveway shall enter into and record
in the county recorder's office an unlimited permanent ingress and egress easement.
A common access driveway shall be permitted in the R-3zoning district only when the other side yard of the property being serviced by the
common access driveway shall be totally landscaped, with the exception of sidewalks.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 184/460
(b) R-4, O Zoning Districts: No parking shall be permitted in the required front yard of an R-4 or O zoning district property.
Parking access driveways shall be permitted in the front yard or required front yard of any R-4 or O zoning district property if said parking
access driveways are set back a minimum of five feet (5') from the side lot line; provided, furthermore, common access driveways may be located
up to the side property line in the R-4 and O zoning district where two (2) properties share a common access driveway; provided, however,
common access driveways shall be permitted only in the instances where the property owners sharing the common access driveway shall enter
into and record in the county recorder's office an unlimited permanent ingress and egress easement.
A common access driveway shall be permitted in the R-4 and O zoning districts only when the other side yard of the property being serviced by
the common access driveway shall be totally landscaped, with the exception of sidewalks.
(c) B-1, B-2, B-3 Zoning Districts: Parking shall be permitted within the front yard or required front yard of any B-1, B-2 or B-3 zoning district property
only when located upon a parking lot constructed in accordance with all village ordinances. When parking shall be permitted in the front yard or
required front yard of any B-1, B-2 or B-3 zoning district property, a landscaped greenbelt, a minimum of five feet (5') wide, area shall be provided
along the lot line or lot lines abutting the streets.
(d) O-R Zoning District: Parking shall not be permitted in the front yard or required front yard of any O-R zoning district property except as expressly
provided for in subsection 5-11-3(G) of this title of the O-R district regulations.
(e) I-1 Zoning District: Parking shall not be permitted in the required front yard of any I-1 zoning district property except for visitor parking which may
be permitted in the front yard or required front yard on a maximum ratio of one parking space for visitors for every twenty five (25) regular required
parking spaces. The visitor parking spaces being provided for herewith shall be restricted for the exclusive use of visitors.
In the case of "through lots", as defined in section 5-1-7 of this title, parking may be permitted in the one required front yard as determined by
the zoningcommissioner based upon prevailing yard patterns.
In no instance shall parking be permitted in more than one required front yard on through lots.
In the case of "corner lots" in the I-1 zoning district, parking may be allowed in the "alternate front yard" (the front yard other than the primary
front yard as determined by the zoning commissioner based upon prevailing yard patterns) as if the alternate front yard were a side yard in the I-1
zoning district.
Parking access driveways shall be permitted in the required front yard of the I-1 zoning district if said parking access driveways are set back a
minimum of five feet (5') from the side lot line; provided furthermore, common access driveways may be located up to the side property line in the
I-1 zoning district where two (2) properties share a common access driveway; provided, however, common access driveways shall be permitted
only in those instances where the property owners sharing the common access driveway shall enter into and record in the county recorder's office
an unlimited permanent ingress and egress easement.
A common access driveway shall be permitted in the I-1 zoning district only when the other side yard of the property being serviced by the
common access driveway shall be totally landscaped, with the exception of sidewalks.
2. Side Yards:
(a) Parking may be permitted in a required side yard of any R-1 or R-2 zoning district property if located on a properly constructed driveway for which
a driveway permit has been issued.
(b) Parking may be located on a required side yard of any R-3, R-4, O, O-R or I-1 zoning district property but not within five feet (5') of a side lot line
or within the external forty percent (40%) of the required side yard, whichever is greater.
Common parking access driveways shall be permitted in the R-3, R-4, O, and I-1 zoning districts only when the other side yard of the property
being serviced by the common access driveway shall be totally landscaped, with the exception of sidewalks.
3. Rear Yards: Parking may be permitted in the required rear yard of any R-1, R-2, R-3, R-4 or O zoning district, but not within five feet (5') of the rear
lot line or within the external twenty five percent (25%) of the required rear yard, whichever is greater. Parking may be permitted in the required rear
yard of any B-1, B-2, O-R or I-1 zoning district, but not within five feet (5') of a rear lot line or within theexternal twenty percent (20%) of a required
rear yard, whichever is greater. (Ord. 2005-3890, 1-17-2005)
4. Parking Adjacent To Residential Districts: Notwithstanding the provisions aforesaid in any district on any lot devoted to other than single-family use, if
any front lot line, side lot line or rear lot line separates the lot from or is across the street or alley from a lot in a residential district, the off street
parking shall not be located closer to said lot line than the minimum front yard depth, side yard depth, side yard width or rear yard depth, as the case
may be, prescribed by the district in which the off street parking area is located; provided, however, that in no case shall the distance be less than ten
feet (10') from the front line.
All open automobile parking areas containing more than four (4) parking spaces shall be adequately screened on each side adjoining or fronting
on any property located in any residence district by a wall, fence or densely planted compact hedge, not less than three feet (3') nor more than six
feet (6') in height. In addition to the provisions of this subsection, screening provisions as noted in subsection 5-13-1-5(D) of this chapter shall be
adhered to. (Ord. 79-873, 7-3-1979)
5-13-1-3: LOCATION OF PARKING SPACES:
Off street parking space shall be located on the same lot as the use for which provided, except as set forth in this section.
Special Location Plan: Pursuant to the procedure hereinafter set forth, either part or all of the required off street parking space may be located off the lot of
the use for which the space is provided. Also, two (2) or more uses may share in the same off street parking space and each of such uses may be
considered as having provided such shared space individually. The following limitations shall apply to the "special location plan":
(A) Separation From Use: Off street parking shall be located as hereinafter specified; where a distance is specified, such distance shall be the walking
distance measured from the nearest point of the parking facility to the nearest point of the building that such facility is required to serve.
1. In all residential districts, parking facilities shall be located on the same lot or lots with the building they are required to serve.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 185/460
2. In all commercial districts, parking facilities shall be located within three hundred feet (300') of the building they are required to serve.
3. In all office-research districts, parking facilities shallbe located within four hundred fifty feet (450') of the building they are required to serve.
4. In all industrial districts, parking facilities shall be located within six hundred feet (600') of the building they are required to serve.
(B) Sharing Of Space: No use shall be considered as individually having provided off street parking space which is shared with one or more other uses
unless the schedules of operation of all such uses are such that none of the uses sharing the space requires the off street parking space at the same
time as any other use sharing the space.
(C) Application: All applications for approval of a "special location plan" hereunder shall be filed with the zoning board of appeals by the owners of the
entire land area to be included within the special plan, and the owner or owners of all structures then existing on said land area and all encumbrances
of said land area and structures; shall contain sufficient evidence to establish to the satisfaction of the zoning board of appeals that the applicants are
the owners and encumbrancers of the designated land and structures; shall contain such information and representations required by this chapter or
deemed necessary; and shall include plans showing the following details:
1. The location of the uses or structures for which off street parking space is required.
2. The location at which the off street parking space is to be located.
3. The design of the parking facility.
(D) Procedure:
1. All applications shall be reviewed and approved by the zoning board of appeals. Any approval may establish necessary conditions and limitations.
2. Upon approval of a "special location plan", a copy of such plan shall be registered and recorded among the records of the county recorder of deeds.
3. All special plans registered and recorded hereunder shall be binding upon the applicants for such special plans, their successors and assigns, shall
limit and control the issuance and validity of all zoning permits and zoning certificates and shall restrict and limit the use and operation of all land and
structures included within such special plans to all conditions and limitations specified in such plans and the approvals thereof.
4. All special plans registered and recorded hereunder may be amended pursuant to the same procedure and subject to the samelimitations and
requirements by which such plans were approved, registered and recorded.
5. Upon application to the zoning board of appeals by the owner or owners of the entire land area included within any special plan registered and
recorded hereunder, the owner or owners of any structures then existing thereon and all encumbrances of said land and structures, any such plan
may be withdrawn, either partially or completely, from registration and released from recording if all uses, land and structures remaining under such
plan can be made to comply with all conditions and limitations of the plan and all uses, land and structures withdrawn from such plan can be made to
comply with all regulations established by this chapter and unrelated to any special plan. (Ord. 713, 10-18-1977)
5-13-1-4: SEPARATE OR COMBINED PARKING SPACES:
Separate off street parking space shall be provided for each use or the parking space required of two (2) or more uses located on the same lot may be
combined and used jointly; provided, however:
(A) Where off street parking space is combined and used jointly by two (2) or more uses having different standards for determining the amount of off street
parking spaces required, the parking space shall be adequate in area to provide the sum total of off street parking space requirements of all such uses.
(B) Where off street parking space is combined and used jointly by two (2) or more uses having the same standard for determining the amount of off street
parking space required, all such uses, for the purposes of this section, shall be considered a single unit and the gross floor area of all such uses in all
structures on the same lot or the number of employees of all such uses in all structures on the same lot as fixed by the applicable standard, shall be
taken as a single total for the purpose of determining the amount of off street parking space required. (Ord. 713, 10-18-1977)
5-13-1-5: DESIGN, DEVELOPMENT AND MAINTENANCE OF PARKING AREAS:
Every parcel of land hereafter used as a public or private parking area, including a commercial parking lot and also an automobile, boat or trailer sales lot,
shall be designed, developed and maintained in accordance with the following requirements: (Ord. 713, 10-18-1977)
(A) Use Limit: In the residential districts, unless in a garage or fully enclosed structure, parking areas shall only be used by vehicles up to ten thousand
(10,000) pounds' gross vehicle weight. Vehicles classified as second divisionvehicles under 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes of more than ten thousand
(10,000) pounds' gross vehicle weight, farm machinery, construction equipment, heavy machinery and the like shall not be parked or housed in the
residential district, unless being used exclusively for building construction or agricultural uses in the immediate residential area. (Ord. 80-968, 12-16-
1980)
(B) Commercial Use: Shall not be used for the sale, repair, dismantling or servicing of any vehicles, equipment, materials, supplies or the parking of
commercial vehicles, except when parking is a permitted principal or special use. (Ord. 501, 2-19-1974)
(C) Design And Construction: Except for parking lots and driveways in the R-1, R-2 or R-3 zoning district not used for temporary festival parking, all
parking lots and driveways shall be provided with curb and gutter and shall be designed in accordance with the current standard detail sheets for
streets, parking lots, drives and alleys of the village as from time to time amended, and the state of Illinois department of transportation "Design Manual
For The Structural Design Of Bituminous And Concrete Pavements". All work shall be constructed in accordance with the current "Standard

Specifications For Road And Bridge Construction", adopted July 2, 1973, by the state of Illinois department of transportation.
Storm drainage shall be designed in accordance with the village ordinances and standard detail sheets and shall be constructed according to the
plans and specifications approved by the village engineer.
For all one- and two-family residences, all new parking areas and driveways shall be constructed of a minimum of four inches (4") of CA-6 crushed
stone base and two inches (2") of class I bituminous asphalt pavement or equivalent concrete construction. Provided, however, that brick or other
paver type materials may be installed if constructed with a minimum of eight inches (8") of CA-6 crushed stone base topped with one and one-half
inches (11/2") of sand base and minimum two and three-eighths inches (23/8") (6 cm) of pavers tested and approved to eight thousand five hundred

have an evergreenplanting berm, fence, masonry wall and/or such other screening that is at least eighty percent (80%) opaque or as may be
determined by the village board of trustees. Berming shall be considered as the preferred treatment when possible.
If parking areas are set in a distance of not less than two hundred feet (200') and access drives are set in not less than one hundred feet (100') from
a residential zoning district, screening shall not be required. (Ord. 501, 2-19-1974)
(E) Access: In the R-1 and R-2 zoning districts, access driveways shall be permitted not less than nine feet (9') in width nor more than twenty four feet (24')
in width, measured at the property line for any lot located within said districts.
Access in all other zoning districts other than R-1 and R-2 shall be provided with entrances and exits so located and designed as to minimize traffic
congestion. The location and design of entrances and exits shall be subject to the review and approval of the village engineer. (Ord. 713, 10-18-1977)
(F) Lighting: (Rep. by Ord. 2006-4025, 6-19-2006)

shall not be subject to structure setback requirements, but shall be subject to setback requirements pertaining to the location of the parking lot and/or
driveway setback. (Ord. 501, 2-19-1974)

5-13-1-6: UNITS OF MEASUREMENT FOR PARKING SPACES:
For purposes of this section, the following units of measurement shall apply:
(A) Floor Area: In the case of offices, merchandising or service types of uses, "floor area" shall mean the gross floor area used or intended to be used by
tenants and/or owners or for service to the public as customers, patrons, clients or patients, including areas occupied by fixtures and equipment used
for display or sale of merchandise. It shall not include areas used principally for nonpublic purposes, such as storage, incidental repair, processing or
packaging of merchandise, for show windows, for offices incidental to the management or maintenance of stores or buildings, for toilet or rest rooms,
for mechanical equipment, or for dressing rooms, fitting or alteration rooms.
(B) Dwelling Unit: A dwelling unit shall mean one room, or a suite of two (2) or more rooms, designed for or used by one family for living and sleeping
purposes and having only one kitchen or kitchenette.
(C) Seat Or Bench: A seat shall be the space intended for oneindividual; in places where patrons or spectators occupy benches, pews or other seating
facilities, each twenty inches (20") of such seating facilities shall be counted as one seat.
(D) Employees: Employees shall mean the average number of permanent staff members working on the premises at any one time as certified by an
affidavit signed by the owner and/or operator of the use or structure at the time application is made for a building permit and/or certificate of zoning
compliance.
(E) Fractions: When units of measurement result in the requirement of a fractional space, any fraction shall require one parking space. (Ord. 501, 2-19-
1974)

5-13-2: OFF STREET LOADING SPACES:
5-13-2-1: PURPOSE AND SCOPE:
It is the purpose of the off street loading regulations to reduce congestion on the streets due to excessive loading and unloading of vehicles on the streets.
The provisions of this section 5-13-2 shall apply and govern in all zoning districts. (Ord. 501, 2-19-1974)
5-13-2-2: GENERAL REQUIREMENTS FOR LOADING SPACES:
(A) Off street loading space shall be required and maintained in connection with any building or part thereof, hereafter erected or altered which is to be
occupied by uses requiring the receipt or distribution of materials or merchandise.
(B) Loading spaces for all types of uses may be provided either in garages or parking areas conforming with the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 501, 2-19-
1974)
5-13-2-3: LOCATION OF LOADING SPACES:
Off street loading spaces shall be located on the same lot as the structure for which provided. (Ord. 501, 2-19-1974)
5-13-2-4: LOADING SPACES REQUIRED:
The duty to provide the off street loading space herein required shall be the joint and several responsibility of the operator and owner of the structure or
structures for which off street loading space is required to be provided. No structure shall be designed, erected, altered, used or occupied unless the off
street loading space herein required is provided in at least the amount herein set forth; provided, however, that off street loading space need not be
provided for structures actually used, occupied and operated on the effective date hereof until such structures are enlarged or expanded, or the uses
within such structures are enlarged or expanded, or changed, so as to require a greater amount of off street loading space than the amount of off street
loading space not required to be furnished by reason of the foregoing exclusion, in which event the structures hereby excluded shall not be used, occupied
or operated unless there is provided for the increment only of such structures, and maintained as herein required, at least the amount of off street loading
space that would be required hereunder if the increment were a separate structure. (Ord. 501, 2-19-1974)
5-13-2-5: DESIGN, DEVELOPMENT AND MAINTENANCE OF LOADING SPACES:
Every parcel of land hereafter used for off street loading space shall be designed, developed and maintained in accordance with the following
requirements:
(A) Shall not be used for the sale, repair, dismantling or servicing of any vehicles, equipment, materials or supplies. (Ord. 501, 2-19-1974)
(B) Shall be graded for proper drainage and provided with an all weather surfacing maintained at all times in such a manner so as to prevent the release of
dust and to be free of dust, trash and debris.
All loading areas located outside of the buildings shall be provided with curb and gutter and shall be designed in accordance with the current
standard detail sheets for streets, parking lots, drives and alleys of the village, as from time to time amended, and the state of Illinois department of
transportation "Design Manual For The Structural Design Of Bituminous And Concrete Pavements". All work shall be constructed in accordance with
the current "Standard Specifications For Road And Bridge Construction", adopted July 2, 1973, by the state of Illinois department of transportation.
(Ord. 79-858, 5-15-1979)
(C) Off street loading spaces that adjoin or are across the street from property zoned for any residential use shall havea dense evergreen planting, fence,
masonry wall or such other screening as may be determined by the corporate authorities after a public hearing and recommendation by the zoning
board of appeals. The zoning board of appeals shall also determine the height, location and density of screening used to provide adequate protection
to adjoining property.
(D) Shall be provided with entrances and exits not less than twelve feet (12') in width and so located as to minimize traffic congestion.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 190/460
(E) No portion of a vehicle shall project into a street or alley while being loaded or unloaded nor shall any vehicle project into any required yard while being
loaded or unloaded. (Ord. 501, 2-19-1974; amd. 1979 Code)
(F) Each off street loading space shall be not less than twelve feet (12') in width, sixty five feet (65') in length and fourteen feet (14') in height, exclusive of
access drives. When more than three (3) spaces are required, the spaces other than the first three (3) may be ten feet (10') in width, twenty five feet
(25') in length and twelve feet (12') in height. (Ord. 79-845, 4-3-1979)
(G) Off street loading spaces may not occupy any part of any required rear yard or required side yard or any part of any required front yard or a front yard.
(1979 Code)

5-13-4: MODIFICATIONS:
The corporate authorities may grant, subject to the recommendation of the zoning board of appeals, after a public hearing has been held on the matter,
modification, reduction or waiver of the foregoing requirements if it should find that in the particular case appealed, the peculiar nature of the residential,
business, trade, industrial or other use, or the exceptional shape or size of the property or other exceptional situation or condition would justify such action.
