https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 207/460
15-97.A. Where a variance to the site runoff storage requirements of section 15-72 is granted, payment into the village of Lisle's site runoff storage
variance fee program shall be made prior to the issuance of a building permit as a condition of the variance.
15-97.B. The village of Lisle site runoff storage variance fee program shall operate as follows:
15-97.B.1. Payment of a site runoff storage variance fee for the varied storage shall be made to the village of Lisle and is determined by applying the
first applicable criteria as follows:
15-97.B.1.a. If the village of Lisle program has an established off-site storage facility(ies), the fee shall be calculated by multiplying the per acre-foot
cost of the closest off-site storage facility times the varied storage where:
15-97.B.1.a.1. A design concept plan for the facility has been approved by the village of Lisle's stormwater committee and the village board containing
an estimate of the per acre-foot cost of constructing the storage, including operation and maintenance costs; and
15-97.B.1.a.2. A formula has been developed to determine that any investment in the facility shall be at least equal to the cost of planning, acquiring of
lands, constructing, operating, and maintaining the facility; and
15-97.B.1.a.3. The facility is located in the same watershed planning area as the variance, or within the village of Lisle.
15-97.B.1.b. Where the Village of Lisle program has not established off-site storage facility(ies) in accordance with sub-parts B.1.a.1 through B.1.a.3
above, the site runoff storage variance fee shall be charged in accordance with an adopted fee schedule, as set out in the annual fee ordinance. The
fees set forth in the annual fee ordinance shall identify reasonable and rational costs to provide site runoff storage in the same watershed planning area
as the subject variance. It is hereby determined that the fee as set out in the village of Lisle's annual fee ordinance includes the village of Lisle's cost of
planning, acquiring land, construction, operation, and maintenance.
15-97.B.2. Fee in lieu funds collected shall be accounted for in separate development or watershed planning accounts. Funds shall be used in the
same watershed planning area as collected or in the village of Lisle to enhance existing site runoff storage facilities and related components, construct
off-site facilities and related components, provide maintenance of stormwater facilities, or undertake other development that provides a watershed
benefit.
15-97.B.3. The finance director shall provide accounting on an annual basis of all funds deposited in each development or watershed planning account
and shall account for each fund on a first-in, first-out basis.
15-97.B.4. The corporate authorities may prioritize and allocate funds on an annual basis within each development or watershed planning account. The
community development director or the stormwater administrator may make a request to the corporate authorities for funds within the accounts for uses
identified in section 15-97.B.2.
15-97.B.5. All site runoff storage variance fees shall be refunded to the person who paid the fee, or to that person's successor in interest, in
accordance with section 15-97.B.6, whenever the village of Lisle fails to encumber fees collected within 10 years from the date on which such fees
were collected.
15-97.B.6. Refunds shall be made provided that the person who paid the fee, or that person's successor in interest, files a petition with the village of
Lisle within one year from the date on which such fees are required to be encumbered.
(Ord. 2012-4463, 12-17-2012)
15-97.C. Funds collected in the village of Lisle shall be used within the village of Lisle, or within the watershed planning area in which the fee was
collected. All accounting records shall be made available to the DuPage County stormwater committee upon request.
(Ord. 2013-4497, 7-17-2013)

15-98. Post Construction BMP Fee-In-Lieu Program
15-98.A. With the approval of the stormwater administrator, and provided the conditions of section 15-63 apply, the applicant may be allowed or

schedule as set out in the annual fee ordinance that identifies reasonable and rational cost to construct and maintain similar PCBMPs for those areas
of the development that remain without effective water quality treatment. For VCBMP, fee-in-lieu payment shall be as set out in the annual fee
ordinance.
15-98.B.2. PCBMP and VCBMP funds collected shall be separately accounted for in watershed planning area accounts. Funds shall be used in the
same watershed planning areas as collected solely to design, construct, and maintain water quality or runoff volume reduction improvements. Funds
may not be used to fulfill obligations required by the ordinance.
15-98.B.3. The finance director shall provide accounting on an annual basis of all funds deposited in each watershed planning account and shall
account for each fund on a first-in, first-out basis.
15-98.B.4. The corporate authorities may prioritize and allocate funds on an annual basis within each watershed planning account. The community
development director or the stormwater administrator may make a request to the corporate authorities by March 30 of each year for funds within the
accounts for uses identified in section 15-98.B.2.
15-98.B.5. All BMP fee-in-lieu payments shall be refunded to the person who paid the fee, or to that person's successor in interest, in accordance with
section 15-98.B.6, when the village of Lisle fails to encumber that development's fees collected within ten (10) years of the date on which such fees
were collected.

(O) Appendix A, Definitions of the DuPage County countywide stormwater and floodplain ordinance is hereby amended by deleting those definitions for
"flood protection elevation" and "substantial improvement" and replacing them with the following: (Ord. 2012-4463, 12-17-2012)
Flood Protection Elevation (FPE). The base flood elevation plus two feet of freeboard, except within the regulatory floodplain of the east branch of
the DuPage River where the flood protection elevation (FPE) is the base flood elevation (BFE) plus three feet of freeboard. If an approved FEQ
watershed plan model produces a higher elevation than the regulatory BFE, the FPE shall be the FEQ flood of record elevation plus three feet of
freeboard.
Substantial Improvement. Any reconstruction, rehabilitation, addition, or improvement of a structure taking place during a ten year period, in which
the cumulative percentage of improvements equals or exceeds fifty (50) percent of the market value of the structure before the improvement or repair is
started. Substantial improvement is considered to occur when the first alteration of any wall, ceiling, floor, or other structural part of the building
commences, whether or not that alteration affects the external dimensions of the building. This term includes structures that have incurred repetitive
loss or substantial damage, regardless of the actual work done. The term does not, however, include either (1) any project for improvement of a
structure to comply with existing state or local health, sanitary, or safety code specifications which are solely necessary to assure safe living conditions,
or (2) any alteration of a "historic structure" listed on the national register of historic places or the Illinois register of historic places, provided that the
alteration will not preclude the structure's continued designation as a historic structure.
(Ord. 2014-4533, 5-19-2014)
5-16-5: INTERPRETATION:
In the interpretation and application of this chapter, the provisions expressed herein shall be held to be the minimum requirements and shall be liberally
construed in favor of the village and shall not be deemed a limitation or repeal of any other powers granted by state statutes. (Ord. 98-2963, 3-2-1998)
5-16-6: SAVING CLAUSE:
(A) Separability: If any section, clause, provision or portion of this chapter is adjudged unconstitutional or invalid by a court of competent jurisdiction, the
remainder of this chapter shall not be affected thereby.
(B) Abrogation And Greater Restrictions: It is not intended by this chapter to repeal, abrogate or impair any existing easements, covenants or deed
restrictions. However, where this chapter imposes greater restrictions, the provisions of this chapter shall prevail.
(C) Disclaimer Of Liability: The degree of flood protection required by this chapter is considered reasonable for regulatory purposes and is based on
historical records, engineering and scientific methods of study. Larger floods may occur or flood heights may be increased by manmade or natural
causes. This chapter does not imply that areas outside the prescribed floodplain boundaries or land uses permitted within such floodplains will be free
from flooding or flood damages. This chapter shall not create liability on the part of the village or any officer or employee thereof for any flood damages
which may result from reliance on this chapter or on any administrative decision lawfully made thereunder. (Ord. 98-2963, 3-2-1998)

SUPPLEMENTARY REGULATIONS
5-17-1: DWELLINGS ON LOTS OF RECORD:
In any district where dwellings are permitted, a one-family detached dwelling may be erected on any lot of official record at the effective date hereof,
irrespective of its area of width, provided the applicable yard and other open space requirements are complied with as nearly as possible. (Ord. 80-968,
12-16-1980)
5-17-2: HEIGHT LIMITATIONS NOT APPLICABLE:
The height limitations stipulated in this title shall not apply to the following:
(A) Architectural Features: Church spires, belfries, cupolas and domes, monuments, water towers, fire and hose towers, flagpoles, masts and aerials; and
parapet walls extending not more than four feet (4') above the limiting height of the building.

(B) Places Of Public Assembly: Places of public assembly in churches, schools and other permitted public and semipublic buildings, provided that these
are located on the first floor of such buildings and provided that for each three feet (3') by which the height of such building exceeds the maximum
height otherwise permitted in the district, its side and rear yards shall be increased in width or depth by an additional foot over the side and rear yards
required for the highest building otherwise permitted in the district.
(C) Elevator Penthouses, Etc.: Elevator penthouses, monitors and scenery lofts, provided no linear dimension of any such structure exceeds fifty percent
(50%) of the corresponding street lot line frontage; or to towers and monuments, fire towers, hose towers and cooling towers. (Ord. 80-968, 12-16-
1980)

5-17-5: MORE THAN ONE PRINCIPAL BUILDING ON A LOT:
Not more than one principal building shall be located on a lot in the R-1, R-2 and R-3 Residence Districts.
In any district where there is to be located a unit group of residential buildings, there shall be provided on the lot an unobstructed accessway of not less
than thirty feet (30') wide from the street on which the lot fronts to all principal buildings on the lot. For any unit group of residential buildings, the lot
frontage shall be not less than one hundred feet (100'). There shall be no residential building on the same lot with another building devoted to any principal
use other than residential. Where there is only one principal building, such building may contain mixed occupancies provided such occupancies are for
uses permitted by the appropriate district regulations. (Ord. 80-968, 12-16-1980)
5-17-6: VISION CLEARANCE:
On a corner lot, no fence or other structure more than three and one-half feet (31/2') in height above the plane of the established grades of the street shall
be erected on any part of the front yard or side yard herein established that is included within the street lines of intersecting streets and a line connecting
such street lines at a point which is twenty feet (20') from their point of intersection, measured along such street lines, and no planting of foliage shall be
placed or maintained within such area that, in the judgment of the building commissioner, will materially obstruct the view of a driver of a vehicle
approaching the street intersection.
In any required principal front yard, no fence or wall shall be permitted which materially impedes vision across such yard above the height of forty two
inches (42") and no hedge or other vegetation shall be permitted which materially impedes vision across such yard between the heights of forty two inches
(42") and ten feet (10').
The provisions of this section shall apply to all districts unless the setback requirements of the district are less restrictive. (Ord. 91-2162, 6-3-1991)
5-17-7: PARKING AND STORAGE OF RECREATIONAL VEHICLES AND TRAILERS:
Uses Yards
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 211/460
(A) Applicability And Definitions: These regulations shall apply to all recreational vehicles and trailers as defined below, in all residential zoning districts:
RECREATIONAL VEHICLE: Any camping trailer, motor home, travel trailer, truck camper or van camper used primarily for recreational purposes; as
well as vehicles including, but not limited to, all-terrain vehicles, boats, snowmobiles, watercraft, and other similar vehicles.
TRAILER: Every vehicle without mobile power in operation designed for carrying property and so constructed that no part of its weight rests upon the
towing vehicle.
(B) Location Of Recreational Vehicles And Trailers: Storage and parking of recreational vehicles and trailers shall be regulated as follows:
1. On any residential lot within any residential district, a maximum of one recreational vehicle or trailer per dwelling unit on said lot may be located
outside of a fully enclosed building or structure;
2. Recreational vehicles and trailers shall only be located on a residential lot if the vehicles and property are properly maintained including proper
drainage and compliance with tall grass and weed regulations;
3. Recreational vehicles and trailers shall not be located in the required front or corner side yards of a property if they exceed twenty five feet (25') in
length; and
4. Recreational vehicles and trailers shall not be located closer than five feet (5') to any rear property line and three feet (3') to any side property line. A
recreational vehicle or trailer stored on a driveway located closer than three feet (3') to the property line is permitted if the driveway was constructed
prior to 2006.
(C) Surface Of Parking Area: If a recreational vehicle or trailer is parked on a residentially zoned property pursuant to subsection (B) of this section, the
vehicle or trailer shall be parked on an improved surface constructed of a hard dustless material, generally asphalt, brick pavers, concrete, pervious
pavers, grasscrete or similar type material as determined by the zoning administrator.
(D) Ownership: Recreational vehicles, equipment or utility trailers stored or parked in a residence district shall be owned by the property owner or
occupant. Proof of ownership or a lease agreement shall be produced upon request by the village.
(E) Guest Parking: Any recreational vehicle owned by guests of the home may be parked on a residential driveway on a lot up to fourteen (14) days every
six (6) months.
(F) License And Registration; Condition Of Vehicle: All recreational vehicles shall be properly licensed, registered and in an operable condition.
(G) Prohibited Uses: No parked or stored recreational vehicle or trailer shall be used for living purposes or to conduct business.
(H) Public Right Of Way Not To Be Blocked; Setbacks: A recreational vehicle or trailer shall not be parked or stored so as to block the public right of way
and shall be set back at least three feet (3') from any sidewalk or five feet (5') from any street.
(I) Parking In A Driveway: Notwithstanding anything in this section to the contrary, any recreational vehicle may be parked in a driveway on a residential lot
two (2) times per month for a period not to exceed ninety six (96) hours for the purpose of loading, unloading, maintenance or repairs of said vehicle.
All major repairs shall be within an enclosed garage in residential areas. "Major repairs" shall be defined as repair work on a vehicle that needs a
complete overhaul or substantial replacement of parts.
(J) Variations: Requests to increase the number of recreational vehicles and trailers located outside of a fully enclosed building or structure in excess of
one vehicle shall be reviewed by the planning and zoning commission (PZC) as a zoning variation. (Ord. 2010-4324, 6-7-2010)
5-17-8: SPECIAL SETBACKS REQUIRED FROM VILLAGE WELL SITES:
(A) Identification Of Well Sites And Minimum And Maximum Setbacks: On any property within the required minimum and maximum setback distances
shown for the village well sites identified below no person or corporation shall construct, install, erect, enlarge or establish any "potential contamination
sources" as defined below:
Well Site
Minimum And
Maximum Setback
2 4710 Walnut Avenue 400 feet
3 4925 Yackley Avenue 400 feet
5 6203 Abbeywood Drive 400 feet
6 4497 Arborview 200 feet
(B) Potential Contamination Sources Defined:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 212/460
POTENTIAL PRIMARY SOURCE: Any unit at a facility or site not currently subject to a removal or remedial action which:
1. Is utilized for the treatment, storage, or disposal of any hazardous or special waste not generated at the site; or
2. Is utilized for the disposal of municipal waste not generated at the site, other than landscape waste and construction and demolition debris; or
3. Is utilized for the landfilling, land treating, surface impounding or piling of any hazardous or special waste that is generated on the site or at other
sites owned, controlled or operated by the same person; or
4. Stores or accumulates at any time more than seventy five thousand (75,000) pounds aboveground, or more than seven thousand five hundred
(7,500) pounds belowground, of any hazardous substances.
POTENTIAL SECONDARY SOURCE: Any unit at a facility or a site not currently subject to a removal or remedial action, other than a potential
primary source, which:
1. Is utilized for the landfilling, land treating, or surface impounding of waste that is generated on the site or at other sites owned, controlled or
operated by the same person, other than livestock and landscape waste, and construction and demolition debris; or
2. Stores or accumulates at any time more than twenty five thousand (25,000) pounds but not more than seventy five thousand (75,000) pounds
aboveground, or more than two thousand five hundred (2,500) pounds but not more than seven thousand five hundred (7,500) pounds
belowground, of any hazardous substances; or
3. Stores or accumulates at any time more than twenty five thousand (25,000) gallons aboveground, or more than five hundred (500) gallons
belowground, of petroleum, including crude oil or any fraction thereof which is not otherwise specifically listed or designated as a hazardous
substance; or
4. Stores or accumulates pesticides, fertilizers, or road oils for purposes of commercial application or for distribution to retail sales outlets; or
5. Stores or accumulates at any time more than fifty thousand (50,000) pounds of any deicing agents; or
6. Is utilized for handling livestock waste or for treating domestic wastewaters other than "private sewage disposal systems" as defined in the
private sewage disposal licensing act1. (Ord. 95-2664, 7-5-1995)
Chapter 18
ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT
5-18-1: REGULATIONS:
The building commissioner shall administer and enforce this title. He may be provided with the assistance of such other persons as the president of the
board of trustees may direct, all of whom shall be appointed by the president. The building commissioner and his assistants, in the discharge of their duties
and upon exhibition of proper credentials, shall have the right to enter at any reasonable hour upon any premises or in any building under construction or
alteration.
If the building commissioner shall find that any of the provisions of this title are being violated, he shall notify in writing the persons responsible for such
violations, indicating the nature of the violation and ordering the action necessary to correct it. He shall order discontinuance of illegal use of land, buildings
or structures; removal of illegal buildings or structures or of additions, alterations or structural changes thereto; discontinuance of any illegal work being
done; or shall take other action authorized by this title to ensure compliance with or to prevent violation of its provisions. (Ord. 350)
5-18-2: BUILDING PERMITS REQUIRED:
No building or other structure shall be erected, moved, added to or structurally altered without a permit therefor issued by the building commissioner1. No
building permit shall be issued except in conformity with the provisions of this title, including the issuance of a certificate of zoning compliance, as
hereinafter provided, except after written order from the corporate authorities, after a public hearing has been conducted and a recommendation submitted
by the board of zoning appeals.
Should any work for which a permit is required be commenced or be done before such permit is issued and obtained, the required permit may be issued
for such and subsequent work, however, the amount of the required fee as provided herein for all work shallbe double that otherwise so provided. The
issuance of such permit does not act to bar any other penalty, liability or action otherwise provided for in this chapter or village code but shall be in addition
thereto.
All applications for building permits shall be accompanied by plans in duplicate, drawn to scale, showing the actual dimensions and shape of the lot to be
built upon, the exact sizes and locations on the lot of buildings already existing, if any; and the location and dimensions of the proposed building or
alteration. The application shall include such other information as lawfully may be required by the building commissioner, including existing or proposed
building or alteration; existing or proposed uses of the building and land; and the number of families, housekeeping units or rental units the building is
designed to accommodate; conditions existing on the lot; and such other matters as may be necessary to determine conformance with and provide for the
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 213/460
enforcement of this title.
One copy of the plans shall be returned to the applicant by the building commissioner after he shall have marked such copy either as approved or
disapproved and attested to same by his signature on such copy. The second copy of the plans, similarly marked, shall be retained by the building
commissioner. (Ord. 97-2889, 6-2-1997)
5-18-3: EXPIRATION OF BUILDING PERMIT; SPECIAL BUILDING PERMIT:
If the work described in any building permit has not begun within ninety (90) days from the date of issuance thereof, said permit shall expire and be
canceled by the building commissioner and written notice thereof shall be given to the persons affected.
If the work described in any building permit has not been substantially completed within one year of the date of issuance thereof, said permit shall expire
and be canceled by the building commissioner and written notice thereof shall be given to the persons affected, together with notice that further work as
described in the canceled permit shall not proceed unless and until a special building permit has been obtained.
At the discretion of the Building Commissioner, such special permit may be based on the original application or he may require submission of a new
application. The special permit may include limitations on time allowed for substantial completion of the work, and provisions for a reasonable performance
bond to ensure completion within the time limit set. (Ord. 350)
5-18-4: CERTIFICATE OF ZONING COMPLIANCE:
It shall be unlawful to use or occupy or permit the use or occupancy of any building or premises, or both, or part thereof hereafter created, erected,
changed, converted or wholly or partly altered or enlarged in its use or structure, until a certificate of zoning compliance shall have been issued therefor by
the Building Commissioner stating that the proposed use of the building or land conforms to the requirements of this title.
No nonconforming structure or use shall be renewed, changed or extended until a certificate of zoning compliance shall have been issued by the Building
Commissioner. The certificate of zoning compliance shall state specifically wherein the nonconforming use differs from the provisions of this title.
No permit for erection, alteration, moving or repair of any building shall be issued until an application has been made for a certificate of zoning compliance,
and the certificate shall be issued in conformity with the provisions of this title upon completion of the work.
A temporary certificate of zoning compliance may be issued by the Zoning Administrator for a period not exceeding six (6) months during alterations or
partial occupancy of a building pending its completion; provided, that such temporary certificate may require such conditions and safeguards as will protect
the safety of the occupants and the public.
The Building Commissioner shall maintain a record of all certificates of zoning compliance, and copies will be furnished upon request to any person.
Failure to obtain a certificate of zoning compliance shall be a violation of this title and punishable under section 5-1-8 of this title.
No dwelling unit shall be occupied as a community residence until a certificate of zoning compliance has been issued by the Building Commissioner. No
certificate of zoning compliance shall be issued for a community residence unless:
(A) The community residence is located at least six hundred sixty feet (660') from any existing community residence, as measured from lot line to lot
line, except when a special use permit issued in accordance with subsection 5-19-1(B) of this title is issued to allow a community residence to locate
closer than six hundred sixty feet (660') to an existing community residence; and
(B) The applicant demonstrates that it has obtained licensing or certification required by the State to operate the proposed community residence, or
that the proposed community residence has been licensed or certified, if required to be licensed or certified by the State.
The Building Official may revoke a certificate of zoning compliance for a community residence if its license or certification, or the operator's license or
certification to operate community residences, is revoked.
A certificate of zoning compliance is not transferable to another operator nor to another location. (Ord. 2017-4724, 5-1-2017)
5-18-5: SECURITY DEPOSITS:
Cash deposit for cleanup of site during and after construction and damage that may result to Village property from construction:
(A) Security Deposit Required: No building permit required under section 5-18-2 of this chapter, or any amendment thereto, shall be issued unless the
applicant has made a cash security deposit with the Village Treasurer in accordance with the provisions of this section.
(B) Purpose Of Security Deposit: The purpose of such security deposit is to guarantee performance by each building permit holder of the obligation to
maintain the building and adjacent public and private property in a clean condition both during and after the course of construction, addition, alteration,
removal or demolition of a building or structure, in accordance with applicable laws and ordinances of the Village. Said security deposit is also to
guarantee that each building permit holder will restore all Village property that may be damaged in the course of construction, addition, alteration,
removal or demolition of a building or structure to its condition prior to the construction, addition, alteration, removal or demolition of a building or
structure, in accordance with applicable laws and ordinances of the village.
(C) Amount Of Security Deposit: The amount of the cash security deposit required under this section shall be as established by the annual fee ordinance.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 214/460
(D) Application Of Security Deposit: If the building official shall determine that a building site or the public or private property adjacent to a building site is,
by reason of construction work being conducted under the building permit therefor by the building permit holder or by any contractor or subcontractor
engaged for such work, not being maintained in a clean condition, free from an undue accumulation of rubbish, mud, debris or waste materials, the
building official shall serve a written notice or order upon the holder of the building permit directing that such condition be remedied within a time period
specified in such notice or order, which shall be not less than three (3) days. If such condition shall not be remedied within such time period, the
building official may request the village manager to direct the proper employees of the village to perform all work necessary to remedy such condition
and all costs thereof shall be charged against and deducted from the amount of the security deposit. If the building official shall determine that village
property adjacent to a building site is by reason of construction work being conducted under the building permit therefor by the building permit holder or
by any contractor or subcontractor engaged for such work, damaged, the building official shall serve a written notice or order upon the holder of the
building permit directing that such damage be remedied within a time period specified in such notice or order, which shall be not less than seven (7)
days. If such damage shall not be remedied within such time period, the building official may request the village manager to direct the proper
employees of the village to perform all work necessary to remedy such damage, and all costs thereof shall be charged against and deducted from the
amount of the security deposit.
(E) Return Of Deposit: After the construction, addition, alteration, removal or demolition at the building site has terminated, any holder of a building permit
may apply to the building official for a return of any unused portion of the security deposit. If, upon such application, the building official determines that
the building site and adjacent public and private property have been left in a clean condition and the adjacent village property has not been damaged,
the building official shall direct the village treasurer to refund to the holder of the building permit any unused portion of the security deposit, without
interest. Any security deposit of which refund is not applied for within five (5) years from the date of such deposit shall, to the extent permitted by
applicable law, become the property of the village. (Ord. 549, 1-21-1975)
(F) Application Fee: An application fee as established by the annual fee ordinance will be charged for each cash security deposit tendered to the village
treasurer pursuant to this section. (Ord. 84-1238, 10-1-1984)
5-18-6: LETTER OF CREDIT:
Prior to issuance of any building permit, the applicant or owner of the property to be improved shall provide the village with an irrevocable letter of credit in
a form approved by the village in an amount equal to one hundred ten percent (110%) of the approved village engineer's estimate of the cost of the
required public and quasi-public improvements for the project. In lieu of a letter of credit, the applicant may deposit cash with the village in the same
amount subject to approval by the village manager. The public and quasi-public improvements covered by the letter of credit shall include, but not be
limited to, street improvements, sidewalks, water systems, sanitary sewer systems, storm sewers, storm water management facilities, recreational
facilities, street lighting, traffic signals and landscaping.
If at any time the village determines that the amount of the irrevocable letter of credit as originally pledged, is insufficient to complete all of the work
guaranteed by such letter of credit, the applicant shall post additional security as required by the village. For such time as the village deems that the
amount of the then posted security is insufficient to cause the completion of the improvements, the village shall not be required to issue building,
occupancy or other permits. (Ord. 2000-3200, 2-21-2000)
5-18-7: ADMINISTRATIVE VARIATIONS:
Variations of six inches (6") or less from the maximum height or minimum yard requirement may be filed with the community development director. The
director, or authorized designee, may review the variation request and determine whether the variation request shall be granted.
(A) Application Requirements: Applications for administrative variations shall be filed with the community development director. The application must
include, but is not limited to, the following application requirements:
1. Plat of survey with legal description;
2. Site plan and architectural renderings, as appropriate;
3. Statement of hardship and neighborhood character, as set forth in subsection (B) of this section;
4. Application fee;
5. Reimbursement of fees agreement;
6. Notarized letters or survey from all adjoining property owners stating the following:
(a) Name of the applicant seeking the variation.
(b) Legal description and address of the subject property.
(c) Name and address of adjoining property owners.
(d) Statement of variation request.
(e) Statement that the adjoining property owner does understand the request and does not object to the variation request.
(B) Standards For Variation: Administrative variations shall only be granted when the variance request is consistent with the general purpose and intent of
the zoning code and the applicant has demonstrated in writing the satisfaction of the following three (3) standards:
1. Hardship Or Unintentional Human Error: That a particular hardship or practical difficulty exists that is unique to the subject property and does not
apply generally to properties in the zoning district, and that the strict enforcement of the zoning requirement deprives the applicant of the reasonable
use of the property.
2. Prohibitions: That the granting of the variation will not:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 215/460
(a) Impair an adequate supply of light and air to the adjacent property;
(b) Increase the hazard from fire or other dangers to said property;
(c) Diminish the value of land and buildings in the immediate neighborhood;
(d) Unduly increase traffic congestion in the public streets and highways;
(e) Increase the potential for flood damages to adjacent property;
(f) Otherwise impair the public health, safety, comfort, morals or general welfare of the inhabitants of the village of Lisle;
(g) Each variance will not set a precedent and each case shall be considered on its own merits.
3. Neighborhood Character: That the granting of the variation will be in harmony with the essential character of the neighborhood.
(C) Application Notification: Upon receipt of a complete application conforming to the requirements set forth in subsection (A) of this section, the
community development director shall review the application within thirty (30) days and notify the property owner via certified mail of his or herdecision.
If an application for an administrative variation is denied, the community development director shall explain the reasons for such denial and advise the
applicant that he or she may petition for a nonadministrative variation pursuant to subsection 5-19-1(C) of this title.
(D) Adjoining Property Owner Objection: In the event that an adjoining property owner objects to the administrative variation, the application for an
administrative variation under this section shall be subject to the requirements for a public hearing for a variation with the planning and zoning
commission, as set forth in subsection 5-19-1(C) of this title.
(E) Approval: If the community development director finds the variation request to meet the standards contained in this section, the community
development director shall do the following:
1. Provide notification to the applicant via certified mail.
2. Provide notification to the mayor and village board of trustees.
3. Record the variation with the office of the DuPage County recorder of deeds. The applicant shall bear all costs of recording the variation. (Ord. 2006-
4042, 8-7-2006)
Chapter 19
BOARD OF ZONING APPEALS, AUTHORITY; PROCEDURE FOR AMENDMENT TO THE
ZONING CODE
5-19-1: AUTHORITY1:
The zoning board of appeals shall have all the powers and duties prescribed by law and by this chapter, which are more particularly specified as follows:
(A) Interpretation: Upon appeal from a decision by an administrative official, to decide any question involving the interpretation of any provision of the
zoning code of the village, including determination of the exact location of any district boundary if there is uncertainty with respect thereto. (Ord. 84-
1175, 1-17-1984)
(B) Special Uses: To conduct public hearings upon applications for special uses, except for planned unit developments, and to recommend to the president
and board of trustees that the special use be either approved, denied or approved with modifications. Applications for planned unit developments shall
be heard by the plan commission pursuant to chapter 14 of this title and nothing herein shall be construed as governing applications for planned unit
developments. The zoning board of appeals shall act only in an advisory capacity to the president and board of trustees, and the power to permit a
special use is expressly reserved to the corporate authorities.
The zoning board of appeals may request and receive written reports and recommendations from the building and zoning commissioner and the
village planner relative to the special use application, if desired.
No special use shall be recommended by the zoning board of appeals unless it finds:
1. (a) It is necessary for the public convenience at that location;
(b) It is so designated, located and proposed to be operated that the public health, safety and welfare will be protected; and
2. Will not cause substantial injury to the value of otherproperty in the neighborhood in which it is to be located; and
3. Such special use shall conform to the applicable regulations of the district in which it is to be located.
Pursuant to 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-13-1.1, no special use shall be permitted by the corporate authorities unless such special use meets
the standards expressly established for such special use classification as set forth in this code.
(C) Variances: To conduct hearings on applications for variances from the strict application of any of the requirements of this chapter, and to recommend to
the president and board of trustees that the variance be either approved, denied or approved with modification. The zoning board of appeals shall act
only in an advisory capacity to the president and board of trustees and, pursuant to 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-13-5, the power to determine and
approve variations is expressly reserved to the corporate authorities.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 216/460
The use of variances is generally intended for cases of exceptional conditions whereby such strict application would result in practical difficulty or
unnecessary hardship that would deprive the owner of the reasonable use of the land or building involved. In recommending approval of a variance, the
zoning board of appeals shall suggest any conditions that it deems to be necessary or desirable. The zoning board of appeals shall not recommend
approval of a variance unless it finds:
1. That there are special circumstances or conditions, fully described in the findings, applying to the property (properties) for which the variance is
sought, which circumstances or conditions are peculiar to such property (properties) and do not apply generally to properties in that zoning district,
and that said circumstances or conditions are such that the strict application of this code would deprive the applicant of the reasonable use of the
subject property (properties).
2. That, for reasons fully set forth in the findings, the granting of the variance is necessary for the reasonable use of the property (properties) and that
the variance proposed is the minimum variance that will accomplish this purpose.
3. That the result of granting by the corporate authorities of the variance will be in harmony with the general purpose and intent of standards set forth
within this code and in harmony with the configuration and shape of lots within the subdivision in which the subject property lies, and will not be
injurious to adjacent property or otherwise detrimental to the public welfare. (Ord. 85-1336, 10-7-1985)
(D) Procedure And Notice:
1. Procedure: The board of zoning appeals shall act in strict accordance with the procedures specified by law and by this chapter. All appeals and
applications made to the board shall be in writing, on forms prescribed by the board accompanied by required plans and documents including, but
not limited to, proposed signage plans, if applicable, and shall be subject to notice and public hearing as provided herein and by statute. Every
appeal or application shall refer to the specific provision of the ordinance involved and shall exactly set forth the interpretation that is claimed, the
purpose for which the special use is sought, or the details of the variance that it applied for and the grounds on which it is claimed that the variance
should be granted, as the case may be. Every decision of the board of zoning appeals shall be by resolution, each of which shall contain a full record
of the findings of the board in the particular case. Each such resolution shall be filed in the office of the village clerk, by case number under one or
another of the following headings: "Interpretations", "Special uses", "Variances", together with all documents pertaining thereto. The board of zoning
appeals shall notify the village board of its resolution to recommend or to not recommend. Upon receipt of the recommendation of the board of
zoning appeals, the corporate authorities, by ordinance, with or without further public hearing, may adopt any proposed special use or variance or
may refer it back to the board for further consideration. Any proposed variance which fails to receive the approval of the board of appeals shall not be
passed except by the favorable vote of two-thirds (2/3) of all trustees of the village. (Ord. 2000-3252, 11-20-2000)
2. Notice: No action of the board of zoning appeals shall be taken on any case until after a public hearing held by the board of zoning appeals in
relation thereto, at which parties in interest and citizens shall have an opportunity to be heard. No less than fifteen (15) nor more than thirty (30) days'
notice of the time and place of such hearing shall be caused to be published by the village clerk at the applicant's expense in a newspaper of general
circulation in the village and shall contain the following information:
(a) The number designation of the petition (case no.).
(b) The scheduled date of the hearing.
(c) The scheduled location of the hearing.
(d) The purpose of the hearing.
(e) The name of the applicant.
(f) A description of the subject property. (Ord. 84-1175, 1-17-1984)
3. Signs: There shall be posted unobstructed notice of the public hearing on a sign to be located upon the subjectproperty for which a variance,
amendment or special use is requested. The sign shall be of size and coloring and with letters of sufficient size as to be clearly legible to the public
view from all adjacent public rights of way. The sign shall include and contain the number of the zoning case assigned by the village; the place, the
nature, the purpose and the date and time of such hearing; and the office address and phone number of the village clerk where information may be
obtained concerning the application. The applicant shall submit with his application, a fee as established by the annual fee ordinance to defer the
cost of erection, maintenance and removal of said sign by the village. Thereafter, said sign shall be furnished by the village and shall be posted not
more than thirty (30) days nor less than fifteen (15) days in advance of such hearing. Provided, however, that the failure of the village to post said
sign shall not impair or in any way affect the validity of any variance, amendment or special use granted subsequent to published notice, the purpose
of this notice requirement being only supplementary for additional convenience to the public.
The sign shall be of a size and shall contain lettering substantially similar to that shown in the village "Specimen Zoning Hearing Sign". The sign
shall be removed by the village within seven (7) days after the zoning board of appeals acts upon the applicants' petition and shall not otherwise be
obscured or removed. (Ord. 89-1816, 3-20-1989)
(E) Decisions Of The Board Of Zoning Appeals: In exercising the above enumerated powers, the board may reverse or affirm, wholly or partly or may
modify the order, requirement, decision or determination appealed from to the extent and manner that the board may decide to be fitting and proper in
the premises, and to that end the board shall have all the powers of the building commissioner from whom the appeal is taken. The concurring vote of
four (4) members of the board shall be necessary to reverse any order, requirement, decision or determination of the building commissioner or to
decide in favor of the applicant on any matter upon which it is authorized by this title to render a decision.
No order of the board permitting the erection or alteration of a building or the use of a building or premises shall be valid for a period longer than six
(6) months, unless a building permit for such erection or alteration is obtained and the work is started within such period or, where no erection or
alteration is necessary, the permitted use is established within such period. (Ord. 84-1175, 1-17-1984)
5-19-2: AMENDMENTS:
This title may be amended from time to time by ordinance. However, no amendments shall be adopted by the corporateauthorities of the village without a
hearing before the plan commission. Notice shall be given of the time and place of the hearing, not more than thirty (30) days nor less than fifteen (15)
days before the hearing, by publishing a notice thereof at least once in one or more newspapers published in the village. In case of a written protest
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 217/460
against any proposed amendment of the regulations or districts, signed and acknowledged by the owners of twenty percent (20%) of the frontage
proposed to be altered, or by the owners of twenty percent (20%) of the frontage immediately adjoining or across an alley therefrom, or by owners of
twenty percent (20%) of the frontage directly opposite the frontage proposed to be altered, is filed with the village clerk, the amendment shall not be
passed except by a favorable vote of two-thirds (2/3) of the trustees of the village then holding office. In such cases, a copy of the written protest shall be
served by the protestor or protestors on the applicant for the proposed amendment and a copy upon the applicant's attorney, if any, by certified mail at the
address of such applicant and attorney shown in the application for the proposed amendment. (Ord. 84-1175, 1-17-1984)
Chapter 20
FEES, CHARGES AND EXPENSES
5-20-1: SCHEDULE:
No person shall erect, construct or enlarge, alter, repair or convert, move, improve or change the use of any building or structure in the village or cause the
same to be done without first obtaining a separate permit for each such building or structure from the building commissioner, in accordance with the
following procedure1. (Ord. 535, 11-5-1974)
5-20-2: PROCEDURE:
The owner, contractor or authorized agent thereof shall file an application for such permit, in writing, with the building commissioner on a form furnished for
that purpose. An agent may be required to submit evidence to indicate his authority. The building commissioner shall examine applications for building
permits within a reasonable time after filing, not to exceed fifteen (15) days.
If an examination by the building commissioner indicates that the proposed work will be in compliance with the laws and ordinances applicable thereto,
approval of such application shall be made and the building commissioner shall issue a permit for the proposed work. If examination and/or physical
inspection reveals that a permit shall not be issued by reason of the proposed work being in violation of existing laws or ordinances, rejection of such
application shall be made and a report showing the reason for rejection shall be attached to the application and returned to the applicant.
A permit under which work is not commenced within ninety (90) days after issuance shall expire by limitation. A new application shall be filed and a new
permit required before work is started, except as may be modified under section 5-18-3 of this title. A copy of the permit shall be posted on the premises
for public inspection during the prosecution of the work and until completion of the same.
Every application shall contain the following:
(A) A description of the land on which the proposed work is to be done, by lot number, street address or by metes and bounds.
(B) Show the type of use or occupancy to be made of all parts of the building or premises.
(C) State the valuation of the proposed work, i.e., contract price or estimated construction costs.
(D) File a plot plan showing size and location of all new construction and all existing structures on the site, including distances from lot lines. (This is
required only on outside construction involving addition to existing buildings or new building construction.) Provision for required off street parking shall
also be shown on the plot plan.
(E) A brief description of the proposed work. (Ord. 535, 11-5-1974)
5-20-3: FEES:
The fee for issuance of a zoning certificate, variance or special use permit shall be as established by the annual fee ordinance. Anyone applying for a
hearing before the zoning board of appeals, the plan commission, the stormwater oversight committee, or for any change of zoning shall bear the expense
for any cost incurred resulting from the application, including, but not limited to, professional services fees, mailing and copying expenses and any legal
advertising costs by such application, and a filing fee as established by the annual fee ordinance. No action will be taken by the corporate authorities until
such costs incurred by the village are reimbursed.
Should any work for which a permit is required be commenced or be done before such permit is issued and obtained, the required permit may be issued
for such and subsequent work, however, the amount of the required fee as provided herein for all work shall be double that otherwise so provided. The
issuance of such permit does not act to bar any other penalty, liability or action otherwise provided for in this chapter or this code but shall be in addition
thereto. (Ord. 2008-4220, 8-4-2008)
Footnote 1: See the annual fee ordinance for building permit fees.
Chapter 21
MODEL HOMES AND SITE CONSTRUCTION
5-21-1: DEFINITIONS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 218/460
ADMINISTRATIVE AND/OR SALES SPACE: The area of a model home used actively for administration, supervision and clerical services in conjunction
with dwelling sales, rental, or project construction, but not including the area of model home used for decorated room mock up, materials and/or product
display, or material storage.
BUILDER, CONTRACTOR DEVELOPER OR MANAGEMENT COMPANY: The individual, company, or corporation responsible for the development,
sales, and/or rental of dwellings.
CONSTRUCTION MATERIALS STORAGE TRAILERS: Any temporary movable trailer which is, was, or may be used for the storage of construction
materials or tools, a shelter for workmen or for construction supervision activity, and which is located at a site other than its permanent storage location.
MODEL HOMES: Any sample or archetype of a dwelling and its attendant accessory uses as "dwelling" and "accessory use" are defined in section 5-1-7
of this code. The term "model home" shall not include "structures" as defined in section 5-1-7 of this code, except archetypes of dwellings and accessory
uses. In addition, temporary buildings constructed as dwelling mock ups may be considered as model homes. Mobile homes, trailers, or construction
trailers shall not be considered as model homes for dwelling display purposes. A model home may be further defined as a dwelling used initially for display
purposes which typifies the type of dwelling that will be constructed and sold or rented in other parts of the development.
PLANNED UNIT DEVELOPMENT: As defined in section 5-1-7 of thiscode, which may be amended from time to time.
SUBDIVISION: As defined in section 6-1-6 of this code, which may be amended from time to time. (Ord. 85-1294, 5-20-1985)
5-21-2: PERMIT REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to establish or operate within a residential district within the corporate boundaries of the village, a model home, a
temporary sales office construction trailer, a construction office trailer, or a construction materials storage trailer, without first obtaining a permit therefor in
compliance with the provisions of this chapter.
Should any person establish or operate the above before such permit is issued and obtained, the required permit may be issued, however, the amount of
the required fee as provided herein shall be double that otherwise so provided. The issuance of such permit does not act to bar any other penalty, liability
or action otherwise provided for in this chapter or this code but shall be in addition thereto. (Ord. 97-2889, 6-2-1997)
5-21-3: ENFORCEMENT:
The building and zoning commissioner shall enforce all provisions of this chapter as described herein or such provisions as hereafter may be enacted, for
the purpose of securing such enforcement. The building and zoning commissioner shall have the right, and is hereby empowered, except as is otherwise
prohibited by law, to enter upon any premises and inspect the model home or other unit regulated under this chapter. The building and zoning
commissioner is further empowered to issue orders granting, renewing and revoking such permits in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. (Ord.
85-1294, 5-20-1985)
5-21-4: APPLICATIONS:
(A) Applicants for a permit under this chapter, whether a person, partnership or corporation, shall file a written, sworn application signed by the applicant,
upon forms provided by the village clerk, together with a permit fee in an amount as established by the annual fee ordinance per model home or each
trailer, in addition to other fees as set forth in this code. The application shall include the following information:
1. Name, address and telephone number of the applicant.
2. The purpose, use and exact location of the proposed model home.
3. The zoning classification of the lot on which the model home is located.
4. Acknowledgment of the applicant that the permit shall terminate upon expiration or cancellation of the permit as set forth herein.
(B) Each application for a permit under this chapter must be accompanied by a site plan for the model home site. The site plan shall be drawn at a scale of
not less than one inch (1") for every one hundred feet (100') and shall include:
1. Location of principal building;
2. Location of accessory buildings or structures;
3. Driveway, walks, and patios;
4. Off street parking (if provided), including construction details and surface type. If parking lot is to be temporary, it should be so designated;
5. Fences or walls;
6. Landscape plans and details;
7. Signs;
8. Lighting plans;
9. Grading plans;
10. Refuse containers; and
11. Adjacent structures or uses, and screening if necessary.

(C) In addition to the foregoing, each application for a permit must be accompanied by a certified check, cashier's check, negotiable security or a surety
bond made payable to the village in an amount as established by the annual fee ordinance in relation to the cost of restoring the land to its original,
unimproved condition. All lots must be so restored within three (3) months after the expiration of the above referenced permit. The amount of the

5-21-5: R-1, R-2 SINGLE-FAMILY RESIDENCE DISTRICTS:
In any R-1, R-2 single-family residence districts, all model home permits shall be subject to the following regulations:
(A) In any subdivision in which one or more general contractor isoffering to construct residential buildings, each general contractor may maintain up to five
(5) model homes per subdivision.
(B) The permit for any model home under this section shall cease and terminate automatically and with no further action on the part of the village, when all
lots except the lot on which the model home rests have been sold. (Ord. 85-1294, 5-20-1985)
5-21-6: R-3, R-4 MULTI-FAMILY RESIDENCE DISTRICTS:
In any R-3 or R-4 multi-family residence district, all model home permits shall be subject to the following regulations:
(A) A model home in an apartment building or condominium building may be used to conduct sales for any dwelling unit within said building, or within
another building or temporary building on the same lot, or in the same planned unit development.
(B) The permit for any model home issued pursuant to this chapter shall cease and terminate automatically, and with no further action on the part of the
village, when all of the permittee's units except the model home unit have been sold.
(C) A management office with model rental units may remain within a rental complex as a continuing operation. (Ord. 85-1294, 5-20-1985)
5-21-7: STORAGE OF CONSTRUCTION MATERIALS:
No construction materials may be stored on the premises of the model home unless contained within a garage or basement of the model home. All such
materials stored in any garage or basement of a model home must be intended and used for construction of buildings within the same or an immediately
contiguous subdivision within the corporate boundaries of the village. (Ord. 85-1294, 5-20-1985)
5-21-8: USE OF MODEL HOME AS OFFICE:
No more than thirty percent (30%) of the living area of a model home, not including any garage or basement, may be used for administration and/or sales
space, as defined in section 5-21-1 of this chapter, but in no event shall such use occupy more than one thousand (1,000) square feet. (Ord. 85-1294, 5-
20-1985)
5-21-9: TEMPORARY TRAILERS AS OFFICE USE:
Trailers may not be used as sales offices, except during the time a model or models are being constructed, at which time it may be possible to obtain a
permit under this chapter and operate a temporary sales office. After the model home is completed or six(6) months elapses, the temporary trailer must be
removed. (Ord. 85-1294, 5-20-1985)
5-21-10: TRAILERS USED AS CONSTRUCTION OFFICES:
After obtaining a permit as provided in this chapter, a trailer may be used as a construction office until construction is substantially completed, provided
that the trailer is located within the same or in an immediately contiguous subdivision within the corporate boundaries of the village. If the building and
zoning commissioner determines that the use of a trailer as a construction office constitutes a "nuisance", as defined by section 1-3-2 of this code, the
building and zoning commissioner may initiate proceedings to revoke the model home permit, as provided in subsection 5-21-14(A) of this chapter. (Ord.
85-1294, 5-20-1985)
5-21-11: CONSTRUCTION MATERIALS STORAGE TRAILERS:
(A) Construction trailers shall not be located as a part of the model home complex, except when used as an office, as permitted under section 5-21-10 of
this chapter.
(B) The use of construction materials storage trailers in the village are subject to the following regulations:
1. Construction materials storage trailers must be permitted as set forth in section 5-21-2 of this chapter and as otherwise provided by this chapter.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 220/460
2. A minimum of four inches (4") of compacted gravel shall be overlaid on the site on which the construction trailer will rest, on the surrounding area,
and on parking areas and access roads to such areas.
3. Construction trailers shall not be located within any public or private right of way nor shall they be located so as to interfere in any way with a public
or private easement.

The use of any outdoor advertising or signs of any type, whether temporary or permanent, used in connection with a model home permitted hereunder,

5-21-13: RENEWAL:
(A) The permit granted herein shall be valid for a period of not more than one year, and be renewed prior to its expiration for a period not to exceed one
year. In order to renew a permit, the permittee must submit to the building and zoning commissioner arenewal application, upon forms provided by the
village clerk, together with a renewal permit fee in an amount as established by the annual fee ordinance.
(B) If the permitted model home is located in a district improved with single-family homes, a condition of renewal shall be that the permittee must
demonstrate that he has sold at least one lot during the one hundred eighty (180) day period immediately preceding the expiration of the permit. Such
lot must be located either within the same subdivision as the model or within an immediately contiguous subdivision within the corporate boundaries of
the village in order to render the permittee eligible for renewal of his permit. Evidence of the sale of a lot must be provided in the form of an instrument
of conveyance to an individual who will reside on the premises, or in the form of an occupancy permit.
(C) If the permitted model home is located in a district improved with multi-family dwellings, renewal shall be conditioned upon a showing that some units
still remain for sale within the same building, upon the same lot, or in the same planned unit development. However, if the model home is operated in
conjunction with a management office for rental units, no such showing need be made. (Ord. 85-1294, 5-20-1985)
5-21-14: REVOCATION:
(A) In the event the building and zoning commissioner determines that a violation of any of the regulations set forth in this chapter have occurred, the
commissioner may initiate proceedings to revoke the permit for that model home or other unit regulated herein.
(B) At the time the building and zoning commissioner decides that a revocation should occur, the village clerk shall give written notice to the permittee by
certified or registered mail, return receipt requested. The revocation will become effective forty five (45) days from the date notice was sent by the
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 221/460
village clerk.
(C) Any permittee may appeal the building and zoning commissioner's decision to revoke said permit by requesting a hearing before the board of zoning
appeals of the village, pursuant to the provisions of chapter 19 of this title. Such request shall be made by completing the appropriate request for
hearing form and filing such document with the building and zoning commissioner and the board of zoning appeals within forty five (45) days from the

(D) If a permittee files a timely request for hearing, the revocation shall be stayed until a hearing before the board of appeals can be held.
