Chapter 26
LANDSCAPING AND TREE PRESERVATION
5-26-1: GENERAL PROVISIONS:
(A) Purpose: This chapter is established to create uniform landscaping, screening and tree preservation standards for development of property in the
village and review of plans therefor, in order to ensure that the village remains attractive, safe and comfortable. The landscape standards herein are
established:
To promote, protect and preserve the general health and safety of the people of the community and, as part of the general welfare, ensure aesthetic
compatibility among land uses within the community;
To conserve soil and reduce soil erosion, reduce stormwater runoff, to provide oxygen regeneration to enhance air quality, and to reduce the effects of
urban heat islands;
To minimize the harmful or nuisance effects resulting from noise, dust, debris, motor exhaust, headlight glare, artificial light intrusions, objectionable
sight or activities, or similar incompatible impacts conducted or created by adjoining or nearby land use;
To safeguard the environmental quality and aesthetic character of the community by limiting the removal and ensuring replacement of trees upon
private property within the village;
To preserve, insofar as practical, existing vegetation and topographical features by limiting unnecessary clearing and modification of land, encouraging
the retention of existing mature trees, requiring the replacement of indigenous trees with approved species; and
To encourage the energy efficient operation of land uses in the public interest.
Landscaping required by this chapter shall be a condition to the issuance of a certificate of occupancy for any improvements built on a zoning lot in the
village.
(B) Applicability: Single-family detached residential and two-family residential uses shall be exempt from the requirements of this chapter except for those
requirements outlined in section 5-26-5, "Intersection Visibility Requirements", of this chapter. Residential lots with underlying commercial zoning,
residential subdivisions, entry features, stormwater detention facilities, public ROW and open space amenities within new single-family detached and
two-family developments shall conform to the requirements of this chapter, and be subject to site plan review. All other uses in any district shall conform
to the applicable requirements of this chapter.
(C) Enforcement: No building permit or occupancy permit shall be issued for any lot or use that is subject to the requirements of this chapter unless all the
requirements of this chapter have been fulfilled. Where a landscape plan is required, no building permit shall be issued unless the zoning official has
approved such landscape plan. Failure to implement the landscape plan, or to maintain the lot or use in substantial conformance with the landscape
plan, shall be cause for revocation of the occupancy permit and/or the application of fines and penalties, as established in section 5-26-12 of this
chapter. (Ord. 2005-3890, 1-17-2005; amd. Ord. 2006-3979, 1-9-2006)
5-26-2: LANDSCAPE PLAN REQUIREMENTS:
On any parcel of land requiring site plan approval by the village, a landscape plan shall be submitted. No permit for work, including site plan approval shall
be issued until the landscape plan has been approved by the zoning administrator, or his designee. Landscaping plans shall comply with the following:
(A) Landscape Architect: All landscape plans must be prepared by a state of Illinois registered landscape architect. Under special circumstances a request
to waive this requirement may be submitted to the zoning administrator for his consideration.
(B) Landscape Plan Content:
1. The name, address and phone number of the landscape architect or other person who prepared the plan; scale, north arrow, date of preparation and
any revision, project name and address, and identification of the plans as a preliminary or final landscape plan.
2. Location and dimensions of existing and proposed buildings and structures within the development site and within one hundred feet (100') of the
development site.
3. The locations and dimensions of all existing and/or proposed parking lots, drives, roadways, loading areas, and rights of way, sidewalks,
freestanding signs, refuse disposal areas, bicycle parking areas, freestanding electrical equipment, building mounted signs, heating, ventilation and
air circulation equipment, and all fences.
4. The location of all existing and proposed utilities and easements.
5. The location of all proposed site, building and parking lighting.
6. The location, quantity, size, root ball condition and type, scientific and common names of all proposed plant materials. All trees used to satisfy a tree
replacement requirement must be clearly identified.
7. The location of all proposed grading, berming and swales indicating contours at one foot (1') intervals.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 235/460
8. Specification of the type, boundaries, size and spacing of all proposed ground cover, turf and method of installation including grass seed mixes.
9. The location, size, and common name of all existing plant material intended to be preserved on the site and within twenty five feet (25') of the site.
10. A tree survey and tree preservation plan as set forth in section 5-26-13 of this chapter.
11. Details of all fences, bridges, retaining walls, or other similar elements proposed to be located on the site (section 5-26-10 of this chapter).
12. Typical planting details for trees, shrubs, ground covers, etc. (section 5-26-15 of this chapter).
13. Final opinion of probable landscape construction costs.
(C) Plan Coordination: The final landscape plan base sheet and site plan must match the final, approved engineering plans. It is strongly encouraged to
use a gray tone copy of the final engineering plan as a base sheet for the final landscape plan preparation.
(D) Plan Size: Landscape plans must be prepared at a traditional engineering scale, and on a sheet size not exceeding twenty four inches by thirty six
inches (24" x 36"). (Ord. 2005-3890, 1-17-2005; amd. Ord. 2006-3979, 1-9-2006)
5-26-3: PLANT MATERIAL REQUIREMENTS:
(A) Selection: Plant materials installed pursuant to this chapter shall be of good quality and of species normally grown in northeastern Illinois and shall be
capable of withstanding the extremes of the individual site microclimates. The size and density of selected plant materials at the time of planting, and at
maturity, are additional criteria which shall be considered in preparing the landscape plan.
All plant material installed must be either balled and burlapped (B&B) or containerized. The use of bare root material is prohibited.
(B) Minimum Plant Sizes: Minimum sizes for plant material at the time of installation for all landscape areas required by this code shall be as follows:
Shade trees, deciduous 3 inch caliper
Parkway trees 3 inch caliper
Evergreen trees 6 feet high
Ornamental trees, deciduous 8 feet high or 21/2 inch caliper
Shrubs, evergreen 24 inches (height or width)
Shrubs, deciduous 36 inches high
18 inch dwarf variety
Perennials/ornamental grasses 1 gallon container
Ground cover 3 inch pots1
Note:
1. Planted at a spacing to achieve complete coverage of the area within 2 years of installation.
(C) Prohibited Trees: Tree species that detract from the village's appearance due to their tendency to produce numerous "weed seedlings" or which
produce dead wood due to their soft wood nature or short span of life shall be prohibited, except where determined appropriate by the zoning
administrator. Specifically, prohibited tree species for new planting shall include, but not be limited to:
Black locust;
Box elder;
Buckthorn;
Elm (except new hybrids);
Mountain ash;
Osage orange;
Poplar (all species);
Red mulberry;
Russian olive;
Silver maples (except new hybrids);
Tree of heaven;
Weeping willow (except in large, wet areas); and
White birch.
In addition, the zoning administrator shall have the right to prohibit plant materials other than those listed above based on current agricultural practices,
regional diseases/insect infestations and recommendations of the American Association of Nurserymen.
(D) Installation: All plant material shall be installed in accordance with the planting procedures established by the American Association of Nurserymen,
latest edition.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 236/460
(E) Planting Design: Innovative landscape design or treatments are encouraged and shall be considered as a positive attribute in connection with any
request for a variation from the requirements of this chapter.
Plant material shall be carefully selected to satisfy all size requirements of this chapter at both installation and at maturity.
(F) Planting Beds: All planting beds shall be mulched in their entirety with shredded hardwood bark mulch or other similar organic material, three inches
(3") deep. Color dyed mulch, lava rock or large diameter bark chips ("chunk bark") are not acceptable. Gravel and stone mulches are not permitted.
Mulch beds at time of planting shall extend a minimum of two feet (2') beyond the center of all shrubs and have a four inch (4") deep spaded edge
around the perimeter.
(G) Maintenance: All landscaping and plant materials installed pursuant to an approved landscape plan shall be properly maintained by the owner thereof
(section 5-26-12 of this chapter). Plant material which dies shall be promptly replaced in compliance with the approved landscape plan.
All new landscape installations shall be warranted by the installing landscape contractor for a period of one year from the date of substantial
completion. (Ord. 2005-3890, 1-17-2005; amd. Ord. 2006-3979, 1-9-2006)
5-26-4: PUBLIC ROW LANDSCAPE REQUIREMENTS:
(A) Parkway Turf: All parkways shall be fine graded with a minimum of six inches (6") of topsoil and sodded. Sod shall be a Kentucky bluegrass blend and
grown on a mineral soil base.
In situations where establishment watering is not possible, drill seeding with a straw blanket cover will be permitted.
(B) Parkway Trees: All parkway trees shall be provided and planted as follows:
1. Minimum tree size shall be three inch (3") caliper, measured six inches (6") above the ground at time of planting.
2. Trees shall have a straight, clear trunk, free of branches to a minimum height of five feet (5').
3. Trees must be balled and burlapped (B&B) with no exceptions. Tree height, width and root ball size shall meet the standards of "American Standard
For Nursery Stock", ANSI Z60.1, latest edition.
4. Substandard "B grade" or "park grade" plants are not acceptable.
5. Trees shall be spaced evenly and planted not more than forty feet (40') apart. Driveways or other pavement areas do not reduce the parkway tree
requirement, which is determined by the total length of street frontage divided by forty (40).
6. Parkway trees shall be planted in all parkways having a width of five feet (5') or more. The village shall have the right to require trees to be planted
outside of the right of way if the parkway is less than five feet (5') wide, or in the case of utility conflicts.
7. Parkway trees shall be installed to maintain the following minimum separations:
Driveways 10 feet
Fire hydrants 8 feet
Intersections See section 5-26-5 of this chapter
Streetlights 15 feet
Other aboveground utilities 5 feet
8. Parkway tree species shall be limited to those identified in exhibits A and B of this section.
9. To ensure genetic diversity, multiple tree species must be planted to avoid a monoculture situation.
10. If requested, evidence must be provided that trees come from state inspected, commercially licensed nurseries.
(C) Prohibited Activities: No person, unless permitted by the village, shall:
1. Plant, treat, prune, remove or otherwise disturb any parkway tree except that normal watering and fertilizing will be permitted.
2. Trim, prune, or remove any tree or portions thereof if such tree or portions thereof may reasonably be expected to fall on village property or
otherwise cause damage to persons or property.
3. Place on village property any planters or plant containers.
4. Damage, cut, tap, carve or transplant any parkway tree.
5. Attach any rope, wire, nail, sign, poster or other manmade object to any parkway tree.
6. Excavate, grade or ditch any village property.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 237/460
(D) Other Improvements: Other decorative elements, mailboxes, traffic control devices, etc., shall be as regulated in section 7-1A-5 of this code.

5-26-5: INTERSECTION VISIBILITY REQUIREMENTS:
Landscaping must be designed and installed to minimize potential obstruction of critical sightlines. Specifically, at the intersection of all commercial
driveways, parking lot aisles, or public and private streets and alleys (including residential lots) unobstructed visibility between twenty four inches (24") and
six feet (6') above the height of the pavement must be maintained. To maintain this visibility, no berms, shrubs or other landscape material which will reach
a mature height greater than twenty four inches (24") shall be permitted within a twenty five foot (25') sight triangle. The sight triangle is measured from the
intersecting property or ROW lines as shown in the illustration below. Trees are allowed in sight triangles provided the lowest branching begins not less
than eight feet (8') above the pavement grade.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 239/460
(Ord. 2005-3890, 1-17-2005; amd. Ord. 2006-3979, 1-9-2006)
5-26-6: BUILDING AND PERIMETER/BUFFER YARD REQUIREMENTS:
(A) Building Foundation Landscaping: All buildings (except single-family residential) shall provide a continuous eight foot (8') wide (minimum) landscape
area around the full perimeter, excluding pedestrian and vehicle access points. This landscape area shall be one hundred percent (100%) planted
along the front, fifty percent (50%) planted along each side and twenty five percent (25%) planted in the rear. Plantings shall be a combination of trees,
shrubs, perennials and ground covers used to enhance the building's architecture, soften its mass and break up blank walls. The remaining areas not
planted must be vegetated with sod or seed and blanket.
(B) Perimeter/Buffer Yard Landscaping: All developments (except single-family residential) shall provide a perimeter landscape buffer as follows:
1. Nonresidential Property Abutting Residential Property: Where nonresidential property abuts property in a residential district, landscaping shall be
provided as follows:
(a) A solid screen six feet (6') in height shall be provided along the entire length of the abutting property line. Such screen shall consist of a solid
wood fence, berms, trees, evergreens, shrubbery, and/or other live planting materials, necessary to provide one hundred percent (100%)
coverage.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 240/460
(b) Shade trees shall be provided at the equivalent of one for each thirty feet (30') of frontage along the abutting property line. Such trees may be
clustered or spaced linearly as determined appropriate.
2. Nonresidential Property Abutting Nonresidential Property: Where nonresidential property abuts property in a business, office or industrial district,
landscaping shall be provided as follows:
(a) Shade trees shall be provided at the equivalent of one for each fifty feet (50') of frontage along the abutting property line. Such trees may be
clustered or spaced linearly as determined appropriate.
(b) Other landscaping materials, including berms if possible, ornamental trees, evergreens, shrubbery, hedges, and/or other live planting materials
shall be provided across thirty percent (30%) of the abutting property line.
3. Multiple-Family Residential Property: Where multiple-family residential use abuts property in any zoning district, landscaping shall be provided as
follows:
(a) Shade trees shall be provided at the equivalent of not less than one for each forty feet (40') of frontage along the abutting property line. Such
trees may be clustered or spaced linearly as appropriate.
(b) Other landscaping materials, including berms if possible, ornamental trees, evergreens, shrubbery, hedges, and/or other live planting materials
shall be provided across fifty percent (50%) of the abutting property line. (Ord. 2005-3890, 1-17-2005; amd. Ord. 2006-3979, 1-9-2006)
5-26-7: PARKING LOT LANDSCAPE REQUIREMENTS:
(A) Perimeter Parking Lot Landscaping: The perimeter of every parking lot shall be landscaped with a minimum five foot (5') wide buffer area and planted
as follows:
1. Front And Corner Side Yards:
(a) Where a parking lot is located in or adjacent to a front or corner side yard in a residential district, continuous landscaping shall be provided across
one hundred percent (100%) of the parking lot frontage to a minimum height of three feet (3'). Such landscaping shall consist of any combination
of hedges, and/or other live planting material. Plantings shall be a minimum fifty percent (50%) evergreens.
(b) Where a parking lot is located in or adjacent to a front or corner side yard not in a residential district, continuous landscaping shall be provided
across sixty percent (60%) of the parking lot frontage to a minimum height of three feet (3'). Such landscaping shall consist of any combination of
berms, shade and ornamental trees, evergreens, shrubbery, hedges and/or other live planting material. Plantings shall be a minimum fifty percent
(50%) evergreens.
2. Rear And Side Yards:
(a) Where a parking lot is located in a yard adjacent to a residential zoning district, landscaping shall be provided as follows:
(1) Screening between the parking lot and the residential property line shall be a minimum of six feet (6') in height along one hundred percent
(100%) of the parking lot.
(2) Shade trees shall be provided at the equivalent of one for each thirty (30) linear feet, or fraction thereof, of parking lot frontage and shall be
clustered or spaced linearly as determined appropriate.
(3) Other planting material, including ornamental trees, evergreens, shrubbery, hedges, and/or other live planting materials shall be provided to
achieve one hundred percent (100%) screening.
(4) Where appropriate, berming or a six foot (6') high board on board wood fence may be used.
(b) Where a parking lot is located in a yard adjacent to a nonresidential property, landscaping shall be provided across not less than fifty percent
(50%) of that portion of the parking lot abutting the property line to a minimum height of three feet (3'). Such landscaping shall consist of any
combination of berms, shade and ornamental trees, evergreens, shrubbery, hedges, and/or other live planting materials.
(B) Internal Parking Lot Landscaping: For all parking lots with five (5) or more spaces the following internal landscaping is required:
1. Parking lots must contain a minimum of one landscape island for every ten (10) parking spaces.
2. Landscape islands must be located at the end of every row of parking and be a minimum plantable size of eight feet by eighteen feet (8' x 18') for
single rows, and eight feet by thirty six feet (8' x 36') for double rows. All islands must be fully curbed and crowned six inches (6").
3. In addition to end row islands, no more than fifteen (15) parking spaces shall be used in a row without a landscape island break.
4. Landscape islands shall contain one deciduous shade tree for single row islands and two (2) deciduous shade trees for double islands.
Note: Parking lot light pole locations must be designed to accommodate the above shade tree requirement.
5. In addition to required shade trees, all islands must be fully sodded, seeded (with erosion blanket) or planted with low shrubs, perennials or ground
cover and maintained at a maximum height of thirty inches (30").
(C) Alternative Parking Lot Landscaping: As an alternative to traditional parking lot design, lots which use conservation design techniques to slow water
runoff, increase infiltration and improve water quality will be permitted. These lots must be properly designed, graded and planted utilizing "best
management practices". Vegetation shall be established using a combination of seeding and plugs. (Ord. 2005-3890, 1-17-2005; amd. Ord. 2006-3979,
1-9-2006)
5-26-8: LOADING, STORAGE AND REFUSE AREAS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 241/460
(A) Loading And Storage Areas: All outside loading and/or storage areas visible from any adjacent property or public right of way must be permanently
screened. Screening shall be provided by a six foot (6') high solid commercial grade wood fence or wall, or a combination berm and dense evergreen
tree planting totaling eight feet (8') in height at the time of planting.
(B) Refuse Disposal Areas: All refuse disposal and grease storage containers shall be screened on three (3) sides by a solid commercial grade wood
fence, wall or equivalent material to a height of six feet (6'). The enclosure shall be used strictly for the confinement of refuse and grease containers
and shall not be used for the outside storage of any other materials or equipment. The open side of said enclosure shall be gated and situated such
that, to the greatest extent possible, it does not face toward an adjacent property or public right of way.
Additionally, a continuous hedge of deciduous or evergreen shrubs is required along the three (3) fixed sides of the enclosure.
(C) Utility Equipment And Ground Level Mechanical Equipment: All equipment visible from any adjacent lot or public right of way must be permanently
screened by dense deciduous or evergreen plantings equal to the height of the equipment. Plant material must be carefully arranged to provide
maintenance and meter access while maintaining the required opacity. (Ord. 2005-3890, 1-17-2005; amd. Ord. 2006-3979, 1-9-2006)
5-26-9: STORM WATER MANAGEMENT BASINS:
(A) Plant Material: Landscaping shall be provided around the perimeter of detention/retention basins generally above the high water level. Only trees
adapted to temporary flooding may be planted below the high water level. Such landscaping shall consist at a minimum of two (2) shade trees three
inch (3") caliper, one ornamental tree eight feet (8') tall, and one evergreen tree six feet (6') tall for every one hundred (100) linear feet of perimeter, as
measured at the high water level. Trees should be clustered or grouped to provide a natural appearance.
(B) Turf Establishment: Turf selection and establishment around detention/retention basins should also tolerate temporary flooding. A turf type tall fescue
grass seed mix, drill seeded at a rate of five (5) pounds per acre and covered with a straw erosion blanket is recommended. For wet basins the area
from eighteen inches (18") below normal water level to five feet (5') above normal level shall be reinforced to prevent erosion from wave action. A five
(5) year coconut erosion blanket, or equivalent, is recommended.
(C) Alternative Native Basin Landscaping: As an alternative to traditional basins, wetland bottom storm water basins with native vegetation slopes are
encouraged to slow water runoff, increase infiltration, improve water quality and reduce goose populations. These basins must be properly designed
and graded utilizing "best management practices" (see example in section 5-26-15 of this chapter). Vegetation shall be established using a combination
of seeding and plugs.
For alternative wetland basins, the ornamental and evergreen tree requirement shall be waived in lieu of an equal dollar value of wetland plug
plantings. (Ord. 2005-3890, 1-17-2005; amd. Ord. 2006-3979, 1-9-2006)
5-26-10: SIGNAGE, FENCING AND WALLS:
(A) Signage: All freestanding or ground signs shall have a landscaped area (exclusive of lawn area) equal to one and one-half (11/2) times the sign surface
area. This landscaped area shall be planted with a mix of plant material proportionate to the size of the proposed sign, in keeping with sign/building
theme and maintaining adequate sightlines and visibility.
See title 4, chapter 4 of this code for additional information on signage.
(B) Fencing: Fences provided for screening purposes shall be six feet (6') high, commercial grade board on board wood fence (see section 5-26-15,
"Village Standard Landscape Details", of this chapter). Alternative fence styles or heights must be approved by the zoning administrator.
Fences shall always be installed with the "finished side" out, facing the adjacent lot.
All fences in nonresidential districts that abut residential districts must be located inside the property line and buffered with berming and/or landscaping
so that no more than fifty percent (50%) of the fence is visible from the adjoining residential district.
(C) Retaining Walls: All retaining walls shall be an interlocking solid concrete block wall system or approved equal (see section 5-16-4 of this title). Where
wall heights exceed forty eight inches (48") terracing walls should be considered and may be required by the village.
All retaining walls shall be designed and installed to ensure public safety. For wall heights from eighteen inches (18") to thirty six inches (36") a densely
planted hedge, minimum thirty inches (30") high at installation, or railing must be installed along the top of the entire wall length.
For wall heights over thirty six inches (36") a railing or approved fence must be used (see section 4-1-1 of this code). (Ord. 2005-3890, 1-17-2005;
amd. Ord. 2006-3979, 1-9-2006)
5-26-11: CENTRAL BUSINESS DISTRICT:
New buildings and development in the central business district shall improve adjacent sidewalk areas from the street curb to the face of the building. This
requirement shall also apply to building additions or renovations as determined by the zoning administrator. The types of streetscape improvements
required shall include decorative sidewalk paving, plant material, ornamental lighting and streetscape accessories. Plans for streetscape improvements
shall be incorporated into project plans submitted for building permit applications. Streetscape and building facade improvements shall conform with the
design guidelines of the "Village Of Lisle Downtown Master Plan" as prepared by the Lakota Group, Inc., and dated May 1999, or any subsequent
revisions thereto. (Ord. 2005-3890, 1-17-2005; amd. Ord. 2006-3979, 1-9-2006)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 242/460
5-26-12: FINAL ACCEPTANCE, PERFORMANCE GUARANTEE, MAINTENANCE AND PENALTIES:
(A) Final Acceptance: All required landscaping materials, both living and nonliving, shall be in place prior to the time of issuance of a final certificate of
occupancy, weather permitting.
(B) Performance Guarantee: In periods of adverse weather conditions, a temporary certificate of occupancy may be issued, subject to the posting of a
cash escrow or irrevocable letter of credit in an amount equal to one and one-half (11/2) times the estimated cost of the landscaping, with said
estimated cost to be certified by a landscape contractor. The cash escrow or irrevocable letter of credit may be forfeited if the landscaping is not
completed within one year after the issuance of the temporary certificate. Forfeiture of any cash escrow or irrevocable letter of credit shall not relieve
the owner of the responsibility to complete the required landscaping. The performance guarantee shall also be accompanied by a statement of the
owner giving the village the right to enter upon the property to complete landscaping in the case of forfeiture.
(C) Plant Substitutions: No deviations in size of plant material or substitution of species shall occur from the approved landscape plan without prior written
approval from the zoning administrator, or his designee.
(D) Maintenance: Trees, shrubs, and other landscaping materials depicted on landscaping plans approved by the village shall be considered to be
elements of the project in the same manner as parking, building materials and other details. The developer, its successor and/or subsequent owners
and their agents shall be responsible for maintenance of landscaping on the property on a continuous basis for the life of the development. Plant
materials which exhibit evidence of insect pests, disease and/or damage shall be appropriately treated, and dead plants promptly removed and
replaced within the next planting season after installation. All landscaping will be subject to periodic inspection by the zoning administrator, or his
designee. Should landscaping not be installed, maintained and replaced as needed to comply with the approved plan, the owner and its agent or
agents shall be considered in violation of the terms of the certificate of occupancy.
(E) Penalties: Any person who violates, disobeys, omits, neglects or refuses to comply with, or who resists the enforcement of any of the provisions of this
chapter shall be fined as established by the annual fee ordinance for each offense. A separate offense shall be deemed to have been committed on
each day that a violation hereof is permitted to exist. (Ord. 2005-3890, 1-17-2005; amd. Ord. 2006-3979, 1-9-2006)
5-26-13: TREE PRESERVATION AND REMOVAL REGULATIONS:
(A) Scope: It shall be unlawful for any person to remove or cause the removal of any parkway tree and any other tree having a caliper of six inches (6") or
greater in the village of Lisle without having first obtained approval from the village of a tree preservation and removal plan as described herein.
Nothing in this section shall apply to tree removal on private property by an owner of a lot having a single-family, two-family or duplex dwelling located
thereon unless said lot has an underlying commercial zoning, or is located in any floodplain area.
(B) Tree Preservation And Removal Plan Required: A tree preservation and removal plan shall be required for any parcel of land involving the construction
of any new building(s) or structure(s) or other site improvements or the removal of any parkway tree, or a tree having a caliper of six inches (6") or
greater. All tree preservation and removal plans shall include or have attached thereto the following information:
1. A tree location survey, prepared by a licensed Illinois arborist, landscape architect, or other qualified professional is required for all areas to be
developed. This plan shall be at the same scale as the plans for the development, but not less than one inch equals fifty feet (1" = 50') and is to be
submitted as part of the preliminary plan.
The survey shall show all trees six inches (6") in diameter and larger, and all parkway trees. All trees over twelve inches (12") in diameter must be
identified by size and species. In addition, all key trees (i.e., a tree classified by the arborist as significant, or those trees which are exceptionally
good examples of their species) shall be identified on the tree survey. Each tree surveyed must be identified with a number on the drawing and
tagged in the field.
2. The location of those trees to be removed, those to be preserved, and the methods which are to be used to preserve such trees during site
development.
3. A written statement indicating the reason for removal of the tree(s). A report from a licensed Illinois arborist or landscape architect may be requested
by the zoning administrator if deemed appropriate.
4. Details, specifications and/or technical information of procedures to be used to preserve and protect trees.
(C) General Tree Preservation And Removal Standards And Criteria:
1. Every reasonable effort shall be made to preserve existing trees through the integration of those trees into the site plan and landscape plan for a
proposed development. Existing trees, when preserved, may be used to satisfy site landscape requirements for parking lots or buffers.
2. Grading and construction equipment shall be forbidden from encroaching within the drip line of a tree. The drip line area is the ground area under a
tree canopy from the trunk to the outermost branches.
3. Crushed limestone and other material detrimental to trees shall not be placed within the drip line of any tree nor at any higher location where
drainage toward the tree could conceivably affect the health of the tree.
4. Snow fencing shall be temporarily installed at the periphery of the tree's drip line and maintained throughout the entire project. The ground area
inside of this fencing shall be protected and storage of any material in this area is prohibited.
5. Tree trunks and branches shall be protected when construction must occur within tree drip line areas.
6. No grade changes shall be allowed under the drip line of any trees designated for preservation.
7. To improve the survival rate of trees, root pruning and/or thinning shall be performed in accordance with industry standards and practices.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 243/460
8. In the event that underground utility lines are proposed within ten feet (10') of the trunk of a tree, auguring of the utility line should be considered and
may be required by the village.
9. Tree replacement required.
(a) Any tree intended to be removed, or unintentionally removed or damaged during construction shall be replaced with new trees in accordance with
the following schedule:

(c) All replacement trees shall have a minimum caliper size of three inches (3").
(d) Replacement trees shall be limited to those species included on exhibit A, section 5-26-4 of this chapter.
(e) The landscape plan shall identify each replacement tree as a replacement tree and indicate its location, species, and size. No replacement trees
shall be used to satisfy the requirements for tree planting in public rights of way, parking lots, or buffer areas.
(f) Removal of trees designated for preservation shall be allowed only by amending the landscape plan.
(g) Tree preservation and replacement required by this section shall be a condition to the issuance of a certificate of occupancy for any
improvements constructed on a zoning lot in the village.
(h) If it is impractical to plant the required number of replacement trees on the same zoning lot due to space limitations or the density of existing
trees, the village shall require the property owner to plant said tree(s) at the village's discretion on other public property or require a cash donation
to be used for village tree maintenance activities.
(D) Guidelines For Reviewing Tree Removal Plans: The village of Lisle shall approve removal of a tree without penalty or mitigation if one or more of the
following conditions exist:
1. It is necessary to remove a tree which poses a safety hazard to pedestrian or vehicular traffic or threatens to cause disruption of public safety.
2. It is necessary to remove a tree which poses a safety hazard to structures.
3. It is necessary to remove a tree which is diseased or has been weakened by age, storm, fire or other injury.
4. It is necessary to observe good forestry practice; i.e., the number of healthy trees a given parcel of land will support.
5. There exists a unique site condition, or extenuating circumstance, which is approved by the zoning administrator.
(E) Tree Removal Permit: When tree removal is necessary by any development or land use requiring the submission of a landscape plan, tree
preservation and removal plan, site plan, or subdivision plan, said plan shall, upon approval by the village, constitute a tree removal permit.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 244/460
(F) Failure To Comply: If, in the opinion of the zoning administrator, the necessary precautions as specified in the tree preservation and removal plan were
not undertaken before or maintained during construction, the land development permit of the parcel shall not be issued or, if previously issued, shall be
revoked until such time as these precautions have been satisfied. (Ord. 2005-3890, 1-17-2005; amd. Ord. 2006-3979, 1-9-2006)
5-26-14: DEAD, DISEASED OR INFESTED TREES; NUISANCES:
(A) Enforcement; Inspection: The community development director is charged with enforcement of this section. The community development director may
authorize an appropriate village employee or officer to enter upon private property, subject to constitutional limitations, at all reasonable hours for
purposes of:
1. Inspecting trees on any such property having the appearance of or suspected of having:
(a) Dutch elm disease,
(b) Elm yellows disease (formerly called Phloem necrosis),
(c) Oak wilt,
(d) Pine wilt,
(e) Any other infectious disease,
(f) Exhibiting an infestation of the emerald ash borer (Agrilus planipennis Fairmaire),
(g) That appears dead or dying, regardless of cause,
(h) Parts thereof in a dead or dying condition which serve as a breeding place for the European elm bark beetle, Scolytus multistristus or other
disease spreading insect, bug or vector, or
(i) Any combination of the preceding diseases or infestations or conditions, and
2. Taking tree and plant samples as required to determine whether a tree or plant is diseased or infested.
It is unlawful for any person to prevent the community development director, or his or her designee, from entering on private property for purposes of
carrying out his or her duties under this section, or to interfere with the community development director, or his or her designee, in the lawful
performance of his or her duties under this section.
(B) Nuisances Declared: In the event that it is determined that the tree or plant from which said samples have been taken is in fact dead, dying, diseased
or infected with:
1. Dutch elm disease,
2. Elm yellows disease (formerly called Phloem necrosis),
3. Oak wilt,
4. Pine wilt,
5. Any other infectious disease,
6. Exhibiting an infestation of the emerald ash borer (Agrilus planipennis Fairmaire),
7. That appears dead or dying, regardless of cause,
8. Parts thereof in a dead or dying condition which serve as a breeding place for the European elm bark beetle, Scolytus multistristus or other disease
spreading insect, bug or vector, or
9. Any combination of the preceding diseases or infestations or conditions are hereby declared a nuisance.
It may be declared a nuisance regardless of the ability to diagnose a disease, if the subject tree is determined to represent a threat to public safety.
(C) Removal: The owner, occupant or agent of a property on which there is any tree confirmed to be diseased, infested, or having any condition listed in
subsection (B) of this section must remove any such tree from the village within ten (10) days of notification to the owner, occupant or agent. All trees
diseased, infested or having any such condition must be legally disposed of in compliance with state and federal regulations. It is unlawful for the
owner, occupant, or agent of any property in the village to permit any tree, portion thereof, including logs, infected with an infectious disease to remain
on his or her property or to be retained for any use. Chipping of tree materials will be permitted provided that any material that is chipped must not
exceed one square inch of final chip surface.
(D) Abatement Of Nuisance: In all cases where the owner, occupant or agent of a property on which there is any tree confirmed to be diseased, infested,
or having any condition listed in subsection (B) of this section cannot be found, or if found and notified, neglects or refuses for any reason to abate the
nuisance within ten (10) days of notification, thereafter the community development director, or his or her designee, may enter upon the property to
abate the nuisance by removal and disposal of the tree. The owner, occupant, or agent charged with removal and disposal of a nuisance tree may
request that the removal and disposal be done by the community development director, or his or her designee. The owner, occupant, or agent will be
charged with any expenses incurred by the village in the removal or abatement of a nuisance tree.
(E) Lien For Abatement Costs:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 245/460
1. Whenever billing for removal or abatement of a nuisance pursuant to this section by or under the supervision of the community development director,
or his or her designee, remains unpaid thirty (30) days after billing for such service has been rendered, the community development director may file
a sworn statement of lien claim with the office of the DuPage County recorder of deeds. This sworn statement will contain the legal description of the
property served, the amount of the billing plus administrative costs, the date or dates the removal costs were incurred and a notice that the village
claims a lien for the total amount.
2. The community development director, or his or her designee, will also personally serve or deliver via certified mail, notice of lien to the taxpayer of
record, based on the property tax records for the year immediately preceding the date of the removal activity, for the property served. The notice
must state the substance of section 11-20-15 of the Illinois municipal code, 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-20-15 as well as this section, identify
the property served by common description, and describe the removal activity.
3. The village attorney may institute foreclosure proceedings, in the name of the village, in the circuit court against any property for which a lien claim
for unpaid service charges and administrative costs has been duly filed in accordance with section 11-20-15 of the Illinois municipal code, 65 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/11-20-15. (Ord. 2013-4491, 5-20-2013)

Chapter 27
OUTDOOR LIGHTING
5-27-1: INTENT AND PURPOSE:
Outdoor lighting shall be designed to provide the minimum lighting necessary to ensure adequate safety, night vision, and comfort, and shall not create or
cause excessive glare on adjacent properties and public street rights of way. (Ord. 2006-4025, 6-19-2006)
5-27-2: DEFINITIONS:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 249/460
FIXTURE: The assembly that houses the lamp or lamps and can include all or some of the following parts: a housing, a mounting bracket or pole socket, a
lamp holder, a ballast, a reflector or mirror, and/or a refractor or lens.
FOOT-CANDLES (fc): A quantitative unit measuring the amount of light (illumination) falling onto a given point, one foot-candle equals one lumen per
square foot.
GLARE: The effect produced by a light source within the visual field that is sufficiently brighter than the level to which the eyes are adapted, to cause
annoyance, discomfort, or loss of visual performance and ability.
HEIGHT OF LUMINAIRE: The height of a luminaire shall be the vertical distance from the ground directly below the centerline of the luminaire to the
lowest direct light emitting part of the luminaire.
LAMP: The component of a luminaire that produces the actual light.
LUMEN: A quantitative unit used to identify the amount of light emitted by a light source. A lamp is generally rated in lumens.
LUMINAIRE: A complete lighting system, and includes a lamp or lamps and a fixture.
MAINTAINED FOOT-CANDLES: Illuminance of lighting fixtures adjusted for a maintenance factor accounting for dirt buildup andlamp output depreciation.
The maintenance factor used in the design process to account for this depreciation cannot be lower than 0.72 for high pressure sodium and 0.64 for metal
halide and mercury vapor.
NONCONFORMING LUMINAIRES: Luminaires not conforming to this chapter that were in place at the time this chapter was voted into effect. The
luminaire shall be changed if other site related improvements are proposed on the property which requires a building permit.
OUTDOOR LIGHTING: The nighttime illumination of an outside area or object by any manmade device located outdoors that produces light by any
means. (Ord. 2006-4025, 6-19-2006)
5-27-3: NONCONFORMITIES:
(A) All luminaires lawfully in place prior to the effective date hereof shall be grandfathered. However, at the time that a nonconforming fixture is replaced,
moved, upgraded, or otherwise changed, the fixture must be brought into compliance with the requirements of this chapter. Any expansion of, or
addition to, an existing lighting system must conform to the requirements of this chapter.
(B) A luminaire shall be changed if other site related improvements are proposed on the property which requires a building permit.
(C) Nonconforming luminaires that direct light toward streets or parking lots that cause disability glare to motorists or cyclists should be either shielded or
redirected within one hundred twenty (120) days of notification, so that the luminaires do not cause a potential hazard to motorists or cyclists. (Ord.
2006-4025, 6-19-2006)
5-27-4: LIGHT MEASUREMENT TECHNIQUE:
Light level measurement shall be made at the property line of the property upon which the light to be measured is being generated. If measurement on
private property is not possible or practical, light level measurements may be made at the boundary of the public street right of way that adjoins the
property of the complainant or at any other location on the property of the complainant. Measurements shall be made at finished grade (ground level), with
the light registering portion of the meter held parallel to the ground point up. The meter shall have cosine and color correction and have an accuracy
tolerance of no greater than plus or minus five percent (5%). Measurements shall be taken with a light meter that has been calibrated within the previous
two (2) years. Light levels are specified, calculated and measured in foot-candles (fc). All fc values are maintained foot-candles unless specified otherwise.
See the definition for "maintained foot-candles" in section 5-27-2 of this chapter formaximum allowed light loss factors. (Ord. 2006-4025, 6-19-2006)
5-27-5: ENFORCEMENT, VIOLATIONS AND PENALTIES:
Any person who violates the provisions of this chapter shall be fined in an amount as specified in the annual fee ordinance, and every such person shall be
deemed guilty of a separate offense for each day such violation shall continue, and shall be subject to the penalty provided hereunder for each and every
separate offense. (Ord. 2006-4025, 6-19-2006)
5-27-6: PARKING LOT LIGHTING:
Land uses required herein to provide six (6) or more parking spaces, or one or more loading spaces, shall provide lighting facilities to illuminate all parking
spaces, aisles and loading spaces in accordance with the following requirements:
(A) Photometric Plan: Site plans for proposed off street parking facilities shall be submitted to the village for approval and shall contain a photometric plan.
The photometric plan shall include all of the following information:
1. Identification of all proposed light fixtures, including those used for site lighting, canopy lighting and exterior building lighting.
2. Identification of all proposed control equipment, conduit and wiring, including material, size and location.
3. Photometric calculations, showing a grid of individual illumination values as well as a summary of the maximum, minimum and average illumination
of the pavement surface in foot-candles.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 250/460
4. Construction details of the pole, pole foundation, electrical trench with warning tape and pole handhole wiring.
5. Catalog cut sheets for the proposed light poles, fixtures and any exterior control equipment.
(B) Illumination Standards: The maximum horizontal illumination at the property line adjacent to or across from detached or attached single-family
residential zoned properties shall be 0.2 foot-candle. Parking lots shall be classified as follows:
1. Low activity level parking lots: These are parking lots in which most of the parking spaces will be occupied by employee vehicles, with very few
parking spaces occupied by customer vehicles after six o'clock (6:00) P.M. The average illumination on the pavement area shall be between 0.5 and
2.0 foot-candles and shall have an average to minimum uniformity ratio of six to one (6:1) or better.
2. Medium activity level parking lots: These are parking lots inwhich most of the parking spaces will be occupied by employee vehicles, but with
significant parking spaces occupied by customer vehicles after six o'clock (6:00) P.M. The average illumination on the pavement area shall be
between 1.5 and 3.0 foot-candles and shall have an average to minimum uniformity ratio of six to one (6:1) or better.
3. High activity level parking lots: These are parking lots in which most of the parking spaces will be occupied by customer vehicles after six o'clock
(6:00) P.M. The average illumination on the pavement area shall be between 2.5 and 4.0 foot-candles and shall have an average to minimum
uniformity ratio of four to one (4:1) or better.
4. Exception for gasoline station canopies: The average illumination on the pavement area under the canopy and around the fuel pumps shall be
between thirty five (35) and seventy (70) foot-candles. The remainder of the gasoline station pavement shall meet the requirements for high activity
level parking lots.
5. Exception for bank and credit union canopies: The average illumination on the pavement area under the drive-up canopy and around automated
teller machines must meet federal regulations. The remainder of the bank and credit union parking lot pavement shall meet the requirements for high
activity level parking lots.
6. Exception for automobile sales lots: The average illumination on the first twenty five feet (25') of pavement area adjacent to the street shall be
between thirty five (35) and seventy (70) foot-candles. The remainder of the automobile sales lot shall meet the requirements for high activity level
parking lots.
(C) Fixture Specifications: All exterior luminaires, except for decorative fixtures and/or architectural lighting approved by the board of trustees, shall be
horizontally mounted, with flat lenses and full cutoff optics. No portion of the lens may protrude below the fixture housing. The luminaires shall utilize
four hundred (400) watt or smaller lamps.
(D) Mounting Height: Light fixtures for parking lots adjacent to or across from detached or attached single-family residential zoned properties shall have a
maximum mounting height of twenty six feet (26') above the pavement. All other parking lot lighting fixtures shall have a maximum mounting height of
thirty two feet (32') above the pavement.
(E) Glare: Sources of light (the bulb) shall be directed, shaded, shielded, or otherwise located to minimize perceived glare on adjacent properties or
streets. Accordingly, canopy lighting with refractive drop lenses, tilting fixtures, floodlights, and wall mounted nonhorizontal fixtures (commonly referred
to as wall packs) are specifically prohibited. Architectural lighting shall be permitted as long as it is ground mounted near the building, utilizes seventy
(70) watt or smaller lamps, and is approved by the board of trustees. (Ord. 2006-4025, 6-19-2006)
5-27-7: STREET LIGHTING:
Subdivisions shall provide lighting facilities to illuminate all public streets in accordance with the following requirements:
(A) General Requirements: Streetlights shall be designed in accordance with the national electrical code as well as the American national standard
practice for roadway lighting report RP-8, prepared by the Illuminating Engineering Society of North America. All street lighting equipment shall be
certified by Underwriters Laboratories.
Streetlights in residential subdivisions shall be spaced approximately one hundred eighty (180) to two hundred feet (200') apart and shall be located
in line with side yard property lines wherever feasible. Additional streetlights shall also be provided at intersections, sharp curves and dead ends.
Streetlights in commercial, business or industrial areas shall be spaced to provide lighting levels recommended by the American national standard
practice for roadway lighting report RP-8 and photometric calculations shall be submitted to the village engineer for review and approval.
Streetlights shall be placed six feet (6') behind the back of curb. Barrier curb shall be provided in front of all streetlights to ensure that they do not
constitute a roadside hazard.
Street lighting systems shall include a pedestal box containing a main circuit breaker located as close as possible to the electric service drop. The
pedestal box shall have a locking cover and shall be clearly labeled "Street Lighting".
(B) Poles: Streetlight poles shall be reinforced prestressed concrete, octagonal in cross section with a central cable raceway, and suitable for butt type
mounting. The poles shall have a black, natural polished finish. The poles shall be equipped for cable entrance from below ground level and shall have
a wiring handhole with an aluminum cover above finished grade. The aluminum cover shall be attached with tamperproof screws.
Poles in residential subdivisions shall be Ameron Centrecon series "M" medium octagonal poles, catalog no. MEO-7.5-612 (providing a 24 foot 7
inch mounting height). Poles in commercial, business or industrial areas shall be Ameron Centrecon series "M" medium octagonal poles, catalog no.
MEO-8.5-612 (providing a 27 foot 11 inch mounting height). Poles in commercial and business areas shall be supplied with a GFI outlet near the top of
the pole.
Unless otherwise approved by the village engineer, mast arms shall be manufactured of tapered aluminum with a smooth internal cable raceway and
shall have a tenon to accommodatethe slip fitter of the luminaire. Mast arms shall be six feet (6') in length. Mast arms shall be attached to the concrete
pole with aluminum castings and stainless steel or silicone bronze screws.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 251/460
An in line fuse holder assembly (Buss no. 1A0512, or approved equal) equipped with the proper fuse for the protection of the luminaire shall be
provided at the handhole of each pole.
Streetlight poles shall be plumbed while carrying the load of the mast arm and luminaire. All voids between the pole butt base and undisturbed earth
shall be backfilled with low strength Portland cement concrete and the pole shall be braced in a plumb position until the concrete has set.
(C) Luminaires: Luminaires in residential subdivisions shall be one hundred fifty (150) watt high pressure sodium General Electric M-250A2 fixtures.
Luminaires shall be fastened to the mast arms with a slip fitter, and shall be provided with an individual photocell and an adjustable lamp socket. The
luminaires shall have an IES type III lighting distribution pattern and cutoff optics. The luminaires shall be provided with auto regulator ballasts, a flat
glass lens and a charcoal filter with an elastomer gasket.
Luminaires in commercial, business or industrial areas shall be two hundred fifty (250) watt high pressure sodium General Electric M-250A2 fixtures.
Luminaires shall be fastened to the mast arms with a slip fitter, and shall be provided with an individual photocell and an adjustable lamp socket. The
luminaires shall have an IES type III lighting distribution pattern and semicutoff optics. The luminaires shall be provided with auto regulator ballasts, a
glass globe lens and a charcoal filter with an elastomer gasket.
(D) Cable And Wiring Methods: Cable shall be single conductor copper, XLP type USE, with six hundred (600) volt insulation. Minimum wire size shall be
#6 AWG for feeder cables to the light poles and #12 AWG for wiring within the pole between the fuse holder and the luminaire and GFI outlet.
Maximum wire size shall be #2 AWG for feeder cables to the light poles. Voltage drop calculations shall be submitted to the village engineer for
approval. Individual conductors within cable shall have solid (nonstriped) color coded insulation for identification as follows:
Black First 120V "hot" leg
Red Second 120V "hot" leg
White Grounded neutral
Green Grounding conductor
Bare copper grounding conductors are not permitted. All underground wiring shall be encased in polyethylene unit duct or schedule 40 PVC conduit.
Galvanized steel conduit sleeves shall be installed under all street crossings andshall extend two feet (2') past the back of curb on each side. After unit
duct or PVC conduit has been placed through the sleeve, the ends shall be sealed watertight. Unit duct and PVC shall be placed in trenches six inches
(6") wide by thirty inches (30") deep and shall be backfilled with materials free from lumps and foreign objects. Plastic warning tape shall be placed in
the trench six inches (6") below finished grade during the backfill operation.
Concrete handholes with cast iron or steel covers shall be required at locations where there is a change in the alignment of the cable greater than
forty five degrees (45). Underground cable splices, including splices in handholes, are not permitted. (Ord. 2006-4025, 6-19-2006)
Chapter 28
WIND AND SOLAR ENERGY DEVICES
5-28-1: INTENT AND PURPOSE:
Uniform standards and procedures shall be established to manage the development, siting, installation, and operation of small wind energy systems
(SWES) and solar energy collection panels (SECP) to ensure that these devices are installed in a manner that will protect and promote public health and
safety and preserve the village's character. (Ord. 2011-4377, 4-4-2011)
5-28-2: DEFINITIONS:
SMALL WIND ENERGY SYSTEM (SWES): A wind energy conversion system consisting of a wind turbine, a tower or post and associated controls or
conversion electronics that is mounted on a principal structure or on the ground as an accessory use/structure and with a nameplate capacity of less than
fifty (50) kilowatts for residential systems and less than one hundred (100) kilowatts for nonresidential systems.
SOLAR ENERGY COLLECTION PANELS (SECP): Solar energy collection panels are a type of photovoltaic (PV) system that collects energy from sunlight
and converts it into usable energy for a building. (Ord. 2011-4377, 4-4-2011)
5-28-3: SMALL WIND ENERGY SYSTEMS (SWES):
(A) SWES shall be permitted on any roof in any nonresidential zoning district as a permitted accessory use.
(B) SWES shall be permitted on any roof in any residential zoning district as a permitted special use. No freestanding SWES shall be permitted in any
residential zoning district.
(C) SWES shall not exceed fifteen feet (15') in height above the elevation of the roof installation point, measured from the point of attachment to the top of
the turbine blade at its highest point. SWES that exceed fifteen feet (15') in height shall be subject to review and approval in accordance with a special
use permit. SWES shall be located no closer than ten feet (10') from the property line in a residential zoning district. No more than one SWES shall be
allowed per zoning lot.
(D) A ground mounted SWES shall maintain a twenty foot (20') clearance between the blades and the ground.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 252/460
(E) In a nonresidential district, all ground mounted SWES shall be set back a distance of at least one hundred ten percent (110%) of the height of the tower
and extended blades from the property line.
(F) SWES shall have a nonreflective finish and shall be neutral in color. No SWES shall be artificially lighted.
(G) SWES shall not be permitted in any location other than the surface of the structure roof, unless otherwise specified in the subject zoning district.
(H) SWES shall have an electronic braking system installed to regulate and limit the speed of the turbine in high wind events.
(I) SWES shall be primarily used to generate energy for the property where it is located.
(J) Any SWES not in service for a period of one hundred eighty (180) days shall be removed and the property on which it is located restored to its original
condition within thirty (30) days.
(K) SWES shall utilize single monopole type tower without guywires. Satellite dishes, antennas and other accessory devices shall not be collocated on an
SWES pole or device. Guyed towers and lattice towers are prohibited.
(L) The maximum noise level allowed for all SWES shall not exceed fifty five (55) decibels measured at all property lines at operational wind speed.
(M) A building permit shall be required prior to erecting any SWES. Mounting for such systems shall be in conformance with all electrical and building code
requirements to ensure wind and weight loading requirements are adhered to. Plans shall be stamped by an Illinois licensed structural engineer. (Ord.
2011-4377, 4-4-2011)
5-28-4: SOLAR ENERGY COLLECTION PANELS (SECP):
(A) Solar panels shall be permitted on any roof in any zoning district as permitted accessory uses. No freestanding solar panels shall be allowed in any
residential district.
(B) Solar panels shall be parallel with the roof line when possible and shall not be elevated more than thirty degrees (30) off the roof pitch where it is
attached or no more than five feet (5') whichever is less. Panels shall not extend beyond the roof line and shall be located no closer than ten feet (10')
from an adjacent property line. Panels shall not cover more than fifty percent (50%) of the total roof surface of a structure.
(C) All frame and visible structural parts of a solar panel shall be neutral in color. No solar panel shall be artificially lighted.
(D) Solar panels shall not be permitted in any location other than the surface of the structure roof, unless otherwise specified in the subject zoning district.
(E) Any solar panels not in service for a period of one hundred eighty (180) days shall be removed and the property on which it is located restored to its
original condition within thirty (30) days.
(F) Solar shingles shall be permitted to cover any amount of roof without the above area and location limitation, provided that they are incorporated into
and made to appear as part of the roof, continuous in area without gap and do not cause glare to reflect onto adjacent properties.
(G) A building permit shall be required prior to erecting any solar panel. Mounting for such systems shall be in conformance with all electrical and building
code requirements to ensure that wind and weight load requirements are adhered to. Plans shall be stamped by an Illinois licensed structural engineer.
(Ord. 2011-4377, 4-4-2011)
