10-1-2: OPERATION OF VEHICLES RESTRICTED:
No person shall operate any motor vehicle in the village unless such motor vehicle is muffled to the maximum extent practicable so as to prevent
unnecessary noise, and further, no person shall operate any motor vehicle in the village so as to cause unnecessary noise by rapid acceleration or
deceleration of the vehicle, or by racing of the engine or by squealing or screeching of the tires on pavement1.
Every person convicted of a violation of this section shall be punished by a fine as established by the annual fee ordinance. (Ord. 96-2776, 5-20-1996)
10-1-3: SCHOOL CROSSINGS:
Permanently mounted automatic school crossing stop signs shall be installed at the locations hereinafter specified and all said signals shall bear red and
amber lenses and signs marked "School Crossing" and "Stop on Red Signal". After said signals are installed, they shall be placed in operation during
regularly scheduled school crossing periods only and shall not be operated outside of such periods.
When said signs are in operation, all pedestrian and vehicular traffic shall stop on the red signal and obey the flashing indications and signs on said
signals, and any person who shall fail to obey said signals shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be fined as established by the annual fee ordinance
for each offense.
(A) A school crossing sign, S 201, as listed in the "Manual On Uniform Traffic Control Devices For Streets And Highways", state of Illinois department of
transportation, shall be placed and a crosswalk designated at the following areas:
Kingston Avenue north of Division
Kingston Avenue opposite Schiesher School
Middleton Avenue opposite Tate Woods School
The placement of signs and designations of crosswalks shall be the responsibility of the street department of the village.
(B) The following sign, S 301, as listed in the "Manual On Uniform Traffic Control Devices For Streets And Highways", state of Illinois department of
transportation, shall be placed in the following locations:
Division and Kingston; Division eastbound, Kingston southbound and northbound
Kingston Avenue; southbound north of Gamble, northbound south of Ohio
Middleton Avenue and Schwartz; northbound on Schwartz
These signs shall be placed at a reasonable distance from the affected schools taking into consideration intersecting streets, driveways and other
appurtenances. The street department of the village shall be responsible for the placement of these signs. (Ord. 96-2776, 5-20-1996)
10-1-4: SCHOOL CROSSING GUARDS:
The chief of police shall have the authority, and he is hereby authorized, to appoint such number of persons as the board of trustees shall from time to time
determine, to be known as school crossing guards, which guards, to be eligible for appointment, shall be a person of not less than twenty one (21) years of
age and shall be of good moral character and in good health.
The chief of police shall have the authority to assign guards to such localities and for such periods of time as shall be best suited to afford protection to
those attending schools, and said chief of police shall be the supervisor of the duties of the guards.
Guards shall maintain the orderly movement of pedestrian and vehicular traffic consistent with the safety of children attending schools in the village, and
shall adhere to and be governed by all the rules and regulations of the police department insofar as such rules and regulations are applicable to and
consistent with the special class of duties prescribed for school crossing guards. Guards shall also comply with all other applicable ordinances, rules and
regulations adopted by the village.
Said guards shall not be a part of or affiliated with the village police department in any official capacity except that they shall have and exercise such
limited police powers as may be delegated to them by the chief of police, and the guards may be dismissed by said chief of police when he finds such
dismissal to be in the best interest of the village. The village board may also dismiss any guard for any reason it shall deem sufficient.
Crossing guards shall be paid in accordance with the rate of pay as from time to time set forth by the corporate authorities. (Ord. 291, 11-5-1968; amd.
1979 Code)
10-1-5: SCHOOL BUSES, MEETING OR OVERTAKING:
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 406/460
The driver of a vehicle upon any public street or highway within the village, upon meeting or overtaking from either direction any school bus which has
stopped on such street or highway for the purpose of receiving or discharging any school children, shall stop said vehicle before reaching said school bus
when there is in operation on said bus a visual signal as specified in 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-1414.
Any person violating any provision of this section shall be fined as established by the annual fee ordinance for each offense. (Ord. 96-2776, 5-20-1996)
10-1-6: VEHICLE WEIGHTS, LIMITED LOAD STREETS:

2. School buses and public mass transit buses, when engaged in local service. For the purposes of this section, "local service" is defined as travel

means of ingress or egress is available; in which case these vehicles must use the shortest direct route between their destination and the nearest
arterial street. For the purposes of this section, arterial streets are defined as Naper Boulevard, Yackley Avenue, College Road, Route 53, I-355, I-
88, Warrenville Road, Ogden Avenue and Maple Avenue.

10-1-7: DRIVING ON SIDEWALKS, OTHER VILLAGE PROPERTY:
The operation of any motorized vehicle including, but not limited to, automobiles, trucks, minibikes, motorscooters, motorbikes, motorcycles and buses is
hereby prohibited on any village parkway, sidewalk, levee, marked depot area platforms or other property for which the village is responsible for
maintenance, excepting village streets and roadways. The foregoing shall not apply to any vehicle authorized by the village to operate or drive upon the
foregoing areas.
The operation of any motorized vehicle including, but not limited to, those listed above, is hereby prohibited on any village street or roadway unless said
vehicle is properly licensed in accordance with state and local laws and regulations.
Any person violating this section shall be subject to a fine as established by the annual fee ordinance. (Ord. 96-2776, 5-20-1996)
10-1-8: DRIVING ON PUBLIC OR PRIVATE PROPERTY:
(A) Definition: The term "vehicle" as used in this section shall be construed to mean any device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be
transported or drawn on a highway or otherwise, except devices moved solely by human power or used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks,
whether said vehicle is licensed or unlicensed. (Ord. 79-880, 8-21-1979; amd. Ord. 79-881, 8-21-1979)
(B) Private Property: For the protection of the public health, safety, welfare and property, the operation of any vehicle upon any private property without the
consent of the owner thereof is hereby prohibited. (Ord. 79-880, 8-21-1979)
(C) Public Property: For the protection of the public's health, safety, welfare and property, the operation of any vehicle upon any public property of or within
any public place in the village, except public highways, publicly dedicated and developed streets and alleys, designated municipal parking lots and
improved driveways transversing public parkways is hereby prohibited. (Ord. 79-811, 8-21-1979)
(D) Penalty: Any person found to have violated any provision of this section shall be fined as established by the annual fee ordinance for each violation.
(Ord. 96-2776, 5-20-1996)
10-1-9: PEDESTRIAN CROSSWALKS:
At those locations determined by the board of trustees of the village to require a marked crosswalk to assist pedestrians in traversing a street, road or
highway, said crosswalk shall be marked by paint striping or other designation upon the roadway and proper signage shall provide notice to oncoming cars
of the existence of such a crosswalk.
Wherever pedestrian crosswalks have been designated, all vehicular traffic shall yield to any and all pedestrians present within said crosswalk before
proceeding. Any person who shall fail to so yield shall be fined as established by the annual fee ordinance for each offense. (Ord. 96-2776, 5-20-1996)
10-1-10: ILLINOIS VEHICLE CODE ADOPTION:
625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-100 et seq., of the Illinois vehicle code is hereby adopted and incorporated herein by this reference. Further, citations
may be issued by authorized personnel of the village, using the Illinois vehicle code in lieu of or in addition to using the sections of this title. (Ord. 91-2135,
2-18-1991)
10-1-11: TEMPORARY PARKING RESTRICTIONS:
The chief of police is hereby vested with the authority to direct, control and regulate traffic through the temporary designation and posting of signs or other
traffic control devices. Any sign or device posted per order of the chief of police shall be deemed an official sign and shall be valid for as long as public
safety requires. (Ord. 96-2754, 3-18-1996)

10-1-12: AUTOMATED TRAFFIC LAW ENFORCEMENT SYSTEM:
(A) Definitions:
AUTOMATED TRAFFIC LAW ENFORCEMENT SYSTEM: A device within the village with one or more motor vehicle sensors working in conjunction
with a red light signal to produce recorded images of motor vehicles entering an intersection against a steady or flashing red signal indication in
violation of 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-306, or similar violation of this code.
DISREGARDING A TRAFFIC CONTROL DEVICE: Failure to stop and remain stopped before an intersection that is controlled by a red signal as
provided for in 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-306.
NO TURN ON RED: Failure to stop and remain stopped, and not proceeding to turn right at, an intersection controlled by both a sign indicating "No
turn on red", or other similar language, and a red signal as provided for in 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-306.
RECORDED IMAGES: Images produced by the automated traffic law enforcement system, which consist of either two (2) or more photographs; two
(2) or more microphotographs; two (2) or more electronic images; or, a video recording showing the motor vehicle and, on at least one image or
portion of the recording, clearly identifying the registration plate number of the motor vehicle.
TRAFFIC COMPLIANCE ADMINISTRATOR: The person appointed as such through 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes article 25 who shall have power
to adopt, distribute and process automated traffic law violation notices and other notices required by this article, collect money paid as fines and
penalties, operate the automated traffic law enforcement system, and make certified reports to the secretary of state as required by this article.
(B) Violations: It shall be a violation of this section for a vehicle to disregard a traffic control device or turn on red in violation of 625 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/11-306.
(C) Administrative Adjudication: For purposes of administrative adjudication of violations of this section, there is hereby established an administrative
hearing system pursuant to 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-2.1-1, which is incorporated herein as though fully set forth. The village manager shall
appoint one or more hearing officers in accordance with 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1-2.1-1. The jurisdiction of the administrative adjudication
system shall include only violations of this section.
(D) Defenses: The following may be considered defenses by the hearing officer for a violation of subsection (B) of this section:
1. That the motor vehicle or registration plates of the motor vehicle were stolen before the violation occurred, and not under the control of or in the
possession of the owner at the time of the violation;
2. That the driver of the vehicle passed through the intersection when the light was red either: a) in order to yield the right of way to an emergency
vehicle or b) as part of a funeral procession.
To demonstrate that the motor vehicle or the registration plates were stolen before the violation occurred and were not under the control or
possession of the owner at the time of the violation, the owner must submit proof that a report concerning the stolen motor vehicle or registration
plates was filed with a law enforcement agency in a timely manner.
(E) Notice Of Violation: When the automated traffic law enforcement system records a motor vehicle entering an intersection in violation of subsection (B)
of this section, the village shall issue a written notice of violation to the registered owner or lessee of the vehicle, which shall be delivered by U.S. mail
within thirty (30) days after the Illinois secretary of state notifies the village of the identity of the registered owner or lessee of the vehicle, and in no
event later than ninety (90) days following the violation. The village shall only be required to notify a lessee if the leasing company/lessor provides the
lessee's name by an affidavit and a copy of the lease within sixty (60) days of the notice's issuance. If the driver information is not provided within sixty
(60) days, the leasing company/lessor may be found liable. If any notice to an address is returned as undeliverable, a second notice shall be sent to the
last known address recorded in a United States post office approved database of the owner or lessee of the cited vehicle. The second notice shall be
made by first class mail, postage prepaid. (Ord. 2007-4139, 9-10-2007)
A notice of violation associated with an automated traffic law violation shall require a review of the associated recorded image by the traffic compliance
administrator, who shall inspect the image and determine whether the motor vehicle was being operated in violation of subsection (B) of this section, or
whether one of the defenses enumerated in subsection (D) of this section is visibly applicable upon inspection. All violations must be reviewed and
approved by a law enforcement officer or retired law enforcement officer of the village. Upon determination that the recorded image captures a violation
and that no defense applies, the notice of violation shall be served upon the registered vehicle owner in the manner provided for above. The traffic
compliance administrator shall retain a copy of all violation notices, recorded images and other correspondence mailed to the owner of the vehicle.
Each notice of violation shall constitute evidence of the facts contained in the notice and is admissible in any proceeding alleging a violation of the
above noted statutory and local provisions and shall be prima facie evidence of a violation, subject to rebuttal on the basis of the defenses established
in this section. (Ord. 2007-4139, 9-10-2007; amd. Ord. 2010-4358, 12-20-2010)
The notice of violation shall include the following information:
1. The name and address of the registered owner or lessee of the vehicle, as indicated by the records of the secretary of state, or, if such information is
outdated or unattainable, then the last known address recorded in a United States post office approved database;
2. The make (only if discernable) and registration number of the motor vehicle involved in the violation;
3. The violation charged;
4. The location where the violation occurred;
5. The date and time of the violation; (Ord. 2007-4139, 9-10-2007)
6. A copy of the recorded images, and a website address at which an alleged violator may have access to the recorded images through the internet;
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 409/460
7. The amount of the civil penalty and the date by which the penalty should be paid (14 days from the date of issuance) and a statement that the
payment of the fine shall operate as a final disposition of the violation; (Ord. 2010-4358, 12-20-2010)
8. A statement that a failure to pay the civil penalty by the date noted may result in an additional late fee being assessed against the owner or lessee;
9. The amount of the late fee;
10. A statement that the failure to pay by the date specified will result in a final determination of liability and may result in the suspension of driving
privileges for the registered owner of the vehicle;
11. A statement that the recorded images constitute prima facie evidence of a violation;
12. A statement that the person may elect to proceed by paying the fine or challenging the charge in court, by mail or by administrative hearing; and
13. A statement of how an administrative hearing may be requested. (Ord. 2007-4139, 9-10-2007)
(F) Hearing: The owner of a vehicle being operated in violation of this section may request a hearing by the respond-by date on the notice of violation (14
days from the date of issuance), to challenge the evidence or set forth an applicable defense. The notice of violation shall constitute evidence of the
facts contained in the notice and is admissible in any proceeding alleging a violation of this section. The notice of violation shall be prima facie evidence
of a violation, subject to rebuttal on the basis of the defenses established in this section. (Ord. 2007-4139, 9-10-2007; amd. Ord. 2010-4358, 12-20-
2010)
The owner's failure to appear at the hearing will result in a finding of liability. In the event of a failure to appear, a "findings, decision and order" letter will
be sent to the owner. The owner's failure to pay the amount by the date specified in that letter will result in a final determination.
(G) Nonresidents: Where the registered owner or lessee of the cited vehicle is not a resident of the village but seeks to contest the merits of the alleged
violation, such person may contest the charges using the same available defenses as stated above, but rather than attend the administrative hearing,
they may submit any and all documentary evidence to the traffic compliance administrator no later than the hearing date, together with a written
statement reflecting that they are nonresidents of the village. The traffic compliance administrator shall forward all timely submitted materials to the
hearing officer for review and determination. (Ord. 2007-4139, 9-10-2007)
(H) Final Determination: A final determination of an automated traffic law violation(s) liability shall occur:
1. Following the failure to pay the total assessed fine or penalty after the hearing officer's determination of an automated traffic law violation(s) liability
within twenty five (25) days and the exhaustion of or the failure to exhaust any administrative review procedures hereinafter set forth, or
2. Where a person fails to appear at the hearing for an automated traffic law violation on the date and at the time and place specified in a prior mailed
notice. The hearing officer's determination of an automated traffic law violation(s) liability shall become final upon the exhaustion of or the failure to
exhaust any administrative or judicial review procedures hereinafter set forth:
(a) Upon denial of a timely petition to set aside that determination, or
(b) Upon the expiration of the period for filing a petition without a filing having been made.
(I) Notice Of Determination Of Liability: A determination of automated traffic law violation liability shall occur following failure to pay the fine or penalty, or to
contest the alleged violation within fourteen (14) days of the notice of violation. Where a person fails to appear at a hearing to contest the alleged
violation in the time and manner specified in a prior mailed notice, the hearing officer will enter findings, decision and order's determination of
automated traffic law violation liability which shall become final: 1) upon denial of a timely petition to set aside that determination, or 2) upon expiration
of the period for filing such a petition without a filing having been made. If a person appears at a hearing and is found liable or contests the violation by
mail and is found liable, the hearing officer will enter findings, decision and order, which is a final determination of automated traffic law violation liability
that is a final, appealable order.
The owner (or lessee) of a motor vehicle is subject to a penalty as set forth in the annual fee ordinance. In the event that such penalty is not paid within
fourteen (14) days after service of a final determination of liability, an additional late payment penalty shall be imposed as set forth in the annual fee
ordinance. A penalty shall not apply if the driver of the motor vehicle received a uniform traffic citation from a police officer at the time of the violation.
The village shall not charge court costs or hearing fees to persons found liable after exercising their right to appear and contest the violation at an
administrative hearing. (Ord. 2010-4358, 12-20-2010)
(J) Notice Of Final Determination: A notice of final determination shall be sent following the final determination of automated traffic law violation liability and
the conclusion of judicial review. The notice of final determination shall include the following information:
1. A statement that the unpaid fine is a debt due and owing to the village;
2. A warning that a failure to pay any fine due and owing to the village of Lisle within fourteen (14) days may result in a petition to the circuit court of
DuPage County to have the unpaid fine rendered as a judgment or may result in the suspension of the person's driver's license for failure to pay
fines or penalties for five (5) or more violations under this section.
(K) Petitions To Set Aside Determination: A petition to set aside determination of an automated traffic law violation must be filed with or mailed to the traffic
control administrator within fourteen (14) days of the date of mailing of the notice of determination of liability. The grounds for the petition are limited to:
1. The person was not the owner or lessee of the cited vehicle on the date the violation notice was issued;
2. The person having already paid the fine for the violation in question; and
3. Excusable failure to appear at or request a new date for a hearing.
Upon receipt of a timely petition to set aside the determination of liability, the hearing officer shall review the petition to determine if cause has been
shown to set aside the determination. If cause has been shown, the village shall forward the petitioner a new hearing date on which the petitioner
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 410/460
must appear to present his case. The village shall notify the petitioner of the hearing officer's decision to grant a hearing or deny the petition within
fourteen (14) days of the village's receipt.
(L) Notice Of Impending Driver's License Suspension: A notice of impending driver's license suspension shall be sent to the person liable for any fine or
penalty that remains due and owing on five (5) or more violations of this section. The notice of impending driver's license suspension shall state the
following information:
1. The failure to pay the fine owing within forty five (45) days of the notice's date will result in the village notifying the secretary of state that the person
is eligible for initiation of suspension proceedings under 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/6-306.5;
2. A statement that the person may obtain a copy of the original ticket imposing a fine by sending a self-addressed, stamped envelope to the village
along with a request for the copy.
The notice of impending driver's license suspension shall be sent by first class mail, postage prepaid, to the address recorded with the secretary of
state or, if any notice to that address is returned as undeliverable, to the last known address recorded in a United States post office approved
database.
(M) Driver's License Suspension: The traffic compliance administrator, by certified report, may request that the secretary of state suspend the driving
privileges of an owner of a registered vehicle who has failed to pay any fine or penalty due and owing as a result of five (5) automated traffic violations.
The report shall be certified and contain the following:
1. The name, last known address as recorded with the secretary of state, as provided by the lessor of the cited vehicle at the time of lease, or as
recorded in a United States post office approved database if any notice sent under this section is returned as undeliverable, and driver's license
number of the person who failed to pay the fine or penalty and the registration number of any vehicle known to be registered to such person in a
state;
2. A statement that the report is being made by the village of Lisle pursuant to this section; and
3. A statement that a notice of impending driver's license suspension has been sent to the person named in the report at the address recorded with the
secretary of state or at the last address known to the lessor of the cited vehicle at the time of the lease or, if any notice sent under this section is
returned as undeliverable at the last known address recorded at a United States post office approved database; the date on which such notice was
sent; and address to which such notice was sent.
The traffic compliance administrator shall notify the secretary of state whenever a person named in the certified report has paid the previously
recorded fine or penalty or whenever the municipality determines that the original report was in error. A certified copy of such notification shall also
be given upon request and at no additional charge to the person named therein.
Any person receiving notice from the secretary of state that their driving privileges may be suspended at the end of a specified period may challenge
the accuracy of the certified report prepared by the traffic compliance administrator. The person shall, within seven (7) days after having received
notice from the secretary of state, request an opportunity to speak with the traffic compliance administrator to challenge the accuracy of the certified
report. If the traffic compliance administrator determines that the original report was in error due to the fact that the person challenging the report was
not the owner or lessee of the vehicle or that the person has already paid the fine for the five (5) or more automated traffic violations, the traffic
compliance administrator shall immediately notify the secretary of state of such error in a subsequent certified report. (Ord. 2007-4139, 9-10-2007)
10-1-13: TOW AND IMPOUNDMENT OF MOTOR VEHICLES:
(A) Definitions: For the purpose of this section, the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning:
AGGRAVATED ASSAULT AND AGGRAVATED BATTERY: A violation of 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/12-2 and 5/12-4, respectively.
ARMED ROBBERY: A violation of 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/18-2.
BURGLARY AND RESIDENTIAL BURGLARY: A violation of 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/19-1 and 5/19-3, respectively.
CONTROLLED SUBSTANCE: Any substance as defined and included in the schedules contained in article II of the Illinois controlled substance act2,
as amended from time to time, and cannabis as defined in section 3 of the cannabis control act3, as amended from time to time.
CRIMINAL DAMAGE TO PROPERTY: A violation of 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/21-1.
DRIVING UNDER THE INFLUENCE: Any violation as defined in 11-501 of the Illinois vehicle code4, as amended.
DRIVING WHILE LICENSE, PERMIT OR PRIVILEGE TO OPERATE A MOTOR VEHICLE IS SUSPENDED OR REVOKED: Any violation as defined in
6-303 of the Illinois vehicle code5, as amended.
DRUG PARAPHERNALIA: Any equipment, product and/or materials as defined in section 2 of the drug paraphernalia act6.
HEARING OFFICER: A licensed attorney who is not an officer.
OPERATION OF MOTOR VEHICLE WITHOUT A VALID DRIVER'S LICENSE: A violation of 6-101 and/or 6-303 of the Illinois vehicle code7, as
amended from time to time, where the driver's license or driving privileges have been suspended, revoked, canceled, never obtained or previously had
been obtained and have been expired for not less than six (6) months.
OWNER OF RECORD: The record titleholder to a motor vehicle.
RETAIL THEFT: A violation of 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/16A-3.
UNLAWFUL USE OF WEAPONS: A violation of 24-1 of the criminal code of 19618, as amended.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 411/460
(B) Vehicles Subject To Tow And Impoundment: A motor vehicle, operated with the permission, express or implied, of the owner of record, shall be
declared to be a public nuisance and shall be subject to tow and impoundment under this section where such motor vehicle is used in the commission
of any of the violations of village or state laws or regulations specified in this subsection and where impoundment of the vehicle is determined by a
police officer on the scene to be reasonably necessary as a community caretaking function so that the vehicle does not jeopardize public safety and the
efficient movement of vehicular traffic. It shall not be necessary for criminal charges to be filed, prosecuted, and/or proven in order to demonstrate that
one of the following violations has been committed in order to trigger the towing and impoundment of the offending vehicle:
1. The possession or delivery of a controlled substance or drug paraphernalia; or
2. Driving while under the influence of alcohol, other drug or drugs, intoxicating compound or compounds or any combination thereof; or
3. Driving while license, permit or privilege to operate a motor vehicle is suspended or revoked in violation of 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/6-303,
except a person whose driver's license, permit or privilege to operate a motor vehicle is suspended only for a violation of the vehicle emissions
inspection law of 2005, 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/13C-1 et seq.; or
4. Operation of a motor vehicle without a valid and current driver's license in violation of statutes including, but not limited to, either 625 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/6-101(a) or 5/6-101(b); or
5. The unlawful possession of a firearm in violation of 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/24-3.1, use of weapons in violation of 720 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/24-1, or discharge of a firearm in violation of 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/24-1.5; or
6. Retail theft, when the value of the merchandise exceeds one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00); or
7. Aggravated assault, aggravated battery, armed robbery, burglary, residential burglary and criminal damage to property; or
8. Any violation of the provisions of the Illinois cannabis control act, 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 550/1; or
9. Fleeing or attempting to elude a law enforcement officer in violation of 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-204; or
10. Driving recklessly in violation of 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-503; or
11. Street racing in violation of 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-506; or
12. The commission or attempted commission of any felony offense; or
13. The motor vehicle is otherwise subject to seizure and impoundment pursuant to 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/36-1.
(C) Tow And Impoundment Of Vehicles: Whenever a police officer has probable cause to believe that a motor vehicle is subject to tow and impoundment
pursuant to this section, and none of the circumstances delineated in subsection (D) of this section are present, the police officer shall cause the motor
vehicle to be towed to a facility authorized by the village or its agents in accordance with the procedures set forth in title 9, chapter 9 of this code. When
the vehicle is towed, the police officer shall notify any person identifying himself or herself as the owner of the vehicle or any person who is found to be
in control of the vehicle at the time of the alleged violation, if there is such a person, of the fact of the tow and of the vehicle owner's right to request a
preliminary hearing to be held in accordance with the administrative hearing procedures set forth in subsection 10-1-12(F) of this chapter, though the
owner is not restricted to the defenses enumerated in subsection 10-1-12(D) of this chapter. Said motor vehicle shall be impounded pending the
completion of the hearings provided for in this chapter, unless the owner of the motor vehicle posts with the village a cash bond as set forth in
subsection (E) of this section and in an amount established by the annual fee ordinance.
(D) Exceptions To Vehicle Tow And Impoundment: A police officer who has probable cause to believe that a motor vehicle is subject to tow and
impoundment pursuant to this section shall first ascertain whether the tow and impoundment is necessary and reasonable under the circumstances. If
in the judgment of the police officer then present, a person authorized by the owner of record or the operator of the vehicle is present, capable and
willing to provide for the lawful immediate removal of the vehicle and the owner or operator of the vehicle executes an indemnification agreement,
holding the village harmless for releasing the motor vehicle into the custody of said person, the police officer shall allow that individual to promptly
remove the motor vehicle without it being subject to tow and impoundment.
(E) Posting A Bond: If a bond is posted with the village, the impounded vehicle shall be released to the owner of record, upon the payment by the owner of
record of the towing and storage costs to the applicable towing company. If an administrative fee is imposed pursuant to this section and established by
the annual fee ordinance, the bond shall be applied to said fee; provided, in the event that a violation of this section is not proven at the hearing
referenced in subsection (C) of this section, the bond shall be returned to the person posting the bond. All bond money posted pursuant to this section
shall be held by the village until the hearing officer issues a decision, or, in the event of judicial review, until a reviewing court issues a final decision.
(F) Preliminary Hearing: Where the owner of a motor vehicle seized under the provisions of this section requests in writing a preliminary hearing within
twelve (12) hours after the tow of the motor vehicle, the watch commander or designated supervising officer must conduct a preliminary hearing within
twenty four (24) hours after the request for a preliminary hearing is received by the village; provided that if the date for the hearing falls on a Saturday,
Sunday, or legal holiday, the preliminary hearing will be held on the next business day following the Saturday, Sunday or legal holiday. For purposes of
this section, the following shall apply:
1. All interested persons shall be given a reasonable opportunity to be heard at the preliminary hearing.
2. The formal rules of evidence shall not apply at the hearing, and hearsay testimony will be allowed and shall be admissible.
3. If, after the conclusion of the hearing, the watch commander or designated supervising officer determines that there is probable cause to believe that
the vehicle was properly towed and impounded in accordance with this section and that no enumerated exception justifies release of the vehicle from
impoundment, he or she shall order the continued impoundment of the vehicle unless and until the owner of the vehicle posts a cash or certified
check bond with the village, and pays all towing and storage costs to the applicable towing company. The village shall hold the cash or certified
check bond, together with payment for all accrued towing and storage charges, until such time as the final hearing is completed.
4. If the watch commander or designated supervising officer determines that there is not probable cause to believe that the vehicle was properly towed
and impounded under this section, then the motor vehicle shall be returned to the owner of record of the vehicle without any penalty or other costs.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 412/460
(G) Final Hearing:
1. Notice Of Hearing: Within twenty one (21) days after a motor vehicle is towed and impounded pursuant to this section, the village shall notify the
owner of record of the vehicle of the date, time and location of a final hearing, to be conducted in accordance with subsection 10-1-12(F) of this
chapter. Such notice shall be mailed by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the owner of record, as shown on the records of the Illinois
secretary of state. Notice by certified mail need not be given when the owner of the vehicle has been personally served with notice in written form of
the time, date and location of the hearing.
2. Hearing: For purposes of this section, the following shall apply at an owner's final hearing:
(a) Unless continued by order of the hearing officer, the hearing shall be held within forty five (45) days after the motor vehicle was impounded.
(b) All interested persons shall be given a reasonable opportunity to be heard at the hearing. The formal rules of evidence shall not apply at the
hearing and hearsay evidence shall be admissible. At the hearing, the violation citation shall be prima facie evidence that the violation was
committed as provided in the citation, and the burden of proof shall be upon the defendant to prove that the violation was not committed.
(c) If, after the conclusion of the hearing, the hearing officer determines by a preponderance of the evidence that the vehicle was properly
impounded, the hearing officer shall enter an order for the continued impoundment of the vehicle until the owner of the vehicle pays to the village
the administrative fee, as established by the annual fee ordinance, plus all accrued towing and storage costs to the applicable towing company.
The administrative fee shall be a debt due to the village and the owner shall be civilly liable therefor. If a cash bond has been posted, said bond
shall be applied to the administrative fee.
(d) If the owner of record fails to appear at the hearing, the hearing officer shall enter an order of default in favor of the village, which order shall
require the payment to the village of an administrative penalty, as established in the annual fee ordinance, plus towing and storage costs to the
applicable towing company, as well as the continued impoundment of the vehicle until the owner remits to the village the administrative fee and
towing and storage costs to the towing company.
(e) If the hearing officer determines that the vehicle was not used in violation of this section then the motor vehicle shall be returned to the owner of
the vehicle promptly and without any penalty or other costs, or, if a cash bond had previously been posted, said cash bond shall be returned.
(H) Unclaimed Vehicles:
1. Any motor vehicle that is not claimed within thirty (30) days after the expiration of time in which the owner of record may seek judicial review of the
action of the village under this section or any vehicle for which payment of all required monies to secure the vehicle has not been tendered within
thirty (30) days of the expiration of time in which the owner of record may seek judicial review of the order entered at the conclusion of the final
hearing, or the time at which a final judgment is rendered in favor of the village by a court of proper jurisdiction, or the time at which a final
administrative decision is rendered against an owner of record who is in default, the vehicle shall be deemed unclaimed and may be disposed of as
an abandoned or unclaimed vehicle, as otherwise provided in the Illinois vehicle code.
(I) Liability For Penalty And Costs:
1. The owner of record of a motor vehicle that is seized or impounded shall be liable to the village for an administrative fee, established by the annual
fee ordinance, in addition to any fees and charges for the towing and storage of the motor vehicle by the applicable towing company.
2. Fees for towing and storage are established by the towing company and not by the village, in accordance with the provisions of title 9, chapter 9 of
this code.
3. A vehicle impounded pursuant to this section shall remain impounded until the earlier of the following events occurs:
(a) The administrative fee is paid to the village, and all towing and storage costs are paid to the applicable towing company.
(b) A bond in an amount equal to the liability of the owner as provided in this section is posted with the village and all applicable towing and storage
costs are paid to the applicable towing company.
(c) The vehicle is deemed unclaimed or abandoned, in which case the vehicle shall be disposed of in the manner provided by law for the disposition
of abandoned or unclaimed vehicles.
(d) Except as otherwise specifically provided by law, no owner, lien holder or any other person shall be legally entitled to take possession of a motor
vehicle impounded under this section until the administrative fee and all towing and storage costs applicable under this section have been paid in
full. (Ord. 2009-4250, 4-20-2009)
Chapter 2
PARKING RESTRICTIONS
10-2-1: STOPPING, STANDING OR PARKING PROHIBITED IN CERTAIN PLACES:
Except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic, or in compliance with law or the directions of a police officer or official traffic control device, no
person shall:
(A) Stop, stand or park a vehicle1:
1. On the roadway side of any vehicle stopped or parked at the edge or curb of a street;
2. On a sidewalk; (Ord. 451, 2-6-1973)
3. Beyond the edge of a driveway into any public right of way; (Ord. 2006-4021, 6-5-2006)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 413/460
4. Within an intersection;
5. On a crosswalk;
6. Between a safety zone and the adjacent curb or within thirty feet (30') of points on the curb immediately opposite the ends of the safety zone, unless
a different length is indicated by signs or markings;
7. Alongside or opposite any street excavation or obstruction when stopping, standing or parking would obstruct traffic;
8. Upon any bridge or other elevated structures or within a highway tunnel, underpass or subway;
9. On any railroad tracks;
10. At any place where official signs prohibit stopping. (Ord. 451, 2-6-1973; amd. Ord. 2006-4021, 6-5-2006)
11. At any place which is designated by official signs as a cab stand, unless said vehicle is duly registered within the village, or is present at the cab
stand for the purpose of dropping off passengers who were initially picked up outside of the village. (Ord. 93-2360, 2-15-1993; amd. Ord. 2006-4021,
6-5-2006)
(B) Stand or park a vehicle, whether occupied or not, except momentarily to pick up or discharge passengers:
1. In front of a public or private driveway;
2. Within fifteen feet (15') of a fire hydrant;
3. Within twenty feet (20') of a crosswalk at an intersection;
4. Within thirty feet (30') upon the approach to any flashing signal, stop sign, yield sign or traffic control signal located at the side of the roadway;
5. Within twenty feet (20') of the driveway entrance to any fire station and on the side of the street opposite the entrance to any fire station within
seventy five feet (75') of such entrance (when properly signposted);
6. In front of curbside mailboxes located on School Street between Main and Spencer;
7. At any place where official signs prohibit standing. (Ord. 88-1766, 12-5-1988)
(C) Park a vehicle, whether occupied or not, except temporarily for the purpose of and while actually engaged in loading or unloading merchandise or
passengers:
1. Within fifty feet (50') of the nearest rail of a railroad crossing;
2. At any place where official signs prohibit parking.
(D) Further, there shall be no parking:
1. On any street between two o'clock (2:00) A.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M. except by permission of the Police Department. (Ord. 451, 2-6-1973)
2. In any officially designated fire lane. Any person violating this subsection (D)2 shall be fined as established by the annual fee ordinance for each
offense. (Ord. 96-2776, 5-20-1996)
3. Where vehicle would reduce the usable width of a street to less than eighteen feet (18'). (Ord. 451, 2-6-1973)
4. In a prohibited parking zone; or in a limited parking zone longer than the time designated and authorized. Each continuing period of time equal to the
posted time limit shall constitute a separate offense. (Ord. 94-2603, 12-5-1994)
5. On private property without the consent of the owner of private property. (Ord. 83-1136, 8-2-1983)

10-2-3: MANNER OF PARKING VEHICLES:
(A) Every vehicle stopped or parked upon a two-way roadway in the village shall be so stopped or parked with the right hand wheels parallel to and within
twelve inches (12") of the right hand curb or as close thereto as practicable to the right hand edge of the right hand shoulder.
(B) Every vehicle parked in a compact car space shall not exceed the size limitation indicated by the posted restriction and shall not protrude or overhang
any space limitation marked on the pavement. (Ord. 92-2321, 10-19-1992)
(C) Any person failing to obey these restrictions shall be fined as established by the annual fee ordinance for each offense. (Ord. 96-2776, 5-20-1996)
10-2-4: TIME LIMIT IN DESIGNATED PLACES:
(A) When And Where Prohibited:
1. Parking Prohibited During Snowfall: It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle on any portion of any public street or highway in the Village during or after
any snowfall resulting in an accumulation of one inch (1") or more, and for a period thereafter of twenty four (24) hours, or within such further period
as may be reasonably required to complete snow removal operations.
2. All Night Parking Prohibited: It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle on any portion of any public street or highway in the Village between the hours of
two o'clock (2:00) A.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M.
(B) Authority To Impound Vehicles: Whenever any vehicle is so parked illegally as to obstruct the normal movement of traffic or interfere with the sweeping
or repair of streets or removal of snow therefrom, the Chief of Police, or any person authorized by him, is hereby authorized to cause such vehicle to be
removed from the public street and conveyed by or under the direction of a member of the Police Department to an authorized garage. The Village
shall be entitled to the fees provided in subsection (C) of this section.
(C) Fees For Redemption: Before the owner or person entitled to the possession of any impounded or removed vehicle shall be permitted to remove the
same from the custody of the Chief of Police, or person authorized by him, he shall furnish satisfactory evidence of his identity and ownership of vehicle
and right of possession thereto, shall sign a receipt for the vehicle and in addition to the fine provided for herein, shall pay the fee as established by the
annual fee ordinance for such vehicle to cover the cost of towing or removal of such vehicle, and in addition thereto, the cost of storage charged by
such authorized garage at the prevailing rate for such storage. (Ord. 79-830, 1-16-1979)
(D) Central Business District: The total maximum time limit for parking a vehicle within the Central Business District shall be two (2) hours, with the
exception of Municipal Lot G, which shall be four (4) hours. No vehicle shall be moved from one (1) parking location to another parking location within
the Central Business District such that the vehicle is parked for a combined total of more than two (2) hours for the entire area, nor shall any vehicle be
moved between a parking location within the Central Business District and Municipal Lot G such that the maximum combined time limit of four (4) hours
is exceeded. The term "Central Business District" shall refer to that portion of the Village bounded by Ogden, Garfield, Division and Center. (Ord. 2003-
3439, 1-20-2003)

10-2-6: PARKING FOR HANDICAPPED PERSONS2:
10-2-6-1: EXEMPTIONS TO PARKING RESTRICTIONS:
A motor vehicle bearing registration plates issued to a physically handicapped person pursuant to 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3-616 or to a disabled
veteran pursuant to 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3-609 of the Illinois Vehicle Code, effective July 1, 1970, as amended3, is hereby declared to be
exempt from any ordinance imposing time limitations on parking in a business district; but otherwise is subject to the laws which prohibit parking in "no
stopping", "no standing" zones in front of or near fire hydrants, driveways, public building entrances and exits, bus stops and loading areas, and is
prohibited from parking where the motor vehicle constitutes a traffic hazard and the motor vehicle must be moved at the instruction and request of a law
enforcement officer to a location designated by the officer. Any motor vehicle bearing registration plates specified in this section or similar registration
plates issued under the Vehicle Codes of other States, as amended, or handicapped motorist's cards issued by the Village, as evidence that the vehicle is
operated by or for a handicapped person or disabled veteran, may park, in addition to any other lawful place, in any parking place specifically reserved, by
posting of an official sign, for such vehicles. Parking privileges granted by this section are strictly limited to those persons to whom the special registration
plates or cards are issued and to qualified operators acting under such person's express direction while the disabled person is present. No person shall
use any area for parking of any motor vehicle pursuant to 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-1303 of the Illinois Vehicle Code, effective July 1, 1970, as
amended, or where an official sign controlling such area expressly prohibits parking at any time or during certain hours. (Ord. 80-952, 9-16-1980)
10-2-6-2: HANDICAPPED MOTORISTS CARDS:
The Business Office Manager shall issue, without charge, upon application of any handicapped person or disabled veteran, a special handicapped
motorist card furnished by the Illinois Secretary of State, pursuant to the provisions of the Illinois Vehicle Code, for the purpose of allowing said card to be
used and displayed on a vehicle being used to transport said handicapped person or disabled veteran, but not owned or displaying a special handicapped
or disabled veteran's license plate, so as to identify said vehicle and entitle it to all the parking privileges afforded to a vehicle possessing such special
handicapped or disabled veteran's license plates as hereinbefore provided. Such card shall be issued only to handicapped persons or disabled veterans
and the same shall be displayed by hanging such card from the rearview mirror of the vehicle and shall allow the vehicle to utilize special, handicapped
parking privileges when used to transport such handicapped person or disabled veteran. The Village shall issue only temporary handicapped motorist
cards. Requests for permanent cards shall be directed to the Illinois Secretary of State.
For purposes of this section, a "physically handicapped person" shall mean every natural person who is unable to walk two hundred feet (200') or more
unassisted by another person or without the aid of a walker, crutches, brace, prosthetic device, or a wheelchair or without great difficulty or discomfort due
to the following impairments: neurologic, orthopedic, respiratory, cardiac, arthritic disorder, blindness, or the loss of function or absence of a limb or limbs.
All applicants shall complete an application form as provided by the business office manager. Such form includes information which shall be completed by
the applicant and his or her physician. The physician shall designate whether the handicap is temporary or permanent. If temporary, the physician must
indicate the length of the handicap. A temporary card will be issued for the designated period not to exceed ninety (90) days. If an extension is needed, the
applicant must complete a new application and furnish proof of the reason for such extension from the attending physician. No handicapped motorist
vehicle card shall be transferable. Use of any such card by any person other than the handicapped person to whom it is issued except as provided herein,
shall be deemed a violation of this section and shall render the card void. Any abuse of the card or unauthorized use shall render any such card subject to
revocation. No handicapped motorist card shall be issued until an application form is completed and received by the business office manager. Providing
false information in the application filed with the business office manager shall be deemed a violation of this section. (Ord. 2000-3185, 2-21-2000)
10-2-6-3: PROHIBITIONS:
(A) It shall be unlawful to park any motor vehicle which is not bearing registration plates to a physically handicapped or to a disabled veteran, pursuant to
the applicable sections of the Illinois motor vehicle code, or similar registration plates duly issued under the motor vehicle code of another state, or
handicapped motorist card issued by the village or such decal, cards, or devices issued by other municipalities pursuant to the authority granted to
them under the Illinois vehicle code as the local authorities of other municipalities deem proper as evidence that the vehicle is operated by or for a
handicapped person or disabled veteran, in any parking place for motor vehicles bearing such registration, plates, decals, cards or devices. Violation of
this section shall carry a fine as established by the annual fee ordinance for each offense. (Ord. 96-2776, 5-20-1996)
(B) The parking spaces located at or near the addresses listed below shall be designated for handicapped parking. However, said list shall not be
interpreted as being inclusive of all such spaces within the village, nor shall such designation limit the effect or enforcement of handicapped parking
prohibitions in locations other than listed below:
4710 Main Street
4739 Main Street
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 420/460
(Ord. 88-1652, 3-21-1988)
10-2-7: PENALTY:
Any person convicted in a court of law of any violation of the provisions of this chapter shall be fined as established by the annual fee ordinance for each
offense. The procedure set forth in section 9-4-22 of this code may be used to settle and compromise a violation. (Ord. 2003-3439, 1-20-2003)
Chapter 3
PARKING METER REGULATIONS
10-3-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter the following words and phrases shall have the meanings herein ascribed to them:
PARK OR PARKING: The standing of a vehicle, whether occupied or not, upon a street or in a village owned off street parking lot, otherwise than
temporarily for the purpose of, and while actually engaged in, receiving or discharging passengers or loading and unloading merchandise or in obedience
to traffic regulations, signs or signals or an involuntary stopping of the vehicle by reason of causes beyond the control of the operator of the vehicle.
PARKING METER: Includes any mechanical device or meter not inconsistent with this chapter placed or erected for the regulation of parking by authority
of this chapter. Each parking meter installed shall indicate by proper legend the legal parking time established by the village, and when operated shall at all
times indicate the balance of legal parking time, and at the expiration of such period shall indicate illegal or overtime parking.
PARKING METER SPACE: Any space within a parking meter zone adjacent to a parking meter and which is duly designated for the parking of a single
vehicle by lines painted or otherwise durably marked on the curb, on the surface of the street or on the surface of the off street parking lot adjacent to or
adjoining the parking meters.
PARKING METER ZONE: Includes any village owned off street parking lot or any restricted street or portion thereof upon which parking meters are
installed and in operation. (Ord. 524, 8-6-1974)
10-3-2: ENFORCEMENT:
It shall be the duty of the police department to enforce the provisions of this chapter. (Ord. 524, 8-6-1974)
10-3-3: PARKING METER ZONES:
(A) Zones Established: The named and described areas, streets or portions of streets shall be established as zones and set forth in the parking meter
schedule as follows:
Zone I Front Street, north side, Spencer Avenue to Center Street.
Zone II Burlington Avenue, both sides, Spencer Avenue to Center Avenue.
Other areas, streets, portions of streets may hereafter be included in said schedule by amendment thereto.
(B) Parking Meter Zone Time Limits: Notwithstanding any other provisions of this code, time limits of parking meter zones shall be as follows:
Zone I 15 hours maximum per day, 9:00 A.M. to 12:00 midnight
Zone II 18 hours maximum per day, 4:30 A.M. to 12:00 midnight
(C) Parking Meter Zone Fees: Notwithstanding any other provisions of this code, the fees are hereby established by the annual fee ordinance and shall be
paid for use of a parking meter space. (Ord. 2005-3930, 6-6-2005)
10-3-4: DESIGNATION OF PARKING SPACES:
The superintendent of streets is hereby directed and authorized to mark off individual parking spaces in the parking zones designated and described in the
parking meter schedule and in such other zones as may hereafter be established, said parking spaces to be designated by lines painted or durably
marked on the curbing or surface of the street or off street parking lot. At each space so marked off, it shall be unlawful to park any vehicle in such a way
that said vehicle shall not be entirely within the limits of the space so designated. (Ord. 524, 8-6-1974)
10-3-5: LOCATION, PLACEMENT OF METERS:
In the parking meter zones the superintendent of streets shall cause parking meters to be installed upon the street or off street parking lot surface, curb or
sidewalk immediately adjacent to the parking spaces provided for in section 10-3-4of this chapter, said installation to be placed not more than two feet (2')
from the curb nor more than four feet (4') from the front line of the parking space as indicated. Each device shall be so set as to display a signal showing
legal parking upon the deposit of the appropriate coin or coins, lawful money of the United States, for the period of time prescribed by this chapter. Each
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 421/460
device shall be so arranged that upon the expiration of the lawful time limit it will indicate by a proper visible signal that the lawful parking period has
expired and in such cases the right of such vehicle to occupy such space shall cease and the operator, owner, possessor or manager thereof shall be
subject to the penalties hereinafter provided. (Ord. 524, 8-6-1974)
10-3-6: SUPERVISION OF METERS:
The chief of police shall be responsible for the regulation, control, operation, maintenance and use of parking meters within the village. (Ord. 524, 8-6-
1974)
10-3-7: OPERATION OF METERS:
Except in a period of emergency determined by an officer of the village police department, or in compliance with the directions of a police officer or traffic
control sign or signal, when any vehicle shall be parked in any parking space alongside or next to which a parking meter is located, the operator of such
vehicle shall, upon entering the said parking meter space, immediately deposit or cause to be deposited in said meter such coin of the United States as is
required for such parking meter and as is designated by proper directions on the meter, and when required by the directions on the meter, the operator of
such vehicle, after the deposit of the proper token, coin or coins, shall also set in operation the timing mechanism on such meter in accordance with
directions appearing thereon, and failure to deposit such proper token or coin, and to set the timing mechanism in operation when so required shall
constitute a violation of this chapter. Upon the deposit of such coin (and the setting of the timing mechanism in operation when so required) the parking
space may be lawfully occupied by such vehicle during the period of time which has been prescribed for the part of the street or off street parking lot in
which said parking space is located; provided, that any person placing a vehicle in a parking meter space adjacent to a meter which indicates that unused
time has been left in the meter by the previous occupant of the space, shall not be required to deposit a coin or token so long as his occupancy of said
space does not exceed the indicated unused parking time. If said vehicle shall remain parked in any such parking space beyond the parking time limit set
for such parking space, and if the meter shall indicate such illegal parking, then, and in that event, such vehicle shall be considered as parking overtime
and beyond the period of legal parking time, and such parking shall be deemed aviolation of this chapter. (Ord. 524, 8-6-1974)
10-3-8: PARKING TIME LIMITS:
(A) No person shall park a vehicle in a parking meter space for a period of time in excess of the maximum parking time limit for said space as set forth in
subsection 10-3-3(B), "Parking Meter Zone Time Limits", of this chapter, except as additionally provided for in this section.
(B) Parking or standing a vehicle in a parking meter space shall be lawful upon the deposit in the parking meter adjacent thereto of the required coins as
referenced in subsection 10-3-3(C) of this chapter. (Ord. 2005-3931, 6-6-2005)
(C) Parking meters shall be operated and parking shall be allowed only according to the following schedule:
Zone I 9:00 A.M. to 12:00 midnight
Zone II 4:30 A.M. to 12:00 midnight, Monday through Friday
(Ord. 2006-4023, 6-5-2006)
10-3-9: VIOLATIONS:
It shall be unlawful and a violation of the provisions of this chapter for any person to1:
(A) Cause, allow, permit or suffer any vehicle registered in the name of, or operated by, such person to be parked overtime, or beyond the period of legal
parking time established for any parking meter zone as herein described, or to deposit in any parking meter any coin for the purpose of parking beyond
the maximum legal parking time for the particular parking meter zone.
(B) Permit any vehicle to remain or be placed in any parking space adjacent to any parking meter while said meter is displaying a signal indicating that the
vehicle occupying such parking space has already been parked beyond the period prescribed for such parking space.
(C) Park any vehicle across any line or marking of any parking meter space or in such position that the vehicle shall not be entirely within the area
designated by such lines or markings.
(D) Deface, injure, tamper with, open or wilfully break, destroy or impair the usefulness of any parking meter installed under the provisions of this chapter.
(E) Deposit or cause to be deposited in any parking meter any slug device or metal substance or any other substitute for lawful coins. (Ord. 524, 8-6-1974)
10-3-10: OVERTIME PARKING NOTICES; FINES2:
Any vehicle which remains parked in parking meter space after the meter indicates illegal parking shall be considered as parking overtime, and the police
officers of the village are authorized and directed to attach to any such vehicle a notice to the owner or operator thereof that such vehicle has been parked
in violation of this chapter. (Ord. 83-1136, 8-2-1983)
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 422/460
10-3-11: COLLECTION OF METER MONIES:
It shall be the duty of the chief of police to designate some member or members of the police department to make regular collections of the money
deposited in parking meters and it shall be the duty of such persons so designated to remove from said meters the coins so deposited in the meters and to
deliver coins to the business office manager who shall count such coins and deposit the same with the village treasurer. (Ord. 83-1136, 8-2-1983; amd.
Ord. 94-2583, 9-19-1994)
Chapter 4
MUNICIPAL PARKING LOTS
10-4-1: DEFINITIONS:
For purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them:
MOTOR VEHICLE: A machine propelled by mechanical power designed to travel along the ground by use of wheels, treads, runners, or slides and used to
transport person(s) or property or pull machinery and shall include, without limitation, automobiles, trucks, trailers, motorcycles, motorized bicycles,
tractors and wagons.
PERMITTED VEHICLE: That vehicle registered in the village business office, for which a permit is issued.
In addition, only those vehicles which are validly registered, as required by the laws of the state of residence of the vehicle owner, may be permitted
vehicles under this definition.
PERMITTEE: The person to whom a permit is issued for the right to park in commuter parking lots as the parking lots have been established for municipal
purposes. (Ord. 92-2310, 9-8-1992; amd. Ord. 94-2534, 6-6-1994; Ord. 94-2583, 9-19-1994; Ord. 2003-3794, 11-17-2003)
10-4-2: MUNICIPAL PARKING LOTS ESTABLISHED:
There are hereby established municipally owned and leased off street parking lots, as follows:
LOT
A
That property lying south of properties commonly known as 1014 and 1018 Burlington Avenue and north of the Burlington Northern right of
way and lying west of Spencer Avenue to the curb line east of Main Street.
LOT
B
That property lying south of Burlington Avenue and north of the Burlington Northern right of way and lying west of Center Avenue and east of
Spencer Avenue.
LOT
C
That property lying south of Burlington Avenue and north of the Burlington Northern right of way and lying west of a line running south of the
former Lisle depot and east of Center Avenue.
LOT
D
That property lying south of the Burlington Northern right of way north of Front Street and lying west of the village of Lisle commuter station
and west to the curb line just east of the Main Street tunnel.
LOT
E
That property lying north of the Burlington Northern right of way, east of the Burlington Northern/Lisle train station and west of the St.
Joseph's Creek culvert.
LOT
G
That property known as 4717 through 4719 Garfield Avenue, lying between Ogden Avenue and Burlington Avenue. (Ord. 2003-3461, 5-19-
2003)
10-4-3: PERMITS REQUIRED; FEES:
(A) General: Except as hereinafter provided, it shall be unlawful for any person to park a motor vehicle in the above described village parking lots without
first obtaining a permit. Certain spaces in certain lots may be, from time to time, designated by signs for purposes other than commuter parking or
public parking purposes. The uses for which certain spaces may be designated shall include, but not be limited to, areas for village employees,
handicapped parking, loading zones, Burlington Northern agent parking, visitors' parking, police use, or other specific uses as indicated by signs. For
regulations pertaining to bicycles, refer to chapter 6 of this title. (Ord. 2005-3965, 11-7-2005)
1. Validity Of Permits; Transfer Prohibited:
(a) All permits required by this section shall be valid only for the permitted vehicle, which shall be owned or leased by the permittee and shall have a
state license number assigned thereto. Two (2) vehicles may be registered under the same permit; provided, that both vehicles are owned or
leased by the permittee and are registered in the village business office under the permittee's name. However, only one of said two (2) vehicles
shall be allowed to use the permit at any one time.
(b) The transfer of any permit required herein between vehicles other than those registered to the permittee is strictly prohibited. Any attempt to
transfer any permit required herein shall result in an automatic revocation of said permit and the imposition of a fine as hereinafter set forth.
Further, if any person violates this subsection (A)1 while he is on the permit waiting list, he shall be automatically placed at the end of the waiting
list for a parking permit in addition to paying any applicable fines.
2. Permit Issuance: The village reserves the right to issue permits based upon rules which, in the opinion of the corporate authorities, further the public
health, safety, comfort, morals and welfare of its citizens, and which, in the opinion of the corporate authorities, are in the best interests of the village.
Such rules may include giving priority to village employees, village residents or any other group of persons determined appropriate by the corporate
authorities of the village.
6/5/2019 Sterling Codifiers, Inc.
https://www.sterlingcodifiers.com/codebook/index.php?book_id=339 423/460
3. Fee Increase: The village reserves the right to increase the fee due for a parking permit at any time prior to the effective date of the permit.
Notification of the increase and the effective date thereof shall be deemed given upon passage of the ordinance modifying the fee.
4. Payment Of Fee Difference Required: Holders of permits which are not yet effective at the time a fee increase ordinance is passed shall pay to the
village the difference between the new fee and amount previously paid for the permit. (Ord. 92-2310, 9-8-1992; amd. Ord. 94-2534, 6-6-1994)
(B) Categories: For purposes of issuing the parking permits prescribed herein, there shall be the following categories:
Category 1 Lots A, B, C, D and E.
Lots A, B, D, and E shall be operated as commuter parking lots for which quarterly parking permits are issued. A portion of lot C shall be operated as a
commuter parking lot for which quarterly parking permits are issued. Other portions of lot C shall be designated by signage as employee parking and
village hall visitor parking. When space is available, daily permits shall be issued for portions of lot C and lot E in a manner as determined appropriate
by the business office manager.
Category 4 Lot G.
The aforementioned lot shall be used by the owners and operators of retail and other businesses and residents of multi-family units located in the
central business district. As used in this subsection, the term central business district shall refer to that portion of the village bounded by Ogden,
Garfield, Division and Center. In the issuance of parking permits for lot G, priority shall be given to such owners and operators of businesses and
residents of multi-family units; however, if spaces remain available after being offered to business owners and operators and residents of multi-family
units, the business office manager may issue permits to others, or provide free public parking as deemed appropriate by the business office manager.
(C) Fees And Purchasing Procedure:
1. Parking permits shall be obtained from the village of Lisle business office manager. Fees shall be as established by the annual fee ordinance. (Ord.
2011-4382, 5-2-2011)
2. There is hereby established the following procedures for purchase of quarterly parking permits: (Ord. 92-2310, 9-8-1992; amd. Ord. 94-2534, 6-6-
1994)
(a) Permits shall be paid for in full and obtained from the business office manager prior to five o'clock (5:00) P.M. on the last village business day of
the quarter preceding the quarter for which the permit is to apply.
(b) Failure to pay for and obtain a parking permit by five o'clock (5:00) P.M. on the last business day of a quarter shall be deemed to be a forfeiture of
the permittee's parking permit without further notice on the part of the village. However, if the permittee pays for and obtains the parking permit
within the first five (5) business days of the quarter to which the permit applies, the business office manager, upon the payment of a late fee in the
amount as established by the annual fee ordinance, may reinstate and reissue the permit. Further, if the permittee pays for and obtains the parking
permit within six (6) to fifteen (15) business days after the first day of the quarter to which it applies, the business office manager, upon the
payment of a late fee in the amount as established by the annual fee ordinance, may reinstate and reissue the permit. Upon the passage of fifteen
(15) days following the first day of the quarter, the permittee forfeits all rights and privileges whatsoever in the permit and must reapply for a permit
pursuant to subsection (D) of this section. (Ord. 2003-3461, 5-19-2003)
(c) Failure to pay to the village any increase in parking permit fees, as set forth in subsection (A)3 of this section, shall render the parking permit void.
(Ord. 92-2310, 9-8-1992; amd. Ord. 94-2534, 6-6-1994)
(d) Any person who has failed to pay any ticket issued pursuant to this chapter, and due pursuant to the terms of this code, by five o'clock (5:00) P.M.
on the last village business day of the quarter to which the current permit applies, shall be denied the issuance of a permit for the new quarter until
such tickets are paid in full. (Ord. 2003-3461, 5-19-2003)
(D) Permit Application: Every owner or operator of a motor vehicle desiring a permit for such vehicle, shall file a permit application with the village business
office setting forth the name and address of the applicant, the description of the vehicle for which the permit is desired, and the state license number of
the vehicle for which the permit is desired. The applicant shall furnish proof of ownership and/or registration if it is requested by the village. Upon
satisfactory completion and acceptance of the application and payment of the applicable permit fees hereinafter provided, the village may issue a
permit. Upon the issuance of a permit by the village business office, the applicant shall be permitted to park said registered vehicle in the appropriate
village parking lot until the expiration or revocation of such permit. In the event that no commuter parking permits are available for sale, the village of
Lisle may at its discretion maintain a wait list for commuter parking permits as provided for in subsection (D)1 of this section. If any applicant uses or
attempts to use a permit in connection with the parking of a vehicle not registered with the village business office; or if any applicant uses or attempts to
use a permit in connection with the parking of a vehicle not owned or leased by said applicant; or if any applicant uses or attempts to use a permit in
any manner not authorized by this chapter, the applicant shall be automatically placed at the end of the waiting list, the permit will be revoked and fines
shall be imposed as hereinafter set forth. (Ord. 2010-4357, 12-6-2010)
1. In the event that no commuter parking permits are available for sale, the village of Lisle may at its discretion maintain a wait list for commuter parking
permits. In order to be placed on the wait list an application must be submitted on a form provided by the business office and a fee paid as required
by the annual fee ordinance. The applicant must be the individual in whose name the permit will be issued. As permits are offered to those on the
wait list, forty five percent (45%) of available permits must be offered only to incorporated village of Lisle residents in chronological order, with those
residents on the list the longest being offered permits first, and the remaining fifty five percent (55%) of available permits offered without regard for
residency in chronological order, with those on the list the longest being offered permits first. (Ord. 2014-4540, 8-18-2014)
(E) Refund: Any owner or operator of a motor vehicle having secured such a permit from the business office manager as provided in subsection (D) of this
section may obtain a partial refund according to the schedule as established by the annual fee ordinance if the owner or operator desires to cancel said
permit at some time prior to its expiration. (Ord. 92-2310, 9-8-1992; amd. Ord. 94-2583, 9-19-1994)
(F) Display Of Permit: It shall be unlawful to park any motor vehicle in any of the above described village parking lots without displaying the permit required
by this chapter in the following manner: 1) parking permits that are required to be affixed to the windshield shall be prominently displayed in the lower
right hand corner (passenger's side) of the front windshield within a twelve inch (12") radius of said lower right hand corner; 2) parking permits that are
required to be hung from the rearview mirror shall be hung from the rearview mirror in a prominently displayed manner, and in no event shall such
permits be affixed to the rearview mirror or otherwise displayed in any manner contrary to this subsection. It shall be the permittee's obligation to

securely affix or hang the required permit in the designated location as provided in this subsection. (Ord. 2014-4540, 8-18-2014)
Notwithstanding the foregoing, no permit need be acquired nor displayed while parking in lots B, C, D, and E for the period starting at two o'clock (2:00)
P.M. to two o'clock (2:00) A.M. each day Monday through Thursday and from two o'clock (2:00) P.M. Friday to two o'clock (2:00) A.M. Monday.
However, any vehicles parked at any location upon a municipal parking lot shall comply with all other parking restrictions and time limits as set forth in

(G) Revenue: All revenues derived from the sale of permits as provided under this section shall be deposited in the general corporate fund of the village.
